pads.content:
Floating solar powered facilities of flood prone Bangladesh
One fifth of Bangladesh floods annually during the monsoon season, but extreme floods cover up to two thirds, which are being exacerbated by climate change. In this context, Bangladeshi Architect Mohammed Rezwan came up with a creative solution ‘floating school’ to this problem. His organisation Shidhulai Swanirvar Sangstha operates classroom on boat, a school that gives to the student when the student can't go to school. The school-boat first serves as a school bus, making periodic stops to collect children from riverside stops. The boat then docks and class begins. In addition to a fleet of floating schools, the organization operates libraries, health clinics, playgrounds and floating training centres with wireless internet access, serving close to 122,000 people in flood-prone areas of Bangladesh. Sustainable agriculture: Floating training centers teach women and girls on new skills, sustainable agriculture, climate change adaptation, and women right. Climate adaptation: The farmer's floating farming helps landless farmers to grow vegetables and raise fish and ducks on river, that secure the income, food and employment throughout the year. Healthcare: With doctor on board, the floating health clinic moves across the waterways and docking at a riverside village the boat provide medical checkups. These initiatives allow people to access education and information, develop new skills, grow flood resistant crops and adapt to climate change.
pads.title: Floating solar powered facilities of flood prone Bangladesh

pads.content:
Democratizing access to entrepreneurship knowledge
The Problem
The Solution

Access to information, knowledge, connections, and opportunities continues to pose significant challenges for businesses in Bangladesh, hindering the growth of entrepreneurship in the country. The distribution of entrepreneurial knowledge and opportunities remains uneven and limited to a privileged few. There is a notable lack of coverage on topics such as business establishment in Bangladesh, local markets, emerging trends, prominent companies, and influential figures. Business education in Bangladesh also pays scant attention to the local entrepreneurship scene.
Entrepreneurship is a social phenomenon affected by numerous factors. Given the inherent difficulties involved in starting a business, young individuals seldom delve into studying local entrepreneurs. Moreover, societal attitudes often view entrepreneurs with skepticism, which discourages many from considering entrepreneurship as a viable career path.
Futures Startup is a free online knowledge platform that reports and publishes original in-depth insights, analyses, and inspiration concerning the business, technology, and entrepreneurship landscape in Bangladesh. This knowledge platform goes beyond conventional sources, providing a unique perspective that is not widely found elsewhere. Futures Startup aims to play a pivotal role in generating increased economic opportunities by democratizing access to entrepreneurship,
Besides educating aspiring entrepreneurs, Futures Startup also supports existing businesses in their growth endeavors. It offers access to information, knowledge, connections, and services that are otherwise scarce in Bangladesh
Their products and services include:
A Free website, www.futurestartup.com, that provides articles, interviews, and reports on entrepreneurship, business, and the tech industry in Bangladesh. They are building the local knowledge infrastructure and the search engine for information and knowledge about entrepreneurship, technology, and business building in Bangladesh. While the website is currently in English, they are working on a local language version to be accessible to more people. 
Newsletter: A weekly entrepreneurship, and tech-focused newsletter with over 13,000 subscribers, probably the largest such newsletter in Bangladesh.
Community: Through interviews, regular community events, and workshops, they seek to foster a community of entrepreneurs and professionals who can come together to support each other in building consequential enterprises.

Narrative Strategy and marketing solutions: They provide a narrative strategy service and a few marketing services to businesses to help them tell their stories better and reach their target audience.

Future Research: Custom on-demand market research around entrepreneurship, startup, and technology business.
pads.title: Democratizing access to entrepreneurship knowledge

We create products influenced by people's stories and inspired by the Jordanian culture. Batrina is a Jordan-based brand that creates storytelling, well designed and affordable everyday products, inspired by the Jordanian culture, influenced by the people of Jordan and produced by local Jordanian craftsmen. Batrina was born from our strong belief of Jordans resources and stories that are not used or told yet that can be transformed into products that presents some of Jordan’s rich history and diverse present. The brand name was inspired from the word (vetrine) vetrina or batrina in the indigenous Jordanian Arabic, which means a window of a store, in which goods are displayed in. pads.content:
Kawon Cultural Library 

https://www.facebook.com/kawonofficial/ 
Kawon Cultural Library was created by Ghaith Bahdoosheh, a young man from the city of Madaba, Jordan. He started off with a mobile bookshop idea. He would drive around parts of Jordan in his old Mercedes, park, and set up his books on his car, and sell them to people. He dreamt of doing more related to books and reading and this eventually led to launching the social enterprise, Kawon. Brief about Kawon in his own words: Kawon Cultural Library is determined to become a daily place for locals to come to it, visitors from neighboring cities and tourists from all over the world, a place to dream and try to escape from the daily pressures of life and try something new, a comfortable place to meet your friends or read a book, all in one. With the increasing demand for high-quality coffee, food and great service, Kawon will benefit from its presence in the city of Madaba and the surrounding areas it serves, aiming to create a healthy environment, where cultural activities and knowledge exchange are the valves to evoke and spread new social values. 
Kawon brings a special experience of book culture to its visitors through its unique collection of books and publications in multiple languages. I made this library because of the lack of safe and cultural spaces that provide basic services to youth We aspire to achieve the developmental sustainability of our social enterprise by applying some of the concepts that will give us our independence, such as solar energy production and food production, both internally and externally. We aspire to be the pioneers in the field of rare and ancient publications, preserving them and re-publishing them to revive the written human heritage.

Male

On your Way, Waslni. Community transportation digital solutions. Social media platforms and applications 
With the increased transportation costs in Syria and the imposed sanctions that affects mobility services, a number of local solutions and initiatives were started in different Syrian provinces. Most of these solutions depended on the concept of sharing transportation costs. It started with people starting a public Facebook page where drivers/ cars owners can post their destinations, time of trip, number of available seats and cost of the trip (sometimes they offer free rides). Recently a number of start- ups created mobile applications that offers mobility as a service. But still the informal Facebook pages covered a wider population, more options, and cheaper costs.

pads.content:
The Duke's Diwan
Solution holder: Mamdouh Bisharat

The Duke's Diwan is one of the oldest, well-preserved stone buildings located in the heart of Amman. Built in 1924 by Abdul Rahman Madi, the building served as the Central Post Office, and after 1948, it hosted the Haifa Hotel.
In 2001 it caught the attention of Mamdouh Bisharat, the "Duke of Mukheibeh," who rented the house to protect it from destruction, with the aim of keeping the city's authenticity and character alive for Jordan's citizens and visitors.
Mamdouh converted the house on Faisal Str. into a Diwan, which traditionally means "council chamber," where people, thinkers, poets and artists meet. The Diwan's doors are always open for visitors, as well as for talents in all fields of culture.
A descendant of one of the oldest families in Jordan, Mamdouh Bisharat has devoted his life to preserving architectural and cultural heritage in Jordan. His family house in Jabal al Jofeh, in Um al Kundum, and Mokheibeh to this day remain landmarks to be admired.
https://universes.art/en/art-destinations/jordan/amman/museums/dukes-diwan

“I was trying the recipe of "Agar Agar+Clay" recipe by @fabtextiles & @fabricademy founder Anastasia Pistofidou, from her Bioplastic Cook Book when I noticed how similar the texture of the clay was to the wastes of Turkish coffee.
I decided to replicate the recipe using dried used Turkish coffee grounds. The first few results weren't what I hoped for, and there was several iterations before getting to this recipe.
The resulting material has a rubbery texture, it can be described as a soft solid that's a little flexible. I've tried soaking this resulting pieces in water for almost a week, and they kept their characteristics, so now I'm trying to develop and test the usage of this material as a coffee cup.

Female
pads.title: Turkish Coffee Waste & Agar Agar

pads.content:
Laafi Bag ou le « sac de santé »
Description de Laafi Bag: Laafi Bag ou le « sac de santé » est un équipement autonome modèle sac à
dos réfrigérant qui fonctionne avec plusieurs sources d’énergie dont l’énergie photovoltaïque. Laafi Bag permet de transporter et de conserver les vaccins et produits pharmaceutiques à des températures entre -10 à 12oC. Laafi Bag
garantit ainsi la distribution des vaccins sans altération dans les zones les plus reculées du Burkina Faso, qui ne possèdent pas de moyens de conservations à basse température pour les vaccins et autres produits de santé. 
Caractères innovants de Laafi Bag : 1. C’est un équipement léger, autonome et équipé d’un module photovoltaïque pour
conserver et réguler la température en son sein afin d’acheminer les vaccins et autres produits sensibles dans les zones les plus critiques sans interruption de la chaîne du froid. 
2. Laafi Bag répond aux contraintes liées à l’ergonomie du sac mais aussi (et surtout) par rapport à son autonomie ; il
maintient la chaîne du froid sur une durée de 90h soit environ quatre jours, alors que les sacs semblables qui sont actuellement sur le marché “tiennent” entre 12 et 24h. 
3. La plus-value de l’invention et son impact social sur le développement des pays africains qui réussiront ainsi un des
défis majeurs qui est la lutte contre la mortalité infanto juvénile prolongeant ainsi l’espérance de vie des populations de manière générale. Dans le contexte de l’apparition de nouvelles maladies touchant le monde, il est impératif de
disposer d’équipements capables d’assurer l’acheminement, dans les conditions idéales, de futurs remèdes vers les zones les plus reculées d’Afrique et du monde.
4. Un système de monitoring basé sur plusieurs protocoles de communications et de géolocalisation est actuellement incorporé dans Laafi bag pour pouvoir localiser les agents de santé qui en sont munis et permettre de surveiller en temps réel les températures et les paramètres de fonctionnement. C'est alors un outil statistique de suivi et d'évaluation des opérations de vaccinations
Problème adressé: L'une des conditions d’une bonne conservation des vaccins est de les garder à des températures basses (2 à 8 oC). Cela est très souvent un écueil pour les services et les agents de santé d’un pays comme le Burkina Faso, où
les températures ambiantes varient entre 30 et 47 degrés et où certaines localités ne disposent pas encore d’installations électriques. Il est alors difficile d’assurer la qualité des vaccins par une bonne conservation.
Ainsi, en dépit de nombreuses campagnes de vaccination pour lutter contre des maladies infantiles comme la rougeole, la poliomyélite, la coqueluche, etc., l’acheminement des vaccins en zones rurales dépourvues d’électricité est souvent un parcours du combattant. Lorsque les vaccins sont transportés, il faut immédiatement les utiliser avant 24h ou 48h, sinon ils ne sont plus utilisables et donc inefficaces. De nombreux enfants sont non vaccinés dans les zones rurales, surtout
les plus reculées.Une telle situation explique que la mortalité infanto juvénile soit encore élevée surtout en milieu rural. L’OMS estime qu’un enfant sur cinq n’est pas vacciné et environ trois millions d’enfants meurent par manque de vaccination. Au Burkina Faso, le taux de mortalité infantile (0-1ans) est de 61 pour mille et celui de la mortalité infanto-juvénile (0-5 ans) est de 184 pour mille. 
C’est dire que ces enfants décèdent entre autres de maladies qui auraient pu être prévenues ou évitées par des vaccins. D'où l'idée de Laafi Bag pour apporter une conservation longue durée des vaccins. 
Impact
L'impact de Laafi Bag est de contribuer à assurer la bonne santé des communautés les plus vulnérables au Burkina Faso
Promoteur : Christian Céderic Toé
pads.title: Laafi Bag ou le « sac de santé »

pads.content:
The social Computer learning Center 
My name is Kalil, When my holder brother and I were studying, we had as idea to create a little business from what we could pay all our bills. 2 years later, we were together graduated Engineers and like most of the cases in our country, it was like you spend all your time dreaming and you finalize by discovering that reallity is different. Those who used to support us now strart claiming from support in return. To be short, life while being student was very far from the reallity when we strart looking for job. Reverting on what we were saying, our first best idea was to manage the mobile money transfert. Full of confidence and faith, we agreed to go on. Whatever it be, we should not resign. 6 first months later we were still optimist to get it well going but one of the aspect that was playing against us, was the area where we decided to hold the business: the zone is full of people with low incomes. Facing that situation, we tried to see if we can find other option of developpment and we ended by proposing printing, copy, scanning services. Still things were not going well. My brother one day asked me to try if we can do an extra exercice and I just replied that it was impossible for me to do additional task as the existing one is not working. Let me tell you, I lost faith at that moment in the fact that one day things could change. He insisted and finally, told me that he has found the solution. For him, as we are dealing with an area with low incomes, we should do the things goin in the same direction so that the people will feel themselves part of our deal. 
What was his way to proceed? Just because of the fact that there is less incomes means they need to have services with low coast and almost all the services in our side that could interest them was claiming from them to have some level of digital litteracy and here is the deal. To realise the tasks, request is made for them to go out of their area side. So to solve that case, we have to give them a proximity solution. His proposition was then to build a mini computer center that could allow us to exploit the maximum of our capacity but also allow them to be part of a circular economy. That circulation could be defined as, they learn from us, use for their needs , produce and then come back to use the other services that was existing before. Wonderful!!! I said but internally i still not convinced by I just let him try. 
To build the center, we were confronted to find cheeper equipments so, we started by the place, we bluit the center with a 6 m2 metal box, 6 chaires and mini computer tables. About the electronics, we have purchased some old computers and used the FAN that is coming from old Air condition. How program is composed by Taptouch, Word, Excel Powerpoint and if requested, before Office training, we can teach some basic knowledge of windows. 
I am pleased to announce you that since we changed our strategy, we finally started receiving clients and some positive comment aboutthe fact that we are contributing to the developpement of the area side. Our particularity is that we are offering the service based on their finacial possibility. Up to today, we have more the 10 students willing to anounce in their networks the good vibes spreaded by the project.
pads.title: The social Computer learning Center

pads.content:
1) « EasySchool » au service de l’Éducation pour tous
DESCRIPTION DE LA SOLUTION : EasySchool est une solution logicielle professionnelle et simple pour la gestion intégrée, synergique et multi-niveau de la vie académique des écoles, universités, instituts d'enseignement et complexes académiques. La solution « EasySchool » a été conçue progressivement pour répondre aux besoins de gestion optimisée des acteurs essentiels du système éducatif à la fois, en l'occurrence les structures en charge de l’enseignement, les enseignants, les parents, les étudiants et l’administration publique. EasySchool adresse des problématiques parfois complexes sur un périmètre
vertical allant du niveau de la maternelle à celui du supérieur, sur un périmètre horizontal de l'intégration fonctionnelle de l'académique, des finances et statistiques entre autres et sur un périmètre circulaire de
synergie entre les acteurs essentiels de l'éducation à travers l'internet, les communications mails et des SMS « intelligents ». Le système innovant développé à travers EasySchool est de promouvoir une éducation pour tous qui s’appuie sur des outils qui ne nécessite pas dans tous les cas l’internet pour : Restaurer l’éducation mise en mal dans les zones affectées par l’insécurité due au terrorisme, avec un niveau de qualité très raisonnable ; Permettre l’accès à l’éducation dans des zones difficiles d’accès ou isolées et à des populations nomades ; Permettre la continuité de l’éducation avec l’avènement de la Covid-19, qui a occasionné la fermeture prématurée et généralisée des écoles.
Le caractère innovant de EasySchool, s’identifie à travers les atouts suivants : Une grande accessibilité qui s’appuie sur le télé-enseignement avec en sus la possibilité d’avoir du contenu pédagogique sur des appareils mobiles tels que les tablettes solaires et les téléphones intelligents (Smartphones) ; Dans les zones sans internet, EasySchool peut
fonctionner hors connexion ; C’est un système qui permet l’interactivité entre les acteurs éducatifs que sont les enseignants, les gestionnaires de l’enseignement, les parents, les élèves et les étudiants. à travers un système
de communication SMS ; EasySchoool permet l’évaluation formelle et à distance avec un protocole de communication SMS propulsé par la plateforme EasySchool ; Il existe une facilité de communication automatique des comptes rendus périodiques par SMS sur l’apprentissage de l’élève aux parents ; Le système génère des bulletins trimestriels et annuels pour les élèves et offre une meilleure prise de décision pour le passage ou non à un niveau supérieur.
PROMOTEUR : EquoService (Abdoul Malick Zorome et Adama Zongo 
PROBLEME ADRESSE : Easy school : LeSystème éducatif des pays en voie de développement fait face à de nombreuxdéfis qui limitent sa performance et les opportunités d'innovation. Parmi ces défis, il y a la problématique de l’accès à une éducation de qualité au profit de tous les apprenants dans un contexte marqué par l’insécurité liée au terrorisme et par la pandémie du Covid-19. Au Burkina Faso, des milliers
d’élèves sont mis sur le banc de touche du système éducatif classique. En raison de l’insécurité ambiante, on estime que plus de 256 000 enfants n’ont pas pu aller à l’école au cours de l’année scolaire 2019-2020. C’est une réalité vécue par plusieurs enfants dans plusieurs zones où la crise sécuritaire amène plusieurs enfants à être hors du système éducatif. Aussi, avec l’avènement du Covid-19 et dont les premiers cas ont été révélés au Burkina Faso en Mars 2020, les premières mesures prises par les autorités ont été la fermeture de toutes les écoles du pays. La pandémie du coronavirus aggrave ainsi la situation difficile créée par l’insécurité dans certaines zones du pays, avec la fermeture des établissements d’enseignement et de formation professionnelle (pré scolaire, primaire, secondaire, supérieur, écoles etc.) dans tout le pays. La
problématique de l’accessibilité à l’éducation et à la formation, qui étaient circonstancielle et localisée, s’est généralisée et touche tout le pays. On assiste alors à un arrêt total des activités d’enseignement et de formation.
Impact : Contribuer à l’accès d’une éducation de qualité au profit de tous les apprenants dans un contexte marqué par l’insécurité liée au terrorisme et par la pandémie du Covid-19.
pads.title: 1) « EasySchool » au service de l’Éducation pour tous

pads.content:
Sarai Stove
Mr. R. M. Salunkhe, Dr. K. Dutta
Pune, Maharashtra,India
Profile Innovators Mr. R. M. Salunkhe and Dr. K. Dutta are from Pune district of Maharashtra. They are working with an NGO working for rural development through the implementation of innovative technologies in the field of non-conventional energy sources and agriculture. Purpose Mr. Salunkhe and Dr. Dutta have developed an innovative stove for fuel-saving, time-saving, and to improve the indoor air quality of the rural kitchen. Technical details The 'Sarai Stove' consists of four parts. All parts are made of mild steel. Combustion chamber: It is an open-ended cylinder, with an aluminum lining from inside. There is a door on the inside, and a series of holes along the periphery at the bottom. The holes serve as air inlets. There are two clamps on the side near the top for holding the outer jacket. Fuel holder This is a mild steel cylinder with an open top and a cast iron grate at the bottom. Solid fuel in the form of wood chips, coal, charcoal, biomass briquettes, etc. are placed in the holder, which in turn is placed inside the combustion chamber through its side door. Outer jacket It is an open-ended cylinder that fits on the top of the combustion chamber. There are two rows of holes circumscribing the cylinder near the top. Cooker with lid The cooker is a cylindrical vessel that can be inserted into the outer jacket, leaving an annular space of just about 2.5-3 mm between the walls of the two. It has a wide rim at the top, which seals up the annular space. The lid fits snugly into the open top of the cooker. To operate the stove, the fuel holder loaded with fuel is inserted into the combustion chamber. The outer jacket is fitted on to the chamber, and the cooker is inserted into it. About 200 ml of water is poured into the cooker and the cooking vessels are stacked in it, one on top of the other. The lid is closed and the fire is started. The air required for combustion of the fuel enters from the holes at the bottom of the combustion chamber and is sucked into the fuel stack through the grate at the bottom of the fuel holder. The hot gases and flames emitted by the fire pass through the annular space between the outer jacket and the cooker, and come out through the holes near the top of the outer jacket. The heat is conducted into the cooker through its bottom and walls and converts the water inside into the steam. The cooker fills up with steam and generates a sufficiently high temperature within the cooker to cook the food. Because of the fuel placed in the burner is limited, the stove extinguishes itself after a certain time. The food inside the vessel remains hot after the fire goes out due to the double jacket surrounding it. For frying or bread making, the outer jacket can be detached from the combustion chamber and the chamber can be used as a portable single pot stove. Performance The stove can be operated on any solid biomass fuel. Only 100 g of the charcoal is required to prepare food for 4-5 persons. The stove design is optimized for good combustion efficiency hence, cooking takes place in a smokeless environment. The outer jacket also can be used with a gas or kerosene stove, to increase fuel efficiency. Benefits The stove has higher fuel efficiency and it is smokeless. It increases the indoor air quality of the rural kitchen.

Product
pads.title: Sarai Stove

pads.content:
Moringa for Sewage Water and Clean Energy
Water treatment, natural fertilizer

Inventor: Fatma Ali Elbanna (Student)
Although water makes up to 71% of the Earth’s surface, only 0.5% is fresh. Fresh water resources are getting exhausted at an exponential rate due to environmental changes, as well as the lack of sustainable planning. This project addresses three of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs); Clean Water and Sanitation (SDG 6), Affordable and Clean Energy (SDG 7), and Zero Hunger (SDG 2). People living in small towns or villages with no access to central services, will be the main beneficiaries of this project. The project is about developing a decentralized sewage unit for sewage purification for agricultural uses; the products are methane gas that serves as a source of energy, and agriculture fertilizers and water. The sewage bulk is filtered through a net, aerated, mixed with grinded moringa seed, and finally charcoal to remove color, taste, and odor. Moringa Oleifera (MO) is widely cultivated in Egypt; its seeds contain 35–40% oil, with potent antimicrobial activity as well as effective coagulant and heavy metal removal properties. The COD, BOD, TDS, and other bacterial count tests are carried out to ensure the suitability of the produced water for agriculture. Therefore, MO can be considered a natural and cheap alternative for chlorine and aluminum sulfate. Through this project, the sewage water treatment unit could be cost-effective and eco-friendly by sustaining the fresh drinking water and increasing the availability of agricultural water and natural safe fertilizers. This eventually leads to increasing crops production and supports the country’s economy.
Video: https://youtu.be/Lk23zxh5DAM
https://projectboard.world/isef/project/isef-booth-id-project-title-groxd?rc=da0d07f8-8cee-49f0-a579-65c64e77dd21

Female
pads.title: Moringa for Sewage Water and Clean Energy

pads.content:
Portable Lighting

The camp located in Ras Mohamed Nature Reserve in Egypt used a DIY lighting solution that helped guests staying at the camp to have some light at night while dinner is served.
The lighting unit used both repurposed materials like the plastic bottles used to get drinking water to the camp, natural material like sand found everywhere in the reserve to add weight to the unit, and an energy source the rechargeable led lamp. The end result is a lightweight portable lighting unit that can be easily moved around the camp and provide enough lighting to carry out minor tasks.
Access to light source
Camps located in the Nature reserve have limited access to resources like electricity as a result the Beduins that run the camps need to find solutions to work around the limitations to make sure they provide their guests with a comfortable stay while still taking care of the environment. Consequently, you would find many DIY versions of many amenities we take for granted in the city. The DIY versions more often than not are sustainable since they are considering the fact that resources are limited.

pads.content:
In our quest for solutions in the #Acceleratorlab we came across with one wonderful recycling experience in Cabo Verde, which we’d like to share with you!
Santo Antão is the further Northwest island of the Cabo Verde archipelago. It’s an island known by its mountains, green valleys, rural tourism, trekking and delicious local food, but since 2017, Santo Antão has also became the heart of plastic recycling in Cabo Verde. This is the incredible story of Maria Teresa Segredo and the Netherlands Foundation “Amigos do Paúl” (Friends of Paúl).
Penedo is a small locality in the gateway to Janela area, after Santa Barbara tunnel for those traveling on the coastal road from the municipality of Porto Novo to Paúl. Arid, eminently a fishing village with some trade and few residents, Penedo is also the access to other touristic places in the region, like Ribeira and Fajã.
Since 2017 the area has gained another movement with the factory that is giving new life to plastics, turning them into tiles and helping to solve one of the environmental dramas in the country, which is the high use of plastic bottles "PET", which after use are thrown to the ground.
Each tile produced in Santo Antão uses eight plastic bottles and they are processed in this innovative recycling factory installed in Penedo. The factory directly employs 5 people and indirectly support many more that collect and deliver plastics from throughout the island, and have an installed capacity to produce up to 24.000 tiles made of plastic with different patterns. The project was promoted by Maria Segredo and the foundation “Amigos do Paúl” in the Netherlands, and was financed by the Dutch Cooperation through the University of TuDelf in Rotterdam.
In November 2018, the factory begun to supply local market with the plastic-made tiles. For the moment, the factory is only recycling “PET” material and producing 20x20 tiles for the construction industry and some decorative material. The acceptance now is good and the orders are increasing rapidly. Each box with 24 tiles costs 3,000 CVE (around 27 Euros) and the company is also exporting the product to the Netherlands, through a partner in that European country.
The project has awarded an ecological merit medal from the Municipality of Paúl.
On a daily basis, the company removes about 25 kilos of plastics from the environment and, in two years, has recycled more than 20 tons of garbage and produced more than 2,000 tiles, which are sold in the domestic market and also abroad. For the moment, the factory is only recycling PET material, but they have stored a large amount of plastic bags for “future experiences”.
Hirondino Silva, manager of the factory, says “often people come here and ask us for plastic bottles, because they say they can no longer find them anymore in the streets.” That’s the sign that our environment is cleaner" he added. Santo Antão is benefiting from an environment more and more free from used plastic bottles, which are now harder to find.
To get all the plastic material they need, the factory promotes collection in hotels and restaurants throughout the island. Individuals and families are also gathering plastic bottles in their homes and neighborhood to deliver in the factory, and the company pays for it. There is a local young man that promotes plastic collection in the municipal waste landfill and in public gatherings and celebrations. There is also a focal point for plastic collection in the neighbor island São Vicente. Anyone who wants to send plastic to Penedo can reach the company through its phone contacts and Facebook page. The company can help with the logistics in sending the material, namely through the municipality environment services.
pads.title: Plastic made tiles: A solution from Santo Antão

pads.content:
Alibaba's floating cabin
On the banks of the Rio Pongo, located a few kilometers from the city center of Kamsar, we discover before our eyes an idyllic scene with hyper-hurried ladies, men overloaded with basins at the edges of which we can identify the few lines of fish and seafood. It is in a good-natured atmosphere that we manage to collect a few words from our friend DAOUDA CAMARA fishing in deep water.
Like most of the unemployed young people of Kamsar, Daouda Camara found himself at a very critical moment in his life confronted with the fact of wanting to carve out a better future and at the same time provide his family with the minimum necessary for a living.
After his primary studies, Daouda was guided by the force of fate towards several types of odd jobs which ultimately remained without a favorable outcome. Always in search of a solution to his dilema, he quickly surrounded himself with a few friends who gave him the chance to enter their favorite exercise. This is how Daouda, a young resourceful man, will discover fishing boats, canoes and other traditional means of navigation at the heart of the port of Kamsar.
Our friend Daouda, day after day will end up enjoying it and will discover the wonders of fishing but also the constraints that go with it such as the level of coldness of the sea during the night, the difficulty of fishing and the scarcity of fish during the rainy seasons, very often the few losses of human life due to the sinking of boats of fortune.
According to Daouda, during his learning cycle, the biggest problem was the conservation of the fishing crops because, they had to quickly return to the surface to prevent the fish from rotting in the sea.
When the Senegalese fishermen arrived, Daouda and his friends had a chance to discover the "YOLI", a kind of traditional fishing boat made up of a very large canoe hull divided into several compartments including the 'front serving as a livewell hold, the middle serving as a transition between the front and the conservation hold. Speaking of conservation hold, here is one of the most innovative components of this traditional fishing boat because before its existence, fishermen like our friend Tinder beat each other up when they delayed at sea with the expiration of fish as an argument.
THE FAMOUS FLOATING freezer is a box whose walls are covered with glue based on liquid floats. In addition to this is added a cover made of polyester sleeping bag which finally makes the structure waterproof, allowing the fish to be kept this time for more than three weeks of duration on the sea. This makes the series of trips more than comfortable. Amadou and his family at sea. According to Amadou, after fishing, the contents of the boxes are distributed between them and the port manager in the following proportions: for each catch of three boxes, a half-box is intended for him. it will be remembered that in the event of an inconsistent setting, nothing is transmitted to him.
As it is often said, rural populations always have a solution to their problem.
From this solution of freezing over a long period, the fishermen act positively on the environment in the sense that they avoid letting empty bags inherit in nature which would probably push the residents to proceed with the calcination and thus pollute the environment. nature. For our Hero Daouda Camara, the conservation mode is more than beneficial since beyond the conservation of fish, without the need for a motor or battery; it offers them the possibility of reselling the residue of ice which is reusable to maintain the fish for the women going from the port to the various places of consumption or markets.
Thanks to Daouda CAMARA.
pads.title: Alibaba's floating cabin

pads.content:
TOLBI : Smart agriculture in local languages 
Description Tolbi provides real-time information for effective decision making on irrigation, disease management and yield forecasting to agricultural stakeholders especially small scale producers for a Climate-Smart Agriculture. e-Tolbi resides in the mash-up of global data (satellite images, research work, plant data sheets, diseases) with data related to the smallholder (credit history, property title, mobile money subscriber service, etc.) and data related to the farm (soil data, location, geography, history, etc.) to deliver highly accurate information, predictions and better decision-making for all stakeholders in the agricultural value chain. The data is collected by satellite, drones, from agricultural cooperatives, national agricultural agencies and then centralized through a platform to deliver real-time and reliable information to small farmers in local languages on IVR/SMS voice. This allows agricultural advisors and investors to be able to remotely monitor small farmers in real time through a web-based SAAS platform for accurate alerts and updates based on the data provided. Through the e-Tolbi marketplace, agregator companies, traders and supermarkets will be able to make pre-orders through yield forecasts based on machine learning algorithms and enable smallholders and their partners to sell at good prices and ensure early marketing. video link : https://youtu.be/W3oviAR0BVU
Challenges Small-scale farmers lose 60-80% of their irrigation water every day due to lack of water control. Late detection of diseases results in an estimated 30% loss of agricultural yield for small farmers. Microfinance institutes lack reliable information and data to set up financial insurance policies to allow small farmers to benefit from financing. They negatively impact the ability of small-scale farmers to innovate in production due to lack of means and to obtain optimal yields due to losses and poor water management.
Insights Tolbi aims to enable small-scale producers to access different services such as production-related services (from the pre-harvest phase to the post-harvest phase to assist and advise them on best practices to combat diseases that can hinder production), finance-related services with detailed field data that can help credit companies to build a reliable credit profile and deliver loans to smallholder farmers more easily, trade and market-related services by facilitating linkages with stakeholders and access to information on best prices, and services related to subscriptions to the cooperative (member management with CRM, distributed communications. .). e-Tobli's services will enable small farmers to take advantage of technological innovations (drone, artificial intelligence, IoT, satellite) with adapted IVR interfaces in local languages and voice SMS for women and illiterate youth and a mobile application for those who are better equipped and also considerably increase their income with accurate information on the agricultural health (disease, weeds), exact needs for water and fertilization as well as forecasts of harvest periods to aid production-related planning.
pads.title: TOLBI : Smart agriculture in local languages

pads.content:
Solid Compost - Aerobic Composting

Its appearance and texture is earthy and granular, resembling soil. It has a dark color due to the high content of decomposed organic matter. In its final stage, it should be relatively dry and should not give off any bad aroma.
Depending on the type of organic matter that has been used in the composting process, solid compost is full of essential nutrients, such as nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium and other micronutrients, which are beneficial for plant growth. In addition to its chemical components, its physical characteristics make it excellent for improving soil oxygenation, moisture retention and protection against the sun's rays. 
It is used to remedy worn soil, to perform pylons transplants and to apply on the roots of the plant directly.
pads.title: Solid Compost - Aerobic Composting

pads.content:
Solid Worm Compost

This type of compost is a mixture between the organic matter naturally degraded in the composting process and the excreta of the worms (red or Californian coquette) that feed on the available organic waste. Its appearance is very similar to conventional compost, with the difference that vermicompost stores more moisture and is less porous.
Thanks to enzymes within the worms' digestive system, nutrients are easier for plants to absorb. 
It is used to remedy worn soil, to fertilize already established plants, increase the number of microorganisms in the soil, increase oxygenation and protect from heat waves.
pads.title: Solid Worm Compost

pads.content:
Compost Tea - Liquid Compost

It is the mixture between the liquid excreta of the digestive tract of the worm used for composting, the moisture of the composting system and the liquids produced in the aerobic decomposition within it. It is a thick brown/orange liquid, which should not generate any aroma.
This liquid is full of microorganisms, which are essential for soil regeneration and increased fertility in plants. The concentration of nutrients in the liquid depends on the materials used in the composting process, as well as the amount used when making the irrigations. 
It is used to remedy worn soil, to fertilize already established plants, protect roots, trunks and leaves from diseases and increase the number of microorganisms in the soil.
pads.title: Compost Tea - Liquid Compost

This program is aimed at people who own land smaller than 15 hectares, paying them to plant trees or manage natural forests. In order to enter the program, people must have a forest management plan and the ability to maintain the forest, either for productive purposes or only for reforestation. 
This scheme allows people to have even 5 hectares of land, making it an excellent model for the conservation of micro-ecosystems.
pads.title: PINPEP

pads.content:
PROBOSQUE

This program seeks to give continuity to the PINFOR project. It aims to promote and encourage the country's forestry development through sustainable forest management and reduce deforestation of forest lands. The conservation of forest cover in Guatemala is promoted through payments to the owners or managers of the forest plantation in question. 
This scheme is for producers with larger tracts of land and applies to areas with a forestry vocation that have a productive objective (firewood).
pads.title: PROBOSQUE

pads.content:
Payment to indigenous communities for conservation

It is the mechanism used for the economic retribution of the actions that indigenous communities carry out for the conservation of the upper part of the sub-basin of the Ixtacapa River. The actions have a positive impact on the maintenance of water resources in the sub-basin.
IThe main actors are nine K'iche' communities in the municipality of Nahualá, department of Sololá, with a total of 4500 people as users of the service, which also benefits five municipalities (90,000 inhabitants) and six private farms that use river water for agriculture and livestock, as well as a sugar mill.
pads.title: Payment to indigenous communities for conservation

pads.content:
Productive REDD+ plantations

Rubber plantations constitute a payment for environmental services for carbon fixation within the voluntary market scheme REDD+, which will last for 42 years (2007-2049). The company PICA is committed to managing and conserving these plantations in a sustainable manner to guarantee the capture 
Rubber forests are an excellent example of productive plantations that can capture CO2 in the same way. Eventually the forests cease to be productive in this way and become timber.
pads.title: Productive REDD+ plantations

Care and WFF Program

Community producers committed to reforest with native species in the areas previously dedicated to the planting of crops, in the middle and upper part of the basin, protect the forests located on municipal lands and promote the processes of natural regeneration. These conservation works will be carried out thanks to the payment of a fee from the municipality of Teculután. 
The contribution of the municipality as a buyer of environmental services is quantified at approximately $ 150 thousand per year.

PC - Forgali Program

This system of payment for environmental services was used in an unconventional way. The funding was mainly allocated to the training of community leaders from various communities in lower Verapaz, with the aim of increasing water resource management capacities so that they themselves could benefit. 
The participating community groups consider that 87% of them have received a direct benefit from the intervention, considering as benefits mainly the obtaining of agricultural, food, financial or material inputs, free of charge.

when greywater flows through them.

Air is pumped to transfer oxygen to the greywater. The bacteria present consume the dissolved oxygen and digest the organic pollutants, reducing these pollutants.

Air is pumped to transfer oxygen to the greywater. The bacteria present consume the dissolved oxygen and digest the organic pollutants, reducing these pollutants.

Bridging the digital gender gap

In February 2021, Microsoft Airband partner New Sun Road (NSR) began implementing a gender-focused connectivity program in Alta Verapaz, Guatemala. To address this lack of connectivity, NSR is using a USAID grant under the Microsoft Airband partnership to build ten Stellar Ixq-Saq'e Digital Community Centers in ten non-electrified rural communities in the region.

The digital literacy programme was recently launched in all ten communities, and the 22 lessons of the first course were successfully completed by 319 women and girls.

Through the ENRICH program, women from different communities in rural areas of Guatemala are trained to use a tablet, smartphone or LED TV to communicate and share content that can be useful to them and their communities. 
For women who have been denied the opportunity to receive a formal education, the Enriche curriculum puts at their disposal a democratic learning environment, barrier-free and inclusive of their many skills and wisdom.

The objective is to provide study opportunities to young Guatemalans with limited economic resources in rural areas of the country, but with great desire to excel. Since its foundation, the EFA has contributed to the agricultural development of our country, incorporating into society technicians with academic excellence and theoretical and practical knowledge in agricultural sciences. People who receive support from the EFA can learn to use technological tools related to agricultural production.
Interesting fact: People can study a career, but shorter practical courses are also offered for interested communities and groups.

The main objective of the project is to complement the field work, through the incorporation and involvement of 500 young volunteers to carry out activities focused on strengthening the capacities of farmers in local regions. These capabilities include agricultural production and the use of technological devices to improve their yields. 
Currently, the project facilitates the knowledge of the "peasant to peasant" methodology for the development of rural extension in 18 departments of Guatemala through the participation of rural youth, who become multiplier agents in their community.

Forest conservation as a key element in water governance

Problem: There was inadequate management of the forest within this partiality (communal land). There were forest fires, overgrazing, excessive felling of trees for firewood and commercialization, contamination of the area and fragmentation of the forest. All these situations in turn influenced that the collection and quality of water began to decrease.
Solution: A society was established where the tasks of caring for the forest could be distributed, inculcating activities such as: thinning, cleaning, sustainable logging, reforestation, maintenance of the greenhouse, among others. This with the aim of increasing water collection and quality.

Programming as a Second Language | IT Job Skills
The Cincinnatus Institute of Craftsmanship is a initiative by businessman and IT professional Chris Corcino and his wife Dalisa Heredia. Their project began as a free programming skills course in a local school. The couple then were allowed to transform the school curriculum and customize it for students to learn conmputer programming by the time they finish high school. Then, at the institute, they recruit youth from this school and from other underserved communities and train them for 1-2 years. If they become proficient, they are offered a job at Corcino's IT software development company, which provides outsourcing services to different companies in the USA. This project is mostly funded by the Corcinos. The institute has been featured in the media and recognized by several gov't institutions for its work to promote a generation of programmers who can make a good living and bring their families out of poverty.
Video about the project

Open source software that stops machinery from deforesting

Code of Conscience uses open-source mapping data from the United Nations World Database on Protected Areas – updated monthly by NGOs, communities and governments – in conjunction with existing GPS tracking technology that’s installed in construction vehicles, to autonomously restrict deforestation crews from entering protected zones. A small, low-cost chip has been developed to equip the code into older, non-GPS models, and the software is available for free to everyone on CodeofConscience.org

Only two families in the village were supplied with water from artisanal wells. In addition to the weather, women put themselves at risk by leaving their homes too early to try to take advantage of the river's flow.
Solution: Formation of the COCODE as a tool to face the problem of water scarcity in the community and The community well is built, which has a system that supplies 465 jets for each house and 5 extra jets which are for communal use and are located in public areas.

Andrea is a woman with disability (cerebral palsy) who was assaulted in a park by a man who had followed her. When she was brought down to the floor, suddenly a dog approached them and barked insistently to the point that the attacker had to let her go. Her story: https://acclabecu.org/en/a-four-legged-hero/
From this experience, Andrea Funded ARNV (Non-violence Rapid Action), a foundation that trains street dogs to protect battered women who have a restraining order.

Social security Schemes: Mutualities

Las mutuales, parte de la economía social, han tenido un papel importante en la seguridad social, especialmente en países donde no ha habido una cobertura universal de servicios básicos. Ofrecen servicios de salud, seguros de desempleo y pensiones con los aportes de sus miembros y/o cubren necesidades insatisfechas. Son sin ánimo de lucro y se financian de contribuciones de los/as trabajadores.
El paraguas a nivel mundial (sobretodo Europeo) es la AIM. “Se estima que las mutualidades prestan servicios a aproximadamente 230 millones de ciudadanos en salud y prestaciones sociales.”
Algunos ejemplos:
• Asociación Chilena de Seguridad (ACHS), cuenta con una red de hospitales, entre ellos, el Hospital del Trabajador en Santiago de Chile.
• En Chile, el Instituto de Seguridad del Trabajo (IST) es una corporación de carácter Mutual, que administra, sin fines de lucro, el Seguro Social contra Riesgos de Accidentes del Trabajo y Enfermedades Profesionales.
• Asociaciones Mutuales de Colombia
**Los aportes no pertenecen al asociado (no se retira el aporte económico). Son contribuciones que fortelecen el patrimonio común. 
• Argentina tiene 4500 mutualidades

Barcoding to catalogue biodiversity in Galápagos

Citizen science used to catalogue fauna and flora in the Galápagos.
This project is led by Universidad San Francisco de Quito and has a 750.000 USD funding from: UK Research & Innovation (UKRI) del Reino Unido, Global Challenges Research Fund (GCRF) y Newton Fund.
The project is starting by training 50 people who live in the Galápagos, who before the pandemic, had economic activities in tourism and fishing. This project helps reactivate their economy while contributing to conservation. These local people have been trained to use barcoding sytem, which consists on using DNA sequences and comparing that information to global databases.
The limitation of this solution is that the project has a one year duration; however, sustainability is expected with new capacities acquired by local people who can continue with science and conservation.
Data should be updated to identify endangered species, however, the project contributes to create an exhaustive catalogue.

pads.content:
Wind resistant vineyards

This is how vineyards grow on Canary Island in Lanzarote where there is no irrigation system and very little rainfall, with strong winds.
The small island has more than 300 volcanoes and therefore the place is mixed with a lot of ash.
Grape saplings are planted specifically in dug pits or, alternatively, a rock wall is placed around the sapling. This is done to make it easier for the roots to reach the fertile soil layer and to maintain the moisture of the grapes. This system works well considering that there is very little rainfall, no artificial irrigation, the plants are fed from the dew, that is concrentraed in the walls of the cones around it.
pads.title: Wind resistant vineyards

pads.content:
Sustainable Housing Solutions

Access to affordable housing remains a major challenge for many poor communities in Eswatini. The Mgidza informal settlement in Vuvulane with a total of over 27 households is one such community whose homes are constructed mostly of stick and mud and present a health and safety hazard for its residents, including children. This is one of five informal communities located in the Farming town of Vuvulane. The Informal settlements supply labour to the sugarcane farmers who either do not make enough from their revenues to provide their workers with proper housing or elect not to do so. The result is that informal workers and their families must resort to building make-shift, usually one or two-roomed houses using local materials like stick, mud and grass that are shared by whole families, as they also do not have land rights to allow them to build more permanent structures. This problem is widespread across the 5 farming communities in Vuvulane and is a common feature across the rural poor. This solution is shared by a locally based education center focused on promoting sustainable living called Gubha. 
Traditionally, Swati homes are made of natural building materials, mostly lutindzi grass, reeds, sticks, stones and mud. These home structures have excellent thermal properties, allowing for a pleasant stay throughout the seasons. The cutting of the grass and reeds is seasonal, to allow for nature to regenerate and provide consistently. Floors are rammed earth with a top coating of wood ash and cow dung. It is important to note that traditional African or Swati architecture has always been environmentally conscious, using what is available within the landscape. It is unfortunate that such indigenous knowledge, in architecture, was neglected for a long time, labelled as primitive and a symbol of poverty, thus giving way to ‘modern’ architectural methods that have mostly been working against nature (i.e. requiring artificial means of temperature control) and are generally more expensive.
The Low Cost High Quality Eco Housing solution, tries to utilise these traditional methods to construct modern, sustainable and affordable housing solutions. This sustainable housing solution aims to provide affordable housing solutions to the poor using locally available and affordable materials. 
The house is made of compressed mud bricks (made by the community from red earth, dug on site, and a mixture of river sand, small amounts of cement) that provide good insulation, thus reducing the energy costs for running them. A wood sawdust bucket compost toilet has been featured, thus reducing the need for solid waste plumbing and unnecessary wasting of water. The construction of up-cycled pallet wooden framed windows with shutters and mosquito nets allows for cross ventilation day and night with no fear of mosquitos penetrating. The window opening has been deliberately made small in width so that burglars cannot enter through it when it is open. Natural airflow and natural light have been considered in the design as the area experiences very hot summers and cold winters.
On one of their solution mapping safaris, the AccLab found this solution to be shared by two locally based NGOs focused on sustainable living, one being the Vuvulane orphans and Vulnerable Children’s Outreach Foundation (VOVCOF) and the Gubha Permaculture Education Center
pads.title: Sustainable Housing Solutions

Locally Made Steamer
When the COVID 19 pandemic gained momentum in 2020, a lot of people in Eswatini turned to steaming as a defense/ prevention mechanism against and to treat symptoms of the virus. Although a traditional treatment for flue symptoms, steaming wasn't totally new to the Swazi culture. however, it was mostly associated with traditional healing methods. However, when COVID hit, such traditional methods gained some popularity. this solution therefore was developed to meet the growing demand for steaming needs around the country with the aim of reducing accidents associatedwith traditional steaming from an open pot or basin.

pads.content:
Energy Efficient Heating Solution
As the world continues to call for climate action and protecting the environment, the re-use or upcycling of non-biodegradable material remains essential. 90% of the rural population in Eswatini, uses fuel wood as the main source of fuel for domestic purposes (particularly cooking, heating and water heating). As a result, more trees are being cut down leading to erosion the destruction of habitats for wild animals. For the Mbuluzi Game Reserve, like most rural communities, access to modern energy services such as electricity especially for water heating purposes, remains a challenge as modern energy services such as electricity and gas are very expensive, yet the need to sustainably use forest resources remains a high priority. This solution was designed to meet this need while ensuring the sustainable use of natural resources.
The solution was developed by the Mbuluzi Game Reserve Manager working with a local artisan (welder) to provide an energy-efficient, affordable off- normally heated more water than required and needed more fuel wood. This solution provided a more sustainable option which was affordable and easy to make with basic artisan skills. It adapted existing technologies to produce a solution that fits the needs of the Game Reserve, but that could easily serve the needs of households.
Mbuluzi Game Reserve is based in the Lubombo region of Eswatini, and its main aim is to conserve the country’s biodiversity. One of the tourism services offered by the facility in addition to accommodation is a camping facility. Initially, the camp site used a large wood-powered boiler system to heat water for its campers. However, this system proved inefficient and time-consuming as it required a lot of wood even if there were only two campers in the facility. This created the need for a more efficient off-grid system. This solution therefore aims to minimise the use of fuel wood resources to conserve the country’s bio-biodiversity. The water heating system can be made with scrap materials and requires minimum technical skills and can be easily made by local welders.
The main objectives of the water heater solution are:
- Provision of an affordable (uses scrap material), energy efficient (uses less than a third of the firewood that was used for the old system), easy to make and maintain (has no moving parts), and timesaving (heats water faster) water heating system
- Provision of opportunities for upcycling scrap metal (from near-by mills),
- Reduced negative impact on natural biodiversity (particularly the flora or forest), and
Reducing the risk of forest fires through a nearly enclosed system.

The water heating system is made up of discarded scrap metals from the nearby sugar factory. The system was designed and fabricated by the Game Ranger and a local retired welder. The structure constitutes of a concrete small shelter to protect the fire word from rain, a small oven-like fire box, a water cylinder, cold water inlet and hot water (shower) outlet. The structure is also fitted with a safety valve to release excess heat/ pressure should it get too hot, as a safety measure.
The system can be used for multiple purposes, e.g., cooking and heating, and possibly baking as it has the properties of an oven, making it easier for campers to prepare food.
What has made it successful is its low cost, use of reclaimed materials, ease of development and opportunity to provide a livelihood. The artisan who fabricates it is now able to make a living out of it.
pads.title: Energy Efficient Heating Solution

pads.content:
Laoob Application
Iraq's First and Largest Assembly of Amateur Football Players
The Problem:
The Solution (Laoob Application):

1- Lack of Proper Coaching and Equipment: Many aspiring amateur football players in Iraq lack access to proper coaching and basic equipment. This deficiency in resources hinders their development and growth in the sport.
2- Limited Financial Support: Financial support for amateur players is limited, making it difficult for them to afford necessary training, equipment, and participation in competitive events. 
3- Media Visibility and Recognition: The lack of media attention and spotlight on amateur players in local teams prevents their talent from being recognized and acknowledged. This lack of visibility impacts their chances for growth and potential professional opportunities. 
4- Disconnect with Talent Scouts: There is a significant disconnect between amateur football players and talent scouts. This communication gap, compounded by the absence of effective channels like social media, irregular competitive events, and potential inequalities, prevents talented players from being discovered and nurtured.
5- Infrastructure Challenges: While playgrounds are available in most Iraqi cities, challenges exist in securing access. High demand, lack of proper scheduling systems, difficulties in reaching playground owners, and inconsistent maintenance can hinder players' ability to use these facilities effectively.
6- Self-Funding and Playground Reservations: Local teams in Iraq are often self-funded and must pay to reserve playgrounds for matches. The process of reserving preferred time slots, accessing owners, and dealing with inconsistent maintenance can be cumbersome and impact team activities. 
7- Unregistered Amateur Players: A significant number of amateur football players in Iraq (more than one million) are not registered with the Iraqi Football Association. This lack of formal registration can limit their opportunities for organized play and recognition. 
8- Uneven Quality of Facilities: While playgrounds are available, the quality of these facilities can vary across different districts, affecting the overall playing experience and skill development of players. 
9- Inequality and Corruption: There is a potential for inequality and corruption that may prevent talented players from being recognized, further exacerbating the challenges of talent development and growth. 
10- Competitive Opportunities: The irregularity of competitive events organized by talent scouts/clubs can limit players' chances to showcase their skills and potential for professional football.
Laoob, a name derived from the Arabic word meaning "skilled player," is a one-stop-shop for amateur football players in Iraq. The platform connects these players and fosters a community, providing opportunities to improve their skills and pursue their aspirations of becoming professional footballers. In addition, Laoob streamlines the reservation issues of local football playgrounds. The platform's mission is to unearth the hidden football gems within local communities and provide them with the support needed to reach their full potential. The key features of the Laoob app are: 
1- Player profiles: a complete player profile, featuring personal information, technical and physical details, match statistics, and evaluations from peers and coaches.
2- Matchmaking: The platform links amateur football players with talent scouts.
3- Match scheduling: players can create and organize matches with one another.
4- Playground reservations: players can easily browse stadiums, learn about the services provided, and select a convenient day and time for reservation through a seamless process.
5- Talent evaluations: utilizing technology, the platform organizes performance trials to evaluate, select, and promote talented players to clubs in Iraq and abroad.
https://www.laoob.app/
https://www.undp.org/iraq/blog/tapping-passion-and-talent-exploring-impact-hosting-25th-arab-gulf-cup-and-role-local-solutions-iraq
pads.title: Laoob Application

pads.content:
Traditional Local Coffee - Ecotourism and Online Business
Local coffee (Arabica) planted at the foot of Mt. Kinabalu (1300m asl), Sabah. Traditionally processed and roasted using firewoods. The processing method has been practiced for generations (over 50 years) at a small village called Kiau Nuluh at Kota Belud, Sabah. It is one of the very few local Arabica Coffee available in Malaysia. An ecotourism business was started which took tourists through the traditional coffee farming process where one could see and taste first-hand the farm-to-cup experience. However, during the Movement Control Order (MCO), the entire village found themselves out of a job as around 90% of them had been depending on the tourism sector as their source of income. Fortunately, with the help of the digital platform, they managed to deliver the beans across Malaysia and even received orders from overseas.
pads.title: Traditional Local Coffee - Ecotourism and Online Business

pads.content:
Biomaterials from pineapple
Transforming biomaterial waste to biodegradable packaging

Substrato is a project that transforms agroindustrial waste into biomaterials that can be applied to developing sustainable products. This is achieved thanks to a multidisciplinary process that connects the field with creative and innovative methodologies and local knowledge and infrastructure.
This project was born as an academic exploration that arises from investigating and analyzing agro-industrial residues in Mexico to develop new alternatives for its use and management. This, in turn, implies the development of sustainable products that demonstrate the economic value of organic waste.
The research focused on pineapple leaves, the primary residue in producing this fruit, representing 75% of the harvested product. The waste that served as raw material for the project's development was obtained from Ciudad Isla, Veracruz, one of the key pineapple-producing states in Mexico.From the experiment, four biomaterials were developed (felt, bioplastic, chipboard, and rope), and some applications of the materials made of fiber and pineapple leaf bagasse.
https://www.sustratodesign.com

Female
pads.title: Biomaterials from pineapple

topic of the society.
People started to comply and adapt with the situation
and succeeded to show great level of resilience 
Waiting for their turns at the Gas station
became social gathering and a picnic including food and drinks, 
One solution that people have came up with to support each other,
that the ones who enjoys better financial
situation are hiring young men and unemployed men to take their cars and wait
on the rues instead of them and pay them in exchange of this service, This way people who suffers from bad financial sutuation and unemployeed men are gaining some money in exchange to their services.
Despite the fact that, this is not an
innovative solution that involves investment of available resources or even
grasshopper solutions , but from my direct observation and what I am hearing
from the community around me , I found that this way od adaptation and sometimes
manipulation of the existing reality and harsh difficulties that my community
is facing can be called a solution and would be considered as social integration solution approach.
Another creative solution that my community has
came up with using their resources f Social networking and facebook, that a
group of people from all over the districts of Damascus created website and a
page on facebook called “ وين عبيت " Where did you fill” which is a participatory page that inform
people about the available , opened and closed Gas stations with full information
and guidance on the better stations to head to, 24/7 and to inform people about
the time estimated for the waiting duration over each gas station, all needed information in this regard are
provided through this site and page.
The page news spread every where very quickly ,
ill it became a social supporting tool for people who needs to fill their cars.
Youngsters knowledge and skills were invested and people have coordinated
together in order to support each others.
The need of basic resouces such as fuel and transportation which affexts all other aspoects of the Syrian Habitants' Daily life and even prevent Taxi and bus drivers from their income.
The lesson to learn , is that community has the power to coordinate together and find alternatives and solutions, Social Cohesion awareness and support is essential during and after crisis.
pads.title:
Hope for
unemployed and fuel for our cars

pads.content:
System O)) Une gamme de solutions de traitement biologique passif anaérobie et aérobie
Les solutions System O)) ont été conçues pour traiter efficacement les eaux usées de nature domestique provenant d’une résidence isolée ou d’un autre bâtiment. La solution System O)), basée sur la technologie Advanced Enviro)) Septic, s’utilise dans une multitude de configurations en fonction des contraintes du terrain, des besoins du client et de la règlementation en vigueur dans la région. Elle permet d’éliminer efficacement plus de 99% des matières en suspension (MES), de la demande biochimique en oxygène sur 5 jours (DBO5) et des pathogènes grâce à un processus biologique naturel et passif. L’affluent doit subir au préalable un traitement primaire avant d’être acheminé vers le système de traitement secondaire avancé ou tertiaire tel une solution System O)). L’effluent de ce système peut être directement infiltré dans le sol ou collecté pour être réutilisé à d’autres fins. Le côté naturel et passif d’une solution System O)) lui confère une grande fiabilité et une flexibilité dans n’importe quel environnement. La conception d’un tel système est relativement simple, mais des règles doivent être suivies afin de réaliser une installation qui permettra d’obtenir le rendement prévu et de maintenir le niveau de performance épuratoire pour de nombreuses années. L’objectif de la technologie La problématique réside dans la limite de traitement par le sol traditionnel, on constate souvent que les champs d’épuration conventionnels (lit ou tranché d’infiltration, filtre à sable...) peuvent se fatiguer et se colmater pour plusieurs raisons : 1- une mauvaise distribution d’eau à traiter : soit latéral (un déséquilibre entre les conduites perforées), soit longitudinal, car on constate souvent que les conduites d’épandage classique ont du mal à acheminer l’eau à traiter jusqu’au bout du filtre. D’où la difficulté des systèmes classiques d’utiliser l’ensemble de la surface de traitement définie à l’origine. 2- Manque d’oxygénation : cela peut être causé par un recouvrement du système avec un matériau inadapté ou par une hauteur trop importante du remblai. 3- La granulométrie du sable : la granulométrie du sable et sa qualité ont un impact très important sur la performance du système de traitement. Il faut mentionner que ces systèmes de traitement classiques peuvent difficilement relancer leur efficacité en cas de problème. Il faut parler aussi de leur manque de flexibilité lors des installations (systèmes en pente, en couloir, en coude...etc.) L’objectif des solutions System O)) est de reprendre les principes de base et naturels de traitement des eaux usées afin de protéger le milieu récepteur tout en remédiant aux problèmes cités plus haut. Adresse de l’innovateur : INOVATECH-Sarl/ Innovations, Agroforesterie, Commerce Général RCCM/NI/NIA/2013/A/397/04/02/2013 ; Nif : 35665/S Cel : 91 10 00 85 / 96 96 48 53/ 96978110- BP 2796 Ny Email : hbissala@gmail.com, hbissala@yahoo.fr, einovatech@yahoo.com

pads.content:
Journey of the sense
In Ho Chi Minh City, it is estimated that there are about 4,000 visually impaired people, many of whom have become role models for their energy, passion and contributions to society. Despite their own efforts and the support of the government and community organizations, visually impaired people still face many challenges in learning, employment, community integration and creating a stable life. Part of this is social stigma, and part is the lack of caring for blind and visually impaired people in general. Job training and creating stable jobs for blind people is limited in Ho Chi Minh City. A current survey revealed that in Vietnam, just only 6.3% of visually impaired and blind people are employed. However for many other blind and visually impaired, the “work” is still mainly unskilled labour and the average monthly income remains low. We at Noir. Dining in the Dark, have opened the door to another career for the blind and visually impaired. Through our innovative training techniques, we improve these talented individuals’ self confidence and career trajectory. We are proud to put them in a position where they assume responsibility for our guests and a transfer of trust is the norm. Since we began this business, we have been inspired by visually impaired and blind people and we are dedicated to the blind community. A certain percentage of our profits will be donated to charities which work with local blind and visually impaired people, including organizations which provide operations to restore sight to visually impaired children. 
Think of modern society and images of shining cities and glowing screens come to mind. Every facet of daily life depends on sight. How would your other senses react to being in complete darkness? At Noir. Dining in the Dark, you will embark on a sensory journey into a different world and savour exquisite tastes and textures in complete darkness. This multi-sensory dining experience will stimulate your senses and open your mind. The experience begins in our pitch black dining room where you will be guided and served by blind or visually impaired staff who have been specially trained to assist and reassure sighted guests who are in complete darkness. Transfer your trust to these skilled guides they lead you to experience a new way of sensing the environment around you. After a few moments of adjustment, the darkness will kill off any shyness or trepidation and bring about an open-minded atmosphere. Our unique menus are a symphony of flavours. And will stimulate your other senses as you are deprived of the dominating sense of sight. Textures and subtle flavours will come to the forefront as you dine your way through unique dishes that have not been described beforehand. You will discover the stunning truth that people tend to experience food with their eyes, rather than with their palates. At Noir. Dining in the Dark, it is more than just a meal. It is a sensory journey that will make you re-evaluate your perception of taste and smell. Be one of the first to try this one-of-a-kind dining experience for a unique date or group outing in Saigon.
OUR TEAM
This has been an experience of people's lives and values.
It has been around four months since we got connected to our future team through the Blind Association Centre. During the job interviews, they have completely eliminated our original concerns about starting a new career in hospitality. They told us inspiring stories of their extraordinary energy, tenacity; about faith, optimism and their values.
They have indeed motivated and inspired us to develop this concept, a concept to help people experience their other senses through dining. This social business will help and boost awareness toward the visually impaired and blind community in the region. And then the first restaurant with the concept Dining in the Dark in Saigon was born, called Noir. Dining in the Dark.
From the first days of training until today, we have learned to live and to experience their world for a better understanding of their lives. For them, it is a doorway to the field of hospitality service excellence. What is wine? How wine is fermented? What is the shape of an artichoke? What does it smell like? What colour is it? Why there are so many types of glasses? Why is a dessert spoon smaller than a tablespoon? In the dark, why do we need to smile when talking with guests? Or why do we need to iron the napkins when the guests cannot even see it? Why does a dish have so many spices and herbs?
Thousands of questions, hundreds of hours of training, and a new world gradually opened up to them and also to all of us. Now, they are fully equipped with the necessary knowledge and skills to perform their job and are ready to welcome the first guests with a most positive attitude and excitement.
We are really proud of our team, because they are the ones who make the difference.
pads.title: Journey of the sense
