pads.content:
Tohe - For disadvantage children
Tohe is a social enterprise established in 2006 with the mission of creating a creative playground for disadvantaged children. Through weekly playgrounds, Tohe gives children the opportunity to learn and experience creative and artistic activities on a variety of media. Their paintings are selected, redesigned and applied to decorate fashion and lifestyle products.
5% of product sales are returned directly to the child artists who authored the paintings used. 
Tohe was established in 2006 by 3 founders: Nguyen Dinh Nguyen, Pham Thi Ngan, and Nguyen Thi Thanh Tu. 
The story of Tohe began in 2005 when a group of friends Nguyen, Ngan, and Tu began to visit the Center for Nurturing the Elderly and Disabled Children Thuy An, Ba Vi as volunteers. They organized art and painting activities for the children at the weekend; thereby understanding more about the difficult and needy life as well as the innocent spirit, love of life and simple wishes of the children. 
May 2006: The founding group came up with the idea of ​​​​founding "Tòhe" after visiting the Picasso museum in Barcelona and reading the famous quote of the artist: "It took me 4 years to be able to draw like Raphael , but had to spend a lifetime drawing like a child". Inspired by Vietnamese folk toys, we want Tohe to become a creative playground where children benefit from their own play. 
September 29, 2006: Tohe Joint Stock Company was officially established and has legal status. 
September 2009: Tohe was recognized as a Social Enterprise and received support from the CSIP Community Service Initiative Support Center and the British Council Vietnam.
2012: Tohe's first retail store is opened.
2013: Tohe exported to the German market, attended a series of events and fairs such as: Fukuoka Giftshow 2013, Vietnam Festival in Tokyo, Asian Social Enterprise Congress and introduced Tohe products in Seoul.
2016: Ms. Pham Thi Ngan - co-founder of Tohe was honored as a Young Global Leader 2016 (voted by the World Economic Forum). 
2019: Tohe opens a second store at Nha Chung Street, Hanoi.
pads.title: Tohe - For disadvantage children

pads.content:
Dong Dong Sai Gon - Recycled & designed in Sai Gon
A Love Letter to the City
Designed & hand-sewed at a small workshop in Bình Thạnh, Dòng Dòng cherishes to manifest the aesthetics of Sài Gòn, to tell a lovely story about the City.
Dòng Dòng aims to create durable and unique recycled bags with high functionality, raising our little voice for the environment.
Collect used tarps
Collect used tarps from local awnings, tarpaulins, truck covers stores. Normally, used tarps would have gone straight to the dumpsters. Hence, we often call those occasions of collecting as tarp-rescue trips. CONTACT US TO DONATE USED TARPS
Cut & wash
Tarps are washed and cleaned with unharmful substances like antiseptic liquid, vinegar, and baking soda. Indeed, scratches from the tarps' previous life are treated as unique pattern of this weather-resistant material. We don’t try to wash away the story of the tarp itself.
Design & sew
Each product of Dòng Dòng is a unique piece, creatively designed and hand-sewed depending on the colors and patterns of tarps collected. We spend time in details, and once again, prevent tarp leftovers from the process.
pads.title: Dong Dong Sai Gon - Recycled & designed in Sai Gon

pads.content:
Largest privately-funded solar grid connect system in the South Pacific.
Given the scale of the Coca-Cola Amatil Fiji production and packing facility, energy costs are a significant percentage of operating expenses. The opportunity to reduce these costs, combined with the benefit of utilizing renewable, clean energy, positively contributing to the environment, are key factors in the decision to connect with Sunergise.
The 1.1 MW PV installation is the largest privately-funded solar grid connect system in the South Pacific.
The Coca-Cola Amatil implementation is further evidence that organizations no longer have to choose the environment and sacrifice profits.Environmentally-driven solutions, such as this one, provide a direct benefit to the organization's bottom line.
pads.title: Largest privately-funded solar grid connect system in the South Pacific.

pads.content:
Amazon cooperative entrepeneurships

ASOCIACIÓN DE PRODUCCIÓN, INDUSTRIALIZACIÓN, Y COMERCIALIZACIÓN DE BIENES Y SERVICIOS AGROFORESTALES, PECUARIOS, ARTESANALES, TURISMO "ASOBIENTUR",
La asociación, que se encuentra ubicada en la región de la Amazonía ecuatoriana, ofrece 4 emprendimientos en las áreas de turismo comunitario, elaboración de jabón artesanal, aprovechamiento de madera a través de un taller de carpintería y un vivero forestal. 
Sin embargo, debido a la emergencia sanitaria por la COVID19, la asociación se centró en la elaboración de jabón artesanal con la ayuda del PNUD. Anteriormente los emprendimientos estaban a cargo de la comunidad, pero por temas de política de cada gobierno se conformó una asociación para el manejo de todos los emprendimientos. 
Su principal diferencia se evidencia en la asociación comunitaria, donde todos los ingresos recaudados por la elaboración y venta del jabón artesanal son compartidos con todos sus socios y socias de forma equitativa. Dentro de las buenas prácticas se encuentra el trabajo en conjunto con socio bosque y PNUD en el tema de la elaboración de jabón. Esta idea inició hace 7 años a través de capacitaciones y ayuda con recursos e insumos por parte de un voluntariado. 
El principal impacto de este emprendimiento es el trabajo que se realiza con los jóvenes para que formen parte del proyecto y mantengan su operación en el futuro. Además, busca tener un impacto positivo en la comunidad al generar ingresos y medios de vida de manera sustentable. 
asobientur@gmail.com, rborislicuy@gmail.com
www.facebook.com/asobientur
pads.title: Amazon cooperative entrepeneurships

Free Study Zone, community solution to address the challenge of long power-cuts hours in Syria 
The study zone is a free, volunteer-based, non-profit group Study zone in Salamieh, Hama-Syria, is a free, volunteer-based place created by the community to address power outage, that sometimes runs for more than 20 hours a day affecting the life and performance of the school and university students. The place is open from 9 am to10 p.m. and is lit using tubular batteries that recharge during power hours. Students can register and reserve a place for an affordable fee using their students' cards.
pads.title: Free Study Zone, community solution to address the challenge of long power-cuts hours in Syria

pads.content:
#InnovationChallenge: Disruptive Education for everyone

This solution was mapped thanks to the third edition of the challenge "Innovating together for children and sustainable development", which aimed to boost solutions that had an impact on clean and affordable energy or solid and liquid waste management. Solutions to the most pressing global problems require creative innovators and critical thinkers. Access to quality STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) education is linked to poverty reduction, economic growth and more resilient democracies; these disciplines play a critical role in addressing many of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). However, communities in Guatemala often lack the resources to provide adequate education at the primary and secondary school level. Enciéndete takes a novel approach that provides a framework that addresses this disparity, empowering students to understand the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through the development of technological solutions to community or health problems; problems that they can relate to or experience directly.
pads.title: #InnovationChallenge: Disruptive Education for everyone

pads.content:
Efficient recycling collection in the City

For a contribution of Q50 per month they make up to 2 collections per month (for Q100 we make weekly collections). they take all recyclable material. They ask that the daily recyclable waste be separated in two; Paper and Cardboard on one side and Plastics, Metals, Glass and Tetra pak (without organic waste) on the other. In addition they are also receiving alkaline batteries (you must fill a plastic bottle with them before handing them in), burnt vegetable oil (you must fill a plastic bottle tightly closed before handing them in), electronic waste and tires. They are also receiving clothes, board games and books in good condition.
pads.title: Efficient recycling collection in the City

pads.content:
Water irrigation systems

Soluciones a la sequía gracias la iniciativa de mujeres de la Sierra ecuatoriana. Utilización de riego por goteo y por inundación mediante diques. El periódico GK realizó un fotoreportaje sobre estas soluciones comunitarias.
"Todas viven de la agricultura y necesitan agua para regar sus sembríos, donde pasan largas jornadas bajo un sol riguroso. Todas, todos los días hacen algo para llevar agua a sus tierras. Desde niñas ayudaban a sus padres campesinos y fueron aprendiendo, de a poco, el trabajo agrícola en esos valles secos rodeados de montañas secas. Pero lo que les enseñaron, hoy les funciona menos porque, según ellas, las temperaturas y la sequedad han empeorado. 
Blanca Atre, Adriana Tapia, Daisy Dota y Mélida Romero no saben con certeza qué es el cambio climático. Todos los días se adaptan a él pero desconocen que eso es lo que están haciendo con sus prácticas concretas para que las altas temperaturas, los soles intensos, la falta de lluvia y la sequedad del suelo no merme la producción de las cebollas, mangos, aguacates, limones, tomates, pepinos que cosechan para vivir."
https://gk.city/2020/02/17/adaptacion-cambio-climatico/
https://www.facebook.com/gkcityec/videos/las-mujeres-que-le-ganaron-al-desierto/566829044174624/
pads.title: Water irrigation systems

Kamana a.i is a solution that encourages the use of Dhivehi language through real time translation and speech-to-text/text-to-speech features. Binheyo is an urban farming start-up designed to address the rapid income loss brought about by the pandemic while also positively contributing to the environment. Binheyo provides people with equipment and expertise to grow microgreens on a contract basis. The harvest will then be bought back from individuals, providing them with a reliable source of income and offering local cafés and businesses to buy fresh, healthy, and organic produce at affordable prices. Binheyo is also one of the winners of UNDP’s Social Innovation Camp.

pads.content:
Land allocation for tourism
The council of Alifu Alifu Thoddoo has an explicit policy to not allocate land from Environmental Protection Zones (EPZs) and the beach area for the establishment of tourism properties. The decision to restrict the development of tourism on the periphery was to prevent a situation where only guesthouses located on the beach area will benefit and guesthouses inland will suffer. This policy gives all guest houses an equal opportunity to benefit from tourism, protects the shoreline and promote the establishment of tourism properties that is more coherent and integrated with the rest of the built infrastructure on the island. 
Innovator: Community Practice Have consent to share: Yes On the web: No
pads.title: Land allocation for tourism

pads.content:
Condiment naturel à base d'oignon 
L’invention concerne la préparation de condiments bios d’oignon (nommés arôme) sous forme de tablettes ou cubes ainsi que le procédé de fabrication. 
On sait que l’oignon est un produit utilisé pour assaisonner les sauces, on sait également que l’oignon est produit qui pourrait facilement et pose beaucoup de problèmes au niveau du stockage. Les pertes peuvent atteindre 50% pendant le stockage, situation ayant un fort impact sur les revenus des producteurs qui vont être obligés de vendre leur production à la récolte quand les prix sont dérisoires. 
En ce qui concerne l’utilisation, les méthodes de cuisson qui consiste à déshydrater l’oignon cru l’huile chauffée à des températures allant jusqu’à 120°C lui font perdre certains de ses nutriments et le goût dans les sauces.
L’invention des arômes 100% oignon sous forme de tablettes ou cubes permet de résoudre tous ces problèmes énumérés ci-dessus car ces bouillons sont utilisés directement pour assaisonner les sauces sans faire recours à l’oignon frais qu’ils remplacent à 100%.
pads.title: Condiment naturel à base d'oignon

pads.content:
The House of Elder Artists: unretirement home

Women ́s movements have conquered rights and transformed the lives of women and girls; however, aging process has been left almost unquestioned.
While we participate in an endless number of activities, when aging, we ́re left with little choices other than private solutions: either payed residences or care services, or family based caregiving.
The House of Elder Artists, or Thea, a cooperative of women writers, artists, community activists have organized an unretirement home. It is a nonprofit residence and cultural center in Manhattan with 100 rental apartments, many reserved for people of low to modest means. It has a partenership with the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to women's housing issues.
pads.title: The House of Elder Artists: unretirement home

pads.content:
Agro fish farm
Agro Fish Farm is company that is engaged in fish farming business. Our major challenge is the lack of fish feed and unfortunate for us we do not have anyone that is producing it in Sierra Leone. So for that reason our solution is a simple and smart method to manage biodegradable waste, while at the same time providing organic and healthy animal feed and fertilizer at cheaper prices. We collect the degradable waste, which is typically household waste such unwanted leftover food and kitchen waste, and place it in a moisture container and leave an opening that allows the black soldier fly to come in and feed on the waste. In that process, they will lay eggs that grow into maggots. The overall process takes one week and the amount of waste the black soldier fly eats is proportional to the maggot it produces. This maggot can then begin to serve as feed for animals such chickens, duck and even in production of fish feed.
pads.title: Agro fish farm

pads.content:
Repair oriented policy

The Council of Ministers in Spain approved a policy to extend the legal guarantee period for products by one year, up to three, and increase the minimum time in which manufacturers must have spare parts once up to 10 years (currently five) a product is no longer manufactured, thus guaranteeing the consumer's right to repair.
This will increase the durability of the products to achieve more sustainable consumption patterns. The extension of the mandatory period of availability of spare parts to reinforce this "right to repair" up to ten years seeks to increase the durability of the goods in the fight against obsolescence and reduce the impact on the environment.

https://www.eldiario.es/economia/gobierno-amplia-plazos-obligatorios-garantia-posibilidad-reparar-productos-aumentar-vida-util_1_7873899.html
pads.title: Repair oriented policy

pads.content:
Reciveci app: connecting informal recyclers with consumers

Ecuador does not have a municipal recycling program. Separated waste goes all in one truck and sent to the dump where some waste pickers separate waste in bad work conditions. Other waste pickers walk around neighborhoods in early hours to look into trash bags and bins separating waste products. Reciveci is a crowdsourcing app where citizens can map local waste pickers, geolocalize them in a city map with their contact information so other citizens can reach them and agree on specific days to collect their recycling materials. The app improves their work conditions as they receive materials separated and clean. It has increased their livelihoods. Ecuador AccLab has held 9 experiments with ReciVeci App, by using behavioral insights methodology to see behavioural change with specific requests, incentives, communicational information. A citizen initiative and Ecuador AccLab partner.
pads.title: Reciveci app: connecting informal recyclers with consumers

pads.content:
Oxygen Concentration Device
Due to the increasing demand of Oxygen bottles for COVID-19 cases, Mosul Space team started working on a device to generate oxygen using ambient air by a physical reaction. The device pressurizes the ambient air (which has 21% oxygen concentration) and then a chemical material (Zeolite) is used to remove other gases and increase oxygen percentage (up to 90%) and lastly store the resulted high Oxygen gas in a vessel to be used later. 
This device will help the health sector and the patients get access to oxygen with a low-cost portable device.
Mosul Space
To Owners
Prototype Stage
Informal Sector
pads.title: Oxygen Concentration Device

pads.content:
Rainwater system for Amazon territories

La Organización Amazon Frontlines, en colaboración de sus socios, han instalado 1164 sistemas de recolección de agua lluvia para ofrecer agua potable a las poblaciones indígenas amazónicas cuyas fuentes de agua se han visto contaminadas por la actividad extractiva. El sistema "Clear Water" ha mostrado la ausencia 100% de metales pesados y un mejoramiento en la salud de las personas de la comunidad.
Amazon Frontlines trabaja con una perspectiva sistémica y mientras se busca la transformación de las condiciones de estas poblaciones, buscan soluciones para incidir en la vida diaria de las personas de forma inmediata.

pads.content:
Tum-Tum Solar-Panel Recharged Vehicle
Innovation Details: Tum-Tum was introduced by Bangladesh entrepreneur who sell Tuk-Tuk transport to local drivers in Timor-Leste. The original Tuk-Tuk Vehicle was transported as Gasol-fueled vehicle but then he converted it with energy coming from batteries which stored energy from solar panel. In Timor-Leste the Tuk-tuk vehicle is renamed and called as Tum-Tum. It is now one public transportation used in Liquica, Manatuto, Los Palos and Oecusse Municipalities which help people generate income while protect the environment at the same time.
pads.title: Tum-Tum Solar-Panel Recharged Vehicle

pads.content:
Clean Energy Biogas Plant
Innovation Details: The Biogas Stove was created as passion of using clean energy initiative for sustainable living. Mr. Aires Almaida is a senior citizen who has been developing this Biogas stove in Timor-Leste. He developed another prototype in his backyard to showcase clean energy stove.
pads.title: Clean Energy Biogas Plant

pads.content:
Solar Panel Roof at UN Compound in Dili
Innovation Details: 2016, UN office installed 1152 solar panels as shade for car parking structure within UN Compound in Dili. The solar panel system has helped UN Compound save its energy for up to 50%. Allowing us with more energy and minimum impact to the environment. Each panel has 260 W, Grid – tied system, No battery storage with expected lifespan about 20 years. In terms for cost reduction, its production from 2016-2019dec is 932.169 kWh. Consumption 2016-2019, 2.229.007 or 41%. Saves over $223k in energy bills per year or $60k/year. Reduces CO2 emission by 286 tons per year. This serves 41% of UN House daily demand. It pays back the cost supply and installation after 6 years.
pads.title: Solar Panel Roof at UN Compound in Dili

pads.content:
Dabung Girl & EdCaptain
Dabung Girl is a superhero (dedicated to SDG goals) that inspires girls to find the hero within and boys to perceive the superhero in girls around them ('Dabung' is a Hindi word that means 'fearless’). She is India’s very own girl superhero for social impact and focuses on breaking stereotypes. She helps children (8 to 14 year-olds) explore SDG challenges and learn how to discover their own solutions. Research shows that superhero stories give wings to the imagination and confidence of children. Dabung Girl stories are currently primarily being shared through comic books. The recently released comic books include child protection themes of child sexual abuse, child trafficking, and child marriage. 
Some reference links:
• Dabung Girl and Muskaan's Smile Story- Preventing Child Sexual Abuse and spreading awareness on resources available to fight this heinous crime [English] [Hindi]
• Dabung Girl and A Lost Friend Story - Preventing Child Trafficking and spreading awareness around the rescue process [English] [Hindi]
https://DabungGirl.com

Lifestraw 

All LifeStraw products start with advanced hollow fibre membrane technology. These are fibre bundles with microscopic holes, so small that organisms such as bacteria, parasites and even dirt and microplastics cannot pass through them. This solution puts pure water within reach of your pocket.

a book whose pages kill microbes in water. Converting Organic Waste into Household Products
Ms. Hong, a woman from Da Nang, came up with an idea to turn organic waste into money when the neighbourhood's garbage truck encountered a problem. She collected plant residue and food waste to create environmentally-friendly household cleaning products. Eventually, she made it into a business with a mission to reduce environmental pollution.
One of her products is dish soap made from vegetable peels containing enzymes. When used, this enzyme removes odour in the air and its residues purify water in rivers or seas.

Despatronados

Despatronados is the Portuguese (Spanish) word to "Boss-less". This is a powerful solution to exploitation, precarity, unsafe work in delivery jobs such as Uber, Glovo, etc.
Delivery workers in Río de Janeiro, Brazil got together to organize themselves into a delivery cooperative with no hiearchies and fair pay. Their work is not mediated by an app, but instead they have decided to build a network together with clients based on trust. "From workers to workers". https://despatronados.wixsite.com/cooperativa?fbclid=IwAR09v1eFlnMwRkt9Zr8hEdnWmHve5OCeFjr2NLTPCXYGd9Uw_0h9bDY58sM

It is a community-led model called that aims to strengthen the social fabric of the community to address issues development issues namely waste management, Gender Based Violence (GBV), substance abuse.

Kicking off the past with Naki Football Academy in Refugee Settlement 
Naki Football Academy is giving people the opportunity to be part of a community and help them to overcome past experiences.
In Nakivale Refugee Camp there is a lack of opportunity and employment, which leads especially many young men into drugs and crime.
Naki Football Academy trains youth into football teams and stays healthy and occupied while competing among each other.
Founder Songa Bahati is also passionate about Poetry and is using this skill for creating awareness and to raise funds.

Tour and Travel in Uganda
Hapi Tours Uganda is perfectly placed to arrange your ideal Gorilla and Chimpanzee Tracking in Uganda as well as Wildlife Safaris. Our staff has worked and traveled extensively in the region commanding a wealth of experience in booking the right accommodation, road networks plus meals of all travelers in Uganda and East Africa In general.
Hapi Tours Uganda is an inbound and outbound Safari Agency based in Uganda with extensive experience in arranging both long and short, individual or group memorable Safaris to the unspoiled Ugandan wilderness and beyond.

Affordable and Sustainable small scale Solar for households by Gboomsa Solar Energy
Region of Uganda, where about 90% of the population are not having access to electricity in their homes. Solar offers an affordable and sustainable solution and the small-scale systems can provide lighting at night and the ability to charge mobile phones.

pads.content:
Irrigation for Agriculture in Refugee Settlements by KilimOasis
Transforming dry soils into fertile soils through irrigation in agriculture in refugee Settlements 
KilimOasis is situated in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement in Uganda, which is home to over 100,000 refugees. Food rations given by the United Nations have been cut down to the bare minimum for survival due to the increase of refugees in Uganda (currently over 1,5 million) and families are malnourished.
The refugee settlement is situated around a vast lake and YesLife Scope is using a mobile water pump to make dry and infertile land suitable for agriculture. Currently, 12 families are trained in farming and watering their crops. The produce is partly consumed by the refugees to have a nutritious diet but about half of it is also sold to urban centres and Kampala. Profits are saved and after three seasons paid out to the families as start-up capital to start their own small-scale farm while new families are empowered.
pads.title: Irrigation for Agriculture in Refugee Settlements by KilimOasis

pads.content:
Self-organized empowerment and social entrepreneurship for Refugees by OPPORTUNIGEE
Refugees creating their own Opportunities in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement
OPPORTUNIGEE creates a self-organized empowerment and social entrepreneurship hub in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement (home to 100,000 people) in Uganda. The space is open for everyone, owned and run by the refugees themselves. It provides internet, tools, learning resources and tutorials on how to use the internet for research and the creation of projects. Design Thinking and Lean Startup push the refugees to test ideas and find solutions to the problems they face and create social enterprises to sustain themselves.
pads.title: Self-organized empowerment and social entrepreneurship for Refugees by OPPORTUNIGEE

pads.content:
Social Rehabilitation for victims of sexual abuses by Totya (Fear not) Platform
Totya Platform supports victims of sexual abuse overcome trauma and get justice. The Social Problem
In Uganda 78% of the primary school children and 82% of the secondary school students report having experienced sexual abuse at school (UNICEF 2013). According to the Annual Crime Report (2013) of the Uganda Police Force, close to 10,000 cases of defilement were reported in 2013, making it the second leading crime committed in Uganda. Astoundingly, only four percent of perpetrators have been convicted. The number of unreported cases are unknown but are estimated to be as high as even 50,000 per year. Tens of thousands of girls suffer in silence, while the perpetrators are not prosecuted. Like in my own case, it often happens within family settings and this is what makes it so difficult and often impossible for the victims to talk about. They do not want to be responsible for breaking the family apart or they fear the consequences of e.g. not receiving school fees or basic needs. The fear that no one will believe often leaves the victim to blame herself, even hate herself sometimes for the rest of their live or committing suicide. Without being able to speak about the events, girls end up being affected for life about the way they perceive themselves, relationships with men and lack of self-belief. Janet Aguti was one of the girls sexually abused as a child. For 17 years she did not find the courage to tell anyone. She started to see her past as strength rather than a subject of shame and Today, Janet Aguti is the founder and driving force of Totya Platform!
The Solution
Totya Platform provides support to victims of sexual violence through Peer Groups, Life-Coaching- in person and online, as well as medical and legal support of severe cases. Anonymous interactions with survivors of sexual violence, who overcame sexual abuse themselves, enable users to speak about their experiences while receiving emotional care and self-help tools. Our service is free and available to those who were victims of sexual violence – no matter what type or by whom – in their childhood or as youths. Totya supports all questions and problems that have resulted from the sexual violence and its effects as an adult. Coaching sessions are absolutely confidential.
If you would wish to talk to Totya Platform, send a message (also WhatsApp) to (+256) (0)759 296 003 (internationally) or call the Free End Sexual Abuse Hotline: 080 0220630 (Uganda only. People who have successfully transformed the experiences are encouraged to find strength in speaking up, joining our campaigns online campaigns to break the taboo on speaking about sexual abuse. For continuous self-organized support among each other, self-help groups are initiated for the women, meeting regularly and in person
pads.title: Social Rehabilitation for victims of sexual abuses by Totya (Fear not) Platform

pads.content:
Bio sand water filter by Tusafishe
Bio sand water filters
Our focus is on eliminating Water borne diseases by providing plenty of safe water to both institutions
and households in a way that preserves our environment. In a country where keeping drinking water clean or even getting clean water in the first place is difficult, there are few communities that don’t face preventable illnesses like typhoid that come from these sources of water. Even pipes are not always safe. Traditionally, people then try and boil their water, which consumes a lot of charcoal and time. Then, the water is stored in pots and jerrycans, and if it wasn’t contamined during transport, bacteria will now easily enter.
This is a lot of effort for a small outcome. Tusafishe has inquired from the communities that there is a need for a better solution, and our solution is a simple one: Sand filters. Using the same principle as natural springs in the ground, it is simply a bucket filled with nothing but freshly ground granite. It filters particles, bacteria, even chemicals out of the water and makes it safe to drink. One small bucket filters up to 40 liters per day, enough for an average household. A large bucket has a capacity of 200 liters per day. And the more the filter is used, the more the material compacts – the water will get even cleaner over time. It’s „forever lasting“: The Tusafishe granite just needs to be washed and dried every few months and the bucket can be refilled right away.
pads.title: Bio sand water filter by Tusafishe

AgSmartic Technologies
AgSmartic was founded in 2017 with a mission to help the farmers improving their life by increasing their farm yield, reducing wastage of resources by designing a system that eliminates the direct involvement of the farmer with respect to irrigation of their fields.
AgSmartic designed a product called CROPLYTICS® which is an autonomous irrigation system uses solar based wireless soil moisture sensor data, satellite images, ET, crop life cycle to come up with a precise irrigation plan. Therefore a new approach of collecting real time data from the field by using soil moisture sensor offers real potential for reliably monitoring soil water status in agriculture fields. Artificial intelligence can help farmers to get more from the land while using resources more sustainable. It provides ways to mitigate the problem and thereby helping farmers to ease the technical know-how through use of advanced technology
www.agsmartic.com https://youtu.be/Ye4W-iLoB-0

Eco-shop and local agricultural network

HUELLA PASTAZA
Se dedica a la comercialización y promoción de productos y servicios propios de Pastaza, que dinamizan la economía circular y local, basada en la producción en la chacra, la agroindustria, la artesanía y la medicina natural/cosmética. Huella Pastaza se encuentra ubicada en la región de la Amazonia.
Se diferencia porque tienen un acercamiento directo con los agricultores y dan la guía para mejorar productos y formalizar emprendimientos. Huella Pastaza es la única vitrina dentro de la provincia que promueve propuestas y emprendimientos locales.
La organización ayuda a las personas de la zona a la comercialización de los productos, fomentando el trabajo entre agricultores. La asociación está conformada por personas de diferentes edades, profesiones y nacionalidades que enriquecen la experiencia de la eco tienda.
huellapastaza.ec@gmail.com/laurimp2228@gmail.com
www.facebook.com/huellapastaza/
pads.title: Eco-shop and local agricultural network

pads.content:
Circular city case: Coffee residue → Roses
The trial exchange between the "Svit Kavy" cafe shop and the National Botanical Garden of National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine. The progressive city cafe provided a 3-day stock of coffee waste to the rose garden management, who in return thanked them for the roses that are now displayed to the customers of the cafe - raising awareness about the circularity. The garden management was inspired by the example of Kew Garden (London) and now is actively using organic matter collected elsewhere in the garden to feed roses. They are especially interested in bringing coffee waste which would be very beneficial for sustaining 3.5 hectares of blossoming roses. Such a symbolic exchange of material "gifts" seems to have a great potential for spreading the message about the circularity. The AccLab and the coffee shops in the area are now exploring possible ways to create sustainable supplies of coffee waste (with a very limited return of roses, of course).
https://undpukraine.exposure.co/tasty-waste-how-a-coffee-shop-is-helping-kyivs-botanical-garden-come-up-roses?fbclid=IwAR1OjWmpSoia5OP6mVIYr-yi4CaJ58idJSUcSYpNEQkti53TRx8fH8cvgs0
https://www.facebook.com/UNDPUkraine/posts/3536629319691383
pads.title: Circular city case: Coffee residue → Roses

pads.content:
Digital security add on for job searchers

UNDP Ecuador AccLab, together with LaLibre.net, has developed a browser add on to make job searchs safer. It is aimed to flag unsafe digital spaces, before providing your personal data.
This plug-in adds privacy or security features to mozilla browser when navigating in job search platforms. Acclab "Safe Browse Guide" is free and open source. In its experimental version, it evaluates job advertisements on the two main platforms: computrabajos and multi-jobs, it allows the reporting of misleading advertisements.
pads.title: Digital security add on for job searchers

pads.content:
Kids are the best teachers of digital skills for their grandparents
When we were tasked by the Ministry of Digital Transformation of Ukraine to find incentives and shortcuts for senior citizens to acquire digital skills, we have come the conclusion that most of the people rely on their grandchildren to show them how to buy medicine online, how to submit a complaint, register for an event or do any other online task. Kids are the solution! No online course can compete with them.
pads.title: Kids are the best teachers of digital skills for their grandparents

pads.content:
A simple way to tell emergency services where you are
During the field study in western Ukraine, we interviewed local firefighters who said that the biggest problem is that callers in need do not know the addresses. Apparently, most of the Ukrainian villages do not have street names while street names in many towns were renamed few times over the last 50 years, creating a mess for emergency services call centers and vehicle drivers. Not to mention locations outside of the residential areas.
One of the solutions to address this issue that we found is the British platform What3Words. It ascribes each 3x3 meter square of the our planet a unique name with three words, providing a more user-centered system instead of GPS coordinates. 
Now the platform has a Ukrainian language and the emergency services in the east of the country are preparing for a full-scale test of the solution with UNDP's guidance and support at the end of 2020.
pads.title: A simple way to tell emergency services where you are

pads.content:
Informal maps to improve the emergency service response time
During one of the field trips, we talked to the local emergency services and realized they do not have updated maps to rely on and many local residents have difficulties describing where they are on the phone. For instance, a third of all of the calls to the firefighting department mentions only informal references to the location. While there are some local firefighters in the team, most of them came from elsewhere and they do not know the area well. Same for the police and ambulance. 
We looked at what these emergency service teams drew on their maps with pencils, collected public part of the info, and combined it with the responses received by requesting guidance to random locations from the local residents. All of this knowledge we added on the existing map (also excluding the surnames of local famous and infamous people, whose houses are often used as a location reference) and passed it back to the emergency teams. Thereby we combined the knowledge of police, ambulance, firefighters, and the local residents. 
The exercise proved to be very much appreciated by the emergency teams, who said it would save them lots of time in the future.
pads.title: Informal maps to improve the emergency service response time

pads.content:
Lessons from Nature: tree surface for buildings
A team from The National University of Kyiv Mohyla Academy led by Borys Vasylkivskyi had the idea of reducing the amount of pollutants in the air, by using the same structures seen in the leaves and trunks of trees on the facades of houses. The tree leaf- and bark-inspired facade tile traps a significant proportion of airborne dust on its surface. The tiles, being rough and having grooves, are then washed clean by rainwater. The tiles can be arranged so that the rainwater flows through grooves to water tanks located at the bottom of the building wall (in the same way tree bark channels rainwater to the base of the tree, and its roots).
pads.title: Lessons from Nature: tree surface for buildings

pads.content:
Lessons from Nature: biodegradable and eco-friendly hemp fur
DevoHome is a manufacturer of textiles and clothing out of hemp, an alternative to leather and fur. In their original research for creating a biodegradable and eco-friendly material, Oksana Devoe and her team found that the heat capacity of combed hemp fiber makes it an excellent insulator, comparable with sheep's wool. They focused on the insulation technology developed by animals to regulate the temperature within the fur layer, and thus created HempFur – a replacement for animal and synthetic fur, from which DevoHome produces hemp coats. The process involves developing and recreating the structure of animal fur to suit human needs – such as natural bedclothes made from hemp for hotels.
pads.title: Lessons from Nature: biodegradable and eco-friendly hemp fur

pads.content:
Lessons from Nature: recyclable houses
In a truly sustainable world, we would build our homes using only recyclable materials, renewable energy, without any waste and without disturbing the habitat. That might seem impossible – and yet that is how the rest of nature operates. ecoPod was created with just this in mind - aligning in harmony with nature. The first modules were built in the form of a geodesic dome for tourist accommodation but can also be used as an alternative for ecovillages, social housing, mobile offices or garages, for business and in the private sector.
pads.title: Lessons from Nature: recyclable houses

pads.content:
Composters integrated into the city infrastructure
Municipal company in Slavutych, Ukraine came up with an idea to dump fallen leaves into the flowerbed, which saves the soil from winter frost and feeds the flowers in the next season. Also, there is no spending and pollution from the transportation of leaves as a waste to the landfill.
Issue background: https://www.ua.undp.org/content/ukraine/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2020/satellite-data-and-creation-of-composter-network-are-to-help-com.html
pads.title: Composters integrated into the city infrastructure

pads.content:
Convincing neighbours to compost
There are not so many people in Ukraine who already compost their garden residue. However, when we talked to those who were composting, they seem to belong to one of two groups: solitary composters and clusters of many composters. Those in clusters seemed to have one thing in common: sociable, friendly neighborhoods where practices can be shared and those, who still burn their leaves and other organic waste, will have a social pressure against them. 
Following is the video filmed by one of UNDP's friends: Lisa Tokarenko from Druzhkivka, Donetsk oblast, who inherited composting practice from her grandma and convinced many neighbors to compost instead of burning. Once one resident starts to compost and promote the practice - others will follow.
pads.title: Convincing neighbours to compost

pads.content:
Changing human practices by visualizing data
Looking at mundane traditional practices from space can be eye-opening. We have attracted significant attention of the communities and policy makers by providing data about open burning in Ukraine via free satellite datasets with notification settings. 
Communities were encouraged to enroll in "Do not burn - compost" challenge to exchange best practices and learn more on how they can use GIS solutions to track current and prevent future fires. The Ministry of Environmental Protection is now designing policy interventions that will incorporate the GIS solution into the state response. 
More about the challenge (in Ukrainian):
https://cid.center/dont-burn/
pads.title: Changing human practices by visualizing data

pads.content:
Surveillance cameras on the top of the churchе to monitor fires
NGO "Gostynets" in Novoyavorivsk came up with a creative solution to monitor fires in the town that is surrounded by dried and highly inflammable peatlands. Since the local church is the highest building in the town with the best observation, they convinced the priest to allow them to install 3 HD cameras with a 360-degree view on the very top of it. They hired professional climbers, who installed the cameras and connected them to the free broadcasting service - so everyone from the local authorities, emergency services, and common residents could monitor the situation. It greatly improved the response rate and efficiency of the fire department to extinguish the fire on peat lands. Priest supported the effort by promoting non-burning practices among parishioners, saying that God sees even more clearly than these cameras. 
Journalists called this project "God's Eye"
pads.title: Surveillance cameras on the top of the churchе to monitor fires

This infographic was sent to multiple retail chains possibly saving many lives. 
Later in April, we hired this company to provide us with the infographic on missing points in the existing communication campaigns targeted at residential buildings in Ukraine.
pads.title: Infographics to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in supermarkets

pads.content:
Helping SMEs during COVID-19 with information via Chatbot
During the Rapid Impact Assessment on SMEs in Ukraine in mid-March, we realized that the anxiety was growing, making it more difficult for businesses to solve a snowball of issues. One of the reasons for anxiety was uncertainty about rental agreements- SMEs did not know whether they will be able to protect their offices/shops/production facilities during the quarantine. They were getting curious about obtaining a Certificate of Force Majeure that is supposed to protect them from any action of a landlord. The only organization that is authorized to issue such certificates is the Ukrainian Chamber of Commerce, so we reached out to them and asked whether they are able to meet the growing demand and issue enough certificates. They said that the storm of requests is coming, while not every business needs the certificate and there is a lot of confusion about it. To support the Chamber, we studied the flow of their conversations with SMEs and designed the chatbot that could answer most of the questions and "take the hit". 
This turned out to be an innovative solution for the Chamber of Commerce of Ukraine that helped to take the increasing workload off the staff shoulders and provide SMEs with the necessary information and recommendations.
pads.title: Helping SMEs during COVID-19 with information via Chatbot

pads.content:
Agave for land restoration and cattle feed
Address climate change, livestock feed, reforestation, and land restoration
Organization behind

Agave plants and nitrogen-fixing trees can reduce and isolate considerable amounts of CO2. They also produce more biomass above and below ground on a continuous basis than any other desert or semi-desert species.It is estimated that this system can absorb and store the dry weight equivalent of 30-50 tons of CO2/ha/year both above and below ground.
Currently the use of agave for land restoration is promoted by the Billion Agaves Project, which is an ecosystem regeneration strategy adopted by innovative Mexican farms located in the high desert region of Guanajuato.
This strategy combines the growth of agave plants and nitrogen-fixing companion forest species (such as mesquite), with rotational grazing of cattle. The result is a high biomass, high forage production system that works well even on degraded semi-arid lands.
The system produces large quantities of agave leaves and pineapples, up to a ton of biomass during the 8 to 10 years of the plant's life. When chopped and fermented in closed containers, the agave leaf makes excellent animal fodder and is cheap (2 cents a pound). This agroforestry system reduces overgrazing pressure on fragile pastures and improves soil health and water retention while reducing and storing enormous amounts of atmospheric CO2.
The goal of the Billion Agaves campaign is to plant one billion agaves around the world to reduce and store billions of tons of CO2 that destabilize the climate. The campaign will be sponsored by donations and public and private investments.
Vía
Orgánica A.C is a Mexican non-profit organization whose mission is to 
promote healthy eating and a sustainable future through the promotion of
knowledge and practice of organic regenerative agriculture, fair trade,
social justice, sustainable living and the protection of the planet.
https://viaorganica.org/agaves/
pads.title: Agave for land restoration and cattle feed

pads.content:
Entrep's Hack with a Cauldron
More than just a cooking equipment, the renowned cauldrons serve another ingenious purpose.
Kakanins traditionally, after cooking are but displayed on Stands and trays. But as for Ate Suman (didn't want to mention her name), her big cauldrons serve as food warmer.
Her loyal customers would always want to buy her variety of suman pilit, balanghoy and tiktik served WARM round the clock.
keeping the delicacy inside the cauldron once cooked, but draining all the water from it, she proudly displays them on her stand. When customers buy, that's when she opens the lid and gets the desired number of kakanin to be bought.
Considering that they are cooked by 5AM, the freshness of the suman are kept for the entire day. Believe it or not, she's a genius!
To provide warm food to customers.
Food entrepreneurs
A. It utilizes the Cauldron, other than being a cooking ware to its optimum use by draining the water after cooking the suman, and displaying them in the store while kept inside it. The lid or cover is only opened once customers purchase the product. This is a deviation from the usual where the suman is displayed openly in stand and trays. The traditional way provides an open for the warmth of the suman to diffuse in the air.
.
B. It keeps the suman as though it's freshly cooked; hence providing greater consumer satisfaction.
C. It's also a very wise sanitary practice to keep them inside the cauldron since bacteria carried by flies and other insects, as well other microorganisms in the air cannot easily contaminate the suman, unlike when it is left in the open.
Food service/manufacturing establishments.

pads.content:
Extending Ice Storage
Opaw Ice 4 Sale shares their techniques in keeping their blocks of Ice frozen even 2 more days than usual time it stays in solid state inside their Storage Facility.
He said that the secret lies in their piling of the ice. Unlike the practice in the Ice plants and other Storage Facilities, the block are piled vertically upright position, they do it in a horizontal position. Moreover, they pile the blocks side by side, eliminating the space in between them. This prevents air to get in between which speeds up the melting of ice. Considering that the facility is purely constructed from concrete, they cover the ice with layers of plastic bags which also aid in slowing the melting of ice.
This makes Opaw Ice 4 Sale one standout in innovation.
The need to extend shelf / storage life of ice blocks.
For ice retailers who are looking to extend ice blocks shelf life.
A. The staff of this ice storage facility are unconscious that they have been applying principles of thermodynamics. This is evidence by their unique way of piling ht e blocks of ice inside the storage room. Unlike the usual practice where the blocks are positioned vertically upright- they pile the ice horizontally. This is done to keep the ice from getting too much exposure from the heat on the room's ceiling. Since the facility is made up of full concrete, the walls and ceilings absorb the sun's energy , hence the nearer the ice is to the ceiling the faster it melts.
B. The usual practice of piling them often creates gaps and spaces in between the blocks. With their innovation, they pile the ice side by side, closely to each other, thereby eliminating the spaces. This keeps air from getting out in between the spaces which speeds up the melting process.
C. Since the facility is made up of full concrete, heat is absorbed and the inside is basically, warm, hot or humid. So, to delay the melting process of ice, they cover the pile with layers of thick plastic bags so as to reduce the penetration of heat. This also more sanitary than the use of rice hulls which was an old practice of delaying the melting of ice.
Other Ice Storage Facilities in other place

pads.content:
Extended Seat Motorcycle or "Skylab" / "Habal-Habal"
Habal-habal is a highly improvised two-wheeled single motorcycle usually ridden beyond its passenger capacity. It is used as public transportation especially in areas with narrow roads, and steeper, rougher terrain where it could possibly carry up to 6 passengers, at the least. Habal-habal could accommodate more than 10 persons, with baggages ranging from vegetables and groceries to livestock like chicken yet to be included.
Public transportation especially in areas with narrow roads, and steeper, rougher terrain.
Locals usually living in mountainous areas wherein roads are mostly not accessible by 4 wheel vehicles
In urban areas, it is an everyday picture that you see 1 to 2 persons riding on a motorcycle. However, it is not the case when it comes to the streets of mountainous areas in Mindanao and some parts of Visayas. Habal-habal big help to locals usually living in mountainous areas wherein roads are mostly not accessible by 4 wheel vehicles. Interesting about this mode of transportation is that the ability/skill of the driver to balance considering the weight of the passengers from side to side, front, plus another 3 to 4 persons at his back.
It is used especially in remote villages with rough and narrow roads. Farmers also need the Habal-Habal to transport their goods to the market.
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Jtmj1SV20GoZSMtvuZIS851e5yCoqRcW

pads.content:
Logistics Solution
The island of Alifu Alifu Thoddoo has a regular overnight ferry (famously known as the fruit ferry) from the island to Male’ for the daily transport of fresh agricultural produce to the capital. These ferries are owned and operated by local islanders and they offer a logistical solution to restaurant and guesthouse operators on the island, providing easy access to daily use groceries and other items usually not available on the island. Guesthouses and restaurant operator could give a list of groceries needed from Male’, and they are delivered to their doorstep on the island. This service offered by the fruit ferry enables a regular and consistent supply of goods needed for the operation of restaurants and guesthouses at a lower cost.
Innovator: Community Practice Have consent to share: Yes On the web: No
pads.title: Logistics Solution

pads.content:
Elhee – Negee 
Elhee - Negee is a youth-led movement that aims to nurture and build a generation of young people connected to the reefs and natural environment around them. The movement started as an initiative to clean up litter from picnic goers on sandbanks close to the island of Alifu Alifu Rasdhoo. Since then, the initiative has expanded with a focus on working with schools, divers, and dive centers to provide young people with an opportunity to learn knowledge and skills needed to spend more time in the ocean. Recently the Elhee-Negee organized a PADI aware week which saw the organisation of marine education workshops and activities for students and community including two PADI courses (PADI aware and PADI coral conservation) for school students. During this week, the group secured sponsorships for four school students to get certified as PADI open water divers and for one individual from the community to get a PADI Master Diver certification.
Innovator: Community Practice Have consent to share: Yes On the web: No
pads.title: Elhee – Negee

Guesthouses on Alifu Alifu Dhigurah have established an informal price control understanding whereby all the guesthouse owners and operators agree on the minimum price that they will not go below and discuss on ways of maintaining service standards across the island. This has allowed the island to maintain is market position, despite competing markets in the Atoll. 
Innovator: Community Practice Have consent to share: Yes On the web: No

pads.content:
Holistic Transport 
Ramzu Speed boat is a speedboat service provider in Alifu Alifu Thoddoo that offers a holistic last mile transport solution to guesthouses by providing complimentary drop off and pick up of guests from the guesthouses. Young men (a mix of local and foreign) are employed in this transport operation and uses a mix of buggies, motorbikes and vans are used for the transport to and from the speedboat. This transport pooling solution brings down operational costs of guesthouses as it reduces the need for individual guesthouses to have their own vehicle to facilitate transport of guests to and from the jetty. This solution also contributes to a reduction of carbon emissions as well. 
Innovator: Ramzu Speed Have consent to share: Yes On the web: No
pads.title: Holistic Transport

pads.content:
Sustainability education as a tourism offer
Rasdhoo Island Inn is a guesthouse operating in Alifu Alifu Rasdhoo whose primary tourism offer is based on sustainability education. The guesthouse works with educational institutions to offer young adults an opportunity to experience a long holiday in the Maldives, which incorporates elements of sustainability education, including exposure to marine education and conservation as well as community-based activities designed to provide an opportunity for cross cultural exchanges between guests and the local community. Most of the guests come in groups and stay for about a month on average and engage in activities such as regular classes, team building and bonding exercises, diving and other sea-based excursions, community cooking classes, beach clean ups etc. Additionally, various initiatives such as providing guests with reusable bottles and a water cooler on site for refilling, blocking huge chunks during the day as time that guests will spend outside of their rooms engaged in activities are introduced to reduce the environmental footprint. 
Innovator: Rasdhoo Island Inn Have consent to share: Yes On the web: https://rasdhooislandinn.com/
pads.title: Sustainability education as a tourism offer

pads.content:
Investing in building local talent 
BLISS, guesthouse operating in Alifu Alifu Dhigurah is investing in building local talent in tourism. The guesthouse pays special attention to hiring Maldivians, especially young women from the island for various positions within the guesthouse and invests in building their knowledge and skills in hospitality by making learning and development an important goal for every employee and giving them opportunities to learn new skills and build their confidence. As part of this endeavor, the guesthouse conducts regular in-house trainings and gives opportunities for staff to step up to assuming more responsibility. Currently the guesthouse has 18 employees of which 60% are local islanders and 33% are women from the island.
Innovator: BLISS Dhigurah Have consent to share: Yes On the web: https://www.bliss.mv/en/

for physical rehabilitation after injuries and neurological diseases 
that provides better outcomes for patients and saves a therapist’s time:

more effective treatment thanks to tracking of patient’s progress;
automation and digitization of examination tests and reports;

response – Raccoon.Recovery Light. Now access to a platform that retains

instead of sensors. More information here: https://raccoon.world/light-facility/

pads.content:
Ultra-cheap heart monitor
The COVID-19 pandemic has raised the issue of the lack and high cost of patient monitors.
Even in hospitals with ventilators, there are many monitors. Now, if a person is connected to a respirator, a monitor is required, on which will display the following information around the clock - electrocardiogram, level oxygen saturation and blood pressure. In a pandemic, it is unlikely to succeed meet the need for patient monitors, primarily due to medical shortages equipment due to the significant cost of such equipment in the market as well temporary restrictions on the export of medical equipment. Yes, a new patient monitor costs from 25,000 hryvnias (1,000 USD) and requires additional measuring modules (some more expensive than the monitor itself). The team We offer solutions based on our two developments uECG and oximeter, which allow obtain electrocardiogram and oxygen saturation levels. The idea is 
therefore, to assemble a set of equipment that will perform the functions of a patient monitor and will cost up to 10,000 hryvnias (300 USD).
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1AmovuuRgIWjdXDJ7pDWJ774RBimSDzsa/view
pads.title: Ultra-cheap heart monitor

pads.content:
Iraqi Innovation Alliance
The Iraqi Innovation Alliance is a cross-border, semi-formalized alliance that merges innovation hubs all over Iraq in one national network. It currently has 8 members: The Station, Recoded, FikraSpace, KAPITA, Five One Labs, Mosul Space, Science Camp & Field Ready, with a rotated coordinator every 3 months who is responsible for coordinating the activities of the alliance. The alliance was born out of an organic Iraqi movement with the support of GIZ.
The purpose of IIA is to increase the visibility of ICT entrepreneurship and employment in Iraq, to widen the entrepreneurs’ network and foster mutual capacity building. The alliance seeks to reach untapped areas in Iraq that have lacked access to opportunities and to provide support to young Iraqi job-seekers, especially between the ages of 15 to 35, investors, entrepreneurs and private sector companies. Lastly, it should eventually represent the needs and interests of the ecosystem on a government level, i.e., lobbying for policies that create a business-friendly environment for entrepreneurs.

pads.content:
Don't-break-the-eggs box with a handle
When buying eggs in bulk (36 pieces), there is no separate box to keep the eggs from breaking. They only come in one tray which is difficult and dangerous to carry. The solution that sales people created is the DIY box made of two pieces of tray with the tape around them to be used as a handle. 
The solution answers the need to have a box for 36 eggs in one go that is safe to transport 
This solution shows how individual entrepreneurs and especially vendors come up with ideas that make it easier to sell their products. For examples, unless the vendor had this DIY box, I would not have bought as many eggs - I would have gotten only 10 eggs that come in the box and are more expensive. 
Because the vendor has done this process of making the box many times, she was quick and efficient in putting it together with the handle - fascinating process that would have taken me longer to implement :)
pads.title: Don't-break-the-eggs box with a handle

pads.content:
Home-made mobile cafe: green idea to earn money.
This a hand-made mobile cafe is an example how local migrants living about Bishkek
(the capital of the Kyrgyz republic) earn money. Ainura sells hot tea, buns and
sandwiches on the local open market. She uses the homemade carriage to transport
her products and the foam plastic box which was made by her husband to keep the
food hot during her working day. 
Ainura came to Bishkek from a remote village, she is internal (local) migrant. She has a big family and she didn’t have work in her village. Because of her small business she earns about 10-15$ daily, 300-450$ per month. She is the breadwinner in her family and can feed and educate her children and support her parents.
Her business is a "green" business because she doesn’t use petrol for her mobile café and electricity to re-heat food. This is also the example how materials can be recycled: the carriage and the foam plastic box are made from the secondary materials.
pads.title: Home-made mobile cafe: green idea to earn money.

pads.content:
Used tires increase economic space
Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. One of most famous place in Bishkek is the Dordoi bazaar (marketplace). It was one of the biggest wholesale and retail trading zone in the Central Asia which linking China, Turkey, Russia, Kazakhstan and other economies. In Dordoi bazaar you can find everything you need food, clothes, shoes, electronics, auto repair accessories, construction materials, etc. Dordoi is surrounded by new settlements where live people who make business, work or provide services.
Today I went to Dordoi to buy some staff for my car. On the way I saw the salt selling point. This salt is used by local farmers to combine feed for cattle with some minerals. It was interesting that the trading place is installed on the artificial bank which is supported by used tires. You can buy for low price used tires in Dordoi, so the salt seller invented how increase the square of plant right-near to channel slope. The seller tied tires and covered them with soil.
As a result, owner created a new land plant with approximately 25 square meters for generating income from selling salt.
pads.title: Used tires increase economic space

pads.content:
Sistema de riego automático

Como parte de la Minga de Innovación del Laboratorio de Aceleración 
PNUD, y con el fin de encontrar soluciones a problemáticas que enfrentan
las hierbateras de la Plataforma Primero de Mayo en el mercado de San 
Roque. Estudiantes de la ESFOT de la Escuela Politécnica Nacional identificaron que una de las problemáticas está relacionada con la carencia de un sistema de riego para abastecer los sembríos de forma eficiente. Por esto, realizaron un prototipo de sistema de riego por aspersión automatizado que usa un sensor de humedad y una bomba, para poder facilitar el acceso del agua a los sembríos, así como evitar que las hierbateras tengan que movilizar el agua de manera mecánica haciendo grandes esfuerzos físicos. De esta forma, además, se aprovecha de mejor manera el agua, evitando desperdicios.
pads.title: Sistema de riego automático

pads.content:
'Tu Pan Suk', or Pantries of Sharing
During the COVID pandemic, I saw the community pantries being set up across the country. Tu Pan Suk, or Pantries of Sharing have been installed by local people to offer food for people who cannot afford food during the pandemic. Pantries are usually filled with dry food such as rice, canned fish, bread, instant noodles, milk cartons and cooking oil but also fresh food such as eggs. Some even include notepads for people to write messages of thanks and encouragement to each other. On the pantry, there is also a sign saying 'Please take anything you need, and leave anything you can share'. 
In addition, a map compiling sharing pantries nationwide has been developed so that the community can record where the food pantries are across the nation.
- Offer food for people who cannot afford food during this difficult time;
- Offer alternative means of donations for those who want to donate but do not know where to drop off donations
- In some locations, I noticed that people are following their conscience, only taking away what they need from the pantries. However, in others, some people being too greedy, snatching everything from a community pantry in one go.
pads.title: 'Tu Pan Suk', or Pantries of Sharing

pads.content:
Offline-Pedia: contenido académico de calidad para zonas rurales y sin acceso a internet

Joshua Salazar, estudiante de la Universidad Yachay, ha sido premiado por ser uno de los innovadores menores de 35 años en Latinoamérica. Con su proyecto Offline-Pedia, pensado para reducir la brecha de conectividad. Así, en zonas rurales en las cuales no hay acceso a internet fijo o móvil, las personas pueden acceder a contenido académico de calidad. Mediante la combinación de materiales reciclados, Joshua ha aportado en la instalación de computadores baratos en cuatro comunidades rurales de Ecuador. El uso de una placa que contiene el software libre Kiwix, permite el acceso a sitios web como Wikipedia, sin conexión a internet. Este innovador está buscando financiamiento para poder convertir este proyecto en una ONG que permita llevar la Offline-Pedia a más zonas rurales del país.
pads.title: Offline-Pedia: contenido académico de calidad para zonas rurales y sin acceso a internet

pads.content:
Biorefinery with water lilies
LIRMEX, turning invasive plants in fuels and fertilizers

Specialists from the Department of Biotechnology of the Iztapalapa Unit of the Autonomous Metropolitan University (UAM) designed a biorefinery for the sustainable management of water lilies in the Xochimilco canals in the south of Mexico City. 
The installation can be adapted to different topographies, replicated, and scaled in other sites, according to parameters of environmentally friendly technology, social justice, and economic viability.

Dr. Ernesto Favela Torres –responsible for the project– has been working for over 40 years in research to use the plant as an absorbent for water purification in rivers and canals.
The purpose is to create biotechnologies to amortize the costs of subtraction and handling, tasks that, depending on the body of water, reach up to 600,000 MXN per hectare.
As part of a first phase, they managed to develop bioprocesses for the production of bioethanol, enzymes, compost, biogas and prebiotics, the latter with a patent involved, he stressed.
pads.title: Biorefinery with water lilies

pads.content:
Waiting Innovation(?) at Hospital
-This was a couple years ago when I had eye sugary.
-It is a public hospital focusing eye health with a large number of patients
-Previously patients would wait at chair and quickly formed a line at 5am when hospital a staff member was on-stand by. It was quite a mess.
-Sometimes later when I visited the hospital again, instead of waiting at chair, patients took their shoes off at put them in-front of counter as "reservation" then they went back to the chair to sit. 
Waiting experience
People wanted to avoid the problem of conflict they get in queue.

pads.content:
Promotion de la Cohésion Sociale par l'Agriculture Intégrée
DOMAINE D’APPLICATION : Agriculture, élevage et cohésion sociale
TYPE D’ACTIVITE : Formation/sensibilisation; culture agricole; élevage
PROMOTEUR : PARE Olivier, ferme POLI AGRO SERVICE
CONTEXTE
Faisant suite au constat des effets du changement climatique et des conflits sociaux qui découlent de la rareté des terres cultivables
et de pâture, le promoteur de la ferme POLI AGRO SERVICE a mis au point une expérimentation de type d’agriculture intégrée appelée « l’exploitation intégrée du fourrage » afin de maintenir les animaux en stabilité, d’augmenter la productivité agricole, de contribuer à l’autosuffisance et à la sécurité alimentaire et partant de là, apaiser les conflits éleveurs/agriculteurs.
PROBLEME ADRESSE
La solution ‘‘Exploitation intégrée du fourrage’’ permet d’adresser les défis majeurs des changements climatiques et de la
cohésion sociale dans la région de la Boucle du Mouhoun au Burkina Faso
OBJECTIF RECHERCHE : Promouvoir la cohésion sociale et l’adaptation des communautés aux changements climatiques.

Drought resistant native plant tree - SAXAUL for the Aral Sea region 
The Aral Sea has lost 60,000 km2, or 90% of its size, over half a century.(Fortunately for us) Saxaul is a plant species native to western Uzbekistan, able to grow in harsh, saline conditions with little water, and providing a niche for varied fauna. Saxaul is a local solution for the lost biodiversity of the region. It has been acknowledged that planting Saxaul on the dried seabed is an effective way of stopping the spread of toxic salts and the desertification process.

pads.content:
Ecolana, connecting with recycling companies
Connecting to the recycling chain, through technological tools.

Ecolana is a Mexican startup is a platform that seeks to facilitate access to recycling, it has a map of recycling centers nationwide, to which the user has access.
Through the map, people can see more than 3,000 collection centers, find out the hours, the address and the type of material they receive.The founders Alejandra Valdez G and Lisseth Cordero started in 2016, when they realized that those who decided to recycle could not find a place to take the material. 
In addition, recycling in Latin America is not so easy because there is no comprehensive waste management system.
For this reason they took on the task of creating a database of the centers, which took them two years, because the compilation was done by hand and from door to door. 
By 2018 the company built the first company and the business was consolidated.
"What we do is connect this recycling chain, through technological tools."
https://ecolana.com.mx/
pads.title: Ecolana, connecting with recycling companies

pads.content:
Keyhole Garden
A keyhole garden works on a similar principle to tower gardens, in that it is a stacked structure with a central cavity in which vegetable food waste is placed together with water or grey water . The walls of the keyhole garden are constructed from similar materials to tower gardens, but they are generally larger in diameter, with an access point (keyhole) to reach the central cavity. In keyhole gardens, vegetable crops are generally grown only at the top of the structure.
pads.title: Keyhole Garden

pads.content:
Re-using plastic bottle for construction of houses by Upcycle Africa
Plastic Bottle Constructions of houses as a means of Upcycling
Winner of the 2020 UN-Habitat Scroll of Honour award, Upcycle Africa upcycles plastic bottles by building houses.
There are over 150 Million Tonnes of Plastic already in the oceans. Every year, eight million tonnes of plastic waste end up in oceans and lakes. Experts predict that there will be more plastic than fish in oceans by 2050. And yet, the more waste we generate, the more waste we need to dispose off, but how? Plastic waste is not the only challenge we have in Uganda and Africa as a whole. Housing is still very expensive especially for people living in slums and low income areas. In Kampala, homes in slums are usually filled up with water when it rains, damaging property and making it difficult for people to live decently and yet, dignified housing is expensive considering that these families earn an average of $40 as monthly income.
Upcycle Africa protects the environment and promotes innovative mind-set while empowering youth. Through up-cycling plastic waste we train our local communities in Uganda especially the disadvantaged youth to protect the environment. Bottles replace environmentally unfriendly bricks, which are burnt for days promoting deforestation. Plastic bottles are collected and compacted with soil, making the houses very cost effective and affordable. Furthermore, the buildings are durable, buffer heat and are earthquake resistant. Upcycle Africa has constructed houses in different parts of Africa while creating employment opportunities for rural women and youths this has ensured economic empowerment for these women. These cash incentive allows low-income families to support their children with school fees. We also have a waste recovery system where we collect plastic waste from beaches, streets and bus stations ensuring clean and safe environments.
pads.title: Re-using plastic bottle for construction of houses by Upcycle Africa

Le moule à pilier direct bétonné de KANKAN 
Pour nos ingénieurs en bâtiment, voici une innovation! Elle est constituée de métaux recyclés et bénéficie d'une particularité qui consiste à donner une allure directe au pilier de nos maisons. C'est à dire, contrairement aux autres types de moules qui on la vocation de produire des piliers en trois sections séparées : les têtes supérieures et inférieures ainsi que le tronc. Et pour nos constructions, cela constitue une autre charge tant en énergie qu'en argent dans la mesure où l'on est obligés de procéder à l'agencement en y mettant du ciment en plus de ce qui a été utilisé pour la confection des parties, ce qui risque d'être instable en cas de mouvement rude. Tandis que pour cette solution, il nous faut juste remplir le moule et une fois retiré, vous avez en un seul bloc votre pilier, lui conférant ainsi sa rigidité contre les probables mouvement inattendus.
pads.title: Le moule à pilier direct bétonné de KANKAN

Open Data Platform in Cambodia
Open Development Cambodia (ODC) is an ‘open data’ website, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia. The open data movement is based on the simple premise that data collected for public interest should be publicly available without restrictions. Information or data in the public domain should be freely available to everyone to use and republish as they wish. Open Development Cambodia does not promote any particular perspective, agenda or bias other than to provide objective information about Cambodia and its development.
https://opendevelopmentcambodia.net/

pads.content:
Data for Cambodia (Alternative Data Source)
Powered by UNDP Accelerator Labs in Cambodia, these dashboards that are a collection of visualizations and insights which seek to explain and dissect the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic in Cambodia. Globally, the pandemic has had not only devastating health effects, but has triggered cross-cutting impacts in economic sectors such as tourism, manufacturing, and service delivery. 
These dashboards showcase trending survey data and geolocation data, collected before and throughout the pandemic. The insights garnered from these dashboards can help citizens, policymakers, decision-makers, NGOs, and CSOs to understand the varied and far-reaching effects of the pandemic on men, women, business owners, MSMEs and any intersections between those groups.
https://www.dataforcambodia.org/
pads.title: Data for Cambodia (Alternative Data Source)

pads.content:
Micro-credentials for BPO skills in Bangladesh
The Business Process Outsourcing (BPO) Industry is rapidly expanding and has huge potential for creating employment opportunities, specially for the youth. For Bangladesh to become a competitive BPO offshore destination for international companies, there is a critical need to develop a skilled human resources pool based on the industry requirements that would pave the way to address job market challenges, especially for the young labour force. Bangladesh has yet to develop a scalable model that would rapidly upskill youth on skills demanded by BPO employers. To address this gap, the Accelerator Lab is designing a scalable online micro credential scholarship program for Bangladeshi youth to learn new digital skills demanded by the world IT market which will accelerate their employment in the rapidly growing local business process outsourcing market and better prepare them for the fourth Industrial Revolution.
pads.title: Micro-credentials for BPO skills in Bangladesh

pads.content:
A Locally Made Kalichangu Desk
George Kalichero
Box 1, Mimosa, Mulanje, Malawi 
No
A lot of students have been struggling with their studies due to persistent blackouts. The Kalichangu desk was specifically designed to help students in their studies. The desk contains an air conditioner, solar panel, phone charger, and bulb. its space can be expanded to accommodate more books.

DIY / open source
Yes
