Talent for Refugee Empowerment and opportunities by RGT (Refugees Global Talent)
Supporting refugees by promoting their talents and creativity
RGT (Refugees Global Talent) is supporting young talented refugees by promoting their talents and creating opportunities for them through an online community. In December 2019 a huge talent festival was organized in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement with thousands of people in the audience and hundreds of performers, whereby a jury selected three winners who are supported to take part in opportunities outside the refugee settlement.
The Enterprise emerged from the SINA Community of Unleashed in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement.
pads.title: Talent for Refugee Empowerment and opportunities by RGT (Refugees Global Talent)

pads.content:
Upcycling and Recycling of Plastic waste by Reform Africa
Upcycling and Recylcing of Plastic Waste
Plastic waste disposal in Uganda is on the increase. It is estimated that 600 tonnes of plastic is disposed of in Uganda daily this is due to the rapid rate of emerging small scale producing companies competing with bigger companies to produce more plastic products hence increase in the accumulation of plastic waste.
Kampala city alone accounts for the vast chunk of plastic waste, which is littered all over the city and clogging sewage systems, according to the National Environment Management Authority. About 51% of the plastic garbage in the city is left uncollected and ends up in drainage channels, wetlands, natural watercourses, manholes, undeveloped plots and on the roadside. In the rural areas, it is a sad story; plastic garbage in most cases left to decompose on its own.
Reform Africa is changing this, we are transforming plastic waste into affordable, durable and waterproof bags.
pads.title: Upcycling and Recycling of Plastic waste by Reform Africa

pads.content:
Mobile nurses for rural and inaccessible areas by Infant’s Health Foundation
Increasing access to maternal health through mobile nurses
The Infants Health Foundation reduces mother morbidity, infant mortality and birth defects in Uganda with an innovative approach to reach rural and inaccessible areas through mobile home-based maternal child healthcare services. Nurses are transported on motorcycles on regular intervals for home visits. The enterprise is fighting for healthy pregnancies to avoid extensive unnecessary death and lifelong, devastating disability/ birth defects of children and women.
pads.title: Mobile nurses for rural and inaccessible areas by Infant’s Health Foundation

pads.content:
Egg shells and plastic waste recycled Floors by Sengonzi Terrazzo
Upcycled flooring from egg shells and plastic waste.
Sengonzi Terrazzo Ltd. produces the world’s first Terrazzo and Epoxy Floorings out of plastic bags and egg shells. It is an invention from Uganda, cost-effective, durable, visually appealing and saves our environment from waste.
pads.title: Egg shells and plastic waste recycled Floors by Sengonzi Terrazzo

pads.content:
Emergency Sex Education App and mobile by Ask Without Shame
Emergency sex education via Mobile
Ask Without Shame is a non-profit social enterprise providing emergency sex education via mobile to improve and promote sexual health. It is a free and anonymous service to answer questions regarding sexual matters without judgment through android App, SMS, WhatsApp and a toll free hotline. Medical experts are available 24/7 to assist youth with the right information. Ask Without Shame has responded to over 30.000 users, is employing eight young sexual and medical experts and has received international awards such as the appsafrica Award for Social impact or the African Women Award.
pads.title: Emergency Sex Education App and mobile by Ask Without Shame

pads.content:
Art for empowered communities by Walyendo Gallery
Empowering young and aspiring artists to be able to impact on societies using their art.
Walyendo Gallery is a movement protecting and rebuilding the true definition of ART empowering young and aspiring artists to be able to impact on societies using their ART as a foundation of their inspiration.
pads.title: Art for empowered communities by Walyendo Gallery

pads.content:
Theatre for problem-Solving and conflict transformations by fReeL 
fReeL transform people’s lives positively through theater problem solving and conflict transformation tools.
We do this by creating an interactive approach that involves the audience in developing real time strategies for enacting social and personal change. Here, actors create, rehearse and present scenes that show moments of conflict or any social problem such as work issues, family problems, racism, bullying etc. and then invite the audience to intervene and enact solution to the problems presented.
pads.title: Theatre for problem-Solving and conflict transformations by fReeL

pads.content:
Women Of Destiny
We rehabilitate and empowers sex-workers to become self-relient.
Many young girls and women are being engaged in prostitution not because they want, but due to the high rate of poverty in their homes, they find themselves at the streets so that they can sustain their families.
Women Of Destiny provide these women with Rehabilitation, Empowerment and Sensitization of prostitutes to become successful job creators and be able to sustain themselves and their families.
pads.title: Women Of Destiny

pads.content:
Online Science Classrooms by Sayans Academy
Sayans Academy covers the gap between learning sciences and its real world application.
We are a providing digital STEM learning platform for secondary schools. This is an online classroom where students undergo tailored training, create collaborations, ask, share and access mentors/experts in given fields.
Who we are
Sayans is a not for profit organization focused on transforming science and technology in Africa through education. It is started and managed by individuals experienced in the application of science, technology and business development.
Sayans supports students in African rural secondary schools experiment with and apply science to real life. We set up spaces within the network schools where students are engaged in hands-on workshops, nurture their creativity and problem solving skills by using science and technology to solve real life challenges and above all have FUN.
Sayans was established in 2016 initially supporting teachers embrace Project Based Learning in their classes. With previous learning, Sayans iterated since 2018 with a focus on working directly with students and supplementing the teachers through a Flipped Classroom Learning model.
Where we are 
Sayans is currently setting up in Mpigi, Uganda with a goal to grow exponentially to add more countries in Africa.
Schools 10+
Students impacted 1000+. Sayans is finalizing a partnership agreement with Ministry of Education, Science, Technology and Sports to have scaled implementation in all secondary schools in the country.
Why Join Us
Our promise is based on our core values. And every school and student who joins gets just that;
Fun
Experiential
Resources for Do It Yourself projects
Co-creation & collaboration
Tailored support
Our workshops span all STEM areas, basic ICT, including coding and programming and we got the right people and partnerships to make each workshop leave a wow moment in each student.
Our program is designed to supplement what teachers teach through a Flipped Classroom Model – students learn outside the class and class-time is used for discussions and review. This model is tested to leave great results both academic and outside the class.
Our people, Our strength
We have a database of over 100 innovative teachers, engineers, doctors... both locally and internationally who are more than willing to share their knowledge with the students. These professionals use innovative analogies to create deeper and engraved understandings of science concepts.
Each Sayans center within a school is run by a Sayans fellow, a university science graduate who is well equipped to guide, empower and mentor each student.
Our team provides valuable information to support the decision and career choice making of the students. We have the right people in the right fields to give the right guidance.
Support now
Want to share your knowledge or give career guidance for secondary school students, commit a few hours of your time with us as an expert/teacher. We fit in your timeframe. Have an old laptop, book or any hands on tool you would love to give away? We do appreciate it. Is it a financial contribution? We shall use it to support more schools set up innovation labs.
pads.title: Online Science Classrooms by Sayans Academy

pads.content:
Interlocking Brick Construction by Justev Building Systems
Eco-friendly,cost effective and innovative construction.
Justev Building Systems offers an alternative solution through Interlocking brick (ISSB) construction.
By building beautiful houses for significant less money while saving the forests in Uganda are key points of the ISSB technology. A technology that is around in Uganda since more than 15 years. However most of the houses, especially in rural areas.
pads.title: Interlocking Brick Construction by Justev Building Systems

pads.content:
e-Fundi a Mechanical online platform 
e-fundi provides a quick and easy way to access to authentic and professional mechanical services through an online application.
e-Fundi is an online platform that aims at a world where everyone has immediate access to mechanical services at the touch of a button. We are doing this through creating an online application that connects car drivers and car owners to nearby reliable, authentic and professional mechanics for mechanical services for car maintenance and repair
pads.title: e-Fundi a Mechanical online platform

pads.content:
Upcycled fashion, accessories and empowering PWDs Kimuli Fashionability
Kimuli Fashionability creates upcycled fashion and accessories and empowers the Persons with Disabilities (PWDs)
Kimuli Fashionability creates upcycled fashion and accessories through training and employing persons with disabilities. African fabrics are blended with waste materials. In the absence of hearing, deaf people for example often have heightened kinesthetic and visual abilities resulting in high-quality products with love for detail.
pads.title: Upcycled fashion, accessories and empowering PWDs Kimuli Fashionability

pads.content:
Economic Empowerment of women through life skills by Gejja Women Foundation
Gejja Women Foundation is a community based women cooperative in Mpigi District to economically empower marginalized girls and women. Widows, school drop outs and other women needing support are equipped with income generating skills to earn a living and have a decent life.
pads.title: Economic Empowerment of women through life skills by Gejja Women Foundation

pads.content:
Biodegradable Fashion accessories by Ssuubi Designs
Empowering marginalized youths in skills of fashion through upcycling waste and using environmentally friendly materials.
The company was founded in 2014 by Josephine Nakiyimba from western Uganda. The name is derived from the Luganda term for “hope”. We use materials that are available everywhere – because we upcycle waste. Out of paper we make beads, and plastic bottles are turned into bracelets and earrings. Bark cloth, being a completely natural product, is blended with colorful Kitenge fabric to become a biodegradable wallet. Bark cloth is the first cloth humans ever made thousands of years ago from the bark of the Mutuba Tree, home only in Uganda.
pads.title: Biodegradable Fashion accessories by Ssuubi Designs

pads.content:
Mosquito repellant products from Lemongrass by Uganics
Uganics is an organisation providing purely organic, mild scented mosquito repellent.
In Uganda, children below five years are the most affected with malaria. According to the Ugandan Ministry of Health, currently 90% of 100,000 recorded malaria deaths are children, especially from rural areas. The majority of rural communities do not have access to treated mosquito nets, and do not have access to preventive measures.
In Uganda, children below five years are the most affected with malaria. According to the Ugandan Ministry of Health, currently 90% of 100,000 recorded malaria deaths are children, especially from rural areas. The majority of rural communities do not have access to treated mosquito nets, and do not have access to preventive measures. The government of Uganda is investing efforts in the reduction of malaria by providing interventions like the distribution of mosquito nets, or spraying homes with DDT. Malaria cases still remain high because the solutions are not long lasting and mosquito nets are only effective during sleep time. DDT is raising also severe health concerns due to its chemical components.
Malaria is one of today’s major global health challenges and has been associated with slow socioeconomic development and poverty. Uganda has some of the highest reported malaria transmission rates in the world, with approximately 16 million cases reported in 2013 and over 100 000 deaths annually.
pads.title: Mosquito repellant products from Lemongrass by Uganics

pads.content:
Baladiaty
Baladiaty is a modern tool that allows citizens to communicate more effectively with their municipality.
Without moving, thanks to new technologies, with his smartphone via Baladiaty the citizen can report problems that affect him closely in his municipality.
pads.title: Baladiaty

pads.content:
El Warcha
is a collective and maker-space founded in 2016 in the medina of Tunis, Tunisia. It aims to promote hands-on education and civic actions through the making of temporary urban furniture and art installations with local inhabitants.
Implementation of a handcrafted hydroponic system to re-imagine public space.
pads.title: El Warcha

pads.content:
Connecting Informal Vendors to an e-commerce platform 
In order to secure the livelihoods of traders in the informal sector, the CO, through its Accelerator Lab, launched an e-commerce pilot project in May 2020 to connect informal traders with consumers, especially given the break in supply chains during the lockdown implemented to curb the spread of the coronavirus. (www.tambula.com). The pilot aimed to assess how market vendors whose only clients were walk-ins, could reach a wider range of customers via an online shopping platform. 
After a three month pilot in the central region (Khomas https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khomas_Region), the digital solution is expanding to a second region (Erongo https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erongo_Region). 
Given the success of the pilot to date, UNDP and the project counterpart has negotiated with an additional 15 vendors who have signed up in the Erongo region to participate in the expanded pilot.
Mapper: Omagano Kankondi
pads.title: Connecting Informal Vendors to an e-commerce platform

pads.content:
Homeless People mobile application 
Homeless people and people living in informal settlements continue to be left behind in terms of receiving social benefits and services. Often, because they do not have a permanent shelter or live under difficult conditions. At present it is challenging for government to keep track of how many people to serve and adequately plan for benefits the underserved are entitled. Homeless People’s Mobile App is a tech solution which registers information of people in order to receive certain benefits. Beneficiaries are registered through a community health/extension worker and they are given a card encoded with a QR code and the card has a lanyard which they use to claim benefits. The QR code is a unique identifier of a beneficiary. Once the card is scanned, data such as geo-location, the person’s demographic information, health information and benefits received (e.g. Food package, soup kitchen credit, shelter and so on) is captured and stored in a central database. The solution is first going to be used to register an estimated 900 homeless people in Khomas region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khomas_Region) and then scaled up to be implemented in at least one other regions (Erongo https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erongo_Region).
pads.title: Homeless People mobile application

pads.content:
African Locust Bean is packed with nutrition, yet very underutilized
Could the local African Locust Bean that's packed with nutrition, yet very underutilized, be the next big super-food trend
Chocaroube is a community-driven innovative and added-value way of looking at the African Locust Bean to make the most of a traditional local snack that went very unpopular. Turning the beans into a cacao-like powder provides a nutritious and inexpensive alternative drink or baking ingredient while preventing micro-nutrient deficiencies in children and women.
pads.title: African Locust Bean is packed with nutrition, yet very underutilized

pads.content:
Repurposing stones and metal for furniture
The welder workshop using disposed metal and stones for creating furniture.
pads.title: Repurposing stones and metal for furniture

pads.content:
Reuse of Remedy Textile
Name of solution owner: Cecil Sagawala from Dar es salaam, Tanzania.
Cecil engages youths in collecting useless clothes and small pieces of textiles from tailor shops and homes and design different products like bags, rugs, decorations, covers, jackets, chairs, shoes, and many others which are eco-friendly. In this way, they contribute to protecting the environment from being polluted by textile wastes and generate employment opportunities for youths in the country. 
Photos
pads.title: Reuse of Remedy Textile

pads.content:
Waste Paper Recycling
Name of solution owner: Belta Kazimoto from Dar es salaam Tanzania.
Belta Waste Paper Recyclers collect waste papers and cardboards around shops, schools and offices and recycle them to produce beautiful paper bags and gift boxes which are eco-friendly.
pads.title: Waste Paper Recycling

pads.content:
Floating Hydro Kinetic Power Plants
Zambia has in the past few years experienced high levels of load shedding due to challenges with the hydro electric supply that powers almost the whole country and coupled by frequent draughts that have hit the region resulting in low water levels at the Dam that is shared with Zimbabwe. 
The innovation is aimed providing energy solution using low cost sources. It is adapted from lessons learnt from India and promises to ensure low cost and efficient turbines placed on shallow surfaces are able to generate power. This will ensure a smart solution to the energy challenges being faced in the country.
pads.title: Floating Hydro Kinetic Power Plants

pads.content:
Recycling single use plastic water bottles
Lack of proper waste disposal mechanisms has led to littering of single use plastic in Wajir town, located in the Northern part of Kenya. 
One resident in this town has devised ingenious ways of recycling single use plastic water bottles to mitigate the challenges brought about by poor means to dispose the bottles by recycling them. He has made his fence out of the plastics and uses the same to harvest rainwater.
pads.title: Recycling single use plastic water bottles

pads.content:
Cholera Detection, Prevention and cure
Cholera outbreaks in Zambia mainly affect Lusaka and the other densely populated peri-urban areas. The outbreak is mainly due to unsafe drinking water and faecal contamination. The affected areas are usually high density areas which mostly do not have running water, mainly have pit latrines and shallow wells where the water can easily be contaminated. 
The Innovation seeks to detect, prevent and cure cholera cases faster. 
Benefits: 
· Promotion of local pharmaceutical industry
· Early detection of cholera.
· Prevention and cure of cholera 
· Reduced Cholera related deaths
pads.title: Cholera Detection, Prevention and cure

pads.content:
Solar powered mobile milk cooler
Farmers in Kenya's West Pokot County struggled to sell their milk as it often got spoilt during transportation. The solution developed by an informatics graduate was a solar powered milk cooler designed to fit onto donkeys and motorcycles. The invention uses aluminium tanks as a cooling system which are connected to a solar panel. It also has a milk PH test kit, an automatic weighing scale and a customized dairy co-operative management application which links the machine and the cooperative society. The machine allows a farmer to keep milk for maximum of three days without going bad. The app automatically collects milk quality and quantity data and relays it to the cooperative's payroll after computing the monthly total collections and relays the same information to the farmer through SMS.
pads.title: Solar powered mobile milk cooler

pads.content:
Meubles à Base de Déchets Papier
Les déchets papier produits par les entreprises peuvent être recyclés comme intrants pour la fabrication de meubles et fournitures de bureau.
L'amidon est utilisé comme liant en lieu de la colle industrielle souvent toxique.
"Il faut environ 70Kg de papier pour fabriquer une table-banc d'école" -- Kombate Palou Poukin, porteur de solutions à l'Innovation Challenge sur les Constructions Durables de l'AccLab Togo.
Quand: 23/01/2020
pads.title: Meubles à Base de Déchets Papier

pads.content:
Fabrication de Pavés Autobloquants à partir de Déchets Plastiques
Utilisation du plastique fondu comme liant à la place du ciment. Le test sur place dans les locaux de l'innovateur n'a pas été concluant.
Quand: 23/01/2020
Qui: TMSU International dans le cadre de l'Innovation Challenge sur les Constructions Durables de l'AccLab Togo.
pads.title: Fabrication de Pavés Autobloquants à partir de Déchets Plastiques

pads.content:
Shamba Records - Digital tool linking farmers to markets
George Maina founded Shamba Records, an agritech startup that uses Blockchain and AI to collect small scale farmers' production data, link them to markets, process their payments and connect them to credit alternatives. So far, Shamba Records has digitized more than 6,000 small scale farmers and their respective cooperatives. Shamba Records solves the challenges of records manipulation, delayed payments, credit score and inadequate farming information.
pads.title: Shamba Records - Digital tool linking farmers to markets

pads.content:
Pavé Autobloquant à base de Broyat de Verre
Le broyat de verre peut remplacer jusqu'à 30% de sable. Cette innovation permet de revalorisée les déchets de verre dans la nature sous forme de tessons de bouteille. 
Quand: 24/01/2020
Qui: Africa Global Recycling
pads.title: Pavé Autobloquant à base de Broyat de Verre

pads.content:
Biodigestion à Ciel Ouvert
Système de biodigestion de déchets organiques dans des bassines contenant des bactéries qui consomment la matière organique permettant d'obtenir une eau riche de nutriment pour arroser les plantes.
Quand: 23/012020
Qui: TMSU International
pads.title: Biodigestion à Ciel Ouvert

pads.content:
Réacteur de Biodigestion
Biodigesteur de déchets organiques humain avec réacteur de méthanisation des intrants pour la production et stockage de biogaz.
La technologie Biofil est vantée comme une alternative économique et durable à la construction de fosses septiques dans la construction d'habitation.
Quand: 14/07/2020
Qui: Germain Kogbe -- Eco Tech House
Quoi: BioFosse
pads.title: Réacteur de Biodigestion

pads.content:
Dispositif de Biodigestion
Disposition de production et stockage de biogaz pour l'usage dans les ménages.
Méthanisation à partir de bouse de vache.
Durée de méthanisation: 3-4 semaines.
Avantages économique - moins cher - et sécuritaire -plus léger que l'air - sur le butane.
Quand: 27/01/2020
Où: Village des Accompagnants
Qui: Prof. Roger Sessou.
pads.title: Dispositif de Biodigestion

pads.content:
Water hyacinth cake
Jack Oyugi, founded Biofit Agritech, a company that harnesses the invasive water hyacinth and converts it into an animal food supplement. The invasive weed which first appeared in Africa in the early 1900s made its way to Lake Victoria where it has closed off fishing routes and provided a new habitat for disease-carrying mosquitoes.
The water hyacinth is steam boiled, dried, crushed and fermented to make a powder, which is then mixed with minerals and energy-rich materials like maize bran to make an affordable feed sold at a fraction of the price of soya feed. The byproducts from making the feed can also be sold as fertilizers. The company employs the fishermen as harvesters as they can no longer fish because the hyacinth levels are so high.
pads.title: Water hyacinth cake

pads.content:
Briquettes Charcoal from farm waste
Name of solution owner: Mike Kuley from Arusha Tanzania co-founder of Baraka briquettes Charcoal
They collect raw materials, mainly organic waste from different places in Arusha and Kilimanjaro regions includes different Argo fibers like wheat straw, rice straw, rice husk, hay, jute stick, groundnut shell,
energy grasses (miscanthus, elephant grass, switchgrass), Seed husks, corn
cobs, corn Stover, energy cane, sugar cane bagasse, and mustard, Stalk, coir
pith, etc. Cotton stalk, bamboo, grapevine clippings, fruit tree clippings,
coffee shrubs, Olive pits, coffee husk, peanut shells, and all other types of
nut shells; Tobacco waste, used coffee grinds, dried tomato vines; Recycled
paper, cardboard, Dried animal droppings, dried sludge from wastewater
treatment plants and carbonize these organic farm waste and shape them to form briquettes charcoal.
Photos
pads.title: Briquettes Charcoal from farm waste

pads.content:
Recyclage de Déchets Ménagers
Les déchets ménagers sont réutilisés dans la fabrication de pelles, bracelets, trousses, etc. par les écoliers qui font partie du programme de sensibilisation au recyclage organisé par l'OMG STADD.
« Nous avons des formateurs qui apprennent aux enfants des écoles avec lesquelles nous travaillons à recycler notamment en transformant les objets. » — Farida AMADOU, formatrice STADD.
Quand: 26/01/2020
Où: ONG Science et Technologie Africaine pour un Développement Durable (STADD)
pads.title: Recyclage de Déchets Ménagers

pads.content:
Remote detection of (de)population processes
The platform has been created with the idea of establishing a sustainable framework that would capture depopulation and factors affecting the occurrence or dynamics of this process in Serbia. In addition to traditional data sources that quantitatively measure the level of population change in Serbia, the platform also relies on alternative sources (e.g. satellite images of nightlights, digital terrain model, GHS Population Grid datasets). Various datasets have been taken into consideration in creating a set of indicators for depopulation monitoring in the territory of Serbia, based on numerous factors that influence the occurrence of this process and determine the tendencies of spatial expression and changes in their intensity. The offered interrelated dataset is of great importance for monitoring the overall population and developmental changes, and it also offers the possibility to predict their future scenarios.
pads.title: Remote detection of (de)population processes

pads.content:
Anti - Army Worm
For the past four years farmers in Zambia have experienced crop attacks by army worms. This problem has resulted into poor harvest thereby posing a threat to food security in the Country especially for the rural population that is highly dependent on small scale farming for their livelihoods and food security.
The innovation provides a chemical liquid that farmers can use to kill Army worms that are prone to attack the country's staple crop - maize
pads.title: Anti - Army Worm

pads.content:
Conservation de la Nourriture dans du Sachet Plastique à Usage Unique
Réutilisation de sachets plastiques à usage unique comme emballage d’aliments pour préservation et protection.
Conservation de la température de la nourriture et protection des nuisibles par l’utilisation de sachets plastiques.
Bien que nuisible à l’environnement et à la santé, les sachets plastiques à usage unique ont bien des utilités dans le quotidien des togolais.
« Ca permet non seulement de conserver la pâte plus longtemps, de la protéger contre les mouches et les microbes, mais également de manier les boules plus facilement » - ménagère
pads.title: Conservation de la Nourriture dans du Sachet Plastique à Usage Unique

pads.content:
Fabrication de Meubles à partir de Pneus Usagés
Transformation de pneus usagés en meubles. Les pneus servent de matériaux de base à la fabrication de chaises, de tables, etc.
Quand: 28/09/2019
pads.title: Fabrication de Meubles à partir de Pneus Usagés

pads.content:
Jawam handwashing machine
A foot operated handwashing machine developed by 9-year-old Stephen Wamukota.
pads.title: Jawam handwashing machine

pads.content:
Depopulation sensing by integrative knowledge discovery from big data
This solution uses mobile, satellite and open data in order to better understand state-level depopulation trends. It focuses on in-country distribution of population and migrations, based on analysis of activity, connectivity and mobility of people in Serbia reflected through telecom data together with data from different sources. The results of the research are easily accessible through a web portal, which will include interactive maps, dashboards, and customized reports.
pads.title: Depopulation sensing by integrative knowledge discovery from big data

pads.content:
Road Rules creating accessibility to learning road rules in Zimbabwe
Road Rules in an app that increases accessibility to educational material and tests for drivers' licenses in Zimbabwe. The app is a cost effective method to learn the highway code which was a privilege reserved for the affluent before.
pads.title: Road Rules creating accessibility to learning road rules in Zimbabwe

pads.content:
Plastic Bottle House 
AfriCraft joined hands with FEMINA and NipeFagio to create an information center for environmental care at Coco Beach in Dar es salaam. In view of the immense problem of pollution of the ocean by plastic waste the center was built out of plastic bottles, transforming plastic bottles into useful products.
pads.title: Plastic Bottle House

pads.content:
The ProFoodApp
The ProFoodApp digitizes Namibia’s local and traditional food system flows thereby providing mapping, visualization and monitoring capacity to allow food to be easily located and procured at the local and regional levels and distributed to the end beneficiary in a more transparent and equitable manner.
The App acts as a “one-stop-shop approach” for local small-scale producers (e.g. women cooperatives & single producers) to procurement hubs and partners (e.g. Government, Semi-Government, Food aid programmes; Private sector) to end users (e.g. consumers and distributors of food parcels) and to end clients (e.g. beneficiaries).
pads.title: The ProFoodApp

pads.content:
Deaftronics building solar powered batteries for hearing aids
Deaftronics developed the first solar rechargeable hearing aid battery which lasts for 2-3 years and can be used in 80% of hearing aids on the market today. The battery can be charged by the sun,household light and through a cellphone plug.
pads.title: Deaftronics building solar powered batteries for hearing aids

pads.content:
Durable Plastic Timber from Recycled Plastic Wastes 
Solution owner: EcoAct- Tanzania
EcoAct recycle plastic wastes into durable plastic timber and poles. This technology enable to reduce the deforestation since poles and planks can be used the same way as normal wooden timber but still perform much better since are;
i) termite free
ii) Do not rot
iii) Long lasting 
iv) Affordable 
v) once you want to replace them, you can sell back to producers as raw materials.
plastic timber ready for fencing
pads.title: Durable Plastic Timber from Recycled Plastic Wastes

pads.content:
Green Slabs creating paving from plastic
Greenslabs is a Bulawayo based startup that manufactures sidewalk paving slabs and decking from recycled plastic.
Green Slabs considers the problem of plastic waste in Zimbabwe. Plastic litter causes an unhealthy environment for pedestrians who use public spaces. The start up creates community clean up campaigns to collect this litter that forms an ingredient in the slabs they manufacture. Green slabs uses different technologies to make pavement slabs from recycled material, particularly plastic and glass and or rubber, in pursuit of a cleaner Bulawayo.
pads.title: Green Slabs creating paving from plastic

pads.content:
Reuse of Car Tyres 
Name of solution owner: Mabali Mali Enterprise.
Mabaki Mali deals with recycling of waste into interior and exterior designs to make eco-friendly products. 
Photo of furnitures made from used car tyres
pads.title: Reuse of Car Tyres

pads.content:
Eco-bricks
Name of solution owner: Arena Recycling Industry co-founded by a young girl Hellena Sailas.
Arena Recycling Industry is a social business that collects plastic waste from beaches in Dar es salaam and produces building materials such as Eco-Bricks, paving block, and tiles out of recycled plastic waste for
construction of affordable houses, toilets, and other buildings in rural areas.
More about the Solution;
This solution not only contributes toplastic-free beaches and waterways, but also helps bridge the water and
sanitation gap by constructing water tanks and latrines with our eco-bricks. We
educate and promote the change of behavior in waste disposal, byinvolvinge
community recycle’s into logistic and improve their income by buying collected
plastic waste fromthe environment, the collected plastic waste is then sorted
according to plastic waste composition (density) melted and mixed with sand to
produce bricks covered during courses.
pads.title: Eco-bricks

pads.content:
Useful insects as bioagents of control for integrated pest management
Certain insects found in nature - gabrobracons, trichograms and lacewings - can be used to control insects that damage crops. These farmer's natural aids has been used for many years in large cotton and grain fields as one of the effective methods to prevent spread of other harmful insects. Application of these 'useful' insects in orchards has been re-invented recently with the assistance of UNDP in Uzbekistan as an important part of integrated pest management and promoting green agriculture in pilot region in Namangan Region of Fergana Valley.
https://www.uz.undp.org/content/uzbekistan/en/home/presscenter/articles/2019/02/13/undp-promotes-modern-eco-friendly-techniques-of-pest-and-disease.html
pads.title: Useful insects as bioagents of control for integrated pest management

pads.content:
Cassava Value Chain Project
Cassava is increasingly being used for different purposes including in the processing of leather industry, paper production, glue production and ethanol production. This provides opportunities for small scale farmers to provide the cassava, which in some parts of the country is grown in great quantities.
The innovation has designed a value chain that will link small scale cassava farmers to the market, while ensuring the farmers benefit from the value chain. The model will provide a stable market for cassava and promote cassava farming as a business.
pads.title: Cassava Value Chain Project

pads.content:
Theocentric Business solution
Most households in Zambia that are connected to electricity use 100 Watts ordinary bulbs that consume a lot of energy and have a short life span. The business aims to supply domestic households in medium and low density residential areas with LED bulbs with a low wattage and long life span. This will result in low power usage at household level and saving of electricity, whose efficiency has greatly been affect by prolonged draughts since the country depends on hydro generated power.
pads.title: Theocentric Business solution

pads.content:
Recycling of Waste Products
The innovation is focused on recycling waste paper into paper egg trays and to repurpose waste plastic into bricks. Reducing the amount of paper and plastic being thrown away would improve the aesthetic beauty of the town and transform the land being used as open landfill into a garden or for other productive uses. The model is designed to re-purpose waste paper and plastic into valuable goods that would ensure they remain sustainable
pads.title: Recycling of Waste Products

pads.content:
Digital Solution Safari - SME's Response to COVID-19
Curious to see how fellow Namibians were addressing issues that are directly or indirectly affecting them during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Accelerator Lab in collaboration with our partner Launch Namibia conceptualized a digital solution safari. The solution safari was a social media campaign that looked at COVID-19 related products and services developed or adapted by not only entrepreneurs but as well as community members in underserved areas. 
Our aim with this campaign was to highlight entrepreneurs who are making a difference within their communities, we were specifically looking at entrepreneurs sharing useful information on COVID-19, gathering resources that can be donated to the less privileged or making innovative strides as entrepreneurs to ensure that they not only continue working but also inspiring others to follow suit. This digital safari was also a means to highlight and collate information on locally owned solutions outside of the entrepreneurship space. Our main way of engaging followers on social media was through a call to action where followers of both UNDP and Launch accounts were asked to submit information regarding community members who have developed COVID-19 specific solutions.
1. Kaushiwetu Johannes came up with a hygiene hand-was system to aid the fight against the pandemic, his design can be customised to suit the needs of the community and it comes in various sizes. The design also allows for multiple people to use it at the same time. 

2.Ingo Shangyenge through his start-up Inansa Investment has been manufacturing masks for essential staff as well as the public at large.
3. Emmerancia Van Wyk has been providing nutritious meals to between 250 & 300 children daily who were formerly dependent on their school feeding schemes while educating them on COVID-19
4. Linda Ndakolo whose start-up manufactures cleaning materials donated dishwashing liquid to over 500 beneficiaries living in an informal settlement in Windhoek. 
5. Sylvanie Beukes alongside his partners has been developing sanitizing tools to aid in the fight of COVID-19 and future pathogenic threats to come.
pads.title: Digital Solution Safari - SME's Response to COVID-19

pads.content:
Growing Blue Chamomile as a new sustainable agri-business for underprivileged women in villages
Blue chamomile is also known as Moroccan chamomile since the plant is native to Morocco. Not well known by Moroccan, it has though a rare ability to sedate without depressive. Blue chamomile oil is obtained from the distillation of the flowering stems and has potent anti-itching, antihistamine and anti-inflammatory properties.
Blue chamomile oil is very effective in soothing the skin. It can thus be applied pure to the skin in the following cases:
itching, such as allergic pruritus
allergic attack, hives or rashes
irritative redness, or inflammation in sensitive or irritated areas
pads.title: Growing Blue Chamomile as a new sustainable agri-business for underprivileged women in villages

pads.content:
Allo Lavagi or how to dry clean cars in the most eco-friendly way
In a dry arid country where drought and desertification are no longer a threat but a reality, a single car wash is exceeds 70 liters of drinkable water in professional car washing services and more than 300 liters for traditional washing which is the way most of the Moroccan clean their cars. a car wash service at home and without water. A water-less way to clean cars in Morocco could not be more helpful in saving the perhaps future most scarce resource.
pads.title: Allo Lavagi or how to dry clean cars in the most eco-friendly way

pads.content:
Simawa Rugs, A Biomimicry Social Textile Project in Iraq
The Solution:
The solution's owner thought of this project as a part of the recovery process after COVID-19. It focuses on developing rug production process in Simawa governorate, especially knowing that this city suffers from poverty, in fact more that 55% of its inhabitants suffer from poverty and that was even before COVID-19. The Rug making (Izar) is an endangered craft, and even more so after the difficult times that our country has faced. We are trying to preserve this craft, by tying it to other individuals, like the people living in the capital Baghdad, or the ones who live abroad. The project’s impact is in providing the artisans from Samawa all the raw materials, developing the Rug making process to help make production easier for them, taking the final product from these poor areas and deliver them to other individuals who are interested in reviving their cultural heritage. This way we can support the artisans, preserve our heritage and make these products available to the rest of the world. The artisans who will participate in this project, are all women from Samawa city. They come from reserved and poor families, and they have amazing skills whether it’s spinning wool, coloring it or embroidery of the Izar. This project is created with the help of Iraqi raw materials, starting from the sheep fleece and ending with the Iraqi artisans. By: Noor Hashim, young entrepreneur
https://youtu.be/qgLsa68r1Dg
pads.title: Simawa Rugs, A Biomimicry Social Textile Project in Iraq

pads.content:
Green Riverbank Sanitation and Sustainability Project
"Rivera Verde" or green Riverbank is a project by Fundacion Tropigas. Due to a lack of gov't intervention, they wanted to collaborate with the Isable river sanitation. This is one of the two major rivers in the city of Santo Domingo. The slum communities around the riverbank are part of the contamination problem because a lot of the solid waste ends thrown into the river. The project consisted in 1) community education efforts to increase awareness and improve garbage disposal practices, and 2) the use of two water collection hunter machines, to collect garbage that floates in the river and usually ends up in the ocean. The AccLab was conduncting a stakeholder mapping when we came across this instituion and tehy told us about the project, which has been featured in the media and has been supported by other public and private institutions.
pads.title: Green Riverbank Sanitation and Sustainability Project

pads.content:
Sugarcane-growing, drone-flying rural woman farmer in Fiji
Mrs. Kaur farms sugarcane in a rural part of Western Fiji. She also raises pigs. Although she is assumed to be in need of “empowerment”, she already maximizes productivity even with lean resources by using a drone to inspect her farm acreage. She also monitors her piggery with CCTV cameras, thereby decreasing incidences of theft. These twin challenges – theft of animals and supervision of a large plot of land -- have served as barriers to other women thriving in the sugarcane farming business.
https://www.asia-pacific.undp.org/content/rbap/en/home/gender-equality/in-depth/transforming_future_work_4_gender_equality_initiative.html
pads.title: Sugarcane-growing, drone-flying rural woman farmer in Fiji

Creativo

pads.content:
Silpakarman
Silpakarman is a for-profit social enterprise where a group of craft enthusiast work with clusters and artisans in the rural parts of India. Their aim is to innovate contemporary products by following the traditional crafts of these craftsmen while providing them with livelihood.Silpakarman is focused to bring the best out of natural fibers. They are working across 3 states in the north-eastern part of India, innovating products made from bamboo, cane and other grasses.
www.silpakarman.com
pads.title: Silpakarman

pads.content:
Loophoop
LoopHoop is looping in handloom weavers, artisans, small manufacturers together with technology driven marketplace. This is a marketplace platform which ensures making authentic and pure handloom and handicraft products available to clients at value for money prices. The endeavor is to endorse the heritage handlooms and handicrafts of India and convert them into contemporary wearable fashion. They support resellers , women who wish to work from home. They have generated employment for working mothers who work from home . They have future plans of bringing in virtual reality to their website for better client services
www.loophoop.in
pads.title: Loophoop

pads.content:
Ensuring Bangladeshi women's safety in public transport
The Bangladesh Accelerator Lab organized a Women’s Digital Innovation hackathon to promote ICT skills and innovation practices to female students and professionals and find new digital solutions to a wide range of SDG challenges. One of the solutions that came out of the hackathon is ‘Bhai Thamen’ (colloquial Bengali for "bro, stop") - an AL and ML based mobile application that aims to support women with a digital tool that provides ways to travel safely. An objective of the app is to decrease women’s risk of facing sexual harassment or assault when they are on the move and commuting. Additionally, the application strives to arm women with knowledge that empowers them to take their safety and mobility into their own hands by creating a social media platform to provide information – generated by other fellow women – to help women make better, informed choices about travel safety.
pads.title: Ensuring Bangladeshi women's safety in public transport

pads.content:
Game For Funding by Alumna Sao Pedro
Alumni Sao Pedro - Social Project is a community group initiative led by alumni of Catholic High School Sao Pedro in Dili. Five members of alumni HS Sao Pedro 2013 took this social project to support community members in need with funding collected from creating Game for Funding project. The group has abled to link other members of community who are disadvantaged to those who are willing to help others in need particularly women who are single and or abandoned by their family.
tags: the vulnerable members of our society
pads.title: Game For Funding by Alumna Sao Pedro

pads.content:
Epulcheuse de manioc "Zongo 2"
Cette machine 100% congolaise, fruit de la créativité et de la passion de Mr. Zephyrin NDOMBI NDOMBASI, Colonel à la retraite et entrepreneur agricole. Cette machine se positionne comme une solution à l’épineuse contrainte de l’opération d’épluchage qui en plus d’être une opération pénible pour les femmes rurales, est extrêmement coûteuse pour la filière du manioc en RDC.
Composée de matériaux très simple à 90 % locaux, cette machine est couplée à un moteur thermique consommant 2,5 litres d’essence en six heures de travail pour le traitement de 3 à 5 tonnes de tubercules de manioc épluchés. Cette machine serait en mesure d’éplucher plus de 15 tonnes de manioc en une semaine avec 4 à 5 personnes pour la manœuvre. 
Pour la même quantité, avec la méthode manuelle, il aurait fallu 25 personnes mobilisées avec tous les coûts correspondants et les risques de santé dus à l’épluchage manuel avec objet contondant. Ceci serait donc un gain en temps et une économie de coût considérable susceptible d’augmenter significativement la production de manioc et par conséquent l’amélioration des revenues des petits producteurs sans oublier l’amélioration de sécurité alimentaire dans les communautés congolaise fortement consommatrice du manioc. 
En plus du gain de productivité qu’elle apporte, son poids sied bien à une manipulation aisée dans les milieux ruraux car elle peut facilement être déplacée par 4 personnes pour des distances raisonnables dans les villages et communautés productrices. une aubaine pour les coopératives et autres institutions financières d’étoffer leur gamme de produits crédit avec destination cohérente.
pads.title: Epulcheuse de manioc "Zongo 2"

pads.content:
Le Portique de Désinfection des Germes de maladies Infectieuses (PDGI) 
Le Portique de Désinfection des Germes de maladies Infectieuses (PDGI) est un équipement physique qui rassemble en seul outil, l`essentiel des mesures barrières conventionnelles recommandées par les États. Il assure un seul passage, la distanciation physique, la désinfection des semelles de chaussures, le lavage des mains, le port des bavettes et la désinfection des tenues vestimentaires des visiteurs. 
Avantage du PDGI : en général les dispositifs de lavage des mains déposés devant les entrées des bâtiments sont très peu utilisés par les visiteurs pour diverses raisons. Le PDGI apporte une correction à cette négligence des usagers des services publiques car les visiteurs sont contraints de passer dans le portique pour accéder aux lieux. 
Le renforcement des mesures barrières d’hygiène et de la lutte contre l’infection peuvent limiter la propagation de micro-organismes résistants et réduire l’utilisation abusive et à mauvais escient des antimicrobiens.
pads.title: Le Portique de Désinfection des Germes de maladies Infectieuses (PDGI)

pads.content:
Filtration d'eau de boisson à partir du moringa 
A travers Bio Niger, Sahabi Souley a mis en place une méthode innovante de filtration d'eau à partir des feuilles de moringa, plante répandue au Niger. Constatant que les producteurs de moringa avaient du mal à écouler leur production dans la région de Tahoua, d'où il est originaire, M. Souley a mis au point une technique innovante de filtration des impuretés présentes dans l'eau grâce aux feuilles de moringa, aux propriétés reconnues. Il utilise des feuilles de moringa cultivées sans pesticides ni engrais chimiques pour filtrer l'eau, conditionnée sous forme de sachets (à l'image des sachets d'eau potable que l'on peut trouver dans les marchés). Un effort est fait sur l'emballage, constitué d'un plastique recyclé qui se dégrade plus rapidement qu'un plastique classique (sans toutefois atteindre le biodégradable). 
Permettant aux producteurs de moringa d'écouler leur surplus de production, la mise au point de cette méthode naturelle de filtration de l'eau, qui peut être réalisée avec des infrastructures de base et ne nécessite pas d'équipements spécifiques, facilite également l'accès à une eau propre aux populations reculées. L'innovation a été mise au point et développée dans la région de Tahoua, avec des équipements sommaires - avant de se déplacer à Niamey pour envisager une production à plus grande échelle.
pads.title: Filtration d'eau de boisson à partir du moringa

The Localized Design Thinking Training Manual
The first localized Design Thinking training manual in Iraq has been developed and tested with individuals and institutions for the people who are interested in innovation and entrepreneurship to find worth- solving problems and build partnerships around them. This training manual covers the five stages of Design Thinking (Empathy, Define, Ideate, Prototype, and Testing) and their tangible application to the Iraqi market represented by selected local entrepreneurial start-ups. Can be used for any young person interested in Innovation, Design Thinking, or Entrepreneurship... alone or working with a team... planning a social initiative or a business... a student planning his/her graduation project... trying to design a training agenda or even a training program on Design Thinking... for anyone who is working at a bank, company, government institution, organization or university and heard about Design Thinking and wonder if it could add value to their work? For people working on Peace Building and Social Cohesion, Design Thinking can be a great method to gather people around ideas, projects and solutions.
Available to everyone.

INGOs
Youth Initiative

pads.content:
Solutions Point
University students in Iraq suffer from the lack of practical experience and the practical aspect of the academic curriculum
In general, and in graduation projects, especially because of the gap between the old academic style and the needs of the labor market, the weak self-development of students and the teaching staff, due to the electronic entertainment temptations for students and the lack of responsibility for the teaching staff under the pretext of receiving monthly dues in a consistent manner and not related to additional activities. 
The proposed value of the project
First: the basic value:
1 - A shared electronic space that brings together private sector companies and university teaching staff
And university students and graduates.
Second: Added Values:
1 - Easy to access (website enabled mobile app).
2 - Free for students and faculty.
3 - The content of the common space is scientifically practical and stems from the core of the labor market.
4 - It is considered a means of development in the practical side of the teaching staff in universities.
5 - The first electronic space in Iraq that brings together the above-mentioned parties.
6 - Increasing the chances of graduates getting a job in the participating companies.
7 - An opportunity for students to work on graduation projects close to the job market.
8 - Reducing the cost of finding solutions to problems or challenges facing private sector companies as a result
Scientific projects resulting from students, which will lead to partnerships between them in the future, however
This is at the cost of time.
9 - It contains a database of the first of its kind for projects and companies.
10 - Providing internship for students and alumni with the participating companies
Under developing
Individuals

pads.content:
Séchoir solaire SolAri
Le séchage des produits agricoles permet, en allongeant la durée de vie des produits et en ouvrant la voie vers une transformation des matières premières produites, de lutter contre le problème du surplus agricole qui touche largement les producteurs nigériens. En mettant au point un séchoir qui fonctionne entièrement à l'énergie solaire, l'innovateur Saidou Madougou propose une technique innovante (aucun relais par énergie fossile n'est prévu, des batteries solaires rechargeables alimentent en continu le système de séchage), facile à utiliser, ne nécessitant pas d'autre ressource que l'énergie solaire, dont la mise à l'échelle pourrait offrir des solutions viables de transformation de leurs produits bruts aux producteurs nigériens. 
Qualifications techniques : 
Le séchoir "SolAri" est formé d'une boîte en tôle d'aluminium ou de zinc peint en noir.
Dimensions : 210 cm x 45 cm x 45 cm 
Capacités de séchage : une surface de 4,32 m3 de séchage, répartie en 3 chambres de séchages (6 claies chacune de 40 sur 60 cm) capable d'absorber 18 à 24 kg de produit frais. 
Alimentation : un ventilateur de 13 W est alimenté par une batterie solaire de 12V, d'une capacité de 200 Ah. La batterie est alimentée par un panneau solaire de 250 W. Un convertisseur de 500 W assure la conversion du courant continu de la batterie en courant alternatif. 
Méthode de séchage : le ventilateur atteint une vitesse de 1 à 5 m/s ; la combinaison entre la chaleur du soleil et la ventilation est l'élément central de la technique de séchage du SolAri. Le séchoir est équipé de deux thermo hygromètres, d’un analyseur d’humidité, d’un thermo anémomètre, d’une balance de précision et des outils de coupe pour mener à bien le travail. Le corps du séchoir est chauffé par la chaleur du soleil afin de favoriser l’évaporation de l’eau de l’intérieur du produit vers l’extérieur des chambres de séchage. L’air introduit par le ventilateur évacue alors cette eau sous forme de vapeur, des chambres de séchage vers l’extérieur du séchoir. L’opération unitaire de séchage sera considérée comme terminée quand la teneur en eau de l’air de séchage à l’entrée du séchoir sera proche de la teneur en eau de l’air de séchage à la sortie du séchoir. Ces deux teneurs en eau sont indiquées par les thermo hygromètres.
pads.title: Séchoir solaire SolAri

pads.content:
Système automatisé lavage de mains - COVID 19 
Face aux risques de propagation portés par la pandémie COVID-19 et la large diffusion des gestes barrières à appliquer, l'innovateur M. Saidou Madougou a mis au point une machine de lavage des mains automatique, alimentée par un panneau photovoltaïque. Elle permet un lavage de mains automatique, sans contact avec le dispositif (distribution automatique de savon et d'eau de rinçage). 
Adaptable, la solution est utilisable à la fois dans les zones urbaines (elle est connectable aux réseaux d'eau potable et d'eaux usées), mais également, en installant des bidons d'approvisionnement en eau et de recueil des eaux usées, en milieu rural (alimentée à l'énergie solaire). Elle offre donc une solution viable aux problèmes d'hygiène de base (non seulement en temps de pandémie COVID-19, mais aussi dans le cadre de la lutte contre l'ensemble des maladies contagieuses qui sévissent au Niger). 
Description de la machine : 
Elle se constitue d'un dispositif de stockage d’eau, d'un autre de solution de savon, de deux robinets (dont l'un d'eau et l'autre de solution de savon) et d’un lavabo. 
Elle fonctionne automatiquement grâce à un système de carte électronique disposant d’un microcontrôleur programmable, de deux capteurs ultrasons, d’un dispositif de commande, de trois relais électriques, d’un système de refroidissement des composants électroniques. La machine est alimentée par un panneau solaire PV, d’une batterie de stockage d'énergie électrique (autonomie de 12h) nécessaire pour le fonctionnement de la machine la nuit, d’une lampe d’éclairage du lieu durant la nuit, d’un système d’évacuation d’eau usée et de la carcasse en tôle contenant tous les éléments. 
Le dispositif de stockage d’eau est connectable au réseau d'adduction d'eau, en cas de besoin, pour le ravitailler en eau (en lieu et place des réservoirs d’eau dans la machine). Le système d’évacuation d’eau usée est aussi connectable au réseau d'évacuation des eaux usées (ou à un système de recueil des eaux usées en fonction du contexte).
pads.title: Système automatisé lavage de mains - COVID 19

pads.content:
Grants for Community Response to COVID-19
Grants for Innovative Community Response to COVID-19: UNDP through Accelerator Labs has issued seven
(7) grants ranging from M100,000 – M500,000 to national partners in the private sector and civil societies for the
implementation of strategic community solutions that promote economic resilience, safeguard lives and livelihood, enable enjoyment of individual and collective rights , inspire communication and advocacy as well as the maintenance of social cohesion. On the 3rd September 2020, the final recipients of the grants were the following organizations: Edmonds Pt Ltd, Lesotho Red Cross, Partners in Health Lesotho, Mineworkers Development Agency, Ether Pharmacy, World Vision International and Development for Peace Education. The receipts of the grants are currently submitting their inception reports.

pads.content:
Enhancing digital literacy of Bangladeshi rural women
The Bangladesh Accelerator Lab organized a Women’s Digital Innovation hackathon to promote ICT skills and innovation practices to female students and professionals and find new digital solutions to a wide range of SDG challenges. As lack of digital literacy and primary digital skills among rural women is a major challenge in Bangladesh, one of the ideas that came out of the hackathon aimed to address this via ‘Sobjanta’ (Bengali for "omniniscient") - a messenger chatbot that will help rural women develop basic digital skills, computer and ICT skills, and also guide them regarding public services, human rights, and women-related opportunities. The bot will also troubleshoot basic challenges faced by users related to digital aspects.
pads.title: Enhancing digital literacy of Bangladeshi rural women

pads.content:
Artisaline - Plateforme e-commerce d'artisanat du Niger
Artisaline est une plateforme de e-commerce spécialisée dans la commercialisation de l'artisanat nigérien. Véritable vitrine du savoir-faire ancestral des artisans nigériens, elle propose une boutique en ligne de maroquinerie, bijouterie et vannerie, sur laquelle le client peut créer son compte, remplir un panier virtuel parmi une sélection de produits et recevoir le produit à domicile. 
Conçue et développée entièrement par des talents numérique nigériens, la plateforme Artisaline offre de nouveaux débouchés aux artisans locaux, en proposant des livraisons à la fois au Niger et dans la sous-région. Dans le contexte sécuritaire actuel qui restreint fortement les possibilités de tourisme au Niger, il est vital pour les artisans nigériens d'accéder à un public physiquement situé en-dehors des frontières nationales. La plateforme propose un prix juste, fixé à l'avance, qui garantit un revenu équitable au producteur et permet à l'acheteur de profiter de tarifs déjà négociés par Artisaline. 
La plateforme met aussi en place un soutien à la formation des artisans mobilisés sur la plateforme. 
Plusieurs options de livraison sont proposées, en fonction du lieu et de la date de livraison souhaitée ; le coût de la livraison, supporté par l'acheteur, varie selon ces principes. 
L'acheteur dispose également de différents moyens de paiement en ligne : en cash à la réception, en mobile money, par carte bancaire ou compte PayPal. 
Une gamme de services après-vente est également mise en place : le retour est gratuit sous 30 jours, la garantie est de 2 ans pour la majorité des produits, et un service permet de suivre l'état d'avancement de sa commande.
pads.title: Artisaline - Plateforme e-commerce d'artisanat du Niger

New Wheelchair: freedom to move around

With the help of undergraduates and international design collaborators, Amos Winter a mechanical engineering, has designed a wheelchair device that can carry users comfortably and efficiently off-road. The device it's intended to help people in countries where the access to wheelchairs is limited, but also where the rough terrain and the long distance travels are a limitation. It is small and maneuverable indoors too. Given the need to have a wheelchair that can move through rocky and muddy paths, the Leveraged Freedom Chair (LFC) performs like a combination of a desk chair and a mountain bike. The deviced has been tested with the people that would use it to make sure it's efficient and useful. The LFC it's now to be prototyped and tested with 30 persons in Guatemala.

pads.content:
TOP RAIN CELL
DOMAINE D’APPLICATION : Changement climatique
TYPE D’ACTIVITE : Mesure des quantités d’eau de pluie tombée
PROMOTEUR : Laboratoire LAME
CONTEXTE
Pour une bonne planification des productions agricoles aussi bien en saison sèche qu’en saison pluvieuse, il est important de connaitre la quantité d’eau tombée et celle dont on a à sa disposition pour mener ses activités agricoles. Pour ce faire, le ministère de l’agriculture et l’agence nationale de la météorologie fournissent des données pluviométriques sur la base de pluviomètres installés dans certaines localités du pays. Il faut noter que de nos jours, ces pluviomètres sont en nombre insuffisants, ne couvrent pas tout le pays et certains sont détériorés ou non accessibles en raison de la situation sécuritaire qui prévaut dans le pays. C’est donc dire qu’une bonne partie des données pluviométriques du pays ne sont pas collectées. Comment alors informer les producteurs et les décideurs sur les quantités d’eau disponibles pour la planification de leurs productions agricoles, surtout en saison sèche ? C’est pour répondre à cette question qu’est née la technologie TOP-RAINCELL. La pluie est la principale source d’apport d’eau au Burkina Faso. Et, TOP-RAINCELL permet de quantifier la pluie reçue.
PROBLEME ADRESSE
Le suivi des pluies en Afrique est une problématique majeure pour de nombreuses applications de recherche comme la modélisation hydrologique, climatique et agricole mais aussi opérationnelles telle la météorologie, les services des eaux (ONEA), la sécurité alimentaire, les alertes précoces aux inondation ou aux sécheresses, l’hydroélectricité, les routes, etc. Les méthodes traditionnelles utilisent des pluviomètres ou des radars ou encore des données satellitaires. Cependant ces différents dispositifs présentent des insuffisances : Pour ce qui est des pluviomètres, l’insuffisance porte surtout sur la capacité de couverture géographique, qui reste limitée. Pour le radar, c’est son coût qui est prohibitif pour les pays pauvres. Enfin, le suivi satellitaire et les prévisions météorologiques y relatives demeurent entachés d’incertitudes, notamment aux échelles temporelles et spatiales fines. Une méthode nouvelle, fiable et accessible, y compris aux pays pauvres d'Afrique, d'Amérique Latine et d'Asie du Sud Est, est donc la bienvenue
OBJECTIF RECHERCHE : Permettre la quantification des eaux de pluie reçue au sol et en temps réel
pads.title: TOP RAIN CELL

pads.content:
Cabine de désinfection contre la Covid-19 pour plus de sécurité sur les lieux publics au Bénin
Cette cabine hybride automatique de désinfection a été conçue grâce à la collaboration entre les chercheurs du Laboratoire de Physique de Rayonnement (LPR) de la Faculté des sciences et Techniques (FAST) de l’Université d’Abomey-Calavi (UAC) et le Laboratoire d’accélération du Programme des Nations Unies pour le développement (PNUD). C’est une cabine à portique automatique hybride (fonctionnant avec le courant conventionnel ou l'énergie solaire) dotée d'un thermomètre infrarouge prenant la température
corporelle des usagers avant de procéder à la désinfection des surfaces de leur habillement avec des jets de vapeur d'eau hydrolysée ou chlorée. Au cas où leur température est supérieure ou égale à 38°C, une alerte sonore les invite dans la langue choisie (Français, Anglais, langues locales) à se rapprocher d'un agent de santé avant l'ouverture des portiques pour subir la désinfection. Elle permet outre la CoVID-19, de protéger les populations contre les épidémies de grippe.
pads.title: Cabine de désinfection contre la Covid-19 pour plus de sécurité sur les lieux publics au Bénin

pads.content:
Using Art to Spread Positive Messaging During COVID-19
The AccLab, in collaboration with the communications department, supported the global UNDP Call to Creatives by running a call in South Africa. The call was to artists to submit works that captured the key messages of UNDP regarding Covid-19 prevention and response. Over 70 art works were received, and a panel of evaluators selected the most relevant and moving pieces. The artists of these works were profiled on social media and other platforms, and their works have since been used in other UNDP knowledge products such as the Annual Report and project calls. In addition, UNDP partnered with the South Africa Creative Industries Incubator to produce a song called “Kindness Contagion” which included musicians across Africa collaborating around this key UNDP message. The music video was launched in a virtual session including many of these artists and other stakeholders from across the continent.
pads.title: Using Art to Spread Positive Messaging During COVID-19

Using WhatsApp Voice Notes to Capture Messages from Vulnerable Groups 
UNDP is collaborating with a consortium of eight partners, led by the Wits University School of Governance, to evaluate the impact of the government’s expanded social protection package in response to Covid-19. This
research will analyse the impact of the grants for individuals, households, and communities which will surface important learnings to inform future programming and decision-making. The evaluation will be capturing insights regarding opportunities for transformative policy reform, feelings of empowerment, income seeking behaviours, access to food, social cohesion, and shifts in gender relations among many other areas. The project will make use of a variety of methodologies, including new and innovative data collection techniques such as drawing on voice notes submitted by youth via whatsapp.
pads.title: Using WhatsApp Voice Notes to Capture Messages from Vulnerable Groups

pads.content:
Trench beds
Provides a fertile substrate with good soil fertility and water holding capacity for vegetable production. The process involves digging a trench, separating the topsoil and subsoil and then replacing the soil in layers intermixed with locally available organic materials (e.g. dry grass and leaves, cardboard, manure and green leafy materials). The lower layers include the dry organic materials to increase water holding capacity and the upper layers include green organic matter and manure for nutrition in the root zone of the plant.
pads.title: Trench beds

pads.content:
Tower gardens
small intensive vegetable production systems that can be grown ‘on your doorstep’. Fundamentally, they involve a vertical, usually cylindrical, structure (constructed, for example, of rocks, wire or shadecloth) into which a growing medium is placed. The centre of the tower has a tubular cavity lined with a filter material into which grey water or potable water can be poured that will slowly infiltrate into the substrate providing a steady supply of water and nutrients for the vegetables. Vegetables are grown at the top of the tower garden as well as on the vertical sides to maximise the planting area and productivity of the system.
pads.title: Tower gardens

pads.content:
le Kénaf ou la plante multi-solutions 
DESCRIPTION DE LA SOLUTION
Le Kénaf est produit dans plusieurs zones du Burkina Faso, mais les usages diffèrent d’une zone à une autre. Les différents sous-produits du Kénaf sont utilisés comme des solutions locales multiples, car ils permettent de résoudre plusieurs problèmes et de faire face à plusieurs défis dont ceux de la nutrition, de la lutte contre la pauvreté, de la protection de l’environnement, etc.
En effet, le kénaf est généralement utilisé comme une solution locale dans l’alimentation humaine et animale. Ainsi, les feuilles, les graines, les fleurs et autres résidus du Kénaf sont utilisés comme des ingrédients
ou des composants alimentaires dans les plats locaux et dans l’alimentation des animaux, surtout en période de soudure.
CARACTERES INNOVANTS
Les principales caractéristiques innovantes de cette plante sont que : i) elle pousse sur toutes sortes de sols et ses besoins en eau sont très réduits ; ii) c’est un puissant fertilisant qui pourrait remplacer efficacement l’utilisation très massive des engrais minéraux; iii) le Kénaf est une alternative très peu couteuse et accessible pour les agriculteurs dans la régénération des sols appauvris et détériorés; iv) le Kénaf en tant que matière première accélérera la production des sachets et de contenants en fibre ou papier.
Dr Sanou Jacob, Institut de l’Environnement et de la Recherche Agronomique (INERA), Station de Farakoba – Bobo-Dioulasso
PROBLEME ADRESSE
Usage des sachets plastiques et faible fertilité des sols agricoles
IMPACT
Remplacer l’utilisation abusive des sachets plastiques qui sont très nocifs pour l’environnement et la santé humaine et animale.
pads.title: le Kénaf ou la plante multi-solutions

pads.content:
Respirateur artificiel : Un appareil d’assistance respiratoire médicale avec du matériau local
DESCRIPTION DE LA SOLUTION : Respirateur artificiel : Cet appareil d'assistance respiratoire
a également été conçu par des jeunes élèves ingénieurs, de l’Institut Supérieur de Génie Électrique (ISGE). C’est un respirateur artificiel made in Burkina Faso, inspiré du modèle OXYgen du groupe espagnol Protyfy. Dans sa première production, le respirateur artificiel fonctionnait à l’aide de ballon auto-remplisseur à valve unidirectionnel pour simuler la fréquence respiratoire. Rappelons qu’avec la COVID-19, le respirateur artificiel est apparu en première ligne des dispositifs nécessaires à la prise en charge des personnes infectées par le
coronavirus en raison des insuffisances respiratoires liées à cette maladie. 
CARACTERE INNOVANT : Le concept en lui-même est innovant, car il vise à promouvoir le ballon auto-remplisseur en permettant à ce ballon d’être auto-activé sans l’aide ou la présence d’un agent de santé ; ce qui crée une autonomie dans le fonctionnement, facilitant ainsi le travail des agents de santé et surtout en les exposants moins au contact des malades. Le respirateur peut être utilisé dans des endroits dépourvus d’énergie électrique. Il fonctionne essentiellement à l’énergie solaire. Il peut être
ainsi utilisé dans des formations sanitaires en zones rurales sans énergies électriques
comme dans des formations sanitaires des zones urbaines.
pads.title: Respirateur artificiel : Un appareil d’assistance respiratoire médicale avec du matériau local

pads.content:
La Stratégie Rurale de Développement communautaire (SRD)
La Stratégie Rurale de Développement communautaire est une innovation immatérielle qui consiste à partir des valeurs prônées par une communauté donnée pour aboutir à une stratégie de développement local. C’est une sorte de démarche de développement conçue et mise en œuvre au niveau communautaire. En mooré on dit : « Teng yiidguiri yengrè » c’est à dire les fondements de développement rural. Il convient de faire la distinction entre la stratégie rurale de développement communautaire et la stratégie de développement mise en place par l’Etat.
Stratégie rurale de développement communautaire (SRD) : L’innovation réside dans plusieurs aspects. Tout
d’abord, la stratégie rurale de développement communautaire (SRD) est prise en mains par la communauté, contrairement à la stratégie de développement rural de l’Etat dont la mise en œuvre est assurée par plusieurs groupes d’acteurs que ce sont : - l’Etat et ses démembrements ; - les collectivités locales et les communautés de base ; - les organisations professionnelles et les opérateurs privés ; - les partenaires techniques et financiers . La stratégie rurale de développement communautaire est conçue par rapport à un territoire défini. Elle est locale et communautaire en ce sens que la population visée forme déjà une « communauté » et ses membres sont liés par des réseaux sociaux informels. De plus, son approche territoriale est vue comme un moyen de mieux cibler les interventions destinées à relever les défis prioritaires de la zone concernée
Promoteur : Joanny Ouédraogo Contact: 70 95 97 09 /Souleymane Ouédraogo Contact: 70 29 98 90
PROBLEME ADRESSE : Cette expérience montre que les populations sont en mesure de s’organiser efficacement, si elles disposent de règles transparentes et clairement énoncées, de l’accès à l’information et d’un soutien technique et financier adapté : les communautés peuvent ainsi définir leurs priorités et résoudre des problèmes locaux en collaborant avec les autorités locales et diverses institutions pour construire de petites infrastructures et fournir des services de base. Les stratégies rurales de développement communautaire concourent activement à une réelle réduction de la pauvreté et à la mise en œuvre de stratégies de développement durable. La SRDC repose donc sur l'établissement d'un large consensus au sein de la communauté. L’expérience montre que les populations sont en mesure de s’organiser efficacement si elles disposent de règles transparentes et clairement énoncées, de l’accès à l’information et d’un soutien technique et financier adapté : les communautés peuvent ainsi définir leurs priorités et résoudre des problèmes locaux en collaborant avec les autorités locales et diverses institutions pour construire de petites infrastructures et fournir des services de base. 
IMPACT : Les stratégies rurales de développement communautaire concourent activement à une réelle réduction de la pauvreté et à la mise en œuvre de stratégies de développement durable.
pads.title: La Stratégie Rurale de Développement communautaire (SRD)
