pads.content:
Mentorship of VUP Beneficiaries in Muko Sector, Gicumbi District.
The VUP program could not achieve poverty graduation which was the main goal of the program in the targeted poorest sectors. This raised several questions such as why there was no significant change in the lives of
beneficiaries after years of implementation, what the issues are and what could be done differently to achieve such results? The sector leadership looked into the reasons behind this challenge and realized that some VUP beneficiaries misused the financial assistance they are given under VUP program (Direct Assistance and
Public Works). The sector leadership initiated a mentorship program where a trusted mentor/coach was given to 1 or 2 households that benefits from VUP programs with the responsibility of monitoring the use of the financial
resources received under VUP. The coaches/mentors also advocate for their respective households (HHs) if need arises. So far, 174/593 households in Muko sector are beneficiaries of this mentorship program. This has increased accountability on the side of VUP beneficiaries, improved mutual understanding, friendship and trust among mentors, VUP beneficiaries and the population of Muko Sector in general. 158 mentors were chosen considering their level of education and understanding of Government Programs who went through trainings
to effectively carry out the task. This is on a voluntary basis. Coaches visit their respective HHs once a month or twice a month and coaches meet every three months to evaluate what has been done.
Some of the mentors met.
pads.title: Mentorship of VUP Beneficiaries in Muko Sector, Gicumbi District.

pads.content:
Veenim, Tiinbo et Kizzi : combustibles de cuisson domestique contre le déboisement massif
DESCRIPTION DE LA SOLUTION : La découverte de solutions locales innovantes en matière de combustible domestique s’avère être une nécessité en raison de la perte accélérée des massifs forestiers, c’est pour cela que des sources de fournitures d’énergie de cuisson comme les combustibles Tiinbo, à base de noix de balanites aegyptica, le Kizzi à base de tourteaux des amendes de Karité et le Veenim à base de graines de Jatropha sont actuellement des solutions locales pertinentes. Elles permettent de relever le défi de freiner la désertification et le déboisement par la protection de la forêt et d’offrir un accès plus accru de la population à l’énergie, et partant de permettre indirectement une meilleure et une plus grande employabilité des populations en l’occurrence les jeunes, etc. 1. le combustible écologique VEENIM. Le terme VEENIM (en mooré), veut dire lumière. C’est une nouvelle lumière (vision) dans le domaine de l’énergie domestique et industrielle en Afrique. Le VEENIM est fabriqué à base du Jatropha curcas ; 2. le combustible écologique TIINBO. TIINBO (en mooré), veut dire Espoir ; donc un nouvel espoir dans le domaine de l’énergie domestique et industrielle en Afrique. C’est un produit à base des coques de la noix de Balanites aegyptiaca; 3. le combustible écologique KIZZI. KIZZI (en dioula), veut dire préservé ; c’est donc une nouvelle solution pour la préservation des ressources naturelles. Le combustible KIZZI est un produit écologique issu des tourteaux d’amandes de karité (Vitélaria paradoxa). 
CARACTERES INNOVANTS Le caractère innovant des combustibles se trouvent dans : 
· La transformation des résidus des produits forestiers non ligneux (tourteaux de karité, coques de balanites) en combustible pour l’énergie domestique et industrielle;
· La réduction ou l’abandon du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois au niveau des ménages et des unités agroalimentaires;
· Le produit est promu par le Conseil régional des Hauts Bassins et porté par des communautés rurales à travers des femmes qui ont acquis la technologie de production.
PROMOTEUR : Amadé Ouédraogo
PROBLEME ADRESSE : déforestation
IMPACT : Environnement protégé, vie terrestre équilibré
pads.title: Veenim, Tiinbo et Kizzi : combustibles de cuisson domestique contre le déboisement massif

pads.content:
Kundwa Kibondo in Sovu Health Center, Huye District. 
64 cases of malnourished children with 17 severe cases (in Red) were registered at Sovu Health Center in 2017, the Head of Sovu Health Center, the Sector Executive Secretary and Community Health Workers came up with an initiative to overcome malnutrition cases. Kundwa Kibondo program was thus established through which each family with malnutrition cases is supported to have a kitchen garden and is required to contribute Frw 100 per month used to support in the preparation of a balanced diet for malnourished children at the Health Center. The Health center and Huye sector staff committed to contribute Frw 200 per month in order to support malnourished children with eggs and fruits. 113 malnourished children were rehabilitated and their parents formed groups that help in monitoring of malnourished children on a daily basis. The sector lent to the families with malnutrition cases government plots to grow some vegetables. The Head of Sovu Health Center carries out numerous trainings with the parents whose children have been affected by malnutrition to teach them how to tackle this issue completely.
2 of 64 malnourished children found at the health center that were still being treated at the time of the safari.
pads.title: Kundwa Kibondo in Sovu Health Center, Huye District.

pads.content:
Water Supply system in Mushubati sector, Rutsiro District. 
Karambi village had water supply crisis and residents used to walk many miles to get water. A resident (Mr. KAGEMANA Naphtal) initiated water collection system using his own financial means amounting to 1,600,000 Frw /1,500USD. Almost 100 households benefit from this water supply system 24 hours, 7 days a week free of charge. For the sustainability of the initiative, the beneficiaries are planning to pay100 Frw per month to afford maintenance costs.
pads.title: Water Supply system in Mushubati sector, Rutsiro District.

pads.content:
Transformational villages in Kaburanjwiri - Kansi Sector, Gisagara District
Kaburanjwiri Village recorded 100% achievement of all family performance contracts (Imihigo y’Umuryango) and 100% achievement of the Village performance contracts for the year 2018/2019 (the construction of an ECD (Early Childhood Development) Center, well-functioning “Itorero ry’Umudugudu”,well-maintained roads, construction of the Village Office, well functioning “Irondo”, the distribution of “Ikayi y’Umudugudu”) to all the inhabitants of the village. The main strategy used was house to house sensitization by the local leaders on the benefits of working together to achieve their own wellbeing.
The start of the transformational villages.
pads.title: Transformational villages in Kaburanjwiri - Kansi Sector, Gisagara District

pads.content:
Coffee Tourism in Mbazi sector, Huye District.
The idea was initiated in 2013 when the manager of Huye Mountain Coffee visited Guatemala and Costa Rica from where he learnt that coffee based tourism is possible. This is an initiative by an individual company that aims at promotion of coffee production and coffee based tourism. The initiative has improved the standard of living of the people who live nearby as they got jobs in the Coffee factory and tourist guides. It has also boosted tourism in Huye District. It is an inspiring business model towards entrepreneurship which is needed for poverty graduation.
pads.title: Coffee Tourism in Mbazi sector, Huye District.

pads.content:
DiagnoseMe : Auto diagnostic et suivi fiable contre le COVID 19
Description de DiagnoseMe
DiagnoseMe est une application web et mobile innovante qui permet l’identification, le traçage et la mise en relation avec le personnel médical d’une personne malade pour contribuer à la limitation de propagation de la maladie et une prise en charge rapide. C’est une application qu’on peut installer sur smartphone et tablette. La plateforme permet également de faire la compilation automatique des données pour le suivi en temps réel des indicateurs.
Caractère innovant de DiagnoseMe
C’est un outil de gestion de la pandémie et peut aussi être remodelé ou programmé pour d’autres pandémies ou épidémies.
Il permet l’identification des cas et la gestion des alertes, par l’implication de bout en bout tous les acteurs de la chaine de prise en charge avec une traçabilité rigoureuse, un suivi télé médical instantané et une fluidité dans la surveillance épidémiologique.
DiagnoseMe garantit un déconfinement dans des conditions saines et sécurisées, étant donné qu’il offre la possibilité de faire un autodiagnostic de son état à chaque instant et d’avoir des signes d’alerte en cas de doute ou de véracité de la maladie.
DiagnoseMe fonctionne en offline (sans connexion internet) et online (avec connexion
internet) de l’interface utilisateur. 
L’identification des situations d’urgence pour une prise en charge priorisée à travers la recherche
et la prise en compte des signes de gravités et des comorbidités.
La recherche active et le suivi des cas contacts ainsi que des perdus de vus à travers une invite automatique aux cas probables et confirmés à remplir la liste et les adresses de leurs cas contacts dans une interface directement transmise à
l’équipe de gestion des cas contacts, ainsi qu’une invite de renseigner quotidiennement leurs symptômes sur la plateforme afin de faire leur suivi.
La téléconsultation par messagerie instantanée avec les professionnels de santé de la cellule de veille.
Le suivi des patients hospitalisés et non hospitalisés grâce à un système de dossier médical électronique continuellement actualisé
L’interconnexion avec les autres bases de données à travers une interface de saisie manuelle et un système d’importation et de sommation automatique des données numériques. Ce système d’importation automatique permet la connexion
avec les bases de données numériques du ministère de la santé.
En outre les données téléphoniques du centre d’appel téléphonique d’urgence (dont le 3535 au Burkina Faso) ainsi que les données papiers des formations sanitaires sont aussi interconnectées avec celles de la plateforme. 
La Compilation automatique des données permet le suivi en temps réel des indicateurs épidémiologiques bruts, éclatées et mis en graphiques. 
La Sensibilisation sur les moyens de prévention et surtout la protection des personnes fragiles présentant des comorbidités ;
L’information sur l’actualité concernant la COVID-19 et les démentis sur les fake news ou les informations erronées
Les liens vers les technologies existantes permettant de s’adapter aux mesures de distanciation sociales à travers des liens vers des services de E-commerce, E-learning, Web TV, Web radio, pharmacies de garde...) ;
Une Web TV et une Web radio pour renseigner les utilisateurs sur la pandémie et sur les questions de santé ;
L’inclusion sociale à travers un guide vocal dans plusieurs langues nationales permettant l’utilisation de la plateforme par les personnes malvoyantes, les personnes ne s’exprimant qu’en langues nationales ;
Cette inclusion prend en compte aussi les enfants à travers un guide de prévention infantile et un jeu concours spécial enfants pour la protection de l’enfance chère à l’Unicef et à des ONG nationales et internationales de la protection de l’enfance.
Promoteur : Traore Sy Adama
Problème adressé:
Le coronavirus, détectée en décembre 2019 est une maladie qui est vite déclarée par l’Organisation Mondiale de la Santé comme une pandémie mondiale au regard par sa propagation et de ses effets sur la santé des populations. La pandémie exige des stratégies et des méthodes pour la contenir, sinon elle s’apparente à un cataclysme mondial. Ainsi, en début mars 2020 l’épidémie touche le Burkina principalement dans sa capital Ouagadougou. Un Hackathon est organisé pour detecter les solutions
technologiques et innovantes destinées à permettre au pays de mieux faire face à l’épidémie est lancé. C’est ainsi que l’ application mobile intitulée « DiagnoseMe », est propose pour le test et la gestion
des cas de COVID 19.
Impact:
L’impact de DiagnoseMe est de contribuer à assurer une bonne santé aux populations du Burkina Faso
pads.title: DiagnoseMe : Auto diagnostic et suivi fiable contre le COVID 19

pads.content:
Wapek: un lave-main intelligent
Description de Wapek:
Wapek signifie « vient laver », en langue mooré parlée au Burkina Faso. Wapek est un lave
main intelligent qui peut être alimenté au solaire, mais aussi à l’énergie électrique fournie par la société nationale d’électricité du Burkina Faso (SONABEL). Si Wapek a été conçu dans l’objectif de promouvoir l’hygiène et de combattre le coronavirus, il sert aussi à la lutte contre d’autres maladies liées à l’hygiène. Ce sont entre autres la diarrhée,le choléra, la dysenterie, etc.
Caractères innovants de Wapek:• Le système de lavage autonome WAPEK permet de laver les mains sans toucher physiquement le récipient et d’éviter des nids de contamination. Il comprend un capteur qui détecte la présence d’une main et déclenche la pompe à eau permettant à la personne de laver ses mains et interrompt la sortie d’eau en l’absence de la main.
• Un autre avantage de ce dispositif est la maitrise de la quantité d’eau à utiliser. C’est une machine faite de telle sorte que l’eau soit utilisée en quantité contrôlée, ce qui permet donc de limiter le gaspillage de l’eau.
• Wapek
offre la double possibilité d’utilisation de l’énergie solaire mais aussi de l’énergie fournie par la SONABEL ;
• Wakep permet de sécher les mains avec de l’air chaud produit par un des dispositifs intégrés au produit. Wapek dispose de deux réservoirs dont l’un pour l’eau propre et l’autre pour l’eau sale qui est recueillie et qui peut être utilisée dans l’arrosage des plantes étant donné que le savon utilisé à petite quantité n’est pas corrosif 
Promoteur: Sandouidi Frédéric, Nignan Rachid et Bouda Yves
Problème adressé:
Avec la COVID-19, le lavage des mains s’est révélé primordial pour se protéger du virus. Cependant en Afrique, il est
souvent difficile de respecter ou suivre correctement les méthodes de lavage de mains comme le préconise l’OMS. En effet, une grande partie de la population et les structures de santé ne disposent pas d’outils ou d’instruments adéquats de
lavage de mains. Dans les habitudes de nombreuses communautés en Afrique, elles utilisent le même récipient (sceau, bouilloire, fût, etc.) pour se laver les mains. Ainsi, les parties de contact avec ces récipients constituent des nids
de contamination.
Aussi, après avoir lavé les mains au savon, les personnes sont souvent amenées à toucher encore des parties à fort risque de contamination. C’est pour pallier cette insuffisance et contribuer à la lutte contre la COVID-19, que Wapek a été concu.
Impact : L’impact de Wapek est de contribuer à assurer une bonne santé aux populations du Burkina Faso
pads.title: Wapek: un lave-main intelligent

pads.content:
Solar Tuk Tuk

This is the Tuk Tuk Solar 2021, a project promoted by the G-22 Environmental Association and the Biciudad Movement to promote the use of renewable energies, analyse the current transport model and at the same time generate a national unity project.
It is a form of transport that uses solar and electric energy.
pads.title: Solar Tuk Tuk

pads.content:
Le Système Hawk par les drones pour une agriculture de précision
DESCRIPTION DE LA SOLUTION : Le drone dénommé « Hawk » est fabriqué au Burkina Faso en vue d’aider à la prise de décision pour une agriculture de précision. Ce drone permet de collecter des images des cultures et de les traiter afin d’identifier d’éventuels problèmes rencontrées par les plantes et ce, en collaboration avec les ingénieurs agricoles.
CARACTERES INNOVANTS : L’innovation du système est qu’il aide le producteur dans l’optimisation de l’utilisation des ressources naturelles et des intrants. Le système estime pour le producteur la quantité d’intrants nécessaire qu’il faut par endroit de son exploitation ainsi que pour l’ensemble, et cela en fonction des spéculations qui sont produites. Le système fournit également au producteur avec précision les endroits et les ressources naturelles de l’exploitation dont il peut se servir pour de meilleures productions et productivités. Les résultats sont quasi disponibles vingt à trente fois plus rapidement que par les méthodes 
classiques.
PROMOTEUR : Faso Drone/Dr Yssouf Ouattara, ingénierie aéronautique, spatiale et intelligence artificielle
PROBLEME ADRESSE : Faible productivité agricole
IMPACT : Augmenter la production agricole
pads.title: Le Système Hawk par les drones pour une agriculture de précision

pads.content:
Windturbine from scrap material
A young man living in Mulanje, Malawi developed this solution to meet his family needs of lighting their homes and charging phones. He has built 3 wind turbines (from scrap metal and worn motors) that are connected to 3 houses in the compound. He uses car battery to store the generated power.
pads.title: Windturbine from scrap material

pads.content:
A cook stove from scrap gas cylinders
A man in one of the peri-urban areas (area 23) in capital city of Lilongwe is reusing discarded gas cylinder casings to make stoves that are energy efficient. The stove can be connected to electricity or solar panel to increase its efficiency. Small amount of Charcoal dust or briquettes can be used to make fire in the stove. The stove can cook beans in 30minutes.
pads.title: A cook stove from scrap gas cylinders

pads.content:
A community borehole from locally available resources
A man who is not very well known by a community created a scant borehole from a community well. The borehole uses locally available materials to operate. Before the borehole the women in the community were spending a long time at the well drawing water.
pads.title: A community borehole from locally available resources

pads.content:
Portable Solar Cooler for COVID 19 samples
Students from Polytechnic have developed this portable solar cooler to allow ease of COVID 19 sample storage and transportation in rural/ hard to reach areas.
pads.title: Portable Solar Cooler for COVID 19 samples

pads.content:
Locally made hands free water tap 
A community in Thyolo have developed a low cost hands free solution for washing hands as a general hygiene and COVID 19 preventative measure. Each household or community meeting space has a bucket of water, a plastic bottle with holes underneath and a long wire handle perched on a piece of wood nailed in the ground. Anyone who wants to wash their holds the bottle by the wire handle, dips it in water and hooks the wire on the wood to create a free flowing water tap
pads.title: Locally made hands free water tap

pads.content:
Household mats from scrap yarn
Edna Thom in Thyolo makes beautiful mats and cushions for household use from scrap yarn/wool. she get the yarn/wool from people in her community as well as pre-used clothe traders at the trading centre. She is a widow and earns a living making and selling these mats and cushions
pads.title: Household mats from scrap yarn

pads.content:
Efficient water heater
A man in Blantyre re-using buckets used for selling cleaning detergent into efficient water heaters which are safe and requires low electricity. He has experience an accident with one of his children due to the usual water heater and had been looking for ways to make durable /thick water heater. He has produced a number of these heaters which he has also shared with his relations in his village which has recently received electricity under the government led rural electrification programme.
pads.title: Efficient water heater
Le lave-main automatique : une solution efficace pour lutter contre la propagation du COVID-19

pads.content:
Sound pollution reduction
Citizen Mr. Royal (a corporate professional), in his free time, stands silently holding up a sign that says in Bengali "only idiots honk without any reason" at some of the busiest streets of Dhaka, in an attempt to catch the attention of drivers and shame them into not honking unnecessarily. He also distributes stickers and fliers with this message for people to use on their windshields, phones etc. and encourages others to join him for short periods on the roads. There is an observable reduction in honking by drivers who pass by Mr. Royal holding the sign, and pedestrians often join for short periods holding up the sign with him (I did too!)
Sound pollution from vehicles blaring hydraulic horns is a huge problem in the streets of Dhaka, making commuting an almost traumatic experience for both pedestrians and commuters alike, whose situation is particularly exacerbated by the hours of traffic jams they have to tolerate on a daily basis. So there is a need to reduce excessive honking by frustrated drivers, who often do so habitually even when there is a red light.
The reason this initiative seems innovative and is successful is because it is easy to take part in and replicate, it feels good and empowering to do it, has minimal costs and leads to almost immediate results.
pads.title: Sound pollution reduction

pads.content:
Zubiar's clips
I did not originally 'map' this solution. I heard about it from a former colleague of mine Gordon Jackson, who works with local communities in Baa Atoll to change the way that they manage their waste. In the month of August he sent me a video of a staff of the Baa Dharavandhoo island waste management center (also known as Eco Centro for its focus on recycling and move towards zero waste), making clips from aluminum fans dumped at the center. Since I am not currently in the Maldives - I decided to use this opportunity to find out the story behind this solution which for me is very innovative and inspiring. So I spoke to Gordon, and with his permission and blessing - got in touch with Zubair to find out the story behind this innovation. Here is the story behind this local solution: Zubair joined the Dharavandhoo Eco Centro last December. By then they had started segregating and bundling recyclables (metal, aluminum and plastic) into neat bundles - which then could be transported to Thilafushi where the plastic is taken in by Parley and the aluminum and metal taken in by Secure Bag for recycling. These bundles are held together with bands which are kept together using metal clips. Gordon and his team at Soneva used to supply the Dharavandhoo Eco Centro with these clips. With the disruptions in supply chains, they were having difficulties in getting clips. Without the clips, the Eco Centro was going into disarray, with the waste piling up in an unorganized mess in the center. Distraught, Zubair decided to try and invent his own clip. But to do this, he took one of the few remaining imported clips and realized that it was a piece of metal with a few bends. He undid the bends to get the exact measurements of the entire piece. Then he looked for waste materials that he could use to make his own clips. What he found and used are "Usha" brand aluminum ceiling fans. They had plenty of that at the Eco Centro. At first, the process was rather rudimentary. He used a hand cutter to cut the fan, and then a hammer to bend. Now he is working on perfecting his own clip making machine (also made from various materials sourced from the waste management center) to make the process faster. Currently, he makes about 40 clips a day. He reckons that Dharavandhoo will not have to rely on imported clips anymore. He says that if he could speed up his process, he could even supply these clips to the rest of the atoll. Photo+ Video credits: Gordon Jackson, Ali Shafeeq and Mohamed Zubair (shared with permission)
Upcycling/ Island Waste Management Solutions/ Circular Economy
When pushed, innovation is inevitable. You find solutions - where the problems are People innovate everyday to make their lives a little bit better - a little bit easier . Conveniences can sometimes kill innovation (?)
https://youtu.be/Vxxhz2x1F4s
pads.title: Zubiar's clips

pads.content:
Lets build together - a warm "hearth" for the stray dogs
Small colorful houses have been decorating Batumi lately. having too many stray dogs roaming in the city of Batumi, local Levan Chkhaidze decided to use his savings for the construction of the houses for the strays dogs. the important aspect of the idea, was to motivate other young people in the city to take care of the street dogs and engage more people in the process. luckily the idea was a success and many were interested in cooperation or support, some were donating money, while others donated material for construction, most of the times this was a leftover from constructions and household, which could go to waste, but instead , due to the Levans idea were used for the construction of dog houses. 
The innovative approach lays not in the construction of the houses per se, but in the approach of solving the problem in the city. particularly, houses constructed by Levan were provided in the areas, where citizens would take the responsibility to engage and take care of the stray dog roaming in the neighborhood. This included vaccination, feeding, etc. 
The dog house or as Levan calls it "hearth" documented on the below photo was placed near the Batumi State University, where students and academic staff took responsibility to take care of two stray dogs.
Overall the interest was so big from the community, that Levan decided to create a special facebook page to engage wider public. 
Local municipalities in Georgia fail to address the problem of stray dogs roaming in the streets of the cities and towns, moreover, it is not a rare find to see malnourished, abandoned dogs wondering on the main highways and roads. The problem is created not only by the lack of stray dog population management from the local self governments, but also by the citizens. particularly, it has become "fashionable" to own a dog, so most of the times families purchase dogs, without realizing the full responsibility. Thus, as a result of irresponsible decision, after some time, people realize that they no longer want or are capable of having a god, so they leave the animal in the street. 
the above mentioned project engages local communities in response to the described problem, ensuring that the stray dogs are vaccinated, sterilized and bring no harm to the locals. 
this case demonstrates an example how one persons idea can engage larger community to target the common problem and to some extent take over the problem solving function of the local municipality. this case is also a good example for crowdsourcing and crowdfunding. Moreover, the fact that waste materials are being used for the construction of the dog houses creates a value for waste and a better understanding among citizens on how it can be used.
pads.title: Lets build together - a warm "hearth" for the stray dogs

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - training tour guides
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and in consultation with the locals, devised a portfolio of solutions to promote sustainable tourism in CHT. One key problem identified is that there is a lack of trained tour guides who can cater to the different needs of tourists. To address this, trainings could be provided to tour guides. These would include high quality training on issues such as first aid, waste management options, skill training for informal workers etc. Location specific training for specific spots could also be provided taking into context the local culture. Do's and don'ts should be part of the training module. Specialised training should be provided to manage tourists with special needs, e.g., people with disabilities. The picture shows a training session organized by the Accelerator lab on emergency first aid.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - training tour guides

pads.content:
Using hides and skins as a business venture to maintain tradition “Lekshat”
Mauritanians eat a lot of meat. Animals are either slaughtered at home or at a slaughter house. The hides and skins of these animals are normally left to perish which causes a lot of pollution. Since a local market for raw hides and skins hardly exists in Mauritania, some groups of people are using these hides and skins to make local traditional products. The most prominent locally produced product from hides is the “Lekshat”. Lekshat is a local traditional leather belt used by men in Mauritania to tie the Sirwal (aerated baggy pant). The “Sirwal” goes with the Moorish boubou or Drâa which is a kind of long sheet with a hole in order to let the passage of the head, with two large opened sleeves in each side. In summer time, when it is very hot, sleeves can be rolled up until shoulders. Pockets are sewed in each side to allow men to put their personal effects in. Boubou can be worn on top of a “Sirwal”. The “Lekshat” and Sirwal is a long standing traditional dress by men in Mauritania.
This helps to ameliorate situations where people have nothing meaningful to engage in within their communities, by creating opportunities through the utilization of available unwanted resources in the community such as animal hides and skins. It helps to foster a safer and more prosperous country where people are seen as active player in moving their own developmental plans forward in partnership with like-minds. It’s also, a source of livelihood and empowerment from community waste.
There is greater socio-economic potential in the hides and skins value chain that could be exploited by establishing a modern production enterprise and take advantage of the opportunity. Leather is probably the most ancient fabric used by humans, and it’s a multi-billion dollar global industry. Demand for leather goods is growing but so is criticism of its severe environmental impact, which is driving a keen interest in sustainable alternatives.
pads.title: Using hides and skins as a business venture to maintain tradition “Lekshat”

pads.content:
Dust collector for drilling waste
The cable guy used a small plastic bag and a tape to fix a small dust collector under the drilling spot on a solid wall.
To leave a clean space after cable installments without the need for extra cleaning work
Customer satisfaction and user experience in service delivery is a concern for all sort of worker including blue collars

pads.content:
Informal and DIY gas stations in remote locations - Aisha
Throughout my daily route, I have come to notice the proliferate existence of small scale gas stations, or 'Pertamini' as they are called here in Indonesia, as a word play from the national energy company's name, Pertamina. These mini gas stations initially started as a collective initiative from various communities throughout Indonesia, utilizing jerry cans or reused bottles (such as those from alcoholic drinks), and are stacked in a wire rack by the side of the road, typically in remote locations. As the years go by, more modern products are developed and sold in the market, entitled 'Pertamini' or mini 'Pertamina' boxes, mimicking the large scale gas stations with their tubular storage, digital display and hose. As seen in the photos enclosed, currently there is a wide array of models available for purchase and usage, displayed in smaller roads. The main target market for these informal gas stations are mostly motorcycle riders, which travels covers to the utmost remote locations of Indonesia.
The sporadic initiative of utilizing jerry cans or used bottles in the early establishments of these small scale gas stations stemmed from the unmet need of fuel coverage for remote locations in Indonesia. As the biggest archipelago in the world, Indonesia is riddled with issues of increasing inequality, not limited to that of infrastructure and development. Thus, despite the unprecedented rate of urbanization, majority of its population still travels to remote locations to fulfill their daily necessities utilizing cars, motorcycles, and other types of vehicles. As the national energy company, Pertamina, only focuses on constructing large scale gas stations in various cities, it is challenging to cover rural areas with limited access and infrastructure. In order to further support daily activities of its population, several creative entrepreneurs started to purchase gas in jerry cans in order to include in their shops' range of products. They then gain profit from increasing the price slightly compared to that of the large gas stations and reaching the outskirts of cities. 
What started out as a seemingly scattered initiative to increase microentrepreneurs' profit, has turned into a collective movement that evolves in an accelerated pace. From employing available materials in the neighborhood, with the healthy competition among other business owners and growing need from the informal market, this particular innovation has even instigated 'proper' the importance of product design as a means to reach customers. This model has proven to be successful with the vast replication throughout Indonesia, with more developing advanced versions of the 'Pertamini' gas station. By accommodating basic mobility needs for majority of the population, this grassroot innovation has supported developments in different areas such as providing access to accessible transport systems, contributing to road safety, enabling access to school and healthcare, among others. If other communal pain points that span over the entire country's population can be identified and adeptly tackled, then the replication process could potentially occur naturally and its impact could be as in-depth as in this case study.
pads.title: Informal and DIY gas stations in remote locations - Aisha

pads.content:
self-emerged bazaar goes digital via Viber
A vendor of the self-emerged but currently formalized bazaar is using Viber messenger to showcase the products that cannot be presented immediately in the 'showroom'. 
Adopting Viber as a platform to advertise goods is a cheap and fast way for small and micro-businesses to retain the costumers and compete with large e-commerce platforms. Many vendors at the bazaar cannot afford a laptop and membership of the e-commerce platform, nor preparing a catalog of the goods they sell. This is when free texting apps come in handy. These apps run on the cheapest smartphones and do not require specific digital skills, nor knowledge of the language, which is an issue in the case of ethnic minorities that represent a large share of the labor force of the bazaar. 
As e-commerce takes a greater share in the economy, it becomes crucial for vendors to develop new tools to run the business. It is especially true now, during the Covid-19 pandemic, since costumers avoid going to the crowding bazaars. Free texting apps coupled with the cheapest smartphone can create a system that would allow the most vulnerable vendors to stay in the business and retain jobs.
pads.title: self-emerged bazaar goes digital via Viber

pads.content:
Homemade
Panama’s health ministry published the “sanitation guide for biosecurity for the operations of in-person retail post COVID-19 in Panama” on June 4th established that all shops must ensure that the infrastructure allows for 2 meters of social distancing. In cases where this is impossible or hinders commerce (e.g. when paying for items or needing to interact on close quarters with staff/shoppers) additional protection measures or barriers must be put in place to avoid potential contagion (acrylic screens or similar). It appears that shop owners have freely interpreted the “similar”, as not all stores erected acrylic screens, but rather crafted own methods of barriers, using saran wrap, plastic films or plastic covers resembling mattress covers, and fixing these to curtain rods, soda crates, and ceiling lights, with holes cut into them to facilitate payments or handling of product.
These creations answer the need to adhere to national sanitation guidelines in an effective and low-cost manner. When asked, shop owners have commented that building these fixtures allowed them to reopen. Unless shops have put in place all sanitation requirements, they remain closed for presential business. However, availability and cost are a barrier to buying ready-made plexiglass fronts which usually function as security measures in larger shops.
As one can observe in the pictures, not only retail shop owners but also street barbers (iconic establishments in this area of Panama), individual street vendors as well as “fondas” (food stalls offering home-cooked meals) have installed these homemade biosecurity barriers in their establishments. These barriers are furthermore only one part of a chain of homemade solutions to keep their businesses alive, which include Lysol-drained foot mats in plastic pails for customers to disinfect their shoes prior to entering, homemade disinfectant constructions and proposing digital payment methods or venturing into e-commerce (please view the other solution safari outputs to learn more).
It appears the city’s hard lockdown of almost 5 months (including the locking down of most stores) has fueled small business owners ́ creativity to adapt to the current conditions to survive the economic plunge the country’s been in for most of the year.
pads.title: Homemade

pads.content:
Micro-business sustainability in the informal sector during COVID-19 in Bangladesh.
During COVID-19 outbreak, most of the restaurants in Dhaka were closed. The restaurants in Bashundhara Shopping Mall (one of the prominent shopping mall in the capital) were closed for 88 days. Consequently, around 80% staff moved to the village. 
In the case of a restaurant, it was found that there were 16 staff in total among whom 13 staff migrated to their local area. Observing the potential of long-term effect of COVID, the restaurant owner was worried and thinking about how he can save the qualified staff and at the same time continue his business in the crisis situation. 
After a few days, he started an alternate restaurant at comparatively a remote area where the infection was lower but the demand of foods was higher. He employed 10 of his staff who were experienced and qualified at the new restaurant and continued the business. 
This alternate business helped him to,
- continue earning
- sustain his business amid the pandemic
- maintain the livelihood of his staff
- hold the experienced staff
- made the restaurant confident to fight against a global crisis
- continuing teamwork.
After around 3 months when the COVID situation improved a bit, he was able to return to the previous business at the same shopping mall in Dhaka while may of his fellow colleagues lost their business.
His alternate business helped him to return to his previous business; save the qualified staff and save the lives of those staff and their respective families.
Continuation of business, income and livelihood amidst a global crisis.
Sources of demand are the main strength.
1. How to ensure long-term business sustainability by introducing new innovation.
2. Integration of demand and resources (new demand in the semi-urban + job creation for experienced staff + livelihood for family members).
3. Experienced team can grow, can manage and can recover.
pads.title: Micro-business sustainability in the informal sector during COVID-19 in Bangladesh.

pads.content:
Choose your Light
Years of unstable electricity has led many Syrians to seek alternative solutions. One that is perhaps the most innovative involves using the existing house wiring network and an old car battery to setup a complete lighting backup system. This allowed the position of the light source to remain the same. Some homes use old truck batteries to further support a TV and a fridge. Interestingly, the fact that only LED lights (for power consumption) can run on these parallel systems, most users also switched their mainstream lighting to LED. 
Backup lighting and power during load shedding. 
How using existing networks and assets with some technical upgrades can create a decentralized backup solution.
pads.title: Choose your Light

pads.content:
Creating personal bonds between green public spaces and citizens
On one of our daily walks with my gf, we noticed that our favorite street in the city, has 'name tags' on the trees crown with names from what appeared to be people from the city. We both thought it was a very cute initiative and began talking about the intended effects from it. We latter learned that there are several initiatives like this one, spearheaded by the administration of the city of Skopje. Bellow is a photo illustration from one of those initiatives.
The official interpretation for this action [as suggested by the administration of the city of Skopje] is that it creates bonds between the citizens and the green spaces in the city. Moreover, the City of Skopje in the past 10 years has seen massive deforestation of the city’s green areas due to building activities. The rates are astonishing and if Skopje in the turn of the new millennium was considered a green city with 75.649 m2 green areas that have decreased today to only 18.680 m2 green areas. Today the city of Skopje has 40% less trees per capita than the EU average. 
In addition to that, our team’s interpretation is that: for a city where ‘green spaces’ are a scarcity this tool can also serve as a public awareness campaign about the importance of green public spaces for the sustainability of cities.
From this observation we can learn that in order for some initiatives to work you have to have the people/public’s buy-in, or sense of belonging in the initiative/or project.
pads.title: Creating personal bonds between green public spaces and citizens

They use an abundant, and local resource and turn them into a local industry. People in neighbor counties often come to Guatajiagua to learn about the process. Their idea went from product to services
pads.title: Nacazcol seeds as a natural colorant

pads.content:
Foot operated hydroalcoholic gel dispenser
At first I was intrigued on the use of piping as a structure to hold the gel bottle, but then, when examining the pipes assembling, realized its function, pushed the lower bar with my foot, and it worked, gel was out! I thought it was very clever to use the spring that already comes in the bottle nozzle as the basic functioning element that enables its working mechanism.
With recent opening of commercial operations amidst COVID-19 pandemic, 
entrepreneurs are finding ways to reinforce their biosecurity protocols 
while making costumers feel safe, but sometimes the implementation of 
these measures can be costly. 
This is the case of this small restaurant in the rural area of San Salvador, which has resorted to using PVC piping used for plumbing instead of buying a commercial solution, to build this hydroalcoholic gel dispenser, which is foot operated, thus reducing the risk for covid infection due to drops in surfaces, and also saving costs. The whole mechanism is based in the bottle's own embedded spring in the nozzle.
Everday objects or ready-made solutions, can serve as the base for incremental iterations, while saving resources as not everything has to be made from scratch.
pads.title: Foot operated hydroalcoholic gel dispenser

pads.content:
Gatavai (Samoa) Youth Tyre'd but Upcycled!
The recycling enterprise of the Gatavai Village Youths is led by its Church Minister who created the initiative to address the rising youth unemployment rate in its village. In addition, the motivation behind the social enterprise was to also cater to and assist the youth of the Gatavai village to care for their families particularly the unemployed males. The initiative produces 2 types of recycled outdoor furniture i.e. upcycled tyre outdoor furniture and natural outdoor furniture made from discarded wood/tree cuttings. The Gatavai furniture sells for $500 a set (including its tyre furniture which are all sold out) and make about $300 in profit given that most of the resources used are recycled or secondhand materials. 
Some challenges to the upscaling of this initiative includes but is not limited to the following i.e.
· Limited marketing capabilities means that the enterprise does not have a foothold in the current market share to promote its products to all of Samoa; and
· Limited time and resources of the Church Minister to conduct continuous training of its young people in the trade skills necessary to create its products.
There are about 92-95 young males involved in this social enterprise. 20 young men assist with the Gatavai Youth Recycle Enterprise. In addition to recycling and upcycling tyres, they also reuse discarded wood/tree
cuttings to construct natural outdoor furniture. The enterprise not only provide income generation and trade skills capacity building but it also contributes to mitigating climate change by promoting and preventing the
burning of tyres in the communities.
The Gatavai Village Youth Social Enterprise is an example of community cohesion and its impact on a larger scale. The enterprise is largely supported in kind by its Church Minister and Village Council and due to its primary business of collecting old and used tyres for its recycling, this has enabled its youth population to promote and push for eco-friendly land clearing practices for agricultural purposes as opposed to families burning the tyres as a method to clear land of vegetation and so forth. In addition, the enterprise has garnered support from its local mechanics and have formed partnerships where the local initiative are able to procure its tyres from the local mechanics who collect and set aside allocated quantities for the enterprise. 
Gatavai is a village located on the biggest island that comprises Samoa called Savaii. To get to Gatavai, Savaii, one must take a ferry trip across the ocean that takes about 1.5 hours. Pictured also are some of the outdoor furniture that the youths create from discarded wood/tree cuttings.
pads.title: Gatavai (Samoa) Youth Tyre'd but Upcycled!

pads.content:
Solar Power for life 
An increased number of household and local businesses ,located in rural areas in Hama, Syria, are installing solar power plants to compensate for the lack of electricity or the long power cuts. The solar plants are considered to be an affordable solution that has multiple uses in these rural areas: They are for example used to power irrigation system, household appliances, heating systems, and poultry farming. People said that for them they are much cheaper than fuel powered plants and more sustainable as they provide free power for around 12 hours daily and the average life of solar plants are around 20 years.
secured livelihood, affordable power source
These kind of solutions, contrary to popular notion, are applicable in small remote villages. villagers have the awareness and the willingness to apply such solutions and maintain them. All what they need is small financial assistance.
pads.title: Solar Power for life

pads.content:
Irrigation with vessels

Millennial system that requires no energy and uses only the water that plants need. In addition, it employs artisans, contributes to food security, is cheap and biodegradable.
Through a system of transpiration, the vessels provide the necessary water to the plants that settle near them. The plants use the water they need and have a reserve at their fingertips, which allows them to reduce water stress in the dry season. 
It uses millenary technologies that allow to reduce water consumption and have no negative environmental impact.
pads.title: Irrigation with vessels

pads.content:
Floating Root System

In this method, the plants are found in a sheet or raft – usually made of duroport – that floats on top of the nutrient solution, so that their roots are immersed within the solution. An air pump provides the roots with the oxygen necessary for their optimal development. 
Only one water base is used for all plants. The nutrient solution is regulated directly in the water tank.
pads.title: Floating Root System

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - addressing language barrier
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. Language barrier acts as a limitation for communication among the tourists and the locals, as the local indigenous people speak a plethora of different tribal languages and the predominantly Bengali tourists speak Bangla. To address this challenge, language training could be provided for the local tour guides in collaboration with Bangladesh Tourism Board. The picture shows one such pilot training organized by the Accelerator Lab Bangladesh.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - addressing language barrier

pads.content:
Spatial design interventions in housing for change in behaviors related to gender norms - House 2 
Portfolio of Experimentation on Gender Norms, Patriarchy and Masculinities 
Gender norms -which emerged from a patriarchal system of rule that is intertwined with masculine ideologies -create social injustices for people around the world. We are testing (whether?) different ways to challenge the patriarchal system, masculine ideologies, and gender norms in Jordan, to see whether they can carve out a space for new systems/ways? of pursuing gender and social justice in the development sector. After the completion of the first experiment as part of the Lab's work on gender and reflecting on the lessons learned, we looked for local initiatives already working on a similar topic. This exploration led us to a collaboration with a new type of partner for upcoming experiments on challenging gender norms -with Basmitak Hat'alem (SAIB) on the effect of spatial design on behavior related to gender norms. After conducting participatory behavioral research on three households, different situations were observed. In some cases, there was a traditional division of gender roles, reflected in the spaces that members spend time in and the chores they do. Others times, positive gender norms were observed, where both male and female family members are taking part in the chores and also spending time in different spaces in the house. The observed positive behaviors were considered potential "solutions" to further explore. 
Theory of Change
If spatial changes were made in houses with negative gender exclusive spaces, then these interventions will positively change the behavior family members towards more equitable gender norms/roles
Remarks & Challenges 1 Entrances of the bedrooms, WC, and the kitchen are exposed to an open to above court. 2 Lack of privacy 3 Poor Psychological well-being 4 5 Mold causes skin diseases. The house is surrounded by other houses on two sides (shared walls) and to a narrow ventilation space from the back. 
Positive points to exploit and develop (Opportunities): The positive gendered spaces. Both the mother and the father contribute to the chores: Focusing on the father (making him an icon and role model for the rest of (males) in the camp). 
Objectives 1 Allocate space for the parents sleeping and the other children in separate rooms (privacy). 2 Allocate play space for the children 3 Connect the bathroom, bedrooms, and kitchen under a buffer zone with a rooftop 
Spatial interventions 1 Rearrange the room of the eldest daughter so that two other daughters can be included in the same room. (Interior design) 2 Solve the problem of the open to above court. 3 Open the kitchen to the living room. 4 Placing a tea corner and a (mini-fridge) in the guest room. 
TBD 1 2 Configure the girls' room to allow adding two extra beds. (Buying new furniture). The location of the bathroom (besides the court, or behind the guest room) will be determined later when the measurements are taken.
pads.title: Spatial design interventions in housing for change in behaviors related to gender norms - House 2

pads.content:
Spatial design interventions in housing for change in behaviors related to gender norms - House 3 
Portfolio of Experimentation on Gender Norms, Patriarchy and Masculinities 
Gender norms -which emerged from a patriarchal system of rule that is intertwined with masculine ideologies -create social injustices for people around the world. We are testing (whether?) different ways to challenge the patriarchal system, masculine ideologies, and gender norms in Jordan, to see whether they can carve out a space for new systems/ways? of pursuing gender and social justice in the development sector. After the completion of the first experiment as part of the Lab's work on gender and reflecting on the lessons learned, we looked for local initiatives already working on a similar topic. This exploration led us to a collaboration with a new type of partner for upcoming experiments on challenging gender norms -with Basmitak Hat'alem (SAIB) on the effect of spatial design on behavior related to gender norms. After conducting participatory behavioral research on three households, different situations were observed. In some cases, there was a traditional division of gender roles, reflected in the spaces that members spend time in and the chores they do. Others times, positive gender norms were observed, where both male and female family members are taking part in the chores and also spending time in different spaces in the house. The observed positive behaviors were considered potential "solutions" to further explore. 
Theory of Change
If spatial changes were made in houses with negative gender exclusive spaces, then these interventions will positively change the behavior family members towards more equitable gender norms/roles
Remarks & Challenges 1 Psychological wellbeing of Females is poor. 2 Poor ventilation in the kitchen 3 There is no significant role for males (complete dependence on females) 4 5 The eldest daughter is highly expected to leave school because of her father. An early marriage is also expected. Absence of family social activities that bring male and female family members in one place and time. 
Risks: The walls and structure of the house are very weak. The building is old and any intervention to the structural elements might collapse the exterior shell and rooftop. 
Objectives 1 Redesign the court to be a more gender-inclusive space for the male and female family members. 2 Provide the physical elements “objects” that would promote a better studying environment for the daughter. 
Interventions 1 2 Designing a tea corner, a cupboard, and a mini-fridge in the court. Rehabilitate the court area. (walls, ceiling, flooring?)
pads.title: Spatial design interventions in housing for change in behaviors related to gender norms - House 3

pads.content:
Sign-IO: Smart gloves that convert sign language into audio
Roy Allela, a 25-year-old engineering student invented smart gloves that he has named Sign-IO. The smart gloves auto-translate sign language into speech. The innovative student created the pair of gloves equipped with flex sensors in order to communicate with his niece who is deaf.
The smart gloves have flex sensors stitched on each finger. The sensors quantify the bend of the fingers and process the letter being signed. The gloves are then paired via Bluetooth to an app which vocalizes the letters. The gloves which can prove useful to over 30 million people across the world have an accuracy of 93 percent. The smart gloves can be customized into different superhero themes, thereby eliminating the stigma associated with deafness.
pads.title: Sign-IO: Smart gloves that convert sign language into audio

The duo came up with the automated machine to eliminate the use of herbicides by farmers making the implication of this technology on the environment a momentous one. The robot discriminates between weeds and crops through cameras and uses the same cameras to navigate through the farm, in between rows of crops.
