pads.content:
Open Street Map Fiji
Open Street Map Fiji is a local volunteer group that promotes community mapping in Fiji using geospatial tools such as OpenStreetMap. OSM Fiji’s work is focused on Disaster Risk Resilience (DRR), through coordinated workshops.
https://openstreetmapfiji.com/
https://www.facebook.com/OSM-Fiji-110457007776664
pads.title: Open Street Map Fiji

pads.content:
Organic Fertilizer—Re-purposing Industrial Food Waste
Description: Locally produced organic fertilizer by OrganicPlus Fiji, made from organic materials that may have otherwise ended up in landfills.
https://www.facebook.com/organicplusfiji
https://fijisun.com.fj/2021/03/18/baywater-engineering-joins-fijian-organic/
pads.title: Organic Fertilizer—Re-purposing Industrial Food Waste

pads.content:
Aeroponics System

Technique in which the roots are suspended in the air, within a dark medium, and watered with nutrient solution in frequency of a few minutes. Although it is a highly efficient technique, the roots can quickly dry out irrigation cycles are disrupted. 
It is watered directly to the root and the roots do not need to be in contact with water directly.
pads.title: Aeroponics System

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - branding areas
1. Tourists visiting the CHT region often do not know the specific unique features of the areas they are seeing, which makes the areas less interesting than they could be. There is scope to innovate via sub district level branding of specific areas such as Thanchi to introduce those areas to potential tourists, highlighting the specific attributes of those areas. The best practices and good practices from different locations should be identified and replicated in other locations. The picture shows a discussion organized by the Accelerator Lab on this topic with the local government representatives and the tour operators association of Cox Bazaar.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - branding areas

pads.content:
Drip Irrigation

In these irrigation systems, a timer controls a pump that causes the nutrient solution to drip onto the bottom of the plants. In some of these systems, it is possible to recover excess nutrient solution for reuse, while in others excess solution is discarded.
It is a hydroponic system where it is necessary to have soil to cultivate, but the water is used very efficiently.
pads.title: Drip Irrigation

pads.content:
Plastic Shredder-Fuel
Shredding plastics in pieces which will then be melted in fuel through a pyrolysis process.
pads.title: Plastic Shredder-Fuel

pads.content:
Ebb and Flow System

In a ebb and flow system, plant pots are temporarily flooded with nutrient solution and then drained back into the reservoir.
The flow is caused by a pump connected to a timer that is activated several times a day. When it stops working, the solution flows back into the tank. 
The nutrient solution can be used many times, as it only floods the pots for a specific time and then returns to the reservoir.
pads.title: Ebb and Flow System

pads.content:
Mobile Shops
Trucks carrying goods from urban area act as mobile shop to indigenous communities who live in rural and remote area. This was especially crucial during MCO when supply chain and logistics were cut off. While some urbanites may think that the Orang Asli live solely off their lands & forests, the reality is that many are also dependent on such mobile shops in lorries & cars that come daily or every other day to villages in rural & even interior areas. These mobile shops sell mainly provisions, dry goods, snacks, hardy vegetables plus fresh & dried fish - and occasionally chicken offal & parts. The proprietor is often well-known to villages as they ply their trade for many years. Some even provide a line of credit to those they trust.
pads.title: Mobile Shops

pads.content:
Rock Wool

Rock or mineral wool can retain large amounts of water and air that aid root growth and nutrient absorption in hydroponics; Its fibrous nature also provides a good mechanical structure to keep the plant stable. The naturally elevated pH of mineral wools makes them initially unsuitable for plant growth and requires "conditioning".
Rockwool is usually used only in the seedling phase or with freshly cut clones, but can remain with the base of the plant throughout its life.
pads.title: Rock Wool

pads.content:
Battery Pack C13
A rechargeable battery pack which is a low-voltage, environment-friendly innovation that replaces conventional electrical generators. It is targeted to help mobile entrepreneurs save on their power generation costs with the benefits of affordability, portability and low maintenance costs.
pads.title: Battery Pack C13

pads.content:
Serunding Lumek Salai (Preserved Fish)
A two-pronged initiative that combines food technology innovation and social innovation. It is based on smoked “lumek” fish, predominantly found in the waters surrounding Bruit Island in Sarawak. The project provides the community of Bruit Island economic and social benefits while the innovators have also introduced a healthy, delicious and calcium-rich delicacy that is produced through innovative processing techniques, healthy cooking and modern packaging to preserve its freshness.
pads.title: Serunding Lumek Salai (Preserved Fish)

pads.content:
Naget Ubi Kayu Sejuk Beku (Cassave Nugget Preparation)
A nutritious, multi-flavoured cassava nugget preparation. The innovation successfully combines the study of food chemistry and modern food processing techniques to create a healthy and conveniently-prepared dish or meal accompaniment that is loved across all generations.
pads.title: Naget Ubi Kayu Sejuk Beku (Cassave Nugget Preparation)

pads.content:
Galah Tuis (Fruit Harvesting Pole)
This handy tool enables fruits to be swiftly and easily wrapped directly on tree branches without the need to climb up trees. The innovation protects damage to ripening fruits caused by birds, insects and tree-climbing animals such as squirrels while also reducing the risk of accidents from falling off trees. It is easy to use with minimal maintenance costs.
pads.title: Galah Tuis (Fruit Harvesting Pole)

pads.content:
Toolkit Seni Cungkilan Kayu (Toolkit for Woodworking)
The toolkit is a boost for local artist-preneurs. It encompasses a modular technical training system that incorporates wood-carving equipment with video training and woodcraft manual. It hones professional wood-carving skills in schools and other grassroots communities, while promoting an interest in traditional woodcraft as a creative and sustainable business model.
pads.title: Toolkit Seni Cungkilan Kayu (Toolkit for Woodworking)

pads.content:
MyTaman (Resident Security App)
Smart app that provides instant connection to the security when emergency arises. The app allows for registration to any resident association. Notifications are sent to security guards as well as other residents with the exact location of the emergency. It also allows for other function like visitor pas using their national ID to prevent unidentified strangers from entering the vicinity. It also allows for notification on community activities and events.
pads.title: MyTaman (Resident Security App)

pads.content:
Vegetable Noodles
The noodles made from vegetable (pumpkins, mustard, spinach, carrots) offers a healthier option to conventional noodles (lined with alkaline, natrium hydorside and natrium silicate and high in carbohydrates). The noodle is high in Ferum which is crucial for brain development. The aim is to reduce chemical infusion that often causes growth and cancerous cells.
pads.title: Vegetable Noodles

pads.content:
Nano Maker Kit
Robotic set for students to learn STEM at a low cost and applied to different science theory and model application.
pads.title: Nano Maker Kit

pads.content:
Afforable Wheelchairs
Adjustable wheelchair based on specifications, locally ensembled wheelchair sold at an affordable price. Designed by a PWD to help other PWD, as well as increase the employability of PWD.
pads.title: Afforable Wheelchairs

pads.content:
Kundasang Aquafarm
Environmentally friendly multistorey aquaponic that requires lower level of land and do not require slopes for better irrigation and yield. Saves 90% of water, no fertilisation and chemical needed for good yield. Fishes are reared as well as a cycle of nutrients. Espeiclaly useful for small space and low capital.
pads.title: Kundasang Aquafarm

pads.content:
Efinity Ez Water Filter Cap
Mobile pump to generate water pressure to operate water filter system, without needing high electricity and infrastructure cost.
pads.title: Efinity Ez Water Filter Cap

pads.content:
Rice Husk Separator
Ideal in size, cost and able to function at mountaineous range.
pads.title: Rice Husk Separator

pads.content:
Heyle bariise technical development
foot operated hand washing stations
pads.title: Heyle bariise technical development

pads.content:
Express Sewing Ruler
Combining multiple tailor rulers into one to speed up measurements for tailoring. Speeds up the ability for new students to learn sewing.
pads.title: Express Sewing Ruler

pads.content:
Low Cost 3D Printer
3D Printer that is of lower maintenance and price, allowing for more entrepreneurship to own it at home and for schools and children to use them for learning in school. Focus is to improve TVET skills among B40 groups.
pads.title: Low Cost 3D Printer

pads.content:
Education Material Tool Kits 
Teach for Malaysia (a Malaysian Non-Profit Organisation) sends monthly box of resources to hard-to-reach students in rural areas. Purpose is to invest in educational recovery to ensure that the long term effects of the pandemic is minimized, especially for rural and remote communities that lack digital access.
pads.title: Education Material Tool Kits

pads.content:
Personal Protective Equipment - Mask Extender
A soft beautiful face mask adapter to help Muslim woman to easily wear face mask while wearing a hijab. It's adjustable and helps women to abide by the new normal. Sewn by a youth during movement control Order at the height of the pandemic.
pads.title: Personal Protective Equipment - Mask Extender

pads.content:
Online Prayers Service for Elderly 
Created an online community to help elderly attend prayers and reading of Quran during COVID-19 MCO as mosques are closed. The session is held with user-friendly application by a youth to help people practice their religion under a lockdown.
pads.title: Online Prayers Service for Elderly

pads.content:
Spare Part Buggy
The Buggy was build by vehicle spare parts that helps to transport residents and goods around the rural village.
pads.title: Spare Part Buggy

pads.content:
Solar-Powered Buggy 
Buggy powered by solar panels was built during MCO as petrol delivery into the rural areas were limited and scarce. Transport of goods from urban to villages were also disrupted and the buggy helps to transport between neighborhood. The four solar batteries provide 1000aH and can last for 3 days without recharging.
pads.title: Solar-Powered Buggy

pads.content:
Solar Electricity Recharge Station
A solar powered charging station was built and designed so that devices can be charged outdoors and in an environmentally friendly way. This system converts solar energy to electricity and stores it in a battery bank.
pads.title: Solar Electricity Recharge Station

pads.content:
Improvised Aquaponic System 
Aquaponic system was built using the materials available in the vicinity during the Movement Control Order (MCO). It was set up in the rural area and low-cost residences to provide food subsistence especially during MCO. THis was done in preparation of future crisis when supply chain will be disrupted.
pads.title: Improvised Aquaponic System

pads.content:
Low Cost Sanitizer Tent
A sanitizer tent was built and it consists of pipping and mist sprayer system, LED lighting, pressurized liquid tank, solar panel and controller, and geomembrane walling. Materials used were materials found at the centre including scavenged parts from pile of junk (Obtainium) that was accumulated over time. This was especially useful during the Movement Control Order (MCO) when rural and remote communities are not able to travel outward to get materials for sanitization. However, standard guidelines from Ministry of Health needs to be followed to ensure it is safe to be used.
pads.title: Low Cost Sanitizer Tent

pads.content:
Solar-Powered Hydroponic
Solar powered hydroponic system that helps to turn the water pam on and off without relying on energy. Electricity is inconsistent in rural areas due to the reliance on petrol to power up generator sets.
pads.title: Solar-Powered Hydroponic

pads.content:
Rain Collecting Mist Sprayer
The water tank collects rain water and is then connected to a mist spraying system that automatically waters the vegetation around the house.
pads.title: Rain Collecting Mist Sprayer

pads.content:
Hygiene Kit in Elevators
To minimize contact among residents in the elevator, a makeshift toothpick holder made from polystyrene foam was made for users to press the buttons.
pads.title: Hygiene Kit in Elevators

pads.content:
Solar-Powered Water Pump
Solar-powered water pump to help provide water to all households during MCO without relying on grid electricity or expensive infrastructures. Grid electricities in rural communities often breaks down due to the reliance on fuel and generator sets.
pads.title: Solar-Powered Water Pump

pads.content:
Spare Part Harvey
A motorcycle prototype built using spare parts from old vehicles. This prototype serves the vision of a circular economy. It allows mobility at the last mile and basic access to transportation in an affordable manner for rural and remote communities.
pads.title: Spare Part Harvey

pads.content:
Rocket Stove
Rocket Stove that saves energy and reduces pollution. It also helped protect the health of the women and community from respiratory diseases. The rocket stove was powered by pyrolysis plastic fuel during the Movement Control Order (MCO) due to lack of supplies.
pads.title: Rocket Stove

pads.content:
ML subsea monitoring platform 
Bluemvmt changes the price/performance curve in the marine monitoring industry by providing a cost-effective hardware/software solution that combines an innovative subsea monitoring platform (SMP) allowing Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) to dock and upload data and recharge without needing to resurface. The data collected from the large array of sensors, hydrophones, acoustic modems, and cameras are uploaded in real-time to our Blue/AI Cloud. The software measures, tracks and reports on Land, Sea and Sky sensor streams and correlates them. The unique business model reduces their total cost of ownership for our customers over time through a unique revenue sharing program.

https://www.bluemvmt.com/solution
pads.title: ML subsea monitoring platform

pads.content:
Solar Photovaltaic
Solar Photovoltaic to power villages when draught happens and micro-hydro are unable to function.
pads.title: Solar Photovaltaic

pads.content:
Stingless Bee Honey Harvest
Stingless Bee Kelulut Honey Harvesting using homemade burrows. The honey is then packaged and sold as source of income to tourist.
pads.title: Stingless Bee Honey Harvest

pads.content:
Invasive Species Lake to Eco-tourism Homestay
To sustain the biodiversity and natural resources for livelihood, local communities have put in close to 15 years continuous effort to fight invasive plants (Salvinia - the yellowish plants in the pic) from taking over their lake. Various methods and innovations were unearthed along the way, from waterweed harvesters, chemical application, to biocontrol (moth, grasshopper, tiny weevil) . Miso Walai Homestay and Campsites were also build to promote ecotourism that generates income for the community. River cruise, wildlife watch and tree planting activities are among other relaxing nature activities tourists get to enjoy.
pads.title: Invasive Species Lake to Eco-tourism Homestay

pads.content:
Asher
The problem
Solid waste is a damaging problem to a lot of countries. Malaysia faces a bigger challenge for being a dumping ground which has caused severe land and air pollution. The current waste management scenario in Malaysia looks at the increased consumption and waste generation, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, the usage of oil and petroleum which produce carbon monoxide and the waste compactor trucks also result in environmental issues due to factors such as traffic congestion, rubbish, wastewater and vehicle emissions.
The solution
Asher is a 6-metre-tall machine that can reduce most solid waste materials to ash. Waste is put into the Asher and ends up in the thermal degradation chamber where it will decompose via the pyrolysis process. The heat generated from the process is sustained only within the chamber and waste are left to dry, become brittle and eventually turns into ash. The only byproduct of Asher is odourless and neutral vapor. 
The Asher modern incinerator has 3 models- the A200S, A250ES, and A400ES which have differences in waste capacity, electric system, and the number of filters. The idea of this machine is to eliminate the waste distribution system and reduce the landfill by treating the waste at its source.
The Asher incinerator machine consists of 3 parts- loading area, electrical (fan and system), and filter & process. To start the initial burn, it requires a wood pallet to increase the heat from room temperature to 600 degrees Celsius. It takes around an hour to treat one batch (per chamber of waste ~ 0.6 m3) of waste, and the ash can be used as a soil conditioner/construction material. It requires continuous feeding of waste for ideally 16 to 18 hours for it to maintain the temperature of the Asher.
The machine is able to destroy various kinds of waste including plastics, electronic waste and rubber with the exception of glass, metals and construction materials. 
The machine is also small enough, the size of one car park, for it to be placed at a low cost residential neighborhood without it travelling to various waste stations.
pads.title: Asher

pads.content:
Grassroot Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)
Plastic bottles, bags and files were made to protect front liners and also improvised by individuals when PPEs were in shortage.
pads.title: Grassroot Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

pads.content:
Coconut Fiber

Coconut fiber is a material that is extracted from coconuts, in order to reuse the organic matter that remains as waste when extracting the edible part of the coconut. It is very good for hydroponics as it retains moisture and is not compacted, which guarantees that there is oxygen, and that water circulates correctly throughout the crop.
Eventually it degrades and it is necessary to periodically change the substrate of hydroponic crops. One of the advantages of this product is that it can be obtained at a lower cost than other substrates, due to the fact of being extracted from a waste.
pads.title: Coconut Fiber

pads.content:
Non-Contact Testing Station
To keep health worker safe while testing for COVID-19 patients. Made by a local public university, University Malaya at the height of COVID-19 cases, with other 3D printing company.
pads.title: Non-Contact Testing Station

pads.content:
Shelter Service for Homeless during COVID-19
Shelter were provided in community halls, sports recreation centers to allow for the homeless to keep safe from COVID-19 and not spread it to the places that they are in contact, as well as to prevent further vulnerability. Employment were further provided for the homeless.
pads.title: Shelter Service for Homeless during COVID-19

pads.content:
Drone Pesticide Sprayer
Agriculture drones can usually carry up to 10kg of pesticide and cover a hectare of a rice paddy field in half an hour. A manual labourer would take five hours to do the same task. Besides that, farmers prefer spraying using drones because the pesticide spreads out more evenly, which increases their yields compared to the normal practice of using pumps. Farmers can now spray up to 10 hectares of paddy fields a day, while charging between RM12 to RM20 for every 0.29 hectare of paddy field.
The youth said he has made up to RM5,000 a month and has been receiving more requests from Yan and Alor Star, which are more than 30 minutes away from his village.
pads.title: Drone Pesticide Sprayer

pads.content:
Pipes as Plant Crawlers
Water pipes were used as crawlers for creeper plants by the hotel gardener due to the lack of budget. Improvisations were made.
pads.title: Pipes as Plant Crawlers

pads.content:
Plastic Bottles Recycled Christmas Tree and Lights
Hotel plastic water bottles were reused as Christmas decorations. They have since reduced use of plastic bottles and changed to refillable water dispenser for events instead.
pads.title: Plastic Bottles Recycled Christmas Tree and Lights

pads.content:
Treetop Hut for Better Internet Access
Student, Veveonah in rural area climbed up tree for better internet to prepare for her exams, with a mosquito net to protect from mosquito bites. She has documented other traditional knowledge in coping with the lack of infrastructure in her community. The videos she made on the treetop have since garnered attention from government ministries on improving internet infrastructure and connectivity in Sabah.
pads.title: Treetop Hut for Better Internet Access

pads.content: Cut-Out Celebrity Cardboards and Mannequins for Social Distancing
pads.title: Cut-Out Celebrity Cardboards and Mannequins for Social Distancing

pads.content:
Special Service and Hours for Disabled, Elderly etc
Grocery stores allocate special hours for people with disability and elderly during Movement Control Order to cater to the needs of vulnerable groups, to ensure they have equal access and supply to basic needs and without rushing with the crowd.
pads.title: Special Service and Hours for Disabled, Elderly etc

pads.content:
Rattan-weaved Ball with Bell for Cats
Miniature rattan “sepak raga” balls with bells made by Dusun women from the Misompuru Muru Buru group of Kg Gansurai in Kota Belud, Sabah. These were specifically designed for cats, though the weavers were initially unsure if it would work. Both the versions with bells (RM7.50 each) and plain (RM5) are not varnished and safe for cats to chase, bite & claw.
pads.title: Rattan-weaved Ball with Bell for Cats

pads.content:
Filter Straw

It is a method to filter any type of water. The straw can filter from the water coming out of the jet, to water from river, lake or wells. It is ideal for communities that do not have access to piped water and the bodies of water to which they have access are contaminated.
It is portable, so it can be taken to very remote communities.
pads.title: Filter Straw

pads.content:
Water Dispenser for Hand Wash
The schools in remote areas serving mostly indigenous groups help reinforce the new norms by preparing a water dispenser using a rubbish bin improvise with a tap at the bottom for students to wash their hands. Soaps were kept in soft drink bottles punctured with a hole for them to wash their hands.
pads.title: Water Dispenser for Hand Wash

pads.content:
Recycled Plastic to Renewable Energy Turbine
Plastics are recycled for pyrolysis to produce turbine micro-hydro from HDPE plastic. This initiative is done under a social enterprise in Sabah to provide rural electrification at a sustainable cost and using community model to maintain the infrastructure. The organization name is TONIBUNG- CREATE
pads.title: Recycled Plastic to Renewable Energy Turbine

pads.content:
Enzyme Cleaner
Homemade enzymes cleaner fermented out of food peels and brown sugar. It was an initiative shared in the resident association.
pads.title: Enzyme Cleaner

pads.content:
SRI (Systematic Rice Intensification)
SRI (SYSTEM OF RICE INTENSIFICATION) is a method of planting which increases yield but reduces emissions because 40% less water. It has been tested and is successfully doing it. Progressive innovations includes bringing in fish, duck rearing to be part of SRI ecosystem. Currently done by one of our grantees called Forever Sabah.
pads.title: SRI (Systematic Rice Intensification)

pads.content:
Recycled Item for Public Infrastructure
Old drains and construction concrete slabs were reused as public benches in the heart of city.
pads.title: Recycled Item for Public Infrastructure

pads.content:
Recycled Plastics as Bricks and Furniture
Ezplast is a company that serve the environment and committed to giving back community by buying plastic waste as an additional income to community. Eco-bricks are made of recycled plastics to a set density to create reusable building blocks for making modular furniture, garden spaces and even full-scale buildings such as schools and houses.
pads.title: Recycled Plastics as Bricks and Furniture

pads.content:
Recycled Glass as Road Pavements
Glass bottles were crushed and and restructured to pave roads. The initiative was done in a rural community that practices circular economy and prevent pollution of waste in rivers. It is organized by Ripple or Persatuan Kitar Semula Sabah. The chairperson is Mdm Anne Lasimbang. Many are interested to give their bottles for this initiative.
pads.title: Recycled Glass as Road Pavements

pads.content:
Micro Hydro Electric
Micro hydro electric to provide power source to the rural communities without relying on electricity /generator sets. It's more environment friendly, lower cost and does not damage the environment like bigger dams does. This is a community model that rural electrification uses together with solar power to interchange between monsoon seasons and dry season.
pads.title: Micro Hydro Electric

pads.content:
Social Enterprise Develops Sustainable Conservation Solutions
Animal Projects & Environmental Education Sdn. Bhd. (APE Malaysia) is an organization that that works collaboratively with stakeholders to develop sustainable conservation solutions. People and organizations can become involved in these projects either through APE’s volunteering program, education program or set up Corporate Responsibility projects. Whether used singly or combined, these methods are used in creative and unique ways to create distinct and dynamic programmes that highlight APE’s model of addressing environment + economics + people in everything it does.
pads.title: Social Enterprise Develops Sustainable Conservation Solutions

pads.content:
Bamboo as Building Material
Bamboo business empowers rural communities by encouraging bamboo farming in the local communities with buy back guarantee. Bamboo is utilised as the affordable building materials and more sustainable material for the communities. Sabah Bamboo Heritage provides services on bamboo construction, bamboo training for bamboo construction and bamboo products- bamboo tea Sabah, charchoal, bambo vinegar and artcraft. https://www.facebook.com/SabahBambooHeritage/about/?ref=page_internal
pads.title: Bamboo as Building Material

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - improving locals' income
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One of the challenges is that local farmers in the CHT are currently not getting the just price for their produce, with agricultural products grown in very remote regions being sold at a very low price. For instance, mangoes are sold for 5-taka per kilogram whereas actual market value is around 60 taka per kg and papayas are sold for 20-taka per kg against a market value of 120 taka per kg. To address this issue, in consultation with the locals, one solution that has been identified is that if tourism is promoted in these areas, the agricultural produce can be sold at a higher value which will create additional revenue for the locals.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - improving locals' income

pads.content:
Social Enterprise for Mothers
Social enterprise that aims to impact the lives of financially dependent and vulnerable mothers by uplifting their skills and talents to the community to be micro-entrepreneurs. Each premium homemade product is professionally baked to bring you joy.
pads.title: Social Enterprise for Mothers

pads.content:
GRO GUERRILLA GARDENERS of LEBANON
Finding and gardening Beirut's abandoned empty lots. Laziza park being one location which turned into an aggregation site for volunteers post Beirut Blast. 
https://grobeirut.com/
pads.title: GRO GUERRILLA GARDENERS of LEBANON

pads.content:
Citizen science on sanitation and waste management: "Mi hábitat: observando con lupa mi barrio"
Collaborative project: Citizens participate in data collection and analysis
Objectives • Raise awareness among young people and families on the health risks posed to their communities by dumping sites, rodents and parasites. • Together with the education community, encourage the most vulnerable neighborhoods (due to this type of pollution) to trigger actions that will improve their quality of life. 
Description of citizen participation: Workshops were conducted to identify potential sanitation issues existing in participants’ neighborhoods. Based on such issues, an app was adapted, and possible preventive measures were discussed. At said workshops, the following main issues were identified: · Dumping sites · Reuse of certain materials · Compost made from organic waste Within 15 days, young people grouped in work teams sent—using the app— images showing areas of their neighborhood, mostly photos of dumping sites and rodents, which pose potential health risks to their communities. Once neighborhood mapping was completed by the work teams, workshops were conducted to discuss findings and possible management actions. 
Time frame. 03/01/2017 – 10/30/2017
Project leaders. • Rosario Robles, Centre for Parasitological and Vector Studies (CEPAVE)/National Scientific and Technical Research Council (CONICET)-National University of La Plata (UNLP) • Bruno Fitte, CEPAVE/CONICET-UNLP • Joaquín Cochero, CONICET y UNLP
Contact information. Email: rosario@cepave.edu.ar
pads.title: Citizen science on sanitation and waste management: "Mi hábitat: observando con lupa mi barrio"

pads.content:
Beirut River Reclaim
Local architect partnered with the Indian social enterprise Afforestt @afforestt to employ the Miyawaki method of afforestation, developed by Dr. Miyawaki in Japan, and which works in any environmental condition, from humid environments to deserts. Miyawaki forests are ideal solutions for cities as they can be grown fast (3years) in very small (10sqm) to very big plots of degraded land, such as leftover spaces, roundabouts, road medians... 
https://www.instagram.com/beirutriverless/
pads.title: Beirut River Reclaim

pads.content:
Kwikpak Shelter for the displaced
KWIKPAK offers a practical emergency shelter model that is structurally safe and sound, while also offering its occupants security from harsh weather conditions. It has been developed using basic materials. The design is collapsable allowing ease in transport and set-up. 
https://www.linkedin.com/company/kwikpak-shelter/about/
tags: the vulnerable members of our society
pads.title: Kwikpak Shelter for the displaced

pads.content:
The Bee Haus
TheBeeHaus is a startup that serves the Lebanese beekeepers using remote monitoring systems and services to support the daily work of Beekeepers to protect and optimize their apiary production.
pads.title: The Bee Haus

pads.content:
Scaling Clothing for disadvantaged communities
FabricAID collects, sorts, and redistributes clothes to disadvantaged communities at micro-prices (ranging from 0.3$ to a maximum of 2$). Our goal is to deliver good quality clothing into the hands of people who need them, while also reducing fabric waste.
pads.title: Scaling Clothing for disadvantaged communities

pads.content:
PSU hand sanitizer
Local made hand sanitizers
pads.title: PSU hand sanitizer

Cement Mixer Forest Fire extinguisher
Forest Fires becoming more and more prominent with little to no resources to fight blaze from government the people of North Lebanon championed a new way to get water into inaccessible steep or dangerous areas caught in fire. Using a cement mixer attached to a water to pump water in a surgical manner. 
https://www.instagram.com/p/CGIvIHyp2xk/

Safety4all
Visible facemask designed for the deaf to allow lip reading

Handmade animal feed mixer
Recycling iron sheets and introducing an innovative way of making animal feed

pads.content:
lander proposis
mesquite charcoal- use of invasive prosopis species of tree for making charcoal that burns more slowly and reduce charcoal consumption and reduce the spread of this invasive plant

Slow Sand Fiter

pads.content:
B-DESINF TDSA : TUNNEL DE DESINFECTION SOLAIRE AUTOMATIQUE
B-DESINF est un système de désinfection solaire automatique conçu et fabriqué )au Niger, avec la participation des jeunes talents dans divers domaines (soudure, électricité, automatisme, énergie, domotique, sanitaire..). Très facile à utiliser et à maintenir, Il existe en deux types de systèmes : 1. B-DESINF TUNNEL modèle TDSA/170/3000 et modèle TDSA/110/1500 à placer dans un passage, ils disposent d’une entrée d’une zone de désinfection et d’une sortie libre. 2. B-DESINF SAS modèle SDSA/170/3000 et modèle SDSA/110/1500 : à placer dans un passage, ils disposent d’une entrée, d’une zone de désinfection et d’une sortie contrôlée par verrou électronique. Autonome, écologique, efficace ,robuste et durable, le -DESINF contribue à la lutte des agents pathogènes (en particulier le COVID 19), Il combine : La désinfection des mains ; Le contrôle de température ; La désinfection des habits et chaussures et la prise en photo automatiques des individus à temperature anormale(option du système)
pads.title: B-DESINF TDSA : TUNNEL DE DESINFECTION SOLAIRE AUTOMATIQUE

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - increasing options for tourists
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One of the challenges is that currently, there are very limited options for tourists in terms of places to visit in CHT. To address this, new tourist spots in the region should be explored and developed to diversify and increase the number of choices available for tourists.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - increasing options for tourists

pads.content:
Up-cycling on the beaches of Tobago
At the beach-front craft market in Store Bay, Tobago, innovative local craftspeople skillfully convert beach waste into precious jewelry and other accessories.
This initiative satisfies several needs in alignment with the UN's SDG's. The sale of locally crafted jewelry to tourists and other beach visitors is a source of decent work and economic growth for this community. Additionally, the goal of re-using waste materials in a sustainable way is achieved through the creative use of organic and inorganic beach waste; such as bottle caps to produce earrings, calabash (local fruit that grows near the beach) husks to make purses, and necklaces made from old smoothed out glass fragments strung onto discarded fishing lines, and many other examples. 
Local crafts-people, Patsy and Thomas, are contributing to coastal preservation through sustainable innovation. Their approach of transforming waste into valuable and profitable products is an approach with global applicability. There is a growing trend towards up-cycling, with plastic bottles in southeast Asia being converted into sneakers, sargassum seaweed being used as organic fertilizers for plants, and many other examples.
Additionally, a small self sustaining economic ecosystem has bloomed around artists like Patsy and Thomas. Thomas mentioned that he purchases the components of his shark teeth necklaces from a man who visits the fish market on a weekly basis to collect discarded waste. Patsy attains components of her "donkey-eye" (seeds of a local fruit) chains from a man who grows and sells the fruit. Both Thomas and Patsy source some of their other products, like hand made wooden or leather purses, drink coasters, etc, from highly specialized local craftsmen. All of these items are sold at a high premium to willing tourists and sentimental locals.
This local example may be applied to other coastal communities in the Caribbean and beyond. Additionally, there are opportunities to grow and scale these businesses through the provision of alternate channels for sale of the art, such as through e-commerce sites.
pads.title: Up-cycling on the beaches of Tobago

pads.content:
Let's go Nutzzzz (Please see the video made specially for this assignment)
The Johnny’s Young Coconuts Story
Aron Jonathan Nerahoo is a 35 year old entrepreneur from Mayaro, Trinidad. He is the founder and CEO of Johnny’s Young Coconuts, a dynamic and innovative business which is revolutionizing how the traditional
coconut is used in the culinary and festival landscape in Trinidad and Tobago.
Johnny grew up in Mayaro Trinidad, a coastal village approximately three hours away from the city centre. In Trinidad, this is as rural as it gets, and as far away from city life as possible. Every day for five years, while attending Secondary School, Johnny would pass through the Manzanilla area on mornings and afternoons, driving past 15 miles of unending coconuts trees that stretch as far as the eye can see. 
After leaving secondary school at the age of 17, Johnny worked a 9-5 making car batteries on a daily basis. He got retrenched after 9 years and wasn’t sure what his next step would be. 
One day, while at the supermarket, Johnny saw a lady struggling to lift a jar of coconut water into her cart. It was there that the idea was born! He got a flash of the miles of coconut trees in Mazanilla and thought how amazing it would be if he could bring the actual coconut, in its natural form to the supermarkets. Johnny figured out a way to brand the coconuts with his business name and started to sell the coconuts in stores and supermarkets. 
He then turned the actual coconut into a cocktail “glass” of sorts, by adding umbrellas and colourful straws and turning the coconut into an experience. Soon, he was sharing the Johnny’s Young Nuts experience in parties and carnival events. People lined up at his booth to sample the party coconut. In these events, people would come to him with their cups of alcohol from other vendors and ask him to throw the alcohol into the coconut. This was difficult to do as the hole for the straw was so small. But he tried to please his patrons. 
One day, while in in the neighbouring island of Grenada, Johnny saw two miniature alcohol bottles in his hotel room. Lightbulbs started going off and he knew that he would need to figure out a way to integrate the miniature alcohol bottle with his coconut. Without a firm plan in place, Johnny ordered bag-fulls of miniature alcohols from the United States. After trial and error, and using various innovative methods, he finally mastered the exact measurements to integrate the miniature bottles with his coconuts.
He set up meetings with the major alcohol brands in Trinidad to try to partner with them for party events and to try to break in to the multi-million dollar carnival industry. At first executives were skeptical. Here was a young man, from a remote village... what did he know about the carnival industry, or marketing and branding. The first brand that took a chance was Hennessey. After the first major carnival event, they knew
they had the next big thing on their hands. Lines snaked around the event and people were eager to sample Johnny’s Young Coconuts.
Johnny now has 27 patents for his product. This includes variations of his coconut with handles and other secrets soon to be revealed. He also innovated around the branding of the coconut itself since he had to figure out a way for the branding to stay on the nut as it is always wet. Now a company can send their logo, or a person can send their picture, and have it branded onto the coconut. Johnny and his team do all the branding themselves and invest money to the equipment that will keep them ahead of the game. They even innovated around the way to peel the coconut as if it’s an orange! He has developed a customized machine that will peel at different speeds and depths.
Johnny now travels across the Caribbean for various events including birthdays, weddings and parties. He has orders from the UK to Israel and his next steps include setting up outlets across the Caribbean and taking his product global.
Sometimes, an innovation does not answer an obvious need. Johnny was out of a job and was searching for the next thing to do. A chance encounter at a supermarket put an idea in his head that he could not let go of. He explained that people eat and drink with their eyes so he needed to come up with a way to "reinvent" the coconut, and to make it appealing and marketable.
The various innovations that he has established around the coconut answer the need he has to improve his product:
- a machine to peel the coconut like an orange (for branding and presentation)
- a branding method that won't wash off due to constant exposure to water and ice (to ensure that his brand is strong and lasting)
- a tool to punch different sizes of holes into the coconut (constant product enhancement)
- a flavourful mixture to give the coconut water taste an even better Caribbean "feel" (service-enhancement)
Lesson One: The Trinidad and Tobago carnival industry is a multi-million dollar industry that is based on costumes, music, dance and revelry. Food and drinks are a huge part of the festival landscape. However, there is a pervasive feeling that big businesses are crowding out smaller businesses and impeding their ability to compete and obtain contracts for the major events. This solution shows that with the right product, and the right innovation, barriers can be broken and even small businesses can compete in major spaces. 
Lesson Two: Partnerships are important. Johnny was able to establish partnerships with bigger brands and this allowed his business to grow faster. However it is important to note that he was already achieving success on his own without the major brands.
Lesson Three: Innovation can take place around the most unlikely subject, product or service. Once a person has a vision, or a need to be met, they can innovate around that. The interview with Johnny revealed that once he started innovating around the coconut, he could not stop. The ideas kept flowing and he now has 27 patents for something seemingly as simple as a coconut. The innovations that he keeps coming up with are all centred on different things he wants to do with the coconut:
- a machine to peel the coconut like an orange; 
- a branding method that won't wash off due to the constant water and ice that the coconut is exposed to
- a tool to punch different size holes into the coconut
- a flavourful mixture to give the coconut water taste an even better Caribbean feel
Once he can imagine it he now knows that he can figure out a way to do it!
pads.title: Let's go Nutzzzz (Please see the video made specially for this assignment)

That this kind of innovations are made by independent workers themselves to respond to their own necessities.

pads.content:
Beyond Organic: Indoor Farming in Residential Trinidad
A fully enclosed, indoor “farm”, controlled, soil-less agriculture in residential area. Low-cost agriculture. 
The farm is just about 180 square feet but produces 200 heads of lettuce and consists of a series of wall pipes, a coy aquarium and rows of custom-made full spectrum China-made, LED grow lights. The single room is air-conditioned and has an air purifier and to the extreme right of the room, on the far end from the entrance, there is a tall blue barrel where the water from the aquarium is purified as well (he has never had to change or replace water since first putting water in May, 2020); the purified water is fed to the plants which are seen at different stages of growth, protruding from the holes in the PVC pipes. The main product of the farm at present is Ronnie’s own variety of lettuce, which he describes as a “douglar” a Trinidadian term for a mix, because it is a cross between the US buttercrunch and a more popular local variety. For lettuces, the main product of the farm, the cycle from seed to harvest is 35 days and is estimated to have at least 18 crop cycles. Ronnie believes he can replicate that cycle for strawberries, compared to conventionally grown California strawberries where the seed-to harvest period lasts 49 to 62-days and where
there are just 3 crop cycles per year. 
According to Ronnie,the secret to the farm is the exact mix of fertiliser, which comprises treated fish faeces, sea minerals and recycled water and the carefully calibrated lighting. Each plant, he explains, requires special lighting for it to absorb the right amount of minerals and for it to grow a particular way. Prior to acquiring custom-made Chinese lights, the lettuce was limp, the way they are preferred in China.Experimenting with other lights, the lettuce was too firm and tough. Ronnie also has mature lettuce plants where he can get his seeds for new germination. Through Ronnie’s own research, he specified the kind of lighting he wants for his own lettuce, suitable for the Trinidad and Tobago customer. In one section of the farm, Ronnie is growing strawberries (there are a few young ones on the shrub), dwarf apple trees and kiwis.
The People Behind the "Farm"
Ronnie Yearwood and his wife are Trinidadian Christian missionaries based in Guinea Bissau for 28 years. They started growing pigeon peas to make Trinidadian “pelau”, a signature dish from Trinidad. In Guinea Bissau’s fertile soils the crop flourished, to the extent that what should have been a pigeon peas shrub quickly became a pigeon peas tree. Having access to 10 acres of land in Cumuto, Trinidad, Ronnie decided to use two acres for pimento pepper cultivation, hoping to replicate his Guinea Bissau experience. But Ronnie soon discovered, that the Caribbean is not Africa. The work was arduous and labour intensive, the temperatures were often too high making irrigation pipes a necessity, soils were plagued with root-eating nematodes, and insects proved too many to beat. Yields were small both in terms of the amount given and the size of the produce. To make matters worse, Ronnie took loan from the Agricultural Development Bank for the project. While the authorities and agriculture shops recommended pesticides, Ronnie, a chemist by training, preferred to avoid the use of commercial pesticides, apart from the standard combinations of nitrogen, potassium, phosphorus (NPK) formulae. Having seen the ease of cultivation in Guinea Bissau, and the success of large-scale controlled agriculture in California, USA, Ronnie decided to study how to produce crops in a clean, pest- and pesticide-free environment, with low water and energy reliance but on a small scale. Today that project has become Beyond Organic – a small commercial farm operating out of the annex of Ronnie and Beverley’s Trinidad and Tobago home in East Trinidad. Ronnie Yearwood and Beverley, his wife, still live in Guinea Bissau but they travel home for a few months from time to time. One such visit, in October, 2019, unexpectedly extended for personal reasons and then on account of the COVID-19 pandemic, has become a year-long stay and the start of Beyond Organic, operational since May 2020. 
The entire cost of the annex, inclusive of construction, temperature regulation and irrigation, was TT$60,000. The most notable recurrent costs, according to Ronnie, is the cotton-wool cosmetic pads that he uses for germinating the seeds, costing TT$10.00 for 100 pads. Ronnie looks back and compares the new farm with the cost of the failed 2 acre project two years ago, where he would have had a loan of TT$200,000, plus extensive manual labour. If he hadn’t used inherited family land, it would have been even more expensive.
Improving the model
The Beyond Organic model has the potential to produce clean agriculture at a fraction of the cost of conventional agriculture. But Ronnie sees ways to further reduce the cost of his operation. For instance, since he is stuck here in Trinidad and Tobago, he’s plugged into the electric grid. However, he had originally wanted to use solar power. In Trinidad and Tobago, a net producer of fossil-fuel energy, commercial rates are too low to make solar generation practical. For poorer countries where energy is more expensive, he envisages solar powered fans and cooling systems. I asked him about something like a staple carbohydrate, like the hardy dry-land rice currently branded Moruga Hill rice, in Trinidad and Tobago. After all, starving
people don’t want lettuce and strawberries. “This method can be used to grow anything. You just have to do the research and experiment,” he explains. Some crops just need more space, he further elucidated, indicating that apples will need to be about 6-7 feet apart.
Ronnie’s Dream
Ronnie wants to experiment with a wider range of crops, especially those that address the cultural needs of people in West Africa. His particular dream is to continue working on the project in West Africa, which is where his heart is. He explains that this model “is not for use everywhere in Africa, or everywhere in West Africa. In some parts of West Africa there are drought conditions from October to July. If they can capture just a little bit of that water and use it effectively, they can have food all year.” One tilapia can spawn more than 10,000 fingerlings, meaning that there is a lot of fertiliser for the crops. He wants missionaries like himself to learn the model and use it to grow what the people want and need. Nevertheless, while Ronnie eyes his adopted home, Guinea Bissau, he sees the usefulness of his model for small-island countries like his native Trinidad and Tobago, where there is a high food import bill. His model, he asserts, can reduce the high food import bill of many small-island developing countries. 
Another area of focus that concerns Ronnie is “light-engineered plants”. Since light affects the plants’ uptake of nutrients, Ronnie envisages the engineering of crops using diffident intensities of light during
their growth phase, to adjust the level of particular vitamins and minerals that they contain. For example low-potassium lettuce would be suitable for consumption by dialysis patients. Confident that he already knows how to do it, Ronnie is currently looking for a laboratory where he can get the biological components of his produce tested. 
The Future
Ronnie is already selling his produce from his home. However, he wants to scale up, train others and experiment. One of the blessings of the COVID-19 is that the economic stagnation has caused some people and groups to look into alternative investments. One such group is a Christian association that runs a hotel and visitor facility. Since their facility could not be used, they have approached Ronnie to discuss giving him access to close to 2000 square feet of land. The future, though still uncertain, looks promising. 
The need for: (1) low cost agricultural production, (2) improved predictability of crop yields, (3) low water intensity. 
There is the potential for crops of special mineral intensities for special health purposes.
With planning and a relatively small investment (less than US$10K), small-scale indoor/controlled agriculture can produce a lot of clean food with low water use intensity for both subsistence and for resale. Perhaps suitable for small islands and arid regions. This should also be explored for animal alimentary needs as well.
pads.title: Beyond Organic: Indoor Farming in Residential Trinidad

pads.content:
Social distancing in a van
This is a taxi van that is using signs traditionally found in restaurants to ensure that social distancing is observed inside the van and avoid potential fines.
This solution answers a need for continued employment during the pandemic and the restrictions imposed by the government to reduce contagion.
Despite there being a potential risk in carrying several passengers, transportation options in Lima will adapt to the so-called "new normal". Also note that these signs might be put up but might not necessarily enforced by the driver if he absolutely needs to income from a trip.
pads.title: Social distancing in a van

pads.content:
Music as a service
During the pandemic it has been possible to observe bands playing music in the streets of affluent neighborhoods, given that their livelihood was severely affected due to the closure (both temporary and permanent) of the businesses who hired their services. 
This solution answers the need for a livelihood based on the arts that can be sustained throughout crises.
Cultural activities are some of the most affected by the restrictions imposed to control COVID-19, but artists and musicians are finding ways to update their craft in response to the new conditions and people's need for connection in a time of isolation.
pads.title: Music as a service

pads.content:
Old Bus Cafe
I observed old bus which was renovated as fast food café
you can use any old object for original decision for your business
pads.title: Old Bus Cafe

pads.content:
Electric Power Microgeneration System 
The electric power microgeneration system is designed to provide rural communities with electric power.
pads.title: Electric Power Microgeneration System

pads.content:
Handwashing Station 
Handwashing station for COVID 19 can be activated either by an electronic sensor or with one’s feet, preventing users from potential COVID 19 infection by handling anything.
pads.title: Handwashing Station

pads.content:
One Peso WiFi
This WiFi hotspot vending machine allows one to connect to the internet for five minutes for as low as Php1.00 only. Filipino hackers managed to flash and reinstall a new firmware from old routers and designed a landing page for ease-of-use. “This is like putting your WiFi in a sachet," according to Francis Capistrano.
The need to have affordable and accessible internet.
The solution is for the public. Most of the users we noticed fall under the youth sector where they use the internet to access social media sites and entertainment sites such as YouTube. Other users also expressed that they use PisoWiFi to research for school. 
The solution matters to the user because internet is expensive in the Philippines and this is their way of sharing the internet to others. This is basically a basic form of the sharing economy. This also means that internet access is something that people have been looking for.
The solution has gained traction among the public and business is observed to be brisk. With an investment of Php20,000, one can set up their own PisoWiFi in their homes allowing them to share and monetize their internet to their neighbors who can't afford.

pads.content:
One Peso Water Station
This is a coin-operated water vending machine that integrates digital coin slot & timer with an analog water pump. This is a mainstay and is found littered all over the place. Users either purchase paper cups or come with their tumblers. Some shops give small plastic pouches to collect water.
Access to clean and potable water.
The solution is for the general public who would like to have access to clean and safe drinking / potable water. In Manila where the safety of public utility water supply is questionable, people look for an alternative way to have affordable, clean and safe drinking water. With just Php1.00 (US$0.02), anyone can have clean and safe drinking water anytime.
This means that there is a need for affordable, accessible clean and safe drinking / potable water in urban centers in the Philippines. 
This is an ubiquitous solution that is found in almost every corner in the urban jungle of Manila. The solution has the potential to be brought to rural areas where clean and safe drinking water is inaccessible and expensive.

Mobile Hot Chocolate Store
Mobile hot chocolate vendor where customers can buy cacao beans, and have them roasted and grounded. The vendor delivers the hot chocolate to his customers within the vicinity. The vendor was able to manufacture the tablea or cocoa pellets themselves and made this ready to drink beverage for the customers.
Accessible and mobile vending to busy market vendors.
The solution is for busy market vendors who have no time to go around and buy food in nearby shops or restaurants.
It was a good experience to see people doing diskarte for a living. Fresh and hot chocolates are availble at a cheaper cost. 
Once this person makes friends and customers, he may influence someone else to do the same. Mobile and delivery of fresh hot chocolate beverages.

pads.content:
One Peso Internet
Pisonets are standalone internet kiosks that operate by inserting Php1.00 coins in exchange for 5 minutes of internet use. We observed that most users access their Facebook accounts and watch YouTube videos. Pisonets are made by assembling old cannibalized computer parts, CRT / LCD monitor, a digital coin slot & timer. In a nutshell, these are decentralized internet cafes.
The need to have affordable internet to those without a smartphone or a computer.
The solution is for the general public, mostly those in the youth sector. Users usually use the solution to access social media sites and entertainment sites such as YouTube.
This means that access to computers and the internet is still a great challenge for people. Just like the PisoWiFi, this is a basic form of the sharing economy where the poor can have access to a computer and the internet through affordable means.
This solution is the next evolution of the internet cafe and presents how internet cafes can be decentralized by bringing it to the customers. There is widespread acceptance by the general public as the arcade game-type design can easily be mobilized and installed in remote areas where there is no access to computers and the internet.

pads.content:
Computer Motherboard Refurbishment
Cannibalizing of computer parts, especially motherboard, and creation of new motherboards from the cannibalized parts.
The need to have affordable computer parts to repair laptops and computers.
Customers who needs refurbished motherboards to fix their laptops or computers.
Computer parts and computers, in general, are still very expensive and inaccessible to ordinary Filipinos. The Philippines is also a dumping ground of electronics waste from more developed countries. And, these innovators / hackers have found a way to utilize and monetize these waste into something useful.
These informal computer parts refurbishers are basically waste workers who found value in the electronic waste of developing countries. There is an opportunity to teach the waste pickers proper ways to ensure safety from exposure to toxic elements from the computer parts. Their knowledge and skills can also be tapped to develop new inventions from the many parts available to them.

pads.content:
One Peso PS4 / XBOX
Piso-PS4 / Xbox machines are game consoles wired to a digital coin slot & timer mechanism and encased in a wooden box. 32” LCD TVs are usually included in the package for the best arcade gaming experience. Users also watch preloaded movies and karaoke videos from hacked gaming consoles.
The need to have access to affordable technology and entertainment.
The solutions is mostly for the youth sector who have no access or are not able to afford digital entertainment systems. According to an interviewee, this is a good alternative for the youth than to go and join gangs especially when they feel bored. 
This means that there is not much rest, leisure, and recreation options for the youth in urban poor areas.
There is an opportunity for enterprising electronic technicians to earn while providing alternative rest, leisure, and recreation options for the youth in poorer urban areas.

pads.content:
Personal Cooling Fans from Recycled Server Fans
These are upcycled server fans that are made into personal cooling fans. Innovators rigged the power input to allow easy operation by anyone without having to overheat the fan motor.
The need to have affordable personal cooling device.
The solution is for those who live in small cramped rooms and apartments in the warm Manila City. This is a good alternative with a lower electricity consumption to the expensive air conditioning units. The device is also small in size which makes it portable.
This means that access to cooling devices in a hot and humid Manila is needed by people. 
There is potential in having these cooling device to be produced en masse providing a cheaper alternative to existing appliances such as electric fans and air conditioning units. It is also more portable and more affordable than the existing solution.

Portable Lathe Machine
The device is a portable lathe machine that is primarily used to make billiard cue sticks but has been used to create small wooden furniture pieces as well.
Alternative, portable and affordable machining devices for use by carpenters and craftspeople.
The solution is for carpenters and craftspeople who work with wood, mostly in machining cylindrical surfaces.
This is an alternative way to machine wooden cylindrical surfaces that can be sold as a component to furniture and general carpentry.
The device has the potential to be redesigned and reproduced to make it portable, accessible and affordable to carpenters.

pads.content:
Modified Measuring Cups
Makeshift liquid measuring cups made from used plastic bottles. The innovation is characterized by holes of varying sizes - the bigger the hole, the lesser amount of cooking oil is left. In this case, the innovation measures up to 1kg, 0.5kg, and 250ml of cooking oil. This eases the way the reseller repackages the product depending on the demand of the costumer. 
The need to have a fast and efficient way of measuring liquid products for repackaging and reselling.
Micro-entrepreneurs who would like to have a fast and efficient way to measure liquid products.
Measurement standardization can be done using simple means. In addition, grassroots individuals can be really resourceful in addressing their needs and concerns.
Can be used by other retailers whose products need to weighed or measured e.g. rice

pads.content:
Paper Flowers
This innovation is about the use of paper flowers from recycled materials.
Recycling used materials into new products that are attractive and saleable.
For micro-entrepreneurs who would like to go into upcycling.
Flowers have been used to beautify our churches, halls, and houses on specials occasions and even during burials. this has gone on for generations, and is not only done in our country.
This Flower vendor from Freedom in Carbon market had to adapt and find another way when the flower stocks started dwindling and the demands were expected to rise d/t upcoming events.
With a pinch of luck and a lot of hard work she came by some people selling paper flowers, a group of senior citizens. She partnered with them purchased their flowers and suggested to soak them in wax to make them shiny and waterproof, thus to prevent them from easily weathering in the sun and rain.
The use of renewable materials, these flowers were made with paper, and wax which was recycled from used candles.
This craft of creating paper flowers can be done with some elbow grease and a little practice and can be used to create livelihood programs.

Improvised Beach Umbrella for Street Vendors
Extra large umbrella recycled from old beach umbrellas. The innovator reinforced the umbrella spine with wires and used sack-type canvas for durability. Resembling beach umbrellas, these are sold to vendors who sell on the side streets.
Affordable and durable large umbrellas to protect products and vendor from the elements.
Street vendors in the market
Recycling is a good way to improve a product from old flimsy beach umbrellas sold in the market. By understanding what the needs of the vendors are, the innovator is able to provide a product that is durable and affordable.
The solution can be a way to help recycle "disposable" mass market umbrellas that are currently sold in the market.

pads.content:
Innovating Business to Beat ASF
This is about being resilient during onset of outbreak like African Swine Fever (ASF).
How to be resilient during the ASF outbreak
For pork retailers and wholesalers in the market
The strategies to beat effects of African Swine Fever (ASF) to the pork vendor was remarkable. Theresa Blanco resorts to the following strategies to compensate income losses due to ASF. These include: business diversification, reducing input cost (labor) and sticking to policies or laws related to meet quality output.
Other pork vendor may benchmark on the coping mechanisms and strategies and also government support.

pads.content:
Electric Cacao Pod Breaker
Cacao merits much economic significance in the producing Region like the Davao Region. Considering all these benefits of cacao, cacao production and processing needs to be mechanized and properly improved to aid profits and reduce losses. Hence, the development of this concept of designing of an electric cacao pod breaker machine. The electric cacao pod breaker which crushes the pod. The breaker includes an agitator that starts the process of separating the beans from the husk. Cacao bean pulpers agitate the material and further separate beans
from husk. Beans drop through grated pulper floor. The machine appears to use standard electric motors and switching equipment. Claims to be able to break different sizes of pods. Breaking rather than cutting makes this possible. Low waste and probably less than 5%.
Efficiency and minimize wastage
Cacao farmers and cacao processors
Alternative affordable way to process cacao efficiently with minimum wastage.
It can be commercialized to cacao farmers to improve their production efficiency and increase profit.

Coal Stove with Electric Blower
9077976982
Coal Stove with Electric Blower - a prototype coal blower with an electric blower as accessory. The operator does not need to monitor and have continues blowing since the accessory does the trick. 
It serves as a solution to the unending monitoring and blowing of stove. It also serves as an answer to the burning inefficiency of the coal.
It will be used by cooks in restaurants, carenderias, and even homes. It will give ease to the operator and makes cooking more easier, less hassle. It is significant since it will improve kitchen operation.
Typical equipment which can be seen in homes and firms can be improved more by innovation. These equipment can be modified through changing the design or adding more accessories to improve its function. 
The prototype can be replicated and adapted by other communities and business firms who are in the food sector, this can be used to improve efficiency and operations and also for those who wish to improve their kitchen errands.

pads.content:
Center for Innovation and Social Ventures
9175486671
emienglis@gmail.com
Future-proofing the products, services and ideas that will be developed by the Institutional Management Enterprise (IME) Program through heritage-based creative entrepreneurship for, with and by the stakeholders of the institution - administrators, faculty, personnel, students, parents, alumni and community extension partners (indigenous groups and emerging urban cottage industry-based communities). The program is facilitated by the 5 units of the Center for Innovation and Social Ventures in coordination with the Community Extension Office. 
Capacity- and capability-building for sustainability of stakeholders. 
Stakeholders. 
Revisiting the current initiatives and strategies of CISV allowed me to reflect on its focus and integration.

pads.content:
Foot Bath Using Indigenous Coco Coir Material
In response to the national, even worldwide, call for control/prevention of the spread COVID19 pandemic, the DOSCST prepared a Foot Bath made of coco coir, which is an indigenous material readily available in the locality. The coir is sprayed with a chemical as disinfectant. This is placed at the entrance Gate that will disinfect the shoes/wheels of anyone (persons) or anything (vehicles) entering the school premises.
This solution (Coco coir foot bath) answers the challenge to immediately support the prevention if not eradication of the virus spread at a very minimal cost as much as possible. There no need for constant refilling of the chemical because the coir is capable of holding the solution for quite a long time.
This is for the faculty, staff, students, and guests entering the school premises. This solution is user-friendly because of the capacity of the coco coir to hold the water intact while giving just enough disinfection needed for both humans and vehicles. This means lesser hassle to the users - no shoes are overly immersed in the disinfectant, thus avoiding wet sandals or feet without jeopardizing the OOTD (outfit-of-the-day/footwear) of the user. 
I found this solution worth-emulating because it is both cost efficient and user-freindly. It is wise to use indigenous materials that can be friendly to nature as well.
This solution can also be applied not only in the academe but also in other institutions: supermarkets, wet markets, hospitals, and other public places.

pads.content:
Amazing Amaranthus
9078332188
Amaranthus, or locally known as "kulitis" is basically regarded as backyard weed- endemic in the province and even in other places. It just grows anywhere, hence,it usually is uprooted or mowed. Despite its quite misunderstood identity, especially to those who know less or nothing about it, there is more to "kulitis" than what meets the eye.
To some, especially to the elders, it is a potential source of food. It's tops/tips are harvested, and are prepared as one of the viands by means of sauteing. In the far flung areas, or to those who cannot always afford to buy themselves sumptuous foods, this edible backyard weed is more than enough to make through the day without an empty stomach.
It is very beneficial for those who are living in far flung areas, as well as those who cannot always afford to buy food.
Even the grass or weeds that seem to be pestering around the backyard or our vacant lots, bring about the saving graces to every stomach.
Various households, especially those of the financially challenged, as well as a supplement to nutrition needs.

Coco Coir Doormat
The doormat is made of 100% pure coconut coir, which is one of the strongest natural fibers in the world. The material easily captures moisture, dirt, and other particles. pads.content:
O2IRAQ, The Next LinkedIn for Climate
The Iraqi community lacks awareness in terms of climate change. We have seen a well-noticed ignorance of the environment from the individuals in the local community and the stakeholders. Not only that, but there is no specific space that is interested in educating individuals about the importance of protecting the environment. As a result, the Iraqi citizens are negatively affected by the current climate change crisis. For that, O2IRAQ is a platform that focuses fundamentally on climate change in IRAQ. For now we call it the next LinkedIn for climate. It is a new space for everyone to discuss environmental issues happening in our region and a space to build and connect the ecosystem related to climate and environment. Nevertheless, it is a space to record the movements and the efforts in this field, gamified system, and the destination for the investors and donors in this field. O2IRAQ aims to build an educated audience about the significance the climate change and its impacts on human-being life.
pads.title: O2IRAQ, The Next LinkedIn for Climate

Inspired by the idea of an active lifestyle, Amid and Bahlul, founders of Handbike Azerbaijan, are promoting
cycling for people with disabilities in Baku.
Notably, the friends started without any bicycle, and, guided by youtube videos, they constructed the first one themselves. "Our first bicycle weighed 65 kg, but, of course, it had a symbolic meaning." Although not comfortable, they managed to participate in the city marathon with that bike. The second bicycle Amid made by considering the lesson learned from the first experience.
Amid and Bahlul emphasized that people with disabilities do not need pity. Cycling empowers them, and they want to share this joy with others.

pads.content:
Towards Smart Cities: Notes from Baku’s Underground
Starting April 2019, the Baku Metro has introduced “accessible subway” service to make subway system accessible for the people with disabilities including people with low vision, people who are hard of hearing, elderly, pregnant women with hand luggage. The user can request the service via phone or app by naming their location and a final destination one hour in advance of taking the ride. The trained staff meet them at the designated location in front of the subway and take to the intended place. During the process they use alternative escalator (in most cases, there are three escalators in the subway) and place a person in the first train. The service operates between 9 am and 9 pm, but the subway administration does not recommend passengers to use it during the peak hours. It is important to note that the subway staff who work for these services undertakes special training sessions on how to work with the end users. The subway administration receives around 35 calls per week, but they have a capacity to handle more requests. As per January 2020, they are planning to grow and build assistive infrastructure in the subway. The system was designed based on the experience similar system in Moscow and London.
Talking about the reconstruction, it is hard to make infrastructure in the subway stations built during the Soviet Union. In fact, based on the past instructions, people with disabilities should not be allowed to go in the subway. Considering the costs and feasibility, the subway administration could not renovate old subway stations to make them accessible. However, the administration is looking towards new stations in the new purple line to be fully accessible with elevators and other amenities.
pads.title: Towards Smart Cities: Notes from Baku’s Underground

pads.content:
Informal Plastic Recycling Loop
Intro
Different stakeholders have been engaged in the collecting, sorting, recycling of the waste in large cities in Azerbaijan, and, noticeably, the collection chain has been managed by the public services while sorting, and recycling has been done haphazardly by individuals and/or small-medium enterprises. It creates a hidden system of plastic recycling in the country, which is, on the other side, a shadow solution to plastic pollution that has evolved organically on the grassroots level. To understand the entire cycle, Acclab has made several field visits and met the representatives at all stages.
Stats
Plastic waste, which is around 6% of the entire waste in Azerbaijan, causes significant environmental threats. According to the State Statistical Committee, the volume of household waste is 907. 3 ths m3 in the country and 204.8 ths m3 in Baku in 2018. However, the independent assessments show that the number of produced waste is much higher than that reported. To illustrate, it has been calculated that the amount of household waste is about 1684.1 ths m3, and the amount of waste per person is around 333 kg per year. In this regard, it is estimated that approximately 20-24 kg of plastic waste per year accounts per citizen in Azerbaijan.
Although the harmfulness of plastic waste has been recognized, in recent years the production and usage of plastic have increased significantly in the country. As evidence, the production of plastic has been doubled, and the import of plastic bags has increased five times. The amount of secondary polymer has risen by 700% between 2015 and 2018. 
Situation
Except for Baku, the collection of the waste is organized by the Cleaning Department of the Regional Executive Authorities. In the large cities except for Baku, there is no formal waste sorting process, and it has been sorted manually
by individuals across the city and in the landfill. Around 100 people are sorting waste in the city, and 30-40 people are doing it on the polygon. They are mostly looking for, so-called mild plastic, and don't collect PET plastic, which is used to make bottles for carbonated soft drinks. A number of small and medium enterprises are purchasing politelen or other types of plastic except for PET plastic and reuse it for secondary production. 
This is the case of a grassroots solution to the problem, which has been solved by the community naturally.
pads.title: Informal Plastic Recycling Loop

While the resourvoir under is filling in the solar panel boils the water and the steam of the drinking water are collected in the resourvoir on the surface. Real-time data can be tracked in the app Photo 1 shows how it might look in real life; photo 2 is the prototype model; photo 3 is the interface of the app.

Infostud data analysis of the process of depopulation in Serbia
This solution uses the datasets of the job portal Infostud (leading career/job search portal in Serbia) on job advertisements, the structure of jobs offered, as well as the number and characteristics of people from different local communities in Serbia who are looking for employment abroad. By analysing these data, the team will find out how many people apply for a job abroad from year to year, where the jobs they are applying for are located, as well as how many applications for scholarships and internships abroad are made each year. Based on these data, one could gain insight into which industries are more and which are less represented in job advertisements, and thus also to which locations Serbian population most often emigrates.
