pads.content:
Nahmdong Eco Plates
This local start-up was found in Luang Prabang in the northern part of Lao PDR. It is not a novel innovation in the world, but it is new to be produced and used in the country. The idea was introduced by the Indian tourists who visited the park which aimed to become environmentally friendly. At first, they planned to ban the use of plastic containers in their activity park, but it has received high interests for businesses in tourism sector. 
Issue they want to solve: 
Leaf plates and containers are optimal alternative plastic and polymer-based products. Most bamboo, palm, and areca sheaths are abandoned or burned everywhere. Therefore, the local villagers are encouraged to collect and sell these sheaths to exchange for some income.
Potential expansion: 
There is a possibility to produce machines with different moles in Lao PDR by collaborating with Faculty of Engineering, Technical Vocational Colleges. The initiative can turn into Sustainable Business Model by generating income in the community and creating jobs by forming a group or cooperative. It can be connected with other development projects in country and the region which support the production of rattan and bamboo and livelihoods for income generation scattering across the countries by government and NGOs.
pads.title: Nahmdong Eco Plates

pads.content:
Activated Charcoal
Activated charcoal is a bio product by a Lao Bio Energy Group. They turn leaves into charcoal by adding natural ingredients such as cassava flour, water and fragrance powder. The activated charcoal is a great solution to solve issue of burning leaves which can be seen everywhere. The charcoal helps reducing bad smell in wardrobe, refrigerator, toilet and car.

pads.content:
Recycle Art Laos 
Recycle Art Laos is a micro business founded by two siblings in 2014. They tested how to turn office paper to become fine art works. Now they have many types of products which proved to be durable and easy to transport. They have a small home-based factory and hires a few staff. However, they work with the fine art students and provide them with jobs and fair pay. Their primary target group is foreign tourists. Due to Covid19, they have severely affected and now they want to develop new products which target more domestic consumers. They are registered as the national "One District One Product".

Claudia Isabel Barona y Andrés Benavides

The same product redesigned and fixed for light waste containing.

pads.content:
Sensibilisation virtuelle contre le COVID-19 à travers les jeux vidéos
Il s'agit de faire des campagnes de sensibilisation pour promouvoir la distanciation sociale dans la perspective de la lutte contre le COVID-19. C'est une innovations présentée au Coronahackaton organisé par l'AccLab-Niger et le CIPMEN (Centre Incubateur des PME au Niger).
Les publics cibles sont les jeunes et les adultes qui disposent d'un téléphone Android. C'est une innovation portée par un groupe de trois jeunes : - Chaibou Maikibi Nafissatou, Master Genie Logiciel ; -Maman Bachir, Maître Réseaux Informatiques ; -Harouna Dan Malam Samira, Maître Réseaux Informatique

pads.content:
AlloDocta-La santé au bout des doigts
La plateforme web mobile est un dispositif de boxes physiques au bénéfice des patients et des institutions sanitaires (clients). Elle permettra de prendre rendez-vous et d’effectuer des téléconsultations. Cette innovation s’inscrit dans le cadre de la gestion des consultations en milieu hospitalier et chez les professionnels de santé. La crise sanitaire du coronavirus (Covid-19) a mis en exergue les lacunes et les limites de notre système de santé. L'innovation répond à trois défis : 1) Salle d'attente saturée : respect des gestes barrières ; 2)Une médecine de contact ; 3) La couverture sanitaire : selon l’INS en 2016, au Niger il y a 20 955 habitants pour 1 médecin contre 10 000 selon les normes de l’OMS .
pads.title: AlloDocta-La santé au bout des doigts

Shilu Ana - mobile taxi hail service
Shilu Ana is the countries first taxi hail app service. Being pioneers in the market they had to educate the general public of the benefits of an app based service. In the less than 9 months of operation their customer base has grown almost exponentially. As a majority of the South Sudan public do not use smartphones the created a voice based system which still always for the tracking of ride journey when the customer is picked up, providing confidence in a fair fare. 
Many youth who have access to vehicles have joined the platform as drivers, earning more take home in a day than they do in their regular work.

pads.content:
Peer support during pandemic - or how people help each other via social media group 
Problem Statement: 
Due to the drastic increase in Covid19 cases Georgian government and medical sector failed to provide adequate services for all who are in need, the 112 emergency services sometimes takes few attempts to reach the operators, when requested an ambulance it take 4-5 hours for an ambulance to reach the patient. additionally, those undergoing the treatment at Covid Hotels and at home are assigned with general practitioner who is supposed to check on the patients on a daily basis, however due to the volume of infected, it becomes challenging to reach every patient for advice on treatment and procedures. Thus many remain uninformed on basic treatment procedures to tackle Covid19. 
Solution: 
In order to provide peer to peer support and inform everyone in need, one of the medical staff representatives in Adjara region of Georgia created an informal group on social media, where people who are either Covid infected and or know someone who is infected become members of the group. the group has already almost 13000 members. the purpose of the group is to provide support to those infected, share experience from those who have already recovered from the Covid, share information on the situations in different hospitals (from those who are undergoing the treatment) and share contact information of DPs who are volunteering to provide phone call advice to the Covid Patients. with this simple solution, citizens are supporting each other through hard times, since the medical sector is failing to provide adequate services and attention to all who are in need.
pads.title: Peer support during pandemic - or how people help each other via social media group

pads.content:
Multiple electrical sockets
Creative way to provide access to electricity at Mutundo informal marketplace.
pads.title: Multiple electrical sockets

pads.content:
Edible gardens in communal areas and balconies
During the first lockdown, I've noticed my neighbors started growing edible gardens on their balconies but in communal areas as well - when I asked questions why they decided to plant vegetables and herbs their explanation consists of a few factors: 1 they would like to enjoy the benefits of home-grown produce 2 take up a new hobby since now they have more time without commuting to offices/workplaces 3 keep themselves and their children busy - some of them said the gardening is helping them to cope with anxiety and stress 
The edible gardening addresses multiple needs 1 psychological needs - a new normal with lockdown has helped us to rethink our experience and appreciate the little things we have, in addition, gardening is well known as the positive activity for mental and physical health 2 social needs - my neighbours have joined the gardening community to share their learning and support the novice gardeners. Moreover, growing more vegetables they were able to support vulnerable groups of people who were shielding themselves 
I'm thinking about how we can use this practice to make edible gardening a part of the city landscape to introduce it not only as a wellbeing exercise and a social practice but as something that is part of the circular economy and one of the ways to combat climate change.
pads.title: Edible gardens in communal areas and balconies

pads.content:
Fabric Shop: Door Racks
Walking in the dark allies of Al-Balad leading to the more lively area where most items are sold, this fabric shop caught my attention. As people would usually continue straight to the busy area and not think to look left as it leads to a dead end, the vendors of this shop created this hack as a way to attract visitors and display their fabrics as a form of marketing. This was done by simply screw-driving metal rails on the doors. 
Marketing purposes: to indicate that a shop is located in a less crowded area and attract visitors by showcasing their products. 
Learning how to utilize space and fixtures to attract visitors with simple tools.
pads.title: Fabric Shop: Door Racks

Old and present innovation: the walking sharpener
The walking sharpener with its characteristic flute and adapted bicycle stills wanders around neighbourhoods offering its services.
The bicycle -apart from being a sustainable mode of transport- is the fundamental tool of the sharpener ́s daily work. It transforms energy to sharpen knives and allows him to freely move around the neighbourhood, offering a door to door service.
Taking care of daily items (like scissors and knives) not only adds value as sharpeners labour but also reduces waste of disposable knives and scissors.

pads.content:
Sanitation system for road hotels and rural public buildings
Within the pilot initiative a sustainable system for expanding the use of local treatment facilities
(LTF) was established mostly in rural areas of the Republic of Belarus. At the same time, the production of LTF components was modernized at the enterprise “Beltechagroplast”, Uzda district, Minsk region, and the fi rst pilot LTF was installed in the Akhremov kindergarten-school in Braslav district, Vitebsk region. The pilot
initiative was implemented by the NGO “Center for Environmental Solutions”
The sanitation system consists of a septic tank attached to a building, a soil filter and a small pond for collecting cleaned water for watering of garden plants 
The septic tank is produced on BeltechAgroPlast medium enterprise. The deteriorated tanks can be melted and new tanks can be produced from secondary PVC. Meet its director, Alexander (young man in a black T-shirt). He was proud to present its enterprise for AccLab enthusiasts
The produced tanks are the materials for another small enterprise - Ecoidea LTD, where Anton Gakhovich is a chief manager and owner. Anton is also a civil engineer that designed the engineering design documentation. His company installs the tanks and constructs soil filters and water collection ponds
That's how it looks like. The tank is connected with tubes to a soil filter. Here it is.
This is Anton Gakhovich. This is his report in Russian, but he speaks English fluently. You can contact him by email: energy@ecoidea.by
pads.title: Sanitation system for road hotels and rural public buildings

pads.content:
Plastic Bag Boxes
Solution: Plastic Bag Boxes
On one of my walks on Woodbine beach broadwalk, I noticed several wooden boxes attached to Lamp posts, where people can deposit empty plastic bags as well as pick plastic bags to pick up trash.
Each box is hand-painted and has instructions with 3 steps:
"CLEAN OUR BEACH
1) Pick a bag from the box
2) Pick up garbage from the beach (even if it's not yours)
3) Put your bag full of garbage in one of the receptacles.
*please don't put your bag full of garbage back in this box"
These Waste Bag Boxes provide people with a place to deposit empty plastic bags for direct re-use on the beach to keep the beaches and lakes clean from plastic bags as well as other types of garbage. One great use case will be for dog-owners who might have forgotten to take a dog waste bag before walking their dogs.
Need: Sanitation - Clean Lakes and Beaches
According to the article in the link below, there was a littering problem on Woodbine beach.
pads.title: Plastic Bag Boxes

pads.content:
Hanger Hacks
Passing by a tiny shop filled with rows of clothing items that covered all the walls and expanded outwards, I spotted a clearly visible metal pipe that was hanging from the door held by metal wires used as a hanger rack. I was curios to see what other hacks were used to showcase such a large number of items which hung from the top of the walls to the bottom. I noticed there were simple chains that were hooked to pipes which allowed more hangers to be hooked on the chains vertically. 
Utilizing limited space to display products.
Simple tools and techniques could be used to upcycle and benefit from available resources.
pads.title: Hanger Hacks

pads.content:
Shoes in Motion
Walking in the lively area of Al-Balad, I reached an open space that had a number of wheelbarrows attached to wood planks where different products were being sold. I asked one of the vendors why there were so many of them here and who started this trend. He mentioned that this technique was used a long time ago and originated in Yemen as he as well as many of the vendors there were from Yemen. 
The need for mobility and ease in transferring items as well as displaying them all in one. Also, creating in a way their own selling booth in an open public space filled with shops around them. 
How to utilize open public spaces. This may not be intentional, but finding other methods to transfer products easily with less carbon emission.

pads.content:
Fabric Shop: Fabric Duster 
Entering the fabric shop, I noticed an object placed in the door handle. I asked the vendor what it was. He explained that it was a fabricated duster which he made out of the excess fabrics attached to a piece of wood. It was also interesting how this hack fit perfectly in the hole of the door handle which could be considered as a second hack; the fabric duster holder.
Cleaning and maintenance: clearing the dust from the fabrics, especially the ones situated outside.
The importance and benefits of upcycling. With simple solutions, one can not only cut costs but more importantly avoid waste.
pads.title: Fabric Shop: Fabric Duster

pads.content:
Holder of hand sanitizer in the public space in Kyrgyzstan
Holder of hand sanitizer in public spaces in Kyrgyzstan
This is a simple holder designed for the hand sanitizer. It is not clear who invented it and where. I first time noticed it in Bishkek airport. People can easily use their arm/elbow to push the bottle pump, instead of using their hand and/or using another part of the arm to touch the small pump of a sanitizer. Later, I see this in small business shops and at some public spaces. But it has not been widely adopted yet. 
P.S.: Later, I noticed that this device is manufactured by a company. We don't know this is the innovation of a business, or the grassroots innovation is adopted by business.

pads.content:
Handmade birdhouse by children
Birdhouses are made by children together with their parents at home or at school. We may observe that they are very common in old neighborhoods. Every yard contains 3-5 handmade birdhouses created with different design and color.
pads.title: Handmade birdhouse by children

pads.content:
HOMEMADE ENERGY EFFICIENT HEATING SYSTEM
I visited Milyanfan village, 20 minutes from Bishkek, capital of Kyrgyzstan. As there is no centralized infrastructure, each family decides on how to heat their house. Because of the high electricity cost, most people use coal for this purpose which is the determinant of extremely bad air quality in Bishkek. In one of the houses I saw an interesting furnace which is the core of the heating system of the house. It was made by the owner of the house. As he said, they bought this house just a year ago and last year he was notifying that they spent too much on coal, moreover it took a lot of efforts for him and his family members to look after the furnace and add coal every 40-45 minutes to maintain certain temperature. Moreover, they also had to pick all the ash with their hands, otherwise the furnace might become clogged very shortly. 
So, with his engineer background, he created a new furnace where you can open the top, put coals in three buckets from which the needed amount of coal automatically goes to the fire; it is enough for 12-14 hours, meaning you need to put coal only twice a day, not every 40 minutes. It is very efficient for maintaining the temperature, as if you miss your time to put coal in the traditional furnace, the home temperature goes lower immediately and you need to spend more coal to warm up the system - > more air pollution & more expenses. Furthermore the ash is also collected in a separate part of the furnace, which they further use as natural fertilizer.
Recently he installed thermostat into the system - so it is already a semiautomated heating system. The inventor also mentioned, that all his neighbors are interested in this approach and ask him either explain the technology or ready to pay him for his help. Thus, he has become a positive deviant in the village (what he does not know yet =) ). Unfortunately, I was not able to take photos of the internal parts as the furnace was on the working mode.
pads.title: HOMEMADE ENERGY EFFICIENT HEATING SYSTEM

pads.content:
"Art-Benches" in the park (Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan)
"Art-Benches" in the park (Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan)
Young artists (Daniel Abdyldaev & Nelli Erkin) devoted their creativity to making Bishkek City more inclusive. This is the winning project in #NewBishkek competition organized by the Bishkek City Development Agency together with its sponsor. This was installed a couple years ago, with the initial concept "bringing strangers together to communicate" (inclusive community). At present during the pandemic crisis, it contributes to observe social distancing while communicating;)
I personally talked to Daniel about this work. He shared me that they got inspired by the benches in Kiev. But together with other creative designs of benches, they proposed to Bishkek City hall to launch a map of art-benches in different parks. Citizens can order their preferred design online and donate money for installing benches for their beloved Bishkek City. Nevertheless, the project was not proceeded further. As for now, let us acknowledge the innovative initiative and their concept of "inclusive community" by this work.
pads.title: "Art-Benches" in the park (Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan)

pads.content:
Second life of meat store rubber bands
In the store, I got curious when I saw the plastic bucket with many colorful rubber bands around it. I was intrigued where they were coming from and what purpose they served in the meat section. I talked to the two ladies at the counter who shared that they [sales people] usually receive plastic bags with one rubber band around it to keep the bags together. This one lady collects the rubber bands instead of discarding them and uses them for various purposes. For example, she said rubber bands help calculators to stick their together when they get old and about to break. Another purpose she shared with me was using the plastic bands to bind cash, which is a more common usage. 
This solution does not answer a particular need, however, it shows creativity to use every day items, such as rubber bands. 
The lesson for me was that people can find different ways to use a simple thing like a rubber band. Even though it was not a primary object (i.e. it came as a 'package' for plastic bags), some sales people saved rubber bands for future use sometimes not even knowing what they would need them for. 
Once I saw these rubber bands and talked to the women who were saving them, I started noticing that quite a few sales people have similar pattern of behavior - saving rubber bands and using them differently. When I talked to multiple (four) people saying it is cool to see how they use the bands, women were smiling mentioning that this is a usual thing and there is nothing special about it. This shows how people often take these small acts of 'innovation' for granted even though someone actually had to come up with it.
pads.title: Second life of meat store rubber bands

pads.content:
Energy-saving thermo-box for fresh vegetables
Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. Today is November 29, 'armed' with ski jacket and curiosity I went out from home on cold streets of Bishkek. It is unusually cold for November in Bishkek - minus 5 degree. The day before strong snowfall colored everything in white. 
In my neighborhood municipal administration arranged temporary market place and allowed local farmers and small producers to sell their products for citizens of the city during weekends. Walking by rows of trading places, I was thinking if I can find something which is worth the grassroot innovation name. It was a last row and I said myself "Where I should go next to find the innovations?", and immediately I faced with farmer selling his vegetables in interesting boxes. Bingo! I greeted him "Salam aleykum!" and he answered "Waleykum assalam!". 
After traditional greetings I asked his permission to interview him and make some photos. Bakhadyr baike (brother in Kyrgyz language) told his story. His name is Bakhadyr and he lives in Sretenka village in 45 kilometers from Bishkek city. Twenty years ago Bakhadyr with his wife decided to immigrate from the South of Kyrgyzstan to neighborhood of Bishkek for 'better live'. Now they have a daughter and a son. His family has a small land (plant is 50 ares) where they grow potatoes, bell pepper, pumpkin and other vegetables. 
Bakhadyr told that last three weeks were very cold in Bishkek (up to minus 12 degrees!), so it was hard to keep vegetables (especially, perishable ones) in good condition. Many traders in the streets challenged with high risk to lose their goods and save the only source of income. Bakhadyr was thinking how to sustain his 'green' worth. One day he decided to construct 'thermos' for keeping temperature warmer than outside. He drawn a design of box, took 2 insulation lists (left after repair works) and scotch tape. After several manipulations two new and promising boxes were ready to use.
Testing was very successful, and it is amazing that fresh bell pumpkins stay 'tradable'. In order to increase temperature in thermo-box, from time to time Bakhadyr lights a candle inside.
By the way, Bakhadyr said that he has another grassroot innovations in his household, and I hope that I will have a chance to discover new innovations and share new stories how ordinary people solve daily challenges.
pads.title: Energy-saving thermo-box for fresh vegetables

pads.content:
A loving father hand-made a "carriage" for his princess to commute to school
Kyrgyzstan News Attatyk reported a story of a father with disability living poor. Amidst the pandemic crisis, it is not safe for children to commute to schools in public transportation. Worse, the family have been poverty-stricken, since the father lost his job after he got injured at the construction work place. 
Poverty with deteriorating health conditions doesn't stop this loving father from taking care of his children. Father, Maksatbek, used his innovative ideas and unconditional love to design and hand-made a special "carriage" for his 7-year-old daughter. Everyday he bikes with this carriage where his daughter sits inside with all necessary facilities equipped. Neighbors and passengers kindly call the girl "Princess", whenever they see this biking father with the carriage passing by. 
Kyrgyzstan AccLab would like to share this moving story to present the empowered family with innovation, despite poverty and all life difficulties. This grassroots invention ensures children's safety in the pandemic crisis. Moreover, it is an eco-friendly transportation tool that can be adopted by other families in poverty.
pads.title: A loving father hand-made a "carriage" for his princess to commute to school

pads.content:
Green Map Belarus
The “Green map” (www.Greenmap.by) is a resource where information on important ecological sites is collected: collection points for waste and unnecessary things; organizations involved in environmental protection; places where there are renewable energy units; unique natural areas such as parks, gardens, nature reserves.
The map makes it possible to leave comments about individual points and their photos.
The community of the volunteers of the map who take constant part in the work on the project, has increased to 50 people. The resource receives 5000–5500 visits per month.
This is Maria Suma, the founder of the Green Map. She is an environmental activist, plastics hater, vegan and struggler fo women's rights and equal empowerment. Her email is suma@ecoidea.by and you can contact her. 
the map is based on OpenStreetMap software and allows to program additional layers on it.
On the picture above the map shows the collection points for paper waste, as an example, and you can see that the whole territory of Belarus is covered with Green Map.
The “Green map” displays information on all the towns of the Republic of Belarus. Educational institutions, eco-NGOs, state environmental organizations, laboratories, wind generators, solar installations, solar water heaters, hydroelectric power stations, biogas plants, natural territories, natural sites, specially protected natural areas, recreation parks, nature monuments and many other environmental objects are marked on the “Green map”.
For the outstanding contribution into the development of the information society, the widespread implementation of information and communication technologies, elimination of the digital gap between and within the countries, the project “Green map of Belarus” won the first place in the nomination “E-environment” at the largest world competition “World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS)”. The prize was awarded at the WSIS Forum held in Geneva on 12-15 June 2017. A total of 345 projects from all over the world were submitted for the contest, and the winners were selected in 18 categories.
That's how the volunteer work of Maria was rewarded on a very high level. This is a wonderful example how digital tools can help to organize the volunteer work.
pads.title: Green Map Belarus

pads.content:
Separate corpopative phonebook on your Android phone
Hello, I'm Dr. Piotr Sachek (piotr.sachek@undp.org), and I'm the Head of Exploration in UNDP Belarus AccLab. And I love programming under Android.
Since I'm working with dozens of people and always need to share contacts of my partners with my teammates, it would be wonderful not to mix personal contacts in a phonebook with corporate ones. It would be nice to have a standalone phoneboom with corporate contacts. And I developed it.
The contact are uploaded from FTP server every time the app starts and connection available, so, the contactlist is always fresh, and is similar on all the devices that installed it.
No more Excel spreadsheets with phones and emails of your colleagues in the office! No more folded papers in the pocket! The secretary can update it on the FTP server, and the updated information on contacts will immediately be available for all your colleagues.
You don't need to search your colleague by its name in your personal phonebook, as the contacts are grouped by companies and departments. You don't need to remember, who is sitting in the chair you need to contact.
By pressing the button with phone number your phone calls to the specified phone number.
By oressing the button with email you're emailing to the person, by pressing the website button or a button with social profile you're redirected to the person's website or social network. 
Wonderful app, always helps me.
pads.title: Separate corpopative phonebook on your Android phone

pads.content:
Oilcloth "house" for local bread is changing women's bread selling business 
Osh bazaar is one of the largest local markets in Bishkek city. It attracts clients with abandance of food products, fruits and vegitables and oriental delicicies. Local bread is called nan, japkan nan or lepeshka, this is a type of bread made in central asian baking technology in "tandyr" heated by firewood. In one of the part of bazaar, the row is specialized for lepeshka bread and you will see energetic women selling traditional breads.
pads.title: Oilcloth "house" for local bread is changing women's bread selling business

pads.content:
Platform to aggregate environmental monitoring data from civic and government
All the purchased equipment complies with the requirements of the legislation of the Republic of Belarus on the uniformity of measurements (equipment is indicated in the State Register of Measuring Instruments and verified). In addition to monitoring equipment, “green schools” received equipment to visualize the results of observations.
The monitoring toolkit includes both equipment for measuring air quality and other environmental components, and this electronic platform for collecting and processing monitoring data. An element of the electronic platform is an electronic diary of environmental observations available to users registered on the site (with a username and password).
The electronic platform is integrated into the NSMOS system and is supported by Belhydromet. Access to entering data on the electronic platform and its receipt is provided both from personal computers and mobile devices (smartphones and tablets), for which a link to download the application for Android is located on the main page. Monitoring data is available to a wide range of users through the Internet on this site, and club members and students of "green schools" act as suppliers of monitoring information, participating in monitoring events.
Monitoring data is available to a wide range of users through the Internet on this site, and club members and students of "green schools" act as suppliers of monitoring information, participating in monitoring events.
For training in the use of equipment, a Guide on the use of equipment for monitoring atmospheric air for “green schools” was developed, published, sent to “green schools” and resource centers that received monitoring equipment and posted on this site (in Russian).
The environmental monitoring platform integrates weather stations operating on the basis of "green schools" and weather stations of Belhydromet into a single network.
Meteorological parameters from weather stations of “green schools” are entered and stored in the section “Data of green schools”. Belhydromet weather stations transmit their data to the platform and this data are stored in the menu item “Data of the Hydromet” information that is collected by the “green schools” is also exported to the Hydromet using this platform for further work.
The geographical coverage of the green school eco-monitoring system covers 18 points. This network covers the whole Republic of Belarus.
The geographical coverage of Belhydromet consists of 53 automatic weather stations that transmit parameters to Belhydromet, and which are also displayed in this electronic platform.
All Internet users can see and download publicly available data in the "Green Schools Data" section - "Green Schools - Base of All Observations Validated by Belhydromet." This is the basis of all observations validated by Belhydromet. This menu item includes the data that Belhydromet has decided to publish.
My name is Dr. Piotr Sachek (piotr.sachek@undp.org). Under my supervision and general management this platform was created, the 18 points tha are situated on the basis of Green Schools were trained in using it, and now I'm responsible for functioning of this platform and data transferring from Green Schools to Belhydromet (State Hydrometeorogical Service) and vice versa. The parameters of CO2 emmision, weather data, etc. can be used by civil society to predict emergency situations.
pads.title: Platform to aggregate environmental monitoring data from civic and government

pads.content:
Public Lights auto managed 
Solution developped by Diao and Condé .
In Guinea, electricity is existing long time ago but with covarage holes. Added to that, in the special rural area, to mitigate power supply need and the management problem to avoid public light being active for 24H in so that the rest of the population could be served. CONDE has decided to set available his auto-managed Public Lights. Composed by a LED lightning and 220 to 12V converter, this solution can be reproduced in different format. It's particularity is the sensor incorporated in the converter that enables the switching to light when dakness comes or OFF when day light is felt. Using it can help decrease the consumption and waste of electricity.
pads.title: Public Lights auto managed

pads.content:
Electric and motorless transport for increasing the speed of touristic flow
This is Nesvizh, a UNESCO point where the ancient park fo 5 ha full of stories is situated.
Many elderly people go there every year. But it was inconvenient for people to go hiking around these 5 ha of specially protected nature area, where the usage of transport with internal combustion engines is prohibited.
So, the Victor Rovba proposed to organize the internal logistics in the park with the use of motorless and e-transport.
For the groups of 7-10 people with elderly ones the electric bus was purchased.
For the small groups of 2-4 people where there are younger people - the velomobiles were purchased,
For the families or pairs - bicycles and hyroscooters were purchased.
All these helped to speed up the tourist flow, and now Nesvizh park can accept 4 times more tourists than before. The revenue also increased, surely. 
The e-bus is widely used to transport weddings. The e-bus was adapted to the climate of Belarus by producing doors and installation of Webasto heater. This allowed to widen it's use during the year and use it until the temperature is upper than +7 degrees Celsium (from early April up to November)
pads.title: Electric and motorless transport for increasing the speed of touristic flow

pads.content:
Recycled
Walking around my locality, I observed that the trees of the taxi stand had been preserved and made into benches by the taxi drivers instead of being cut (like so many other taxi stands over the island). They wanted to preserve the environment and hence have transformed the trees into some sitting space as well as shade providers as they work through the day, especially during the hot summers over the island. Just a small note, there was also an area within the trees that they had transformed into a prayer spot for their work.
Dry, heavy sunshine and droughts are affecting so many areas of the island. Trees are cut for development and most of the time no new trees are planted. Therefore this observation of preservation of trees throughout development and enhancement of the locality is the perfect example that sustainable development of the locality, cleaner environment for the taxi drivers as well as the preservation of trees for shade making and sitting area can work together.
Development is possible, through the most sustainable way. Trees do not need to be cut down for development or settlement. Development and preservation of the environment can work together and this observation is the perfect example of the community commitment to sustainable development and preservation of the environment.
pads.title: Recycled

pads.content:
Eco-friendly glycerol-based antifreeze for internal combustion engines
The production was established within the UNDP project "Supporting the Transition to a Green Economy in the Republic of Belarus".
Establishment of this production led to the creation of the conditions for the transition from the use of environmentally unsafe coolants based on ethylene glycol polluting the soil to a low-risk analogue produced in Belarus; it is based on glycerol, a substance widely used even in the cosmetics industry as safe in small quantities and not polluting the soil.
To avoid engine overheating, vehicle manufacturers recommend changing the coolant every 45-50 thousand kilometers.
Capacity - about 1000 tons of antifreeze per year (up to 5% of the Belarusian market capacity).
Emissions - 0.3 tons of substances into the air per year (filter installed).
The samples of the new product “Antifreeze ECO-100” underwent laboratory tests in RUE “Scientific and Practical Center for Hygiene”. The distinctive feature of the product is that with its properties it may replace the more expensive imported hazardous analogues of the 1st and 2nd classes, while the disposal of this product would cost enterprises with vehicle fleets a lot cheaper.
Implementation of the pilot initiative made it possible to create conditions for gradual replacement in the Republic of Belarus of up to 5% of the annually consumed volume of the existing coolants to an environmentally friendly analogue produced in Belarus and to access the markets of the Eurasian Economic Community (the volume of coolants consumed in the Republic of Belarus is about 13,000 tons per year).
To get the sample of this antifreeze or establish a partnership, you can contact gomelhimtorg@tut.by
pads.title: Eco-friendly glycerol-based antifreeze for internal combustion engines

pads.content:
From Shipping Drums to Mini Gardens
In my childhood village, I observed swathes of blue in almost every backyard. They turned out to be mini vegetable gardens being cultivated in old shipping drums, which people started when COVID-19 began to impact Barbados. I spoke with Angela, who said she's been planting everything from eggplants to beans to lettuce to herbs -- out of necessity and as part of their efforts to stay active during the lockdown. She and her neighbors are doing it all organically, without chemicals. In addition, the community is recycling the water drums and experimenting with rainwater harvesting, instead of irrigating with water from the country's stressed water supply system.
Barbados is a country heavily dependent on food imports -- and faced the harsh reality of a dwindling food supply at the height of the pandemic. In addition, it is classified as a water-scarce country, an issue that climate change has exacerbated. This solution encourages sustainable community agriculture where land space is limited but the need for food and nutrition is high. It addresses multiple needs for food, water conservation, and income.
There are many lessons to be learned. Here are some of them:
1. When communities work together to solve a common problem, there can be viable solutions.
2. Start where you are, use what you have -- in their small backyards, with recycled shipping barrels/drums, and homemade agriculture solutions, this community is saving money, saving water, and eating well.
3. Be willing to experiment. -- Not every vegetable they've tried has succeeded. The okras didn't work out well, neither did some of the herbs but that hasn't deterred them.
pads.title: From Shipping Drums to Mini Gardens

pads.content:
The remote Power reboot
Created by Djime CONDE
In general case, for remote actions we see in the movies it is all about connected houses. Some households in Africa and most part of the world are wasting energy just because the owner forgot to switch off the power before leaving the place. In France, Out of 250,000 annual fires, 80,000 are of electrical origin. 40% of the victims are children under 9 years old. So to avoid such kind of problem and taking in consideration that power is very expensive ressource that should be well managed, here is a proposition of Power management with a GSM mobile phone. all you need is to send an SMS of instruction that is going to enable the requested action. So if you have to switch off any electrical component remotely, and you just have GSM coverage, this is yours!
pads.title: The remote Power reboot

pads.content:
Mobile Garden Composting
This one wheel chart traditionally was designed in order to help the farmers to feed the animal. Though I found a very creative redesign of it. The owner of the device has added additional net around the base, and has adopted it for his garden. 
He described that, no longer he has animals, though only fruit trees, and in autumn there are many leaves in the garden. This old equipment was redesigned for the garden; he collects all the leaves and puts them here continuously. The equipment is able to move and come next the the trees, and then move it somewhere where the rain will not flood it. 
The owner described that he lets the leaves compost here, and in spring the compost is put back to the garden of the flowers, vegetables, and fruit bushes and trees. 
Natural compost is in high demand, especially for the farmers that grow organic products. He explained that circular production is very important, and that he reuses the leaves both reducing the waste, as well producing his own resources for organic production. 
Creative setup from a old tool, to a new purpose - the farmer had in-depth understanding on the circler cycle of the natural resources, as well as was able to add a greater value to his product by reducing the carbon footprints, and lowering the production cost for his flowers, vegetables, and fruits.
pads.title: Mobile Garden Composting

pads.content:
Heating brick
Every day, between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. in winter, Casavalle has low voltage. If you want to plug something in, the thermal keys get off. This is because there are many people who are hanging from the electric lines.

Even garbage trucks often do not pass because the cables are low, and that is because people hang from the line. It is a vicious cycle of poverty.

5 teenagers from Casavalle (a very low-income neighborhood in Montevideo) decided to create something that could help everyone. They created a heating system using wind energy with materials that are easily accessible. Fan propellers, washing machine pumps and fire bricks. The energy comes from the wind that makes the fan blades spin rapidly; behind the paddles the washing machine pump is connected. This washing machine pump can be removed from any that is in disuse. A cable is connected from the pump that transmits the energy to a shielded resistance (it is found inside the electric jugs). Finally, the resistance is embedded within a firebrick.
The idea is that the brick is part of the structure of the house and that all this installation goes outside the houses, because today there is a risk in precarious houses that the resistances above the bricks set everything on fire.

Whit this brick, the house can be heat in a very cheap way and accessible.
1- The cold of the winter in precarious houses. 
2-People hanging from the electric lines.
3- Garbage trucks often do not pass
The energy and the disposition of the people who live in the neighborhood that wants to find solutions is very great.
pads.title: Heating brick

pads.content:
Horse House
Due to lack of space, and also due to economic resources, this neighbor could not have a stable for his horse. So what he did was this little house that puts her in a space to keep her horse overnight.
The lack of space to keep the horse safe. 
Not only did he solve this need that he had with the horse, but also many neighbors began to consult him to rent this little house for housing. This shows the need for space on the one hand, and on the other hand that the need that many people have to have home where to live, leads some people to consider sleeping in a space as small and without comforts as where the horse sleeps.
pads.title: Horse House

pads.content:
WARMING OF A BUILDING'S GROUND FLOOR
In order to keep warm inside the building, people use plastic film over the windows. In general the temperature inside could be 8 degrees higher than without the film.
pads.title: WARMING OF A BUILDING'S GROUND FLOOR

pads.content:
Recycled water tank trailer with a drinker for cows
For some, it may be an old and rusty water tank, for Henry, an opportunity to reuse and recycle, but above all, to solve a challenge in the field.
This solution allows the cows to drink water regardless of the place and time of year. In this way, Henry can reuse the water and take it or share it where it is most needed.
That with a little ingenuity, you can achieve great solutions.
Using recycled materials, it is possible to contribute to better water management in the field.
Never underestimate a solution. This water tank trailer with a drinker could be vital in critical situations in the countryside.
pads.title: Recycled water tank trailer with a drinker for cows

pads.content:
Drivers of Bishkek minibuses
Drivers of minibuses which play a role of public transport are like octopus. They give a change, listen to music, talk over their phones with their peer drivers to learn where the traffic police stay and mobile tripod speed cameras are installed.
pads.title: Drivers of Bishkek minibuses

pads.content:
Bikeshaw
To introduce you to this innovation, I have to gave you a bit of background information.
Trishaw is a common neighbourhood transportation in Yangon, Myanmar. When you want to go to the market and carry a load of groceries, trishaw is always a first option for the city dwellers. And, Yangon never allowed motorbikes due to a controversial policy under the military regime, which has not changed under two terms of civilian government. However, under the difficult circumstances of Covid-19 restricitions, motorbikes came into picture with new form, bikeshaw!
A traditional trishaw is a tricycle, a bicycle with a carriage attached to it, but this new motorbike trishaw (which I named as bikeshaw :D ) attached a carriage to a motorbike. Those of you who know tuk tuk would wonder, what's the difference? Then, I would have to say this is Yangon's new interpretation of tuk tuk. :)
Check out the comparison of traditional trishaw and the modified bikeshaw in the below picture.
These bikeshaws mostly serve as mobile shops during Covid 19. When people are reluctant to go out to buy their daily needs, these bikeshaws fulfil these needs by transporting the local vendors in front of your house. Instead of tedious peddling of trishaw, the bikeshaw drivers easily carry the goods and sell around or carry both a street vendor and the goods on their bikeshaws. My mornings would start with the recorded voices of these local vendors playing from their bikeshaws selling raw meat and fishes to fresh coconuts. The convenience of these bikeshaws expand the coverage of the local vendors who would usually use trishaws or carts. In return, it increases their sales and empowering them their businesses running during this difficult time of Covid-19.
Need is one of the main driver for innovation.
These bikeshaws are still in question for legality, but these serve the purpose for the people already and it would be difficult for the government to neglect it. I believe that these bikeshaws would change the policy on bikes by the local government of Yangon. Sometimes, needs prevail the rules.
While the potentials of these bikeshaws such as in the delivery services limited by utilising bicycles because motorbikes are illegals, and in solving traffic congestion, we also need to foresee the potentials of third order negative consequences.
pads.title: Bikeshaw

pads.content:
Parasol stall
Vendors set up stalls on the street with parasols
Limited resources and space to set up a store
Vendors can set up their stalls without structures and improve visibility
pads.title: Parasol stall

pads.content: Travel truck for the store
pads.title: Travel truck for the store

pads.content:
Playing LIDO in the Night !
By Diallo and Conde 
The game is called "LIDO" and we enjoy playing it in Africa. Most of time precisely during the holidays. Fine, if ti is to be played in the day time also in the night where light is. In general, once there is power outage, no more game and we have to wait untill it come back again. So to stay active during outages, here is a solution created by the team. It is supplyed in power by 2 to 4 LEDs that are working with 5V Battery. so if you are projecting to travel and are not sure to find light were you are targetting to go please check "the Freedom fighter ̈Power bank" that can easily be used with this one to produce up to 5 years power stock for you.

pads.title: pillars from old tires for the food store made of trailer

pads.content:
The solution is the cooperation of several neighboring restaurants that sha...
The solution is the cooperation of several neighboring restaurants that share the kitchen to keep the business running. Due to the Covid-19 Pandemic, many restaurants in Georgia were closed. Lack of customers and the bargain of the regulations made the business unprofitable. To maintain the business open and at least some of the staff, three neighboring restaurants decided to run only one kitchen that would serve all three menus. The solution required a rearrangement of tables to meet the Covid-19 restrictions and create a menu-bundle. Shared space allows them to receive more visitors, while at the same time keep jobs of at least some of the personnel.
pads.title: The solution is the cooperation of several neighboring restaurants that sha...

pads.content:
Recyclage de pneus usagés en matériel de collecte de déchets
La structure Fortitude / REAGIS s'intéresse à la gestion des déchets à Niamey, et travaille étroitement avec les communautés et les acteurs en charge de la salubrité de la ville de Niamey pour mettre en œuvre des solutions concrètes à la prolifération des déchets dans la ville . Elle est à l'origine de la conception et de la réalisation de poubelles à partir de pneus recyclés. Faisant partie des plus gros déchets, régulièrement brûlés lorsqu'inutilisables, les pneus retrouvent une seconde vie : la structure les recycle essentiellement en poubelles, mais aussi en mobilier intérieur (poufs, tables...) et parfois même pour le remballage des nids de poule sur les voies goudronnées (qui sont dans ce cas plus solides qu'à travers la voie normale).
pads.title: Recyclage de pneus usagés en matériel de collecte de déchets

pads.content:
Shoreline Protection
Communities repurpose used oil drums for protecting shorelines from erosion
pads.title: Shoreline Protection

pads.content:
Food Security- Pawpaw Diversification
A household diversified into various forms of food security on an atoll setting. This is for food security and various other purposes. The pawpaw leaves provides medicinal values, whilst the fruit is used for many other reasons such as making of jam, provision of nutrition, curry, etc.

The game is called "DAME" and we enjoy playing it in Africa. Strategy and reflexion...

The game is called "DAME" , strategic and High reflexion game. We enjoy playing it in Africa. Most of time precisely during the holidays. Food Security- Table top Gardening

Repurposing old refrigerators for growing food.
A household repurposes old used refrigerators for growing taro.

pads.content:
Repurposing Pipes and Tanks
A fisherman use a PVC pipe to provide balance and keep the canoe afloat, the fisherman also utilize pieces of old water tank to compartmentalize the canoe, and as well utilize an ice cream container as a water decanter.
pads.title: Repurposing Pipes and Tanks

pads.content:
Handicraft- Hand held fans.
Women in Tuvalu (only few who know how to weave it) craft hand held fans. These fans are weaved in by using different colored plastic raffia strings, and also by fetching bird feathers. Only few women are able to weave is such types of fan in Tuvalu.

pads.content:
TELE-IRRIGATION
La « Télé-Irrigation » : c’est un procédé technologique qui permet à un agriculteur de piloter à distance le système d’irrigation de son exploitation agricole quelque soit sa position géographique et le temps au moyen de son téléphone mobile, du solaire et des capteurs IOT suivant une distribution intelligente de l’eau (besoins, quantité, temps, type spéculation...). La Télé-Irrigation permet également de collecter et diffuser en temps réel et à distance les données météorologiques et hydrologiques notamment la température, le taux d’humidité du sol, la pluviométrie, la radiation solaire, la vitesse du vent..... Ce dispositif permet à un agriculteur de s’enquérir de l’état du besoin hydrique de son exploitation et les conditions climatiques qui y prévalait quelque soit sa position dans le monde. Ce dispositif permet également de disposer de la traçabilité des données climatiques d’une zone et sur plusieurs années grâce à son système de stockage des données. Ce procédé permet à l’exploitant (i) un gain de temps et d’énergie, (ii) une augmentation de la superficie irrigable, (iii) un accroissement de la production et du revenu et (iv) une gestion maitrisée d’eau d’irrigation. Le kit Télé-Irrigation est composé d’une station solaire, d’un moyen d’exhaure (pompe solaire), d’un réseau de distribution d’eau, d’un équipement télécom et d’une application vocale mutualisée hébergée dans notre datacenter.
En quoi est-ce que cette innovation locale est innovante? La Télé-Irrigation est indépendante du temps et de l’espace et contribue à la réduction de la pauvreté par la génération de revenu aux producteurs. Elle contribue à la réduction de gaz à effet de serre par la substitution de l’énergie thermique avec l’énergie renouvelable. Au plan macro économique elle participe d’une part à la réalisation de l’Objectif N°1 des Objectifs du Développement Durable (ODD1) qui est de réduire l’extrême pauvreté et la faim qui doit passer nécessairement par la bonne gestion de l’eau donc de l’irrigation et d’autre part à l’accroissement du taux de pénétration de la téléphonie en zone rurale et la création du trafic chez les operateurs.
Quelques photos de télé-irrigation au Niger
pads.title: TELE-IRRIGATION

pads.content:
Cleaning the Nile 
VeryNile is the first initiative to develop sustainable means to clean the Nile while raising awareness on the importance of protecting our environment. VeryNile interlaces social and environmental impact and develops eco-friendly solutions to remove inorganic waste from the river. The key activities of the initiative are: - Cleaning (Socially and economically empowers local fishermen to clean the Nile on a daily basis, Launched the first cleaning boat in Africa. VeryNile I has been designed in Germany by the NGO One Earth One Ocean and built in Egypt thanks to their support. Finally, VeryNile organizes various clean-up events where volunteers can gather in one predetermined location to physically clean the banks of the Nile) - Recycling (To make this project sustainable and to replicate and scale it elsewhere, collected recyclables are sold to recycling agencies. VeryNile is currently in the process of developing collaborations with various sectors to begin integrating Nile recyclables into new upcycled and recycled products. - Preventing (Banning single use plastic bags in Zamalek, Awareness Campaigns, Developing Solid Waste Management Solutions) - Social impact (Community Engagement, Job creation, Very Nile Hub) http://verynile.org/
pads.title: Cleaning the Nile

pads.content:
Art and the Future of Climate
The Future of Climate in Iraq Exhibition is an art exhibition that invites new players in the community to think about the future, grasp the aspiration of the Iraqi community in response to climate change challenges and share their own perception of the climate they want to see in Iraq in the long-term using visual art. This participatory future approach will invite people to avoid short-termism and think in the long-term as well as engage the public through creating the purpose to start impacting decision-making and identifying local solutions that are aligned with the local community priorities. This exhibition aims to build the capacities of the Iraqi local community to think long-term and participate in drawing the future they want, and throughout the whole process unite people, give them hope, and a shared identity about the future they want. Goals: The sensing initiatives aim to engage people through online submissions to scan, sense, explore and forecast the future of climate and mainly: - Change the way of thinking of the Iraqi local community to think long-term and participate in drawing the future they want through art. - Engaging more people and new players in thinking about the future will lead to startups that satisfy market needs and better decision making. The initiative does not target only experts and decision-makers but target the local Iraqi community in order to avoid cognitive bias and groupthink. - The future thinking participatory approach helps the implementers of the initiative to: - Show “blind spots” that are not included in our research. - Harness collective intelligence of the future - Analyze change in a specific issue over time - Spur ideas and knowledge that help in drawing out potential futures and achieve that through promoting collective actions in the present. - This approach will engage citizens in long-term thinking about climate change and inform the Accelerator Lab and partners next steps when analyzing the challenges and drawing the portfolio of solutions. - Imagining the future solutions for the climate challenges in order to help the implementers to direct and dig deep to shape the current solutions to match the future needs. - Supporting the UNDP Environment Energy and Climate Change pillar (EECC) and the partners to have another point of view from the community level to tackle the challenges by bringing the community priorities on the table. - Brining new players to have a voice; minds in the margins are not marginal minds! Giving the voice to artists. - Using unusual and new data sources and analysis to provide input for UNDP and partners. - Identifying the prioritizes of the local communities in order to support in building local solutions, startups, around them.
https://www.iq.undp.org/content/iraq/en/home/blog/stories-from-the-future-of-climate-in-iraq.html
https://www.iq.undp.org/content/iraq/en/home/stories/2020/12/young-iraqis-sharing-their-vision-for-a-greener-iraq.html
pads.title: Art and the Future of Climate

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - making tourists more informed
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One of the challenges is that tourists often lack information on the history of the specific places within the CHT region. To address this issue, one solution that has been identified in consultation with the locals is that the history of the tourist spots should be documented very clearly, consulting relevant literature, and some experts with relevant knowledge should be employed to do so. This can help increase interest among tourists, particularly those interested in travel, and also make them more mindful about maintaining the integrity of the places they are visiting.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - making tourists more informed

pads.content:
Kaya Slice
This innovation changed the texture and form of kaya jam (coconut egg jam) into slices. Kaya slice can be eaten on its own or with bread. This innovation makes storing and preparation of the jam easier. Moreover, through innovations and application of food technology, the fishy smell of jam has been solved and it also increased the shelf life of the product.

pads.content:
SASER Scientific Calculator
This is the first scientific calculator built by Malaysian. This non-programmable calculator comes with transformation modes such as translation, reflection, twist and augmentation. It is able to determine the image coordination accurately once the object coordination and transformation instruction are keyed in. Moreover, it is user-friendly, doesn't require high cost, time-saving and easy to use. The innovation has received gold medals at the International Engineering Innovation Exhibition (i-ENVEX) 2018 and International Young Scientist Innovation Exhibition (IYSIE) 2018.
pads.title: SASER Scientific Calculator

pads.content:
Volvariella Volvacae Mushroom Planting System
District Education Office officer, Mr Mohamad Yuzaidi Azmi introduced the farming of Volvariella Volvacae Mushroom to small farmers in Kedah as an alternative crop to increase their income. 
The volvariela mushrooms (strawed mushrooms) are planted using soaked palm branches as crop sites, instead of previous method where they use rice straw as a planting medium. The crops use no chemical substances while maximizing the land use in rubber plantations. 
The suitable climate and palm branches in Malaysia help to produce up to 6 kilograms of mushrooms at each crop site after 30 days.
pads.title: Volvariella Volvacae Mushroom Planting System

pads.title: Mangrove restoration

pads.content:
Foklic Trolley
Based in Sabak Bernam, Selangor, the innovation of foklic trolley is used to carry heavy loads. On the front side of the trolley is a forklift moving the trolley upward and downward. This innovation can lift loads to a higher level up to 1.5m high without the need for many workers. The trolley requires 12V battery and is rechargeable.
pads.title: Foklic Trolley

pads.content:
Medi Bike Exerciser
Rehabilitation Units may face insufficient equipments problem for patients with muscle weakness, paralysis and imbalance and coordination problems. This increases the treatment time for patients and slows their discharge process. Medi Bike Exerciser was innovated to able exercise activities for upper and lower limbs to be carried out simultaneously, reducing the treatment time by 50% . The bike has four pedals- two four hands and two for feet, enabling patient to move their upper and lower body simultaneously. The MBE can be adjusted to the patient's height and position, maintaining an ergonomic body posture. The flexible shape of the bike allows patients to cycle easily from various locations such as beds, wheelchairs and chairs. Made of strong and stainless steel, the MBE weighs only 6.7 kg and is also equipped with wheels for easy transfer. It is also equipped with rubber on the base to reduce slippage. The bike is an affordable alternative and does not require electricity. With this price, patients can afford to own and rehabilitate in their respective homes without having to commute to the hospital.
pads.title: Medi Bike Exerciser

pads.content:
TremorX
TremorX is a tool to help parkinson's and autistic patients in improving hand stability when writing. Tremors in the hands also affect the quality of handwriting and this problem will limit the ability of the patient's hands. The product is able to control and produce writing that is easier to read.
pads.title: TremorX

pads.content:
Reusable Electronic Components
Electronic devises are collected and stored in a warehouse. Electronic components are then separated and transformed into a new devise or sold individually to repair another electronic devise
pads.title: Reusable Electronic Components

pads.content:
Community Farm Enterprise
At Ulu Gumum Indigenous Village in Pahang, Malaysia, the villagers are stricken by poverty and low income, have diminished natural resources and access to clean water, poor housing and roads, and poor access to health and education. Despite these, the community shows interest in farming where the Foundation for Community Studies and Development's (YKPM) came and supported them to provide a source of stable income and limiting the needs to clear the forest for cash crops. The solutions: Community Farm Enterprise was introduced to the local villagers of indigenous people to encourage organic farming. The initiative started with 8 farmers after months of preparation and has increased to more than 50 farmers at present. The farmers planted over 30 types of vegetables such as bottle gourds, eggplants. tomatoes, long beans, corn, Brazilian spinach and okra. After five years since the project started, major supermarket franchise Jaya Grocer became a marketplace for the farm produce to be sold under their own brand, OA Organik. Progress: A dedicated team for compost making was initiated as more produce are being grown while keeping the price affordable for all the farmers. At the same time, the community is able to build a stronger organization in managing quality control, packing produces, procurement of seeds, maintenance for irrigation and equipment and bookkeeping. Impact: Since the project started, the local villagers are able to purchase their own seeds and farming equipment after earning up to four times their previous total income. They have also purchased washing machines, cars, motorbikes and expanded their house to live more comfortably. With funding support, management workshops and farm training are able to take place for the local communities to get hands-on training and coaching. The success of this initiative for the indigenous people to improve their livelihood has allowed replication of the farming practices to other villages. OA Organik also hopes to build an integrated farm with fruits, vegetables and farm animals while practising compost making from recycled materials and farm waste.
pads.title: Community Farm Enterprise

pads.content:
All-Lights Village Project
Most villages in rural Pahang still do not have access to electricity and have to rely on oil lamps for light sources. Some issues faced by the villagers include the high energy spending for electricity but a small return, and environmental and health impact by burning palm kernels. A common electricity source used by the villagers is a battery that can only be used for charging at a limited number of times. Global Peace Foundation (GPF) All-Lights Village solar project is a sustainable solution that combines solar technology with clean water solutions, education, income generation, and public-private partnerships to improve the quality of life of the Indigenous People communities. The initiatives taken include building custom houses to preserve their customs and traditions, introduction to committee building with participation from women and youth, and livelihood skills workshops such as on food farming.
pads.title: All-Lights Village Project

pads.content:
Prefabricated ecological stoves
Prefabricated ecological stoves designed to replace the use of the traditional stove, that produces high smoke emissions that cause serious health problems. Mexican concrete company CEMEX manufactures the stoves with a clean technology design that concentrates heat in a closed and protected concrete compartment, and reduces smoke emissions inside the home by up to 99%. Efficiency: 65% reduction of wood / 1lt of water boils in 7' min. Lifetime: 15 years
https://www.cemexmexico.com/sostenibilidad/vivienda/estufas-ecologicas
pads.title: Prefabricated ecological stoves

pads.content:
Power Bank of the Freedom fighter
Inventors : Mamadou Cellou Diallo and Djime Condé.
If you are in pain to recharge your phone, in a non-electrified area, if you don't have time to wait for your phone to recharge even better, if you think you are paying too much for power banks that do not last for long time then here is your solution: the power bank of the freedom fighter. With a compact frame, it has a minimum autonomy of 5 years and is self-charging without a foreign source of electricity. It allows you to generate by using two dynamos of the voltage current of 12 and 5V (for this prototype in picture) stored using batteries, all connected on by two switches, the first one is responsible for activation a 12V dynamo to generate power to be stored in the batteries and the second is responsible for the distribution of needed power. For this case 5V for charging the phone. 
In picture, the power switcher allowing the bateries to receive electricity.
Applying charging cable through the USB port to power supply the phone.
Please see how it works, Enjoy!
pads.title: Power Bank of the Freedom fighter

pads.content:
"MINI-RESPIRATOR", imagination and créativité at the front line of resistance to the COVID19 ! 
Here is our local frespirator invented by Mamadou Cellou DIALLO and Djime CONDE.
Like a simple letter box, with a empty ballon stuck on the back orifice, please see the local respirator invented to support the ministry of public health to secure and save lives of millions of citizen. the box itself is a 25cm side cube in what you have a system realising all the mecanism on the respirator as we see in the hospital. The respirator is powered by a 12V source. It is equiped with an electrical switch and a tube that will be linked to the patient for him to breath easily 
The Back side with the 12V power entry and the switch to stop the operation.
Please see how it works, Enjoy !
pads.title: "MINI-RESPIRATOR", imagination and créativité at the front line of resistance to the COVID19 !

pads.content:
Empowering Indigenous People towards Environmental Stewardship
Wildlife Conservation and Science (WCS) Malaysia works to protect the habitats of orangutans, tigers, elephants, sharks and rays in Malaysia. Through their project, “Empowering Orang Asli Jakun in Johor and Iban Communities in Sarawak towards Environmental Stewardship”, it empowers local communities via conservation education towards the survival of endangered animal species. The project focuses on the site's importance for remnant orangutan populations, elephants and tigers. Solutions: 1. Connects communities with agencies for patrolling efforts by implementing an effective first line surveillance on the ground. -A Siren fence system was introduced to solve Human-Elephant conflict. An early warning system will alarm the farmers when elephants try to enter their crop fields, reducing crop-raiding problems. The siren fence consists of a thin, horizontal steel wire supported by wooden poles along the perimeter of the crop field. The alarm kit consists of a switch, car siren and 12 volt dry-lead acid battery attached to the wire which will trigger the siren when elephants come in touch with it. Local communities are also able to operate GPS devices, satellite phones and digital cameras on their own though patrolling training. Allowances are given to participating patrols. 
2. Pilot Eco-tourism program - The eco-tourism program is a community-based eco-host project through nature education. To ensure the program runs smoothly and materials as well as seminars can be conducted online, they introduced an Internet booster initiative that will help the community to participate. The success of this tourism plan will allow replication on other sites and promoting tourism at indigenous village sites. 3. Publishment of a folklore book entitled ‘Wildlife Tales and Iban Myths from Sabah and Gunung Lesong’ - The book consists of 21 folklore stories originally in Iban language and are translated into English language. As of now, 200 copies of books are ready for distribution. 4. Radio program - Poor phone and internet coverage in the villages lead to the hosting of a radio program consisting of 9 episodes of 3 minutes weekly. Radio program is one of the suitable ways in getting communication and information to learn and share knowledge.
pads.title: Empowering Indigenous People towards Environmental Stewardship

pads.content:
Strengthening Community-based Enterprise in Conservation and Commercialisation of Products 
Sarawak Biodiversity Centre (SBC) in Malaysia conducts general biodiversity inventory and regulates general biodiversity research. Their work focuses on the documentation of traditional knowledge in Sarawak. SBC, together with local communities have discovered the commercial potential of local herbs (Adenosma nelsonioides) during their traditional knowledge documentation program with the Bidayuh and Iban communities. The opportunities to transfer traditional knowledge into research, product development and commercialization will promote benefit-sharing between entrepreneurs and the local community. Solutions: Supply of plant materials and oil production The discovery of the plant species Adenosma nelsonioides which possess anti-bacterial properties as well as fragrant smell sees an opportunity to develop essential oil products, hygiene products and natural repellency. Efforts by SBC to supply plant materials and in production of oil have allowed the community to plant, harvest and distill the essential oil by themself. The project also empowers women farmers as they learn new skills and get extra income from providing the raw resources to SBC. Following the discovery and production, the intellectual property of this plant has been filed for protection, empowering the community to have a strong ownership towards their biological resources. Community empowerment Co-operative establishment to manage community funds. Entrepreneurship workshop and skills training. myOrganic workshop. Community-based eco-tourism and farms Community-based projects such as eco-tourism and farms will explore more opportunities for the local community to provide a sustainable livelihood and protect their natural resources. This comes with the application of good agricultural practices and well-equipped facilities provided by SBC.
pads.title: Strengthening Community-based Enterprise in Conservation and Commercialisation of Products

pads.content:
Strengthening Indigenous Communities in Malaysia 
PACOS is an organisation based in Sabah, Malaysia dedicated towards empowering indigenous communities through systematic building and strengthening of community organizations. The project, “Strengthening Indigenous Communities in Malaysia by Initiating Community-Based Enterprise, Promoting Traditional Knowledge and Addressing Land Degradation” has benefitted 19 Indigenous People communities to ensure they have their rights on using resources and strengthen indigenous knowledge, culture and belief systems. The initiatives by PACOS to accomplish their objectives include: Skills training program for community-based enterprise. Training on nature farming and food processing, and basic entrepreneurship skills. 6 out of 10 groups who participated in the training are now suppliers for the community market. Sales and marketing program. Use of natural resources to provide income to the communities. Products sold include local delicacies, vegetables and fruits from 26 suppliers. The program has reached 175 online customers in which 25% of customers have repeated the orders. Documenting and promoting traditional knowledge. Knowledge in handicrafts, traditional herbs, clothing wear, food recipes, traditional musical instruments, and traditional fishing instruments.
pads.title: Strengthening Indigenous Communities in Malaysia

pads.content:
What3Words for tourism navigation
The platform allows sharing the exact GPS coordinates in three common and unique words. Every 3x3-meter spot has its unique in most languages which helps remote businesses in the tourism sector, where addresses are often confusing or missing at all, ensure comfort in the navigation to their customers. 
Ukraine Lab is working with the National Tourism Agency to scale up the technology in Ukraine.
As an example, GPS coordinates in the viral video about tourist locations in Ukraine on Instagram could be easily substituted for the 3 words that describe exactly the same spot (screenshots below). It is much easier to remember/type/dictate with voice the three easy words, than 16 numbers.
pads.title: What3Words for tourism navigation

Autonomous Sargassum Seaweed Harvester
Sargassum harvester that is scalable and autonomous, providing an electric harvesting solution in the Caribbean. Called "Thalasso," this solution can forecast, contain, protect, harvest, and commercialize sargassum, thus managing its influxes in the region. This also provides a much more affordable option for sargassum maintenance. The idea is to use the sargassum harvested by Thalasso for high value products, such as sargablocks, animal food or fertilizer.
pads.title: Autonomous Sargassum Seaweed Harvester

https://www2.whoi.edu/site/cohenlab/super-reefs/

pads.content:
Indigenous Communities and Forest Reserves in Central Sabah
Forever Sabah serves a collaborative social movement by building programs through engaging communities, government agencies, private sector and NGOs in supporting the state’s transition to a diversified and circular economy. Their project, Indigenous Communities and Forest Reserves in Central Sabah: Livelihood Transformation in the Context of Shared Forest Governance and Jurisdictional Certification of Oil Palm smallholders adopting sustainable agricultural practices focuses on solutions for oil palms at forest reserves in Telupid and Tongod districts. The solutions and activities carried out include: Facilitate land-use agreement. Agronomic planning and exposure visit. Launch and implement transition by sourcing seedling and planting in designated zones. Communities are to be part of the supply chain in the long-term. Discuss and decide on specific crops for transition with communities.
pads.title: Indigenous Communities and Forest Reserves in Central Sabah

pads.content:
Lower Kinabatangan Segama Wetlands Conservation
Land Empowerment Animals People (LEAP) Spiral engage and empower communities in moving reactive conservation to proactive stewardship. Through their project, "Lower Kinabatangan Segama Wetlands Conservation: Advancing Indigenous Initiatives for Sustaining Fisheries, Mangroves, Forests and Wildlife in the Co-management of Malaysia’s Largest Ramsar Site", the solutions and activities carried out are as follow. Solutions: Open Data Kit system to determine income baseline and as a community-based fisheries monitoring program. They have received 700 datasets from over 400 fishermen since June 2020. The system allows each community member to extract data in Excel to see income levels, capital cost, and strategies for fisheries recovery plan. Procurement of raw materials for community cleaning up activities. Created a database for orang utan and ongoing community mapping. Established community internet facilities- projectors, audio equipment, electricity control units and internet signal booster.
pads.title: Lower Kinabatangan Segama Wetlands Conservation
