pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - enhancing transport infrastructure
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One of the challenges is that there are some tourists who go to camp to the most remote parts of CHT e.g., Marathon mountain to observe sunrise and sunset and live-in tents to do so. But the absence of proper road networks makes it difficult to access these areas. Putting road numbers and creating new road networks between tourist spots such as Bilai chhori Ruma, Thanchi and Cox's Bazar without damaging the eco-system can be potential solutions and these will be useful not only to attract new tourists who want to venture off the beaten path but also to encourage repeat visits.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - enhancing transport infrastructure

pads.content:
Scrap Sites as an Informal Business for Provision of Waste as Reusable Material
Scrap sites in Jordan serve as a provider of waste as a material that can be reused by different creatives, like designers of furniture and home accessories, "Escape the Room" businesses for their spaces, and film directors for movie sets. 
They function as an informal business and a scrap site owner we spoke to described himself as a business owner. They also work with pick up truck drivers who drive around to pick up scrap from neighborhoods. They may also have connections with migrant workers who work as apartment building guards and cleaners, who help the scrap sites with procuring material from apartments. 
They not only sell material, but they may also repair products (such as electronics) and sell them for half the original price. 
Notes from site visit: 
Pickup trucks gather waste from houses
Trucks sell the scrap to the sites,
Scrap sites sell to factories 
Mostly customers are individuals Or stores downtown; sometimes small companies 
Export to Syria 
No connection to fablabs in the country. Didn’t seem to have any sense of what a fablab is - something to explore further. 
Land is not regulated . Difference in opinion on whether regulation would be a good thing. One person said it would be a headache financially, procedurally, etc. The other said that it would allow them to go into official tendering processes عطاءات 
They advertise their material on an online platform called Open Sooq. https://jo.opensooq.com/en 
Screenshots from OpenSooq
Observations: so many toilets, bidets, and sinks! What is the deal with so many being thrown away? So many colorful wooden doors. Steel, tires, wood scraps, plastic items
Outliers: exercise machines, children’s bikes and electric cars, typewriter, mannequin, old sewing machine, branded store shelves 
Questions/ideas: 
Can Fablabs use these scraps? Could the scrap sites benefit from a collaboration with the Fablabs in the country? 
Would they benefit from a way of organizing the scraps (currently very messy, some better than others) 
Do a visual mapping of what items get thrown away and use that to analyze consumption and what are the most commonly found scraps 
Can something be tested related to maintenance and reuse of these items?
pads.title: Scrap Sites as an Informal Business for Provision of Waste as Reusable Material

pads.content:
Jordan Open Source Association -filling the gap of open tech expertise in Jordan
https://www.josa.ngo/ 
"JOSA is the not for profit organisation that works for a better Jordan through openness in technology."
The Jordan Open Source Association (JOSA) is a non-profit organisation based in Amman, Jordan. The association is among the few non-profits registered under the Jordan Ministry of Digital Economy and Entrepreneurship.
JOSA’s mission is to promote open source principles for the good of the Jordanian society. We believe that information that is non-personal – whether it’s software code, hardware design blueprints, data, network protocols and architecture, content – should be free for everyone to view, use, share, and modify. Our belief also holds that information that is personal should be protected within legal and technological frameworks. Access to the modern Web should likewise remain open.
pads.title: Jordan Open Source Association -filling the gap of open tech expertise in Jordan

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - respecting indigenous culture
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One key challenge is that the predominantly Bengali tourists coming to the Chittagong Hill Tracts region often do not explore and understand the local and ethnic culture of the indigenous minorities residing in the CHT. Tourists are also often not respectful of the local culture, customs, which can create friction with the indigenous people. To address this issue, initiatives need to be taken to identify, prioritize and promote local and ethnic culture among the ethnic majority Bengali tourists. One solution could be provision of training to the tourists to make sure they aware of the local customs and respectful of the traditions of the places they are visiting.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - respecting indigenous culture

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - reducing environmental impacts
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. Tourists visiting the CHT region are often not mindful of the impact of their activities on the environment and litter indiscriminately. To address this issue, preventive measures can be taken such as sending text messages about waste disposal, setting up billboards with such messages and providing bins for tourists. There can also be a website developed with the relevant information and some videos made to raise awareness of waste disposal and management. A digital platform can be developed under the district office and all content can be made available under that. Tourist guides should always mention the waste disposal issue at the beginning of the tour and some messages against littering could be made available at the tourist spots.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - reducing environmental impacts

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - uniforms for tour guides
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. To this end, one of the challenges identified during local consultations was that tourists often find it difficult to identify tour guides in crowded places. A potential solution for this could be providing the tour guides specific uniforms such as the one pictured so that tourists can easily identify them in case they are lost.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - uniforms for tour guides

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - exploring remote regions
Difficult to access areas in the CHT are not meeting their tourism potential, as such areas are not offering much to attract tourists. Such areas that are challenging can be made more interesting through addition of some extreme sport activities and made more expensive to access so that only those with the highest threshold for risks and adventurous will venture into those areas. It is important to note that expenses will be higher for ensuring safety of extreme sports, and hence tourists need to be informed and targeted accordingly or some form of sponsorship/subsidization will be needed.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - exploring remote regions

pads.content:
Conversion of fuel to electric cars
Profiting from existing car structures to eliminate their pollution

They start with the vehicle by eliminating the components that will not be of use: main engine, gear, cooling system, exhaust system and tank and everything related to fuel.
Then they adapt and take advantage of existing parts using the same manual transmission, brake system and electrical system.
Finally, they install new components. The electric motor, its controller and the battery are the vital elements for the system. Additionally, other auxiliary and control components are installed.
pads.title: Conversion of fuel to electric cars

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - mindful driving
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. A key complaint of many tourists visiting the CHT is that the drivers often drive in a risky manner and do not have legal documents, which discourages many tourists from venturing into different parts of the region. To address this issue, a solution is to provide training for the local drivers on maintaining safety protocols while driving in the hill tracts region and also helping them access driving license following the completion of their training.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - mindful driving

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - need for better tour packages
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One of the challenges identified is that there is a lack of tour packages that provide combined mountain & sea tours, which is an expectation from tourists since CHT is close to Cox Bazar - the largest uninterrupted sea beach in the world. To address this issue, training can be provided to the tour operators to develop tour packages such as 3 days package, 5 days package and 10 days package for areas such as Thanchi, Ruma Cox's Bazar and Bilai chhori, thus covering both mountain and sea.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - need for better tour packages

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - need for conducive policies
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. 
One of the key challenges identified is that there is a dearth of relevant local policies regarding tourism in the CHT region. For e.g., the rates of boat rides are not standardized, with different boats charging different amounts to tourists. Similarly, when tourists rent cars, there is no clarity regarding whether parking fee is included with the renting fee of the car, and when tourists are unprepared for these hidden costs and are charged different parking fees at different spots, it often creates resentment and can give them a negative tourism experience, discouraging future visits.
To address these concerns, policies can be developed to make such fees standardized and publicly listed. If there is a price list available, that can help increase transparency and enable the tourists to make informed decisions about the costs. Relevant good policies regarding tourism from other regions in the country could also be replicated in the CHT.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - need for conducive policies

pads.content:
Promoting entrepreneurial education at the K12 level in Bangladesh
UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab joined hands with 'PathFinder’ - a unique, virtual cross-cultural educational platform that aims to educate K-12 level students, including disadvantaged schools - to develop a multi-country program to introduce entrepreneurship education to high-school students. The idea was to empower these students, unleash their creativity, encourage a mindset of abundance and self-determination, and promote purposeful entrepreneurial action. The Accelerator Lab in collaboration with Pathfinder organized a bootcamp in which 24 students participated, of which fourteen were from Bangladesh, six from Zambia, four from India, one from Sweden, and nine from the Philippines. There were three workshops designed for the participants, focusing on SDG - 4 ‘Quality Education’, SDG-5, ‘Gender Equality’, and SDG-17 ‘Partnership for Goals’. The workshops were on SDG learning, Problem Framing, and Human-Centric Design Thinking which was conducted by subject matter specialists. These workshops enhanced the participants’ knowledge about digging into a problem and finding practical solutions. During the problem-solving sessions students identified some of the biggest challenges in their home countries and other participating nations in the Bootcamp. The students devised solutions to their identified problems and presented their solution ideas to the judges and the winning team was provided a mini grant from Peace First to implement their idea. This bootcamp sparked passion among the participating high school students and inspired them to put their ideas into action. The Bootcamp was an international collaboration made possible due to strong support from a diverse group of institutions including The Resolution Project, Peace First, Impact Hub Dhaka, OC365, and Unleash Plus. In early 2022, PathFinder is launching its three-month-long cohort with UNDP Accelerator Lab Bangladesh and partner organizations. Through these cohorts, 250+ students will be engaged to become SDG solution change-makers to make our community more inclusive and sustainable.
pads.title: Promoting entrepreneurial education at the K12 level in Bangladesh

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - ensuring tourists' safety
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT region. One of the challenges to this end is that tourists are often unaware of and unprepared for the physical rigor of exploring the CHT, which can lead to them being demotivated or worse, injured. To address this, the tourists should be trained so that they are aware of the physical rigor of the venture they are embarking on and associated risks, including topics such as basic first aid, height they will be climbing, ways they can build a small bridge using locally available resources and ways to manage risks in different weather conditions. The picture shows a pilot first aid training organized by the accelerator lab in collaboration with the tour operators association of Bangladesh.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - ensuring tourists' safety

pads.content:
Sustainable tourism in CHT - reducing "othering" of ethnic minorities
Sustainable tourism can be a viable pathway to achieve economic empowerment, particularly of informal workers of Bangladesh. Cooperation between indigenous minorities and Bengalis living in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) - a major tourist destination of the country - is key to achieving this. To formulate solutions to this end, the Bangladesh Accelerator Lab conducted several extended field visits to this region and, in consultation with the locals, identified a portfolio of solutions to address the plethora of prevalent challenges and promote sustainable tourism in the CHT. One challenge identified is that with the influx of hoards of tourists of predominantly Bengali ethnicity, the local indigenous populations can feel a sense of loss of agency. To reduce the level of “othering” of the locals, the tour guides should be local residents instead of people from outside the CHT who might be better trained but not necessarily familiar with the local context.
pads.title: Sustainable tourism in CHT - reducing "othering" of ethnic minorities

With over 400 entries, Majalla.mv is one of the largest digital repositories in the Maldives, aiming to revive the old and lost Dhivehi magazines and books. Whistles to stop and prevent violence against women, teenagers and children
Photograph: Red Mesa de Mujeres The organization Red Mesa de Mujeres from Ciudad Juárez is promoting neighborhood support groups and the use of whistles to call the attention, prevent and stop acts of harrasment, violence and potential danger against women, teenagers or children. The whistle is distributed along with flyers and other items that have the telephones of police and authorities. The sound will be an alert signal to call for support and to try to disinhibit the attacker while the authorities are called to 911. The whistle is relevant because often the police can take a long time to answer and alternative means of support are required. "Although we are confined by the pandemic and we wear masks, we must not remain silent when we see acts of violence ” –Isabel Aguilera González, neighbor and promoter of the Riberas del Bravo neighborhood network.

pads.content:
Retail chain supporting women employees escape violence
Companies can have an impactful role in helping employees in escaping gender violence as Maga Lu, a large retail company in Brazil, has done since 2017. The solution includes a hotline, that beyond only redirect to social services, also has psychologists, monitors of cases, and resources to offer relocation and a support network through the process of recovering.
Beyond the tools, the innovation here is the focus, reconsidering work as an important network for every person that can be more than just a transactional salary-task exchange.
So far more than 700 have been supported to escape abusive relationships legally, financially, and emotionally and the company has paid to relocate over 100 of these women.
The level of engagement is unusual for a company, especially when many see it as a too complex matter, but helps support the idea that gender violence is NOT a problem of women, but of society as a whole where we all have a responsibility and a role to play.
https://reasonstobecheerful.world/magalu-brazil-domestic-violence-help-employees/
pads.title: Retail chain supporting women employees escape violence

pads.content:
"Ai Nono" - Traditional practice of constructing rock formations in the sea for fish habitats. 
Ai Nono involves carefully constructing rock formations in the sea, within the traditional fishing ground, with the goal of it becoming a location where fish, octopus, clams, sea urchins, and many more sea creatures have a safe breeding space to reproduce and nurture their young. The ‘Ai Nono’ has a special significance in the tradition and culture of the Vanua of Nawerelevu since it is the site where the people catch ‘Dekedeke’, a traditional delicacy which is only caught, prepared, and served during special traditional ceremonies for guests who come to Sinuvaca. The Dekedeke delicacy consists of the different types of fish that are nurtured within these carefully constructed rock formations. Because of the Ai Nonos, the people of Sinuvaca are fortunate to have an abundant supply of fish, for generations, and the fishing grounds of Sinuvaca are always bountiful.
pads.title: "Ai Nono" - Traditional practice of constructing rock formations in the sea for fish habitats.

pads.content:
BILA - TRADITIONAL FIJIAN DELICACY MADE FROM FERMENTED CASSAVA

Selling ‘bila’, a traditional Fijian delicacy made from fermented cassava is a major source of income for many women from Tailevu, Fiji. To make bila: cassava is peeled, washed, and grated. Juice from grated cassava is left to sit for over four nights before cooking it, which takes approximately two (or more) days. It is a long process that usually takes more than six days. The end product is then sold for FJD$1 a piece.
Fermentation increases the amount of B vitamins in the cassava, therefore the process of making bila adds nutritional value to cassava.
Additionally, bila is usually made from leftover cassava crop from farms and market produce that were not able to be sold, so it has become an innovative way to address food waste.
: https://www.fbcnews.com.fj/business/bila-is-a-fast-seller-in-the-suva-market/
https://www.spc.int/DigitalLibrary/Doc/PHD/Unsorted/Healthy_Lifestyle/Nutrition/Food_leaflet_compilation.pdf
pads.title: BILA - TRADITIONAL FIJIAN DELICACY MADE FROM FERMENTED CASSAVA

NEW PACIFIC ONLINE PAYMENT SOLUTION
A new and innovative payment platform for Pacific businesses has been introduced by the trade and investment promotion agency, Pacific Trade Invest (PTI) Australia, Fiji Hotel and Tourism Association, Hotel Link and WHL. ‘Hotel Link Pay’ was created by Hotel Link and Kovena, offering accommodation providers a fully integrated solution to process online payments cost-effectively and efficiently via their Hotel Link Booking engine or Front Desk module. With tourism in the Pacific so badly impacted by the pandemic, the service helps enable operators of all sizes to accept payments from guests locally and internationally. This was previously a service that was hard for small and medium operators to access, and often extremely costly.
https://fijisun.com.fj/2021/10/12/new-pacific-online-payment-solution-introduced/
pads.title: NEW PACIFIC ONLINE PAYMENT SOLUTION

pads.content:
Traditional Fijian Marine Protected Area Brings Life Back to Reef
Local managers of Leleuvia Island Resort enforced a ‘tabu’ which is a traditional Fijian ban in a certain marine area, where there is to be no fishing or disturbance of marine life. Cyclones, overfishing and poor waste management system left the reef in poor condition. However, 2 years after the tabu was implemented the reef and marine life began to flourish, with a permanent shark nursery now in place, which has also become a tourist attraction. ‘Tabu’ or a no-fishing zone is a traditional Fijian instrument used in many Fijian communities. They are traditional marine protected areas which have been reintroduced to Fijian waters after many decades, ‘tabus’ represent a return to traditional approaches of reefs and fisheries management. These locally managed marine protected areas empower coastal communities to take ownership of their natural resources.
https://www.leleuvia.com/blog/tabu-leads-to-shark-nursery
https://wwf.panda.org/wwf_news/?55580/Tabu-waters-Protecting-Fijis-Great-Sea-Reef#:~:text=Waitui%20tabu%2C%20or%20prohibited%20fishing,species%20and%20habitats%20as%20possible.&text=In%20efforts%20to%20protect%20the,network%20of%20marine%20protected%20areas.
pads.title: Traditional Fijian Marine Protected Area Brings Life Back to Reef

pads.content:
CO-WORKING SPACE (GREENHOUSE COWORKING AND MYDESK)
Provides people from various professional backgrounds a comfortable space to work, with internet access, particularly convenient at a time when more people are working remotely due to COVID19 pandemic restrictions.
This was first introduced in Fiji by The Greenhouse Studio founder and director, Maria Ronna Luna Pastorizo-Sekiguchi. Coworking spaces are shared workspaces, made affordable for those starting up a new business, entrepreneurs, consultants, freelancers, and small teams because the cost of running an office and all amenities is also shared by the members of the space.
The co-working space is an innovative solution as it is very relevant to the current challenges facing MSMEs in the country.
Additionally, in the current socio-economic context, working remotely and/or in isolation for long periods of time can become emotionally/ mentally overwhelming, so having a supportive community both virtually and in person is important.
https://www.greenhouseco.work/
https://www.fbcnews.com.fj/business/koya-launches-mydesk-co-working-space/
pads.title: CO-WORKING SPACE (GREENHOUSE COWORKING AND MYDESK)

pads.content:
TAVIOKA ORGANIC PRODUCTS (FIJI) PTE LTD—COMMERCIALIZING CASSAVA FLOUR
The introduction of the company's new cassava flour product, using locally sourced cassava, will provide increased employment, reduce food loss, and raise people’s standard of living. The process of turning cassava into flour adds value to an already commonly grown crop.
Cassava flour is gluten-free, rich in carbohydrates and Vitamin C, and low in calories, fat, and sugar. It also contains more protein and fiber than white (wheat) flour.
In 2020, Fiji imported approximately $111.4million worth of wheat. A shift to cassava flour by the local market, or occasionally alternating between wheat and cassava flour may mean a slight reduction on the high importation of wheat, as the latter works as a suitable import substitute for wheat flour.
https://fijisun.com.fj/2021/12/07/cassava-flour-enterprise-launched/
https://www.fiji.gov.fj/Media-Centre/News/INNOVATION-CRITICAL-TO-BOOST-IMPORT-SUBSTITUTION
pads.title: TAVIOKA ORGANIC PRODUCTS (FIJI) PTE LTD—COMMERCIALIZING CASSAVA FLOUR

The move to the new platform, which has online loan approvals, automated documentation and can be operated from the cane fields, is especially crucial during COVID19 pandemic lockdowns and travel restrictions.

pads.content:
NATURE BASED SEAWALL—SOLUTION TO COASTAL EROSION
300 villagers and 1 school will be benefit from the construction of a 450-meter nature-based ‘hybrid’ seawall built with bouldering work, land reclamation, and rows of mangroves and vetiver planting. The seawall will not only protect the coastline and village but will promote marine biodiversity by creating a home for many marine species. In 2020, a similar nature-based seawall was successfully implemented in Macuata, Vanualevu, Fiji using mangroves, boulders, and vetiver grass. However, more time is needed to assess the level of success these nature-based seawalls will provide in the long term.
https://www.fiji.gov.fj/Media-Centre/News/NAMATAKULA-SEAWALL-CONSTRUCTION-WORKS-BEGINS
https://www.fbcnews.com.fj/news/relocation-never-an-option-for-namatakula-villagers/

#InnovationChallenge: Learning thru family games
This solution was mapped thanks to the third edition of the challenge "Innovating together for children and sustainable development", which aimed to boost solutions that had an impact on clean and affordable energy or solid and liquid waste management. It is a game that teaches how to classify common solid waste to children from 5 to 14 years old, being this a population of 3,290,835 children according to the CENSUS conducted in 2,018 by the National Institute of Statistics. The game is based on intuitive challenges that complete 5 levels where they will learn to classify their household waste. The tool seeks to provide environmental education through a digital application that facilitates learning to care for the environment through the proper disposal of household waste and solid waste

This solution was mapped thanks to the third edition of the challenge "Innovating together for children and sustainable development", which aimed to boost solutions that had an impact on clean and affordable energy or solid and liquid waste management. It consists of collecting solid waste for recycling and creating urban gardens that allow families to take advantage of the resources they have around them and the creation of a collection center to collect recyclable waste and sell it to a recycler to generate income for families so that they can obtain the harvest of their production and not despair that this can contribute to improving their family, personal and community economy.

#InnovationChallenge: Connecting people wirelessly 

Social Hub is smart furniture that generates sustainable energy and provides high speed internet. Powered by solar energy with wired USB chargers and wireless charging, rest and socializing space, chargers for electric mobility, energy storage, information points, high speed Wifi Hot Spot, environmental sensors and non-polluting digital advertising. Divided into circuits or zones that create modern communities to transform Guatemala into smart cities, one smart space at a time.
They help with community solutions for sustainable development, such as waste management through wireless sensors, promote micro-mobility, reduce the digital divide, generate big data in real time, we are inclusive and aimed at growth from rural to urban, supporting the most vulnerable population.

Social work to build formalize waste Pickers associaton and build trust and accountability
Inclusive Recycling
Asuncion Green City of the Americas (UNDP Paraguay Environment Portfolio)
Improving labor productivity of informal waste pickers (as an enabler for financing better social protection) requires collective action in the recycling system to improve sorting of waste and the logistics of waste collection. We observed how strengthening the capacity of associations or organizations of informal workers, particularly the trust among them and between them and other actors in the recycling system, are key elements in the pathway towards productivity and the formalization of associative relationships. Both these processes are signaling toward a long-term investment in their cooperative practices and collective assets as the tools to facilitate the formalization of their work by enabling access to social protection.
https://www.py.undp.org/content/paraguay/es/home/blog/2021/recycling-as-a-collective-action-dilemma.html
pads.title: Social work to build formalize waste Pickers associaton and build trust and accountability

pads.content:
FLOUR MADE FROM BREADFRUIT
Description: A 25-year-old Fijian medical student came up with the innovative idea to make breadfruit flour and through this business venture ‘Grassroots Fiji’, he is also assisting some Nadi villagers who have been affected by COVID-19, by sourcing all raw produce from these villages. Breadfruit flour is said to be a healthier alternative to wheat flour as it is gluten free, has low glycemic index, and is nutrient dense. Additionally, breadfruit protein is easier to digest than wheat protein.
https://www.fijivillage.com/news/Breadfruit-flour-and-moringa-powder-business-helps-families-in-Nadi-x458rf/?fbclid=IwAR3Z58e5sVuRK01MZNEYw1JrBqrcBP3iSkubz9VioleOXY8AvaNUEkcnqKw#.YEBvhD-ro40.facebook
https://www.facebook.com/search/top?q=grassroots%20fiji
pads.title: FLOUR MADE FROM BREADFRUIT

pads.content:
‘MESOVU’ - SOAP MADE FROM GOATS’ MILK CREATES EMPLOYMENT AND SUPPORTS LOCAL FARMERS
Fiji's first goat milk soap by woman entrepreneur Beatrice Nast has created employment opportunity for 2 Fijian women who will be making the soaps, as well as provided a means of income for 5 local farms that will be supplying the goats’ milk, and local virgin coconut oil producers. It will serve as a natural and organic product for both local people and international visitors, an ideal option for those with skin sensitivities as it is a natural alternative to soaps made with harsh chemicals.
https://fijisun.com.fj/2021/11/22/the-value-of-me-sovu/
pads.title: ‘MESOVU’ - SOAP MADE FROM GOATS’ MILK CREATES EMPLOYMENT AND SUPPORTS LOCAL FARMERS

pads.content:
YOUTH ENTREPRENEUR INSPIRES FELLOW ISLANDERS TO LEAD A PLANT-BASED LIFESTYLE
An indigenous Fijian youth entrepreneur ‘The Maoli Chef’ has made a business out of making and selling meat alternatives such as homemade firm tofu pack, tofu balls, and veggie patties. After the initial success of his products, he went on to expand his product offerings and now offers healthy plant-based breakfast, lunch and dinner meals that can be delivered anywhere within the Suva area.
The Maoli Chef can be found on Facebook and Instagram, with a full display of product offerings and weekly menu updates.
The aim of this business is to encourage other Pacific islanders to eat healthier and reduce meat consumption.
https://www.facebook.com/theMaoliChef/
pads.title: YOUTH ENTREPRENEUR INSPIRES FELLOW ISLANDERS TO LEAD A PLANT-BASED LIFESTYLE

pads.content:
LUXURY HIGH END PRODUCTS MADE WOTH PANDANUS LEAVES
‘Jiana&Me’ is a local Fijian business that sells high end purses and bags made from ‘voivoi’ (pandanus). The products are weaved by women from the village of Nakorosule, Naitasiri. It is generating consistent income for these women, and their products are also being sold internationally.
The products are 100% organic and bio-degradable, and can be used as a plastic alternative that is environmentally friendly.
https://www.facebook.com/jianaandme
pads.title: LUXURY HIGH END PRODUCTS MADE WOTH PANDANUS LEAVES

pads.content:
MOANA TAKA PARTNERSHIP TO ADDRESS CRITICAL WASTE MANAGEMENT ISSUES IN THE PACIFIC ISLANDS 
The Moana Taka Partnership is a memorandum of understanding (MoU) between the Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment (SPREP) and The China Navigation Company (CNCo). The partnership allows for CNCo vessels to carry containers of recyclable waste from eligible Pacific Island ports, without charge, to be sustainably treated or recycled in appropriate ports in Asia Pacific. This helps address some of the issues the Pacific Islands face regarding waste management barriers such as lack of waste treatment/ recycling infrastructure and geographical limitations. 21 countries are eligible for these opportunities: American Samoa, Cook Islands, Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, Fiji, French Polynesia, Kiribati, Republic of the Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Nauru, New Caledonia, Niue, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Timor Leste, Tonga, Tuvalu, Vanuatu and Wallis and Futuna. How it works: Swire Shipping, the liner business division of CNCo, regularly repositions empty shipping containers across the Pacific, which presents an ideal opportunity to transport recyclable waste out from these islands to other countries with suitable infrastructure.
https://www.sprep.org/news/moana-taka-partnership-unfolds-exciting-recycling-possibilities-pacific-islands#:~:text=Known%20as%20the%20%22Moana%20Taka,suitable%20ports%20in%20Asia%20Pacific
pads.title: MOANA TAKA PARTNERSHIP TO ADDRESS CRITICAL WASTE MANAGEMENT ISSUES IN THE PACIFIC ISLANDS

pads.content:
WASTE RECYCLERS FIJI LIMITED 
Waste Recyclers Fiji Limited (WRFL) is the leading private company in Fiji that provides a wide range of recycling and waste management solutions to a range of business houses, hotels and resorts—they have been in operation for over 25 years. 
Over the years, WRFL have built a special relationship with informal waste pickers, who are an essential part of their supply chain. Informal waste pickers ensure recyclables from dumpsites are recovered and delivered to WRFL. 
Through WRFL recycling incentives, an iTaukei (indigenous Fijian) woman was able to turn waste picking into a sustainable livelihood for herself and her family, where she was able to finance her children and grandchildren’s education abroad.
https://www.facebook.com/IRECYCLEFIJI/
pads.title: WASTE RECYCLERS FIJI LIMITED

pads.content:
Solve Ninja - Tech Platform for young people solving hyperlocal problems using micro-data 
Solve Ninja is a platform by Reap Benefit that activates young citizens to solve small problems that leave a big dent on their local communities. Reap Benefit is a social enterprise based in Bengaluru, India. Reap Benefits works with young people, enabling them to solve small local community problems. This not only helps young people in developing changemaking skills but also sow the seeds of active citizenship at a young age.
By using relatable graphics and language, Reap Benefit makes solving local problem engaging, fun and cool for young people. The Solve Ninja platform is user friendly and taps in the natural curiosity of the technology native young people. 
Solve Ninja does not promote any one way of solving a social problem. Instead, it acknowledges that each person can contribute in problem solving using their unique strength. This gives young people the self-permission to take charge of their local problems and come up with their unique solutions.
https://reapbenefit.org/about/
pads.title: Solve Ninja - Tech Platform for young people solving hyperlocal problems using micro-data

pads.content:
Garbology 101 - Waste Management Education through 101 interactive games and activities
WasteLess is a social enterprise based in India that works with school students in bringing behavior change around responsible consumption and proper disposal of waste, especially plastic waste. Garbology 101 and kNOw PLASTICS are two of the flagship programs designed and run by WasteLess. Garbology 101 is a set of interactive games and activities divided into 6 different themes, each providing a unique perspective on the generation and responsible management of waste. These themes work as lenses through which students can critically and holistically analyze the issue of waste. Through these programs, students understand different ways of understanding the waste problem and role children can play in solving this problem. kNOw PLASTIC is designed exclusively for children to understand different kinds of plastics that make up the waste and how different kinds of plastics can be up or recycled. Both these games use behavior change approach and are user centric. They also include instructions guide for teachers/ facilitators to run these games and design their waste management education sessions.
Garbology 101 – Wasteless (wastelessindia.org)
pads.title: Garbology 101 - Waste Management Education through 101 interactive games and activities

pads.content:
Accelerating Trash Economy using technology, policy interventions and social financing
Paperman is a social enterprise with a mission to accelerate the Trash Economy by investing in game-changing leaders and ideas, creating an enabling ecosystem through research and facilitation, and designing behavioral change interventions through collaboration. The portfolio of solutions includes different systemic solutions that enable efficient collection of waste, avenues for commoditizing waste thereby creating livelihoods and income for waste collectors, using the revenue from waste for social programs like healthcare and education.
product page - paperman (papermanfoundation.org)
pads.title: Accelerating Trash Economy using technology, policy interventions and social financing

pads.content:
Digital Literacy: Back to Basics and Moodle
To explore and map the untapped potential in ‘digital transformation’ that can accelerate action towards achieving SDGs in Cook Islands, Niue, Samoa, & Tokelau. Exploration and mapping of untapped potential in digital transformation for this GAP encompasses citizen participation with digital literacy. It is why the Accelerator Lab has chosen to map selected high schools under the Governance and Poverty Reduction Unit project with the Samoa Information and Technology Association as its initial foray into understanding the potential areas of interest in digital transformation.
Observations: Most of the computer labs visited including all government schools’ in Savaii either had obsolete machines that was only good for MS Office use or the labs were empty with the computers having been cleared out due to damage or non-use. The Accelerator Lab supported SITA in this endeavor by providing 2 routers (i.e. Vodafone and Digicel) for students and teachers to access the internet. However, it is to be noted that the best coverage in most of Savaii is that of Digicel. During the school lockdown when Covid-19 was first declared a pandemic, the schools has manually prepared and printed all learning materials for students which were then dropped off and picked up individual using teachers personal resources. Accessibility to wifi internet was very limited. SITA had also shared that when there is no router available, internet access for the trainings would be via mobile hotspot. Owning a personal smartphone or laptop device is not a priority for most students and teachers. Most of the surveyed are of the expectation that such devices should either be donated or provided by projects. Technology devices such as smartphones and laptops are not seen as another essential tool for education etc.
pads.title: Digital Literacy: Back to Basics and Moodle

pads.content:
Optimized design of streetside waste baskets
Inclusive Recycling
Asuncion Green City of the Americas (UNDP Paraguay Environment Portfolio)
An important barrier to sustainable waste management is the low level of separation of recyclable waste at the point of origin. A redesigned and optimized version of the typical street-side waste basket used by most households can facilitate better sorting behavior. This toolkit, developed by AccLabPY for a "light urban interventions" contest provides instructions for households or organizations to modify existing wastebaskets.
https://www.py.undp.org/content/paraguay/es/home/blog/2021/prototyping-a-new-generation-of-eco-friendly-wastebaskets.html
pads.title: Optimized design of streetside waste baskets

pads.content:
Open CRVS as a Digital Public Good
Even though civil registration is critical to citizen participation and effective governance, 44% of countries do not have functioning CRVS systems. Countries are currently stuck with inefficient paper-based systems or expensive and poorly designed information systems that are not flexible enough to adapt to changing operational environments. These existing systems do not meet the needs and capacities of the civil registration staff, leaving large parts of the population unregistered, unrecognised, and unprotected.
OpenCRVS is challenging the current gap in the market for a user-centric and rights-based CRVS system by leading the development of OpenCRVS, an open-source digital CRVS solution that is free to use, adaptable to the country context, interoperable with other government systems (e.g. health and ID systems), and rights-based to ensure it protects and provides for those most vulnerable.

OpenCRVS has the potential to go well beyond the scope of traditional CRVS systems. We see OpenCRVS as a foundational identity and population data system which will support and maintain the integrity of many other service delivery, statistical and identity management functions. In particular, OpenCRVS will ensure that these functions are above all inclusive, providing a digital response to the global call to “Leave No One Behind”.
Digital Transformation is one of the top priority areas for the government. In this a secure, open source technology for creating digital public good is quite relevant for Samoa and other SIDS that are trying to overcome the geographical exclusion through effective employment of digital solutions.
Our Solution | Opencrvs
pads.title: Open CRVS as a Digital Public Good

pads.content:
Recyclable Handmade Shopping Bag
Innovator: Dalida J Borlasa from Ambae Island in Vanuatu
Narrative: Single-use plastic has been banned in Vanuatu, however, the alternatives still comprise other plastic types. Dalida Borlasa from Malekula Island, Vanuatu, created a recyclable shopping bag that consists of a plastic rice bag sewn on the outside, fabric on the inside and a fabric handle that is comfortable to carry on the shoulder. She explains that it is waterproof due to the plastic rice bag side facing out, and if turned inside out, it can be used to carry frozen meat, or wet clothes during a day out at the beach, and the fabric outside can be used for fashion. It is easy to wash, dry, it is cheap and easy to carry around and can be easily folded.
Link: https://web.facebook.com/watch/?v=621290452435564
pads.title: Recyclable Handmade Shopping Bag

pads.content:
Handmade Plastic Wallets
Narrative: Despite the banning of single-use plastic in Vanuatu, there are other plastic materials that get thrown around Port Vila town and these include used packets of milk tea and coffee. Another initiative that Dalida Borlasa from Malekula Island, Vanuatu, came up with, are these wallets that are woven from used packets of milk tea and coffee. It is recyclable, handy, easy to wash, and the locals can afford the wallet. 
Innovator: Dalida J Borlasa
Link: https://web.facebook.com/veleniejacob/posts/332606138871275
pads.title: Handmade Plastic Wallets

pads.content:
Mara Technique: Banana Preservation Manual
Innovator: SPC/GIZ and elders in Futuna Island
Narrative: The mara technique is a food preservation method developed by the people of Futuna Island wherein unripe bananas are preserved over 2 years. It is a common technique that benefited the Futuna community from generation to generation, especially during cyclone seasons when food is scarce. The SPC-GIZ project documented the elders in Futuna explaining the Mara Technique and created a Bislama language guidebook and manual that anyone in Vanuatu can use to preserve bananas when severe cyclones or tropical disasters hit in the future.
Link: http://www.b4fn.org/news-events/news/going-bananas-vanuatu-turns-to-old-traditions-for-food-security/
pads.title: Mara Technique: Banana Preservation Manual

pads.content:
Imanaka Fishing Village
Innovator: Department of Fisheries
Narrative: The villagers of Tanna Island controlled their ocean resources using custom tradition techniques since 2011. However, some did not respect the ways of traditional fishing and violated the sacred area. The department of Fisheries stepped in and officially protected the area under the law of fisheries department, earlier in 2021. It is currently an official conservation area, as well as a fishing village that will benefit the community of Imanaka and Tafea Province as a whole. It is also a site where fishermen can go to fix their boats, and buy fishing gears and will also be a research facility for the department of Fisheries.
Link: https://web.facebook.com/departmentblofisheries/posts/2640599052909730
pads.title: Imanaka Fishing Village

pads.content:
Vanuatu Golden Hybrid Yam
Innovator: The Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) and Vanuatu Agriculture Research and Technical Centre (VARTC). 
Narrative: After 10 years of research work, the Vanuatu Golden Hybrid Yam (VGHY) was produced. It is a crossbreed of soft yam (Dioscorea Alata) and wild yam (Dioscorea Numularia) that can be harvested all year round. It is the first breeding trial that was conducted in Vanuatu and yields about 2kg and above. Twenty-three varieties of VGHY were raised in the multiplication plots in Santo in early 2021. This yam was bred to resist diseases affecting Yam and allow farmers to have access to climate-resilient varieties of root crop as well, which will benefit the population of Vanuatu in tropical disasters and also generate income for exporters.
Link: https://www.dailypost.vu/news/countdown-to-launch-of-vanuatu-golden-hybrid-yam/article_58d6c5b6-96db-5c2f-a753-c4c17b4b27f6.html
pads.title: Vanuatu Golden Hybrid Yam

pads.content:
Solar Food Dryer
Innovators: SPC/GIZ programme and Late Charlot Long Wah, Chinese origin, former Kava store entrepreneur in Vanuatu.
Narrative: Climate change threatens the bountiful harvests of fruits in Vanuatu such as mango, papaya, and tamarind. It is both a source of food and income for most of the population of Vanuatu. Charlot Long Wah, a Chinese living in Port Vila, developed this system of solar drying in collaboration with the SPC/GIZ programme and launched the solar drying system project. The solar drying system uses solar energy to naturally dry and preserves fruits, nuts, fish and meat, that can last up to a minimum of a year. This innovation was launched in North Efate in Vanuatu and helped the village women to produce dried quality products for food security as well as earn income.
Link: https://www.spc.int/sites/default/files/wordpresscontent/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Enhanced-food-security-and-alternate-income-opportunities-through-solar-fruit-drying-on-Pele-Island-Vanuatu.pdf
pads.title: Solar Food Dryer

pads.content:
Vetiver Grass and Pandanus: Coastal Erosion Prevention Measures
Innovators: Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD)
Narrative: The threat of climate change is a real concern to the beautiful beaches of Ifira Island. With the help of the Ifira community and the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Vetiver grass were planted along the coastal areas to help prevent sea sprays, prevent sand mining, it acts as windbreakers, trap sediments thus preventing coastal erosion. It is a cheap and locally available method that can minimize the negative impacts of Sea Level Rise. Every coastal community should adapt this soft measure.
Link: https://web.facebook.com/1638942406347986/posts/vetiver-grass-at-the-coastal-area-at-ifira-point-picture-below-showing-vetiver-g/2401757620066457/?_rdc=1&_rdr
pads.title: Vetiver Grass and Pandanus: Coastal Erosion Prevention Measures

pads.content:
Lokol Vibes Mobile Application
Innovator: James Rory from Malekula Island
Narrative: James Rory saw the potential in the young people of Vanuatu through their creativity with regard to music. Because the government hasn’t launched any music policy in Vanuatu, most of Vanuatu’s local musicians still struggle to promote their music at both local and global levels. James Rory developed the lokol vibes mobile application as an initiative that will help musicians in Vanuatu to protect, promote and at the same time sell their music in Vanuatu and wistfully, global as well. This app will regroup all the musicians in Vanuatu in order to build the music industry. Through the app, any individual can have access to any local songs of Vanuatu.
Link: https://web.facebook.com/yumiwork.vanuatu/posts/493383212066742
pads.title: Lokol Vibes Mobile Application

pads.content:
CB Vanuatu Microfinance Business: Mobile Application
Innovator: Celine Bareus of Malekula Island
Narrative: Celine Bareus started lending cash to friends about five years ago and it wasn’t a business plan back then, but mostly helping friends out. As days went by, more people started to access her services, proving it difficult to handle the demands of the growing number of clients. She consulted advisors and accountants to help her with a business idea, but she did not find the help that she needed. She thought around, her clients all used mobile phones, therefore the idea of developing an application came to her mind. And so, the CB Vanuatu microfinance business app was created and since then it has helped a lot of people with unstable financial statuses. At present, the business is growing, and every 10% of the businesses profit is donated to the communities around Vanuatu.
Link: https://apppage.net/preview/org.cb_vanuatu.cb_vanuatu
pads.title: CB Vanuatu Microfinance Business: Mobile Application

pads.content:
Moringa Local Products
Innovator: Nelsie James, former student of Aore Adventist Academy
Narrative: The majority of the Vanuatu population do not trust pharmacies and health centres but rely on natural remedies when they have health issues. Nelsie James, a former Aore Adventist student, has ventured into a small business with Moringa products such as soap bars, oils, even Moringa Jam. These local products help with white spots, ringworms, dandruff, helps rejuvenate dead skin cells caused by excessive kava drinking, heal and build the muscles, and freshen up the body after a shower. The price is affordable and provides individuals with huge health benefits.
Link: https://web.facebook.com/elizabeth.galomule/posts/10226473116994251?__cft__[0]=AZVV034miR9UWG2NONor2FfXYllhWK-miRDz_pCvrZaM-4XQJH21UcpNDlzKCHTsv7bBtDB-KG2A43XM93-tFs7piwQ6CiApyA_LTVIhwGDIZDJNpLLuT5Ti6lWV4r9RAbs&__tn__=%2CO%2CP-
pads.title: Moringa Local Products

pads.content:
Solar electric three-wheeler vehicle
Reduced a carbon emission and minimize expenditures through bringing a clean energy consuming vehicle into the transportation system.: The main aim of this innovation is to contribute a reduction of greenhouse gas emission from the transport system, while offering a cheapest and healthy means of transportation for low end economic community in sub-Saharan Africa and in particular Ethiopia. The innovative product is made out of mainly locally available resources and local capacity (a grassroot innovation). It is designed as a three-wheeler vehicle for space economy as well as energy efficiency. During its development the right partners were approached for standardization of the necessary parts of the three-wheeler vehicle for safety reasons. The product’s prototype has already tested functional and needs to be piloted with few revisions and under realistic situation in the transport system. In sub-Saharan rural parts such as Ethiopia, where population is growing at an alarming rate that exceeds the transport support system of the country. Therefore, opting to local innovations that solve this problem through making source of transportation energy renewable, and affordable by such low economic classes in the country. This will save the governments expenditure for fossil fuel subsidization that would rather fill other development gaps. This initiative will also put Ethiopia in fulfilling climate change mitigation strategies. Moreover, this innovative product supply chain of production could also open an opportunity for employment in the local automotive industry.
pads.title: Solar electric three-wheeler vehicle

Ethio Locate
Ethio Locate is a travel guide platform, that helps users find locations information and events for free with just simple clicks. This initiative intends to achieve a central database where travels or tourists or anyone seeking valuable information’s and locations of services providers on the digital world. The methodology that will lead us to a successful outcome is there is lack of information’s and locations of hospitality services providers in every city in Ethiopia and a high number of information seekers and services providers wanting to have a digital profile will lead us to a successful outcome. Providing our country Ethiopia on a digital world and giving services providers a digital profile of their information’s and location is the outcome to be achieved. Our country Ethiopia has a lot of tourism destination places in different cities, currently we started to gather data from Addis Ababa but we are growing to different cities like Bahir dar, Gonder and Lalibela trying to replicate and so far we have good attraction and building network. The initiative is sustainable as long as the services providers are available. Given there is a gap of information in the service center, this product will be highly replicable.

pads.content:
notebooks from recycled waste
Felek is a notebook brand under Savannah Printing Press Plc, which started recycling after witnessing the increased amount of wasted paper from its printing press. 
"We use a historical Coptic stitching method to produce hand-made paper," said Sulieman Dawit, managing and creative director of the company. "We use customizable leather or recycled jerrycans to produce covers for the notebooks."
After launching Felek Notebooks & Journal in 2016, the company found it challenging to penetrate the market because of a prejudicial view that questioned the quality standards and assumed that recycled products are more expensive, according to the director.
"The prices of the recycled commodities have to compete with their virgin counterparts made straight out of the wood pulp," Suleiman said.
pads.title: notebooks from recycled waste

pads.content:
Recover fuel oil, carbon black and steel wire from used tires using pyrolysis machine
Globally, the effort for solving waste tyre problems through market-based value-adding waste tyre management options is as old as tyre itself. These include reusing, de-vulcanization, mechanical and thermal (including pyrolysis) processing. Disposal options such as land filling and stockpiling are also practiced. Tyre pyrolysis is a thermal process carried out in the absence of oxygen for producing oil, carbon char black and gases from used tyres and recovering the steel wires in the tyre. This presents an opportunity to consider scrap tyre pyrolysis as a business. Pyrolysis is emerging as a more efficient way to utilize the resources in scrap tyres compared to the other options. From pyrolysis of scrap tyres, four products are obtained: oil, carbon char, fuel gas and steel wire. Pyrolysis is preferable because of the following reasons: It recycles 100% of the waste tyres. All valuable materials are extracted. It produces four valuable products out of waste tyres with no effect on the environment. They are “green” products. There exists a huge and increasing demand for the products. It delivers clean steel after processing than other technologies. The pyrolysis machine can be design and manufacture locally
pads.title: Recover fuel oil, carbon black and steel wire from used tires using pyrolysis machine

pads.content:
Hello Erf is an Agri-tech solution that aims to solve smallholders' challen...
Hello Erf is an Agri-tech solution that aims to solve smallholders' challenge to access mechanization service through a direct call to our call centre or through our agents in their village. The solution also helps mechanization service providers to manage and grow their business. Service providers through an IoT powered mobile app will track and monitor their machineries, revenue and manage bookings from smallholder farmers. It also provides up to date research findings, suppliers address, events, and professionals and so on within the agriculture mechanization ecosystem. Applying human centered design approach has helped us to go through discussions with farmers, service providers, sector experts in public sector along with those working in NGOs in search of the problem on the ground and how they think will be solved. Though the problem to be solved are a bit difficult and ranging difference in literacy level, mobile device types of users were complicated. Years of experience of the team in the Agri-tech industry has helped to come to reach into innovative and inclusive solution to be provided. Hello Erf is winner of the 2018 innovation slam award by Green Innovation Center, GIZ project promoting innovative solutions transforming agriculture.
pads.title: Hello Erf is an Agri-tech solution that aims to solve smallholders' challen...

pads.content:
Water box for afforestation 
This innovation enables to increase the survival rate of trees after afforestation, which supports an environmental greening programs and combat climate change, and desertification through an increased vegetation cover and carbon sequestration. The suggested solution for the aforementioned problem is a designed structure that could be put around tree seedlings. This product shall also be simple for carriage and application to support extensive afforestation programs, and in line with circular economy (reusable and recyclable). The innovation is a Water box that has a moisture retention capacity (90%), which supports trees survival with a minimum care in countries that do not afford a logistical cost for post afforestation. The product’s colour is intentionally black to reflect sunlight and minimizes the soil penetrating radiation. Also, it has an extension wire mesh of 1-meter length to protect the seedlings from browsing animals. Such innovative methods need to be also affordable and technically applicable for their saleability. The innovation is to be piloted in the moisture scarce lowlands and pastoralist community. The unit cost per Water Box is 6.8USD including all the installation and follow-up costs. This water box’s production could be also a source of employment for small and micro enterprises. Also new SMEs could be engaged with rental services of such moisture maintaining boxes to government, and non-government organizations in the afforestation businesses. This innovation has been tested at experimental state and planning to conduct a medium scale piloting with 10,000 seedlings.
pads.title: Water box for afforestation

pads.content:
MoveEt delivery and logistics solution
MoveEt delivery and logistics system was developed with objective of improving (introduce digitized management) the existing delivery and logistics which is generally fragmented and manually managed in inefficient and ineffective manner.
MoveEt Delivery and logistics is a system serves suppliers to deliver their goods efficiently and timely while fully controlling the movement of the transport system using GPS system, thus improving the efficiency of their transport system. The system enables to select the best route to deliver goods to customers. The system had been established with the objective of optimizing the business activities through efficient utilization of transport means.
Move.ET service includes
1. MoveET Rental Fleet Management System:
MoveEt provides a robust system to Enterprises to manage their vehicles. This system enables the Enterprise to see detail information about the delivery and track the vehicles on map. MoveEt installs the system on the computer of the customer and provides support services such as system maintenance, training and upgrading the system.
2. MoveEt Enterprise :
MoveEt Enterprise is a delivery management system controlled by MoveEt, enabling customers (Enterprises) order a delivery using a web portal or call center. The Vehicles are managed by
MoveEt where MoveEt uses its own cars or verified car owners
(Drivers) who qualify for the enterprise delivery requirement.
3. MoveEt Public:
The MoveEt Public is a delivery system managed by MoveEt prepared for the public user to manage a logistics and delivery. This system includes various verified vehicle drivers to manage the delivery service. A user can use a mobile application or a call center to make the order (request the service).
The initiative is sustainably replicable because All users shall be charged for the service of logistics and delivery as they use of the system. At this time the system has already been developed, tested and is being loaded on smart phones of drivers, ready for use.
pads.title: MoveEt delivery and logistics solution

pads.content:
Anti Striga (weed) biological solution
Striga hermonthica (witchweed) is a parasitic weed that attacks and significantly reduces the yields of maize, sorghum, millet, and sugarcane throughout sub-Saharan Africa. Low cost management methods such as hand weeding, short crop rotations, trap cropping, or conventional biocontrol have not been effective. Therefore, the toothpick project is led by a foreign scientist and experts from the Ethiopian biotechnological institute. This solution will:
1. Improves crop yield by reducing the Striga weed. Improving crop yield will lead to food security and economic improvements.
2. Considers the environmental impact for weed management as a locally-sourced agent (vs. chemicals that have toxicology concerns as well as increasing issues with herbicide-resistant weeds - eg. in the last three decades, over two dozen weeds have developed resistance to glyphosate).
3. Operates as a sustainable business – providing an affordable product for farmers as a social enterprise. We have a second economic opportunity for micro agribusinesses to produce our live inoculum at the village level. This opportunity is designed to keep the economy strong at a local level rather than diverting funds out of a village to a large manufacturing center.
pads.title: Anti Striga (weed) biological solution

pads.content:
Solidarity Map: MAPA19
Mapa19 is a technologically simple solution that connects people in need with potential donors or solvers. Through a map that geolocates both the needs and the help, users from anywhere can make a call for solidarity and connect with people ready to help. A simple validation process filters the veracity of the information, allowing the aid to be carried out directly from citizen to citizen. In 2020, more than 6,000 families received financial aid (500,000 PEN transferred P2P) and other non-financial aid (as shelter or food) solving urgent needs during the pandemic.
https://www.tuweb7.com/mapa/
License free, ready to expand.
Formal Consent in process.
pads.title: Solidarity Map: MAPA19

pads.content:
"Public Servent Welfare" Safe Workplaces Intervention
Conacyt Social Innovation
National Science and Technology Council
The performance of a worker in a company is closely linked to the commitment of their employer to make them feel satisfied with their work environment. We want to implement as a project a space of well-being for the officials of the institution, where they can find a monitor with images that congratulate them for their achievements through messages from the authorities or bosses, and images with motivating phrases for the official, where they can leave feedback on a tablet or box for complaints and suggestions. Also that it is a coworking space to socialize with other dependencies and there are amenities such as water, coffee, and once a week professionals from health fields such as nutrition, psychology, medicine, etc. appear. to develop healthy programs, Emphasis will be placed on mental health care with a research study on it. Another idea is that of a nursery in the institution for children of officials. Law 5508 and Regulatory Decree No. 7550/2017, on lactation rooms and nurseries oblige public institutions and public and private sector companies to implement them, but this does not really happen. Working Families points out in a study that employees who are parents and have a job that gives them a balance between their work life and their private life increase their sense of belonging and, for the most part, increase their productivity. Studies will be carried out to measure the impact of this solution.
https://www.conacyt.gov.py/premian-ganadores-convocatoria-innovacion-social
pads.title: "Public Servent Welfare" Safe Workplaces Intervention

pads.content:
"Healthy habits programs in prisons" Intervention to Improve Chronic Health Conditions
Conacyt Social Innovation
National Science and Technology Council
The idea is to create a General Health Program to promote healthy habits and the control of diseases such as hypertension and diabetes in the Coronel Oviedo Penitentiary. Within this program, the axes would be exercise, healthy eating and mental health. Within the exercise axis, treadmills, bicycles and other safe elements would be acquired to carry out a crossfit program in the Penitentiary together with a trainer. Within the area of ​​healthy eating, training will be carried out with nutritionists since food is prepared within the penitentiary, and drinking fountains will be purchased to promote water intake. A base measurement will be carried out before and after the implementation of the Program together with the support of the Regional Institute of Health Research of the National University of Caaguazú. It will also be measured whether this exercise and healthy eating program has positive implications for mental health.
https://www.conacyt.gov.py/premian-ganadores-convocatoria-innovacion-social
Https://clipchamp.com/watch/WyWCEdAsbJU
pads.title: "Healthy habits programs in prisons" Intervention to Improve Chronic Health Conditions

pads.content:
Training workshops on history of Primary Health Care Model and Participatory Health Policy Planning
Positive Deviance in Community Health
Ministry of Public Health and Social Wellfare, Tesaireka Paraguay (NGO)
Community health agents and other staff of the territorial Family Health Units have very little historical perspective about the relationship between primary health care policy, human rights frameworks regarding health and citizen participation in policy making. This appears to limit their understanding and appropriation of participatory policy making and management tools that are mandated but underutilized by the ministry of public health. This led us to develop the following hypothesis, which is the focus of our experimental intervention in this learning loop: If we provide Family Health Unit workers training in the history of the Primary Health Care perspective, the role of participation, and the use of participatory planning tools, then they will appropriate these tools and make use of them in identifying their operations and priorities.
pads.title: Training workshops on history of Primary Health Care Model and Participatory Health Policy Planning

pads.content:
Heat Maps to identify social capital hot and cold spots
Social Capital Learning Loop
NorthEastern University
Using secondary data from various soruces, AccLabPy and a team of researchers from NorthEastern University (USA) generated proxy indexes of social capital and vulnerabilty and produced heat maps to identify "hot spots" where social capital was high in relation to the levels of vulnerability and "hold spots" where social capital was low in relation to the levels of vulnerabilty. Subjet to data quality, this type of map can serve to guide public policy decisiones.
https://undp.sharepoint.com/:b:/s/PUNDAccLabParaguay/EQHUE85efqRPho7V0JBGWfQBO6Urf2RwRSIy_0xVdBID1w?e=wcBurB
pads.title: Heat Maps to identify social capital hot and cold spots

pads.content:
Investment in Collective and Community Assets to Reduce Vulnerability
Social Capital Learning Loop
An original survey conducted by AccLabPy during the pandemic as part our learning loop on Social Capital and Vulnerability, we identified a statistically significant and negative relationship between the participation in the production, maintenance, and use of community commons or collective assets and economic vulnerability. Based on this, interventions aimed at participatory design of community commons hold great promise for reducing vulnerability of the territories.
https://www.undp.org/publications/social-capital-paraguay-asset-combatting-vulnerability-during-covid-19-pandemic
pads.title: Investment in Collective and Community Assets to Reduce Vulnerability

pads.content:
"My waste-free neighborhood": recycling collection service that links households to informal recyle
Inclusive Recycling
Asuncion Green City of the Americas (UNDP Paraguay Environment Portfolio), Coca Cola Local Bottler, Moises Bertoni Foundation, Soluciones Ecologias (private company)
For this community recycling pilot (Mi Barrio sin Residuos), we connected a waste picker collective with households, protytping a regular weekly schedule of routes and household "clients" for members of the waste picker collective. The main effect we observed is that this interaction increased trust between them. This, in turn, opened interesting opportunities for knowledge transfer and growth, particularly, by further exploring how to establish and maintain engagement between participatory neighborhood institutions, such as neighbor’s commissions, and waste picker collectives.
https://www.py.undp.org/content/paraguay/es/home/blog/2022/Mi-Barrio-sin-Residuos--innovacion-en-reciclaje.html

Informational Seminars and Reflection Workshops to improve construction workers's valuation of Social Insurance
Employment Formalization Laboratory
Lack of accurate information about social insurance coverage, policies and procedures is a major barrier to formalizing work in the construction industry because it leads to an undervaluation of social insurance and lowers workers interest or willingness to make social insurance contributions. AccLabPy and the Ministry of Labor developed methodologies for informational seminars and reflection workshops.
pads.title: Informational Seminars and Reflection Workshops to improve construction workers's valuation of Soci

pads.content:
Personalized advising for household heads to register their domestic workers for social insurance.
Employment Formalization Laboratory
Cooperatives of university and health profesionals (COMECIPAR y Cooperativa Univesritaria) and social club (Club Centenario)
One of the main barriers for households to formalize their domestic workers so that they can gain access to social insurance is the adminstrative and bureaucratic process of registering themselves as employers and their domestic workers as contributor to social insurance. To overcome this AccLabPY and the Ministry of Labor developed a protocol for one-on-one advising via whatsap and telephone calls. It is a prototype of a public service that could be offered by the Ministry of Labor or the Institute of Social Provision.
pads.title: Personalized advising for household heads to register their domestic workers for social insurance.

pads.content:
"Sabores del Norte"
Moiru
National Innovation Strategy, Presidential Delivery Unit. National SDG Comission
The Flavors of the North initiative is a group of organized peasant women who are dedicated to producing fresh food, nutritional supplements, pickled vegetables, sweets, jams and some sauces to sell at fairs in the Department of Concepción, in the northeast of the country. It is a team that works well together, with clear leadership and a good working environment between them. The fresh products that they currently sell have a very good acceptance by consumers and are also produced in most of the family farms in this rural area. The dream of this group of entrepreneurs is the amount of being able to improve their production capacity and quality, to occupy the market at the local and national level, with the added bonus of being organic products. Currently they sell these products as a complement, but they do not have sufficient quantity and quality because they do not have equipment (processing machines) and they do not know the appropriate techniques to prepare and package them so that they are preserved for a few days. They have their own premises, not very large, but it is the place where they make and process the products, it is located in the town of Arroyo de Oro km 92.5, district of Arroyito, department of Concepción PY.
https://mapa.wenda.org.py/posts/5230
pads.title: "Sabores del Norte"

pads.content:
Ecoarami Consultoría Agroecológica
Moiru
National Innovation Strategy, Presidential Delivery Unit. National SDG Comission

It is a single-person brand of products and services that offers assistance and accompaniment to Peasant and Indigenous Communities from an Agroecological approach.
