Bani Hamida Weaving Project
This women's cooperative in Mukawir village (by the side of the road leading to the castle) is run by the Bani Hamida Centre and is a good place to buy gorgeous, colourful kilims and cushions. Designs reflect contemporary tastes and traditional Bedouin patterns. The kilims aren't super cheap, but the fixed prices fairly reflect the labour that went into their weaving.
https://www.lonelyplanet.com/jordan/mukawir/shopping/bani-hamida-weaving-centre-gallery/a/poi-sho/1106149/1299086
Rebecca Salti is a pioneer of women’s empowerment in Jordan. In 1985, she established the Bani Hamida Weaving Project as country director of Save the Children in Jordan. The project became a model income-generation project throughout the developing world and is internationally known. It continues today with the participation of three generations of rural Bedouin women of the Bani Hamida Tribe. Rebecca’s skills, energy, and vision led her to establish other income-generation programs in Jordan. This article includes excerpts of an interview with Rebecca, a U.S. native, which presents her insights about the project and women’s empowerment.
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0886109910392525

https://barakadestinations.com/
https://www.instagram.com/barakadestinations/
Founder: Muna Haddad
pads.title: Baraka Destinations

Local business Ceramics, soap, fabrics, paper, food... All handmade! خزف، صابون، نسيج، ورق، طعام... كل شيء يُصنع يدوياً! Supported by بدعم من @investbankjo

pads.content:
The Blended Learning Teaching Methods Curriculum - Iraq
Education System in Iraq Amid COVID-19, The Challenges:
E-learning signal started emerging in Iraq after the spread of COVID-19 in April 2020; this is actually a tremendous window of opportunity to strengthen the Iraqi education system. In Iraq, the education system is largely focused on offline teaching tools. The incorporation of e-learning will support digital skills of teachers and students, more efficient and effective teaching methods, and the suitability of youth to the digital job market. When COVID-19 hit the world, restrictions related to the coronavirus pandemic have disturbed education systems all around the world. In Iraq specifically, all learning has moved online suddenly and without prior notice. This affected mainly the way the material is being delivered and the assessment methods. Hence, this required a quick intervention from the eco-system enablers (UNDP Accelerator Lab Iraq) to induce structural changes to the education system through introducing blended learning.
The Solution, Blended Learning Teaching Methods Curriculum:
Seventeen Iraqi experts from the higher education system worked together to tackle the above challenge with the support of the UNDP Accelerator Lab Iraq and in partnership with the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research by writing the first from its kind teaching methods curriculum "the Blended Learning Teaching Methods Curriculum" for seven specializations; Administrative, Medical & Health Sciences, Engineering, Educational, Humanities, Agricultural and Veterinary, Scientific.). The Blended Learning Teaching Methods Curriculum upskills higher educational professionals to adopt new technological skills and encourage a hybrid mode of learning, combining online learning with on-campus learning. It is the first of its kind in Iraq, and the newly-developed curriculum is officially rolled out across 35 Iraqi universities to serve more than 50,000 academic staff.
This newly developed local curriculum is the first of its kind in Iraq, and is officially adopted by the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research and rolled out across 35 Iraqi universities to serve more than 50,000 academic staff.
Links:
https://www.facebook.com/AlJameiaTV/videos/3278211112502351/?extid=CL-UNK-UNK-UNK-AN_GK0T-GK1C
https://www.undp.org/iraq/blog/shaping-future-education-iraq-through-collective-intelligence
https://www.facebook.com/AlJameiaTV/videos/546844183644172/?extid=CL-UNK-UNK-UNK-AN_GK0T-GK1C&ref=sharing
https://www.undp.org/iraq/blog/signals-spark-strategic-direction-covid-19-pandemic-uncovers-new-opportunities-education-iraq
pads.title: The Blended Learning Teaching Methods Curriculum - Iraq

pads.content:
Citizen science on Phytoplankton (microalgae) monitoring: "FjordPhyto"
Contributory project: It is designed by scientists, and citizens participate in data collection. 
Overall goal: Study how melting glaciers affect phytoplankton communities in the west of the Antarctic Peninsula. Specific goals: Analyze phytoplankton biodiversity and dynamics in coastal areas, which are not so broadly studied in the west of the Antarctic Peninsula. - Raise awareness among visitors as regards the importance of microalgae communities in Antarctic ecosystems. 
Description of citizen participation: Participants with no formal training arrive at the points of interest by tourist ships and disembark in Zodiac-type boats together with a polar guide, who was previously trained by the researchers of the project. They take different water samples (tap, bottle, and meltwater samples), make environmental measurements (conductivity, temperature, and depth measures [CTD], and the Secchi disk) with tools provided by the project team, and duly record data in spreadsheets. At the end of the season, data and samples are collected and sent to the researchers in order to be analyzed. 
Time frame: 11/16/2016 - N/A. 
Leaders. • Maria Vernet, Scripps Institution of Oceanography/Universidad de California en San Diego (UCSD) • Allison Cusick, Scripps Institution of Oceanography/UCSD • Martina Mascioni, Department of Phycology, Natural Science School and Museum (UNLP)/National University of La Plata (UNLP) • Rick Reynolds, Scripps Institution of Oceanography/UCSD • Gastón O. Almandoz, Department of Phycology/FCNYM/UNLP
Contact information: Email: fjordphyto@gmail.com Website: www.fjordphyto.org Facebook: facebook.com/fjordphyto Instagram: instagram.com/fjordphyto Twitter: https://mobile.twitter.com/FjordPhyto YouTube: youtube.com/fjordphyto
pads.title: Citizen science on Phytoplankton (microalgae) monitoring: "FjordPhyto"

pads.content:
Eat your cup
Did you know that you can eat your coffee's cup? 🥤 Plastic waste from the food and beverage industry is occurring in large quantities every day, which is a global waste issue. However, at present, a group of change maker in Lao PDR came up with a creative and a tasty products. ☕ "Eat your cup" is a product from a Lao youth that aims to create a change in the consumption of coffee in an environmentally friendly way. Latdavanh or "Marina", a Lao youth who is only 18 years old, makes "eat your cup" and won the 2nd runner-up prize in the Toyota Incubation Program in 2022. 🍪Marina invented this edible cup by using ingredients like chocolate cookies and green tea, which are all plant-based ingredients, without using eggs or butter, so that everyone can eat it, whether they are vegan or vegetarian. This cup is able to receive hot drinks up to 100c and cold up to -20c for a period not less than 1 hour. The good thing about using an edible cup is that you can drink your favorite drink and still eat the cookie later. In addition to filling the stomach, it also helps reduce the amount of waste that may be made from toxic materials such as plastic. 🌎 Also, Marina is a young person who likes and is obsessed with doing business for the society and is also a volunteer of the Zero Waste Laos, an organization that works on raising awareness about environment. Also, "Eat your cup" was born from Marina's experience when she went to study in Japan, where one day her Japanese sister took her to make plant-based cookies and it was a delicious cake. Marina came back to adjust the recipe and experimented with it until it became an edible cookie cup. 🍪Currently, Marina herself is developing a recipe to overcome various limitations and aims to release "eat your cup" soon so that her customers can try it and enjoy a delicious cup with their favorite coffee. The long-term goal of "eat your cup" is certainly to preserve the good environment. But in addition, she also set the goal of sharing the profits in future youth development projects.
EAT YOUR CUPS | Facebook
pads.title: Eat your cup

pads.content:
Time-varying kinematics to solve oil palm automation
In the pursuit of automation in the oil palm industry, the harvesting collection process of oil palm remains largely unresolved as current research in automation would not yield a robot that is as efficient as a human operated tractor. This is due to the lack of research in time-varying kinematics, something a human can be easily trained to do but has not been successfully replicated in robotics.
This project aims to create a custom algorithm, a time varying kinematic solver with a "reflected" trajectory predictor, that when combined with supplementary algorithms, will create a robot that is able to collect object goals automatically - without stopping in its movement. This would replicate the efficiency and efficacy of human operated tractors in the oil palm industry. A prototype mobile grabber will be created for this project to prove its efficiency and efficacy against conventional methods of robotic grabbers.
pads.title: Time-varying kinematics to solve oil palm automation

pads.content:
Solar-powered desalination system for clean water
The Clean Water Solution for Seaweed Community using Solar Hybrid Powered Desalination is a dual-purpose integrated system to produce clean drinkable water using renewable energy source. This project is implemented in Semporna, a coastal region in the state of Sabah, Malaysia where the local communities still do not have stable and consistent supply of electric and clean water. 
The project benefits the local communities who work as seaweed farmers. The system is able to generate 1-5 cubic metres of clean water from the sea per day. This will benefit 100-120 residents living in the surrounding areas. The system also generates electric from the same solar panels. 
The project has demonstrated that it can solve the issue of basic water and electric necessities in remote communities where the major utilities networks cannot reach. The project is scalable to other communities in other remote geographical locations where these communities face the same problem.
pads.title: Solar-powered desalination system for clean water

pads.content:
SIRIM ceramic Itama beehive with Kelulut Integrated Information System
The SIRIM Itama stingless beehive is made of innovative porcelain material. The beehive has a topping with 15-inch diameter and 3-inch depth. It has the properties of zero water absorption, flexural strength of 30MPa and density of 2.3g/cm3. The ceramic beehive has a lifespan of 20 years, and is capable of keeping out invading pests. It is waterproof and maintains a conducive temperature for the bees and the honey produced in the ceramic hive. While the Kelulut Integrated Information System is a registered digital sensory device and system to measure temperature and humidity of Kelulut (stingless) beehives in real time. Through the assistance of the device, a continuous and consistent monitoring of the hives ensures that the colony stays productive, which will result in an increase of honey productivity and beekeeper income. 
This product is an innovation of SIRIM Berhad.
https://youtu.be/0AjVPzPyq1E
pads.title: SIRIM ceramic Itama beehive with Kelulut Integrated Information System

pads.content:
Teh Anggerik
'Teh Anggerik' is a research product by the Forest Research Institute Malaysia (FRIM). It is created in the form of exclusive gift package that consists of four (4) types of herbal tea flavours: Misai Kucing (cat's whiskers), Roselle, Asam Gelugor (tamarind), and Karas (agarwood). 
Each type of tea has its unique nutritional and health benefit and is suitable for tea lovers who are also health-conscious. The 'Teh Anggerik' tea box that is designed with its personal 'Teh Anggerik' logo has received trademark recognition by MyIPO (TM2020029856). The logo is inspired by the Anggerik flower, or tiger orchid. The close relationship between the tiger orchid and the parent tree that shelters it symbolises the interdependence of humans with the forests for the continuity of life and well-being of living. The tiger orchid is a natural treasure that should be protected, preserved and conserved for the next generations. 
This product is produced by GMP and HACCP status manufacturing factory to ensure the quality and safety of the product.
pads.title: Teh Anggerik

pads.content:
Smart Agriculture Farming (SAFAR)
The Smart Agriculture Farming (SAFAR) project functions to help mushroom growers use Industry 4.0 technology. With SAFAR, 60% of manual labour can be reduced, while increasing yield up to 30% more in grey oyster mushroom farming. SAFAR monitors temperature and humidity in the mushroom house, waters the mushroom in the morning and evening, and has other functions to aid in mushroom growing. The system can also be used for other vegetable farming.
pads.title: Smart Agriculture Farming (SAFAR)

pads.content:
IoT enabled smart plantation
Integrated IoT systems, mobile application development, artificial intelligence (AI), as well as robotics and automation have made great improvements to the plantation experience and will make agriculture a highly appealing career option for many bright and talented Malaysians. In this project, digital tools are used by smart farmers to continuously monitor a wide range of metrics, including water levels, the amount of nutrients that crops need to optimally grow, soil samples, fertiliser inputs. The solution has enabled the creation of conducive operational conditions through the application of IoT which will provide resource and time savings, heighten convenience, and minimise human intervention. The solution will benefit all segments of the society, where it can provide a platform for income generation and as a useful tool to empower targeted groups such as the youth, B40, and undeserved communities.
pads.title: IoT enabled smart plantation

pads.content:
AiRBOX Sense
Clean air is one of the most fundamental principles of life quality and well-being. Outdoor and indoor air pollutions both can contributes to human health problems. Recently, researchers found that an increase in exposure to hazardous air pollutants is associated with a 9% increase in death among patients with COVID-19. Thus, it is important to emphasize continuous real- time air quality monitoring system throughout the globe after this pandemic occurred.
AiRBOX Sense is an air quality detection system created by Dr Mohd Shahrul Mohd Nadzir. It is a device that is co-created with a PhD student from Indonesia, and it is smaller in size and more cost-effective to monitor air quality. Some of the benefits of AiRBOX Sense include:
Capability to measure real-time concentration of air pollutants for volatile organic compounds (VOCs), ozone (O3), sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), and particulate matters (PM2.5, and PM10);
Capability to measure real-time measurement for meteorological parameters such as wind direction, wind speed, atmospheric pressure and rain fall;
Access to viability of renewable energy projects with long-term studies. 
An integrated system based on the Internet of Things (IoT), it sends real-time API data to the user through the mobile application. The application also supplies the user the locations of the installed sensors, as well as provide recommendation to the user on whether it is safe to be outdoors based on the air quality of the time.
pads.title: AiRBOX Sense

pads.content:
Heat pump solar dryer
This dehumidification system is a solar collector system that incorporates storage system, generation and regeneration absorption, and drying chamber. The drying chamber can be maintained at a stable temperature and the relative humidity for drying is of high quality. The herbs that have been dried using the solar dryer have been tested to contain many of their active ingredients after the drying process. This system is suitable for herb and agriculture produce drying.
pads.title: Heat pump solar dryer

pads.content:
Nanocellulose from oil palm biomass
The nanocellulose is made from oil palm biomass waste. Nanocellulose is a versatile material and has special characteristics such as high mechanical strength, high specific surface area, renewable and biodegradable. It can be used in various industrial product development. For example, industrial plastic packaging, cosmetic and pharmaceutical products, vehicle building material, paper processing and paint. 
The nanocellulose that is made from oil palm biomass has characteristics that are comparable to nanocellulose made from wood in developed countries such as the USA and Canada.
pads.title: Nanocellulose from oil palm biomass

pads.content:
Retractable drying and planting rack for agrophotovoltaics farm
The concept of AgroPhotovoltaic (AgroPV or Solar Farming) utilises the unused space under large-scale PV arrays for agricultural purpose. As such, the construction cost is negligible or at minimum due to the optimisation of existing infrastructure of PV farms. In AgroPV farms, PV arrays for electricity production are installed directly above crop covering. PV facilities can protect the plants from severe weather patterns such as drought and storm. 
The installation of the Retractable Drying and Planting Rack for AgroPhotovoltaics Farm can provide the following benefits:
- no additional cost for PV structure
- monetary surplus for the unused land
- low cost with high grade materials
- easy installation and operation
- green innovation with Nexus Integration
pads.title: Retractable drying and planting rack for agrophotovoltaics farm

pads.content:
VERSMAP: multi-level technology for Azolla production
VERSMAP is a multi-level planting technology to increase Azolla Pinnata production as a source of animal feed. With VERSMAP, Azolla production can be increased fourfold, amounting to 900kg of Azolla produced every month for each VERSMAP. This is sufficient to feed approximately 300 ducks, ensuring food security for the animals. The cost of poultry feed can be reduced by up to 50%.
pads.title: VERSMAP: multi-level technology for Azolla production

pads.content:
FS Feed: Life food replacement in aquaculture industry
FS Feed is a life food replacement for fish and prawn larvae due to limits to life food and high cost of feed. Life food production and quality are unpredictable, which has a negative impact on fish and prawn larvae production, which then affects the aquaculture industry. FS feed is made of 100% organic matter, mainly from fish oil.
pads.title: FS Feed: Life food replacement in aquaculture industry

pads.content:
River Kim Kim restoration
The U4S Southern Zone Sungai Kim Kim Restoration project is a joint venture of expertise of four universities, led by Universiti Teknologi Malaysia (UTM), Universiti Tun Hussein Onn Malaysia (UTHM), Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka (UTeM), and Universiti Sains Islam Malaysia (USIM). It focuses on environmental sustainability and community development around Pasir Gudang, where the river is located. 
Design concept
"Ri-unite": River unites local community. Sungai Kim Kim, located between two industrial areas will act as the new recreation sport for the local community through the interconnected trail and walkway system. Recreational needs such as fitness facilities, jogging trail, bike lane and fishing activity are proposed to encourage people to engage with nature. 
Design:
The project has four main design phases:
Eco Industry: reducing water pollution while greening the industrial zone with nature
Eco Residence: constructing linear park along the river for the residents
Eco Bio: eco-biological park that weaves across numerous pathways will be established along the river
Eco Commercial: commercial area will curve seamlessly along the river and the surrounding natural area
Each design targets different social groups along the river, with the eventual participation of all communities in the project.
pads.title: River Kim Kim restoration

pads.content:
Intelligent Kitchen Waste Segregation System
Intelligent Kitchen Waste Segregation System via Deep Learning is an innovation product that is capable of segregating kitchen and other types of waste into two (2) categories: (1) compostable waste, and (2) non-compostable waste. Compost is a biodegradable material that can be used in the agriculture field as a form of fertiliser or for soil conditioning. 
This system is equipped with artificial intelligence (A.I.) technology to enable the segregation operation to be conducted automatically. The prototype system encompasses a motor, camera, micro-controller, grinder and segregation board. The micro-controller will identify the category of the waste that has been placed on the segregation board using the camera. The motor will then run and separate the waste according to the appropriate category. The waste will then go through the grinder to be made into smaller sizes. 
This system is suitable for segregating kitchen waste such as canned foods, sauce bottles, lemons, eggshells and the like.
pads.title: Intelligent Kitchen Waste Segregation System

pads.content:
Green sustainable cosmetics
The cosmetic products are made from natural ingredients, contributing towards green and sustainable economy:
1. MGs Young+ : a new green youth-enhancing face cream for made from certified mangosteen peel extract (MPE) and other natural ingredients. The development of the product supports circular economy through waste reduction in line with SDG 3 and 12 because it uses alternative resources that are fully renewable, including 100% recyclable containers.
2. TomaLight: a cosmetic product made from plant-based sources, with tomato seeds as its main ingredient. The product does wonders on skin brightening. 
3. CuberClearC+: Based on cucumber extract, CuberClearC+ is an eye cream that targets dark eye circles. 
4. CocoameltTabs THC 100mg: an immunity booster for better health and is suitable for all ages. 
5. Mangosteen (0.1% w/v) Face Serum: a botanical face serum from organic components to fight ageing.
pads.title: Green sustainable cosmetics

pads.content:
Magnetic nanoparticle carbon powder
The magnetic nanoparticle carbon powder transforms agricultural waste to nano materials for latent fingerprint visualisation in forensic crime scenes. This product is synthesised from rice husk, making it non-hazardous to the environment. It does not leave any pollution trail, ensuring the sustainability of the environment.
pads.title: Magnetic nanoparticle carbon powder

pads.content:
Cantas: oil palm cutter
The Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB) has developed a motorised cutter popularly known as CantasTM for harvesting fresh fruit bunches (FFB) at less than 4.5m in height. CantasTM is a hand-held cutter powered by a 1.3hp petrol engine. Trials carried out on CantasTM revealed that the productivity of the machine was 560 to 750 bunches per day (equivalent to 9.50 to 12.6 t day-1 at a bunch weight of 17kg). The productivity very much depends on the cropping level, the topography of the estate and the operator's skills.
pads.title: Cantas: oil palm cutter

pads.content:
Super Butterfly
OUR SOLUTION
Without disturbing water production and water demand, our Super Butterfly technology can take advantage of this wasted or untapped excess pressure and convert it into clean energy.
BENEFITS FROM OUR SOLUTION
We complement water operators’ energy cost with revenue from selling energy by utilizing their untapped excess pressure (using our Super Butterfly). We promote the full utilization of water infrastructures where expensive pipelines can be used not only to transfer water but generate clean energy concurrently. This initiative also will lead to the reduction of Green House Gas (GHG) emission.
There are currently three (3) products: P20, P40, and P50. The product range refers to the excess pressure the product can tap in a pipe line, with P20 tapping at 20%, P40 at 40% and P50 at 50% of full water pressure capacities, respectively. 
The solution has won multiple awards, including Climate Launchpad (CLP) Malaysia National Final 2020 (2nd Place winner), and Malaysian Technology Expo 2021 (Gold Award winner).
pads.title: Super Butterfly

pads.content:
Sustainable concrete from oil palm shell
At present, worldwide cement consumption is approximately 4.5 billion tonnes per year. The primary ingredients in the cement require heating up to 1450 °C, accounting for 40–50% of CO2 emissions globally.
One of the main goals of this research is to achieve sustainable construction materials to reduce the overuse of virgin materials used to produce cement and coarse and fine aggregates. The utilization of industrial by-products such as palm oil clinker (POC), palm oil fuel ash (POFA), and fly ash (FA), steel slag, manufactured sand as cement and aggregate replacement, or as additional cementation materials have had a constructive effect in minimizing greenhouse gas emissions.
The suitability of using more sustainable materials for concrete production and other applications was investigated. The approach taken was to make material substitutions so that the environmental, energy, and CO2 impact of concrete could be reduced. This was accomplished by using the local industrial waste materials in our various research, such as the construction of low-cost houses, the development of blast-resistant slabs using oil palm shells, the construction of the first cement-free geopolymer house in Universiti Malaya campus, and recycled plastic aggregate pavements, and the development of self-healing bricks using microalgae.
pads.title: Sustainable concrete from oil palm shell

pads.content:
Boom Grow
The greens are nurtured indoors in a highly-controlled environment, based on the principles of hydroponic with filtered water. The system is supported by AI platforms, enabling the growers to continuously gather data and improve the system. 
The system uses patent pending Machine Farms and Tower Farms technology to grow in a modular system with a diversity of cultivars. The flexibility to scale up is based on demand from the local communities. The system is/has: 
1. Space efficient and scalable: the modular racking system allows planting of variety of greens, with the option of scaling up according to demand. 
2. 95% less land used: the modular stacking system saves space. By stacking the trays with zero compromise on taste and nutrition, valuable real estate space is saved. 
3. 95% less water used: the farms use far less water than traditional farming. Nutrient-enhanced filtered water are placed in direct contact with the roots, reducing water wastage and enhancing efficiency. 
4. A year-round harvest: the climate-controlled facility enables shorter plant cycles, lower yield loss and year round harvest. 
5. Controlled lighting: controlled and customised LEDs ensure optimal and balanced growing conditions. The lighting spectrum for each produce is carefully managed for better yield and energy-efficiency. 
6. Continuous improvement: the cloud-connected IoT farms collect multiple data points to help the farms grow healthier, tastier greens. The farms also have a live data feed and an analytics system to guide crop cycles for optimum harvest.
pads.title: Boom Grow

pads.content:
SURI Lifestyle
SURI is a Malaysian social enterprise that aims to empower underprivileged mothers by providing financial opportunity and living skill of sewing. All of the beneficiaries undergo a 3-month training of creative sewing to ensure quality of products under the brand SURI Lifestyle. Currently, 40 mothers work on full- or part-time basis with SURI. 
Objectives
To give mothers a long-term, reliable source of income. This creates a social impact beyond just supporting themselves and their families, giving the mothers a way to develop their personal growth and self reliance.
We are committed to help these mothers to become more productive and resourceful in order to be the best parent they can be for their children.
We educate and equip these mothers with resources, assistance, encouragement, training and networking in order for them to live a successful and productive lives.
We will continue to make a difference in the lives of the mothers and their families in the years to come.
We aim to erase the mindset of charitable offerings to these mothers, but instead we are geared towards income based plan through employment support program. As they work and earn a living it will leave an impact of growth and personal improvement to them and their children.
All products sold are made from unwanted used denim that have been washed and treated before being made into products. All designs and products are created by the mothers, and the profits from the sale will be given to them. Products include bags, footwear, household accessories, and wearables. 
Thus far, SURI Lifestyle has helped 40 mothers, recycled 5,496kg of fabric materials, and produced 38,982 pieces of products.
pads.title: SURI Lifestyle

pads.content:
Bohomys: natural fabric dye
Bohomys is a social enterprise dedicated to using natural dye for textile dyeing. 
Textile dyeing is a contributor to one of the largest pollutions in the world. Bohomys is committed to reducing the use of toxic synthetic dye by exploring the traditional way of dyeing using plants that are sustainable to the Earth. The dyes are non-toxic, natural, and gentle to the skin. All products are special because they are hand-dyed.
Bohomys has a mission to empower youth by offering opportunities to them to up-skill, create and earn better. A part of their profits will be used to sponsor training classes for the youth to up-skill or upgrade their skills. Bohomys also offers them employment and business opportunity to create products for the enterprise, enabling them to earn better and use the experience for their entrepreneurship journey.
How do we recruit?
Why do we hire first? Because we want to show that we are serious about them. A lot of the youth feel demotivated when they need to go through months of training without getting any paid. The first thing that they need is to survive. So with this, we give them confidence that we are serious about them.
During this time too, we could analyse their strength and weakness and identify which part they could improve or what can they learn in order for them to earn.
Exploring 'tie-dye'
Tie-dye is a technique of tying the fabric before dipping or spraying it with dye, producing unique patterns. The dyes are made from natural products such as mulberry and mangosteen peel.
pads.title: Bohomys: natural fabric dye

pads.content:
Koondos!
"Koondos" is a Kadazan word for "Happy".
Koondos! is a brand managed by Moyog Innovation house (MIH) with the support from PACOS Trust and TONIBUNG to help the rural areas community in Sabah affected economically by the pandemic to market their products and produces online.
Sabah is a state full of resources, with a variety of local products to be enjoyed by our consumers, including handicraft, ginger, honey, vegetables, fish, rice and many more. Most of the communities in the rural areas make a living by selling produces scavenged from the forest, handicraft or through farming activities. Due to the pandemic, the earning capability of the villagers has been severely limited by the restriction of movement to sell their produces at Tamu (local farmers market).
The implementing partner is positioned to assist the villagers in selling their products online by providing education and training to them on basic e-commerce application, marketing strategies and methods to increase product value.
The implementing partner hopes to improve the quality of the life for the rural communities by empowering them with adequate knowledge, tools and infrastructure to build a more resilient economy through digitalisation, in response to the current COVID-19 pandemic and in preparation for future crisis.
This initiative hopes to provide the community and their children with equal access to opportunities in livelihood and other basic human rights and close the gap on inequitable outcomes.
pads.title: Koondos!

pads.content:
Robot Hubot
Social distancing is difficult in practice in our daily lives, especially when various tasks that require close contact. To prevent COVID-19 from spreading, social distancing has become a necessary principle to follow. Hubot is a solution to the problem. It reduces physical interaction while not compromising the effectiveness in information transfer. 
Hubot is a movable robot that can interact with humans through three languages: English, Chinese, Malay. It can also recognise human faces. The person can interact with Hubot through a touchscreen interface on it. Hubot is suitable to be placed at service counters to communicate with humans and answer general questions.
pads.title: Robot Hubot

pads.content:
CRUSH-IT 
CRUSH-IT is a machine designed to crush recyclable items like plastic bottles and aluminium tins. Users can use the machine's touchscreen display to choose the type of item that needs to be crushed. When the plastic bottle or aluminium tin is crushed, a mechanical presser in the machine will flatten the item for storage inside the machine. This is a more economic method because it involves lower travelling distance and transportation costs to collect recyclable waste. This technique can also minimise carbon emissions from the waste. 
Operating based on Internet of Things (IoT), the Crush-It machine not only detects the total collection but can also send notifications to the collector to inform that the machine is full. A text message will be sent with the phrase 'TONG PENUH' (translated as 'full bin'). The user can also access data and download the data into a USB drive. 
One additional feature is that there is a dump bin prepared on the side of the machine to enable users to insert bottle caps and collecting rack to hold plastic cups and used cup covers. The machine also comes with a panel display for commercial advertisement purposes.
pads.title: CRUSH-IT

pads.content:
STUMP-NO-MORE
Tree stump removal works is a global issue whereby the stumps that are not removed completely can cause accidents, tarnish the scenery and increases the difficulty in planting new tree plants. For example, in 2014, a motorbike rider became victim to a tree stump after hitting it. There have been various methods that remove tree stumps that involve the use of machineries that are costly. However, the operation of the machineries also require high costs. To overcome this, the Legendary Group, composed of officers in the National Landscape Department and Hulu Selangor Municipal Council, took the initiative to create STUMP-NO-MORE. STUMP-NO-MORE functions as a stump remover. The equipment is made from recycled materials such as drum tin, scrap metal and used items easily obtained and of low value. Based on the portable concept, the equipment is easy to be moved from one place to another, requiring only 2 handlers. Using STUMP-NO-MORE saves up to 80% of operating costs compared to conventional tree stump removal techniques. The equipment completely and cleanly removes tree stumps, leaving behind an ash-filled hole that can be refilled with soil and then flattened. The hole left behind can be used to plant new plants, easing the landscaping process at an effective cost. This innovation is patented with the Intellectual Property Corporation of Malaysia (MYIPO).
pads.title: STUMP-NO-MORE

pads.content:
Smart gas detector
The Smart Gas Detector (SGD) is created by the Selangor Fire and Rescue Department, Malaysia. It was produced following a rise in house fire incidents that were caused by kitchen gas. The gas detector is easy to install, requiring only plugging into sockets at homes. The user can also receive notifications through their smartphones. The intelligent automatic sensing device is capable of detecting gas leaks from Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), and has high sensitivity. 
If the device detects any LPG (propane) gas leak that occurs in the surrounding, the device will automatically send out signals to the alarm system. The SGD is wifi-enabled, allowing the device to be connected to the internet at all times. The user will also receive a notification through the mobile application that is downloadable to the user's smartphone. Additionally, the user will also be provided with relevant information on compulsory early safety action, as well as emergency contact details that can be contacted through the application.
pads.title: Smart gas detector

pads.content:
Smart Evacuation Plan
The Smart Evacuation Plan (S.E.P.) is the brainchild by the group One Step, of the Kuala Lumpur Fire and Rescue Department Malaysia. This was a project that entered the Department's internal innovation competition in 2020. 
The project is inspired by the rise in fire incidents such as the fire incident at Hospital Sultanah Aminah in Johor Bahru on 25th October 2016 that saw 6 casualties because the victims were trapped in the building. The accident was a departure point for the Setapak Fire Department to increase their service delivery for the year 2018. The One Step group was hence created. 
Post-mortem discussion of the fire incident suggested that ineffective Fire Training was a contributing factor to the fire. This caused the following reasons: failure of fire warning system, lack of preparedness by building occupiers towards fire incidents, physical obstruction at fire exits, late action by the emergency response team, and inadequate handling of the fire by the response team. 
The S.E.P. was born from the need to improve the efficacy of disaster management for fire incidents. The S.E.P. is an innovative and cost effective online integrated system with multiple functions to:
(a) access building evacuation guide online
(b) contact the nearest Fire and Rescue Department without dialling
(c) contact other Fire and Rescue Department, hospitals and safety agencies without dialling.
The S.E.P. works through the building occupiers' smartphones. It is activated through scanning the S.E.P. 's QR code that is placed at strategic locations in the building. On the interface, the user only has to press the icon Fire Exit Plan to access the evacuation guideline with animated directions. Pressing the Fire Station icon allows dialling to the nearest fire department, while the Emergency icon connects to other fire departments and safety agencies.
pads.title: Smart Evacuation Plan

pads.content:
Paralysed physiotherapy glove
Paralysed Physiotherapy glove is a glove designed to help paralysed patients to conduct physiotherapy activities in a more organised manner. The glove is capable of performing ball-grasping movement, via training of nerve movement through controlled action using a remote control button that is placed on the glove. 
Patients can also choose to do physiotherapy on one or all of the fingers of choice.
pads.title: Paralysed physiotherapy glove

pads.content:
KEIFh System: honey quality indicator
The Kelulut Essential Indicator of Fresh honey (KEIFh) is a system for evaluation of fresh kelulut (stingless) bee honey. This system is equipped for detecting synthetic honey to ensure the supply of high quality kelulut honey. The product package is portable and comes with a manual, analysis report, beekeeping information guide, and the KEIFh station. 
The KEIFh Scale is a copyrighted chart that maps out the parameters detailing the physicochemical components in the honey. There are a total of 8 parameters: 
1. water content
2. pollen
3. aroma
4. acidity
5. colour
6. HMF
7. enzyme
8. rheological behaviour.
These parameters combine to identify natural kelulut honey.
https://brainey.my
pads.title: KEIFh System: honey quality indicator

pads.content:
Sublime textile printing
The story began when Anne Antah (the founder) produced hair accessories using the Kain Sarong found in the local market. She found it challenging in sourcing the correct fabrics and crafts that defined the local culture identity. Anne then began to research and study about the local cottage industry. She discovered the delights of many various ethnic groups that she had never heard of or known. 
In 2018, the first production and in-house textile brand produced by Chanteek Borneo hits the market, focusing on contemporary ethnic clothes making. Chanteek Borneo is the first local business in Sabah that produces contemporary ethnic designs for textile. Chanteek Borneo designs and prints textiles, with expertise on Sabah's ethnic motifs. 
Technology
The company uses dye-sublimation method to produce textile prints. Dye-sublimation is a technology to digitally print textiles whereby the designs are created by digital drawing and then printed on a transfer medium before heat printed on to the fabric.
pads.title: Sublime textile printing

pads.content:
Citizen science on wildlife corridors
Collaborative project: Citizens participate in data collection and analysis.
Overall goal: Restore and reconnect wildlife corridors in Escobar district to give food and shelter to pollinators. 
Specific goals: Create wildlife corridors in all the towns of the Escobar district and add the community’s gardens with native plants in an online collaborative map with georeferencing, photos, and descriptions - Improve large spaces of biodiversity and pollinators’ capacity to pollinate the big municipal agroecological vegetable gardens of the district. 
Description of citizen participation: Citizen participation consists of many tasks. Citizens receive training every month on topics related to wildlife corridors, native species, and environmental restoration. Citizen participation also consists of seed collection and exchange among neighbors for the creation of seedlings in different garden centers of native species around Escobar. In the same way, butterfly gardens and tiny native forests are created in the public squares of the district, the port of Escobar on the Paraná Delta, and every sidewalk where there are urban trees. By taking part in these activities organized by the municipality, citizens can take the following things to their homes: seedlings they made from native plants, butterfly shelters with native plants, native trees, seeds for agroecological gardening, aromatic plants for insects, compost made with pruning waste done at the municipality, pots made with processed ecobricks, or plantable pencils, that is, everything allowing citizens to grow and take care of species at their gardens at home. Thus, another instance of citizen participation involves identifying and georeferencing native species at private home gardens, contributing to the creation of a collaborative map on which urban wildlife corridors are rebuilt. 
Time frame: 08/13/2021 - N/A.
Project leaders: María Victoria Bandin, municipality of Escobar. 
Contact information: Email: vickybandin88@gmail.com - Web: www.escobar.gob.ar/biocorredores
pads.title: Citizen science on wildlife corridors

pads.content:
Masar Initiative
Founder: Darine Dairiah
https://instagram.com/masarinitiative?igshid=ZDg1NjBiNjg= 
https://web.facebook.com/masarinitiative/?_rdc=1&_rdr
A tourist community through which we seek to encourage domestic tourism in Jordan and empower the local community. We go on different tracks that include all parts of the Kingdom, north, south, east and west. Our paths are available to everyone and are diverse, as they include: community tourism, eco-tourism, cultural tourism, as well as accessible tourism - tourism for people with disabilities - it is our right to see Jordan through the eyes of a path and be able to know the identity of the land. The land always has a story that expresses who lives and passes through it. Our story is told by the souls of its participants. In each path, we exchange new experiences from everyone who joins us and the Masar family, and our story is completed by getting to know the people of the areas we visit, which are forgotten or unknown places to discover hidden stories. A path that includes: a walk in a new place, a new attachment to the customs and traditions of the inhabitants of the regions, a more adherence to the homeland. We climb the mountains through the valleys to see the magic of nature and the beauty of spring in the north of the country. We contemplate the stars of the sky and walk on the sand in the desert. We venture and defy the obstacles in the water valleys in the Jordan Valley. Each of us has a different vision and a different spirit, we hope with a path to spread and share a comprehensive vision of the concept of tourism and land
Source (originally in Arabic): https://web.facebook.com/masarinitiative/?_rdc=1&_rdr
pads.title: Masar Initiative

pads.content:
Citizen Science on water quality motoring: "El desafío del agua"
Collaborative project: Citizens participate in data collection and analysis. 
Overall goal: Promote the knowledge of variables for water quality monitoring. - Raise awareness on the importance of protecting this resource. Specific goals: Learn about the water quality of bodies of water (sea and lakes) in the area of San Jorge Gulf in the province of Chubut
Description of citizen participation: Young people from 12 to 21 years old participated in the project for 3 days. On the first day, they participated in online training sessions on the use of equipment and supplies provided by the project. On the second day, an in-person meeting was held, where material for measuring physicochemical water variables was given. On the last day, participants reflected in person about the collected results, the environmental issues impacting bodies of water, and the possibility to generate alternatives for improvement in water management. Afterward, in a self-managed manner and together with a youth leader of the foundation, each participant uploaded the data to a section of the EarthEcho International's website, where there are more than 1.5 million records from all over the world, to share with the whole community. Moreover, participants collaborated later with data analysis, phenomenon monitoring, and solution planning in meetings with activity coordinators of the organization EarthEcho International and the Coastal Development Institute Dr. Héctor Zaixso (National University of Patagonia San Juan Bosco [UNPSJB]). 
Time frame: 10/01/2020 - 09/04/2021. 
Project leaders: Javier Tolosano, Coastal Development Institute Dr. Héctor Zaixso /National University of Patagonia San Juan Bosco.
Contact information: Email: javiertolosano@gmail.com EMAIL. srussell@earthecho.org Web: www.earthecho.org Web: www.unp.edu.ar/idc/ Instagram: instagram.com/earthecho Instagram: instagram.com/institutodedesarrollocostero/ Facebook: facebook.com/earthecho Facebook: facebook.com/institutodesarrollocostero/ Twitter: twitter.com/earthecho YouTube: youtube.com/c/EarthEcho
pads.title: Citizen Science on water quality motoring: "El desafío del agua"

pads.content:
Citizen science on monitoring of the argentine horned frog: "Gigante de las Pampas"
Contributory project: It is designed by scientists, and citizens participate in data collection.
Overall goal: Learn about the current and historical geographic distribution of the Argentine horned frog (Ceratophrys ornata) in Argentina, Uruguay, and Brazil, and encourage the participation of local communities in its conservation. Specific goals: Monitor the species collaboratively to detect it in real time. Use this information to guide actions for conservation and handling. Disseminate the conservation issues of the Argentine horned frog in particular and amphibians in general. 
Description of citizen participation: Citizens participate by sharing records on the Argentine horned frog. There are three ways of participation: (1) By filling in a Google form available on the project’s social media. There, participants can upload a photo and add a GPS coordinate, date, time, and weather and environmental data associated with the record. (2) By downloading the Escuerzo: Gigante de las Pampas App available for Android on Google Play Store. Through the app, the user can sign up and, by just taking a photo, the record is sent with the associated information. (3) Through in-person surveys at locations where Internet connectivity is low or is not available. For this purpose, the Gigante de las Pampas team visits towns and conducts surveys in person. Records can be current or from several years back, but in all cases, they should include a photo or go through a validation process. 
Time frame: 09/15/2015 - N/A. 
Project leaders: Gabriela Agostini, Institute of Ecology, Genetics, and Evolution of Buenos Aires (IEGEBA)/ University of Buenos Aires (UBA)-National Scientific and Technical Research Council (CONICET) and the Amphibian Conservation in Argentina (COANA) Initiative Camila Deutsch, IEGEBA/UBA-CONICET and COANA Initiative
Contact information: Email: gabrielaagostini18@gmail.com; deucamila@gmail.com Web: www.coana.com.ar Facebook: facebook.com/coanaarg Instagram: instagram.com/coana_arg Twitter: twitter.com/coana
pads.title: Citizen science on monitoring of the argentine horned frog: "Gigante de las Pampas"

pads.content:
Code Khana (A futuristic educational platform)
About the Challenge:
In Iraq, many people face many difficulties in obtaining high-quality education for several reasons, including: (1) High costs of tuition fees, transportation, and living costs. (2)There are no universities and institutes in most villages and cities. (3) People with disabilities cannot go to education centers. (4) Many women are prevented from going to education centers because of customs and traditions. (5) Many young people are deprived of education because of the need to work. (6) The displaced and refugees in the camps are not able to go to the education centers. (7) Poor quality of education in most universities and institutes. (8) Many graduates face difficulties in gaining hands-on experience. (9) There are no courses (in Iraq and in most Arabic countries) related to Programming, Artificial Intelligence, Data Science, and Web development. All these reasons result in more unemployment, deteriorating living conditions, poverty, ignorance, and deprivation of education.
Goals of Code Khana Platform:
Code Khana platform seeks to achieve the following GOALS: (1) Providing free, and high-quality education (%100 online) in Programming, Artificial Intelligence, Data Science, and Web development. (2) Qualifying Youth for the labor market to get jobs in the top companies. (3) Supporting the private sector by helping young people build their own projects and encouraging them to build tech companies, applications, and smart systems. (4) Encouraging students to learn by offering jobs and prizes for outstanding students.
Code Khana Main Features:
Code Khana platform seeks to achieve the above goals by providing the following SOLUTIONS: (1) High-quality online courses and educational programs (for free). (2) Anyone can register and learn via smartphone or via a simple computer, and there is no need to purchase any hardware or software. (3) Providing equal opportunities for all students (in cities and villages) to learn without attendance. (4) People with disabilities can register and learn from any place. (5) All women can register and learn at home. (6) All young people can register and learn on their own time and without having to leave their work. (7) All refugees and displaced are welcome to register without the need for documents and without the need to leave their camps. (8) Code Khana platform offers a high-quality curriculum (certified by the best educational institutions in the world). (9) Code Khanna platform provides hands-on experience and real projects for all students to gain real-world experience.
https://codekhana.com/
pads.title: Code Khana (A futuristic educational platform)

pads.content:
Artificial intelligence technology for court sentencing
AI Sentencing System is a machine learning-based system developed by Sarawak Information Systems Sdn. Bhd. (SAINS), in collaboration with the High Courts of Sabah and Sarawak, to generate sentence recommendations in court cases. This is an initiative to reduce sentencing discrepancies in court cases for similar offences. 
The system works by giving out sentence recommendations, but it does not mean that it is the AI system that passes the sentence. Instead, it provides the magistrate with a benchmark based on past sentencing trends across all the courts. The power to make a final sentence decision remains within the discretion of the magistrate. By making the sentencing process more consistent across courts in different locations, AI sentencing can support a more equitable justice system the public can believe in. AiCOS (AI Court Sentencing) is currently deployed for possession of scheduled drugs, an offence under section 12(2) punishable. 
The use of AI Sentencing System is increasing as magistrates become more familiar with the process and observe the outcomes. Over time, as a majority of magistrates adhere to the recommended baseline, this innovation will help to synchronise common grounds among the magistrates thus promoting consistency in sentencing. In the long run, it is expected to increase effectiveness and transparency in the delivery of justice.
pads.title: Artificial intelligence technology for court sentencing

pads.content:
Mobile Courts in the Heartlands of Borneo Malaysia
While catered to many legal issues, the mobile court initiative in the state of Sabah, Malaysia focuses to address the challenge of late birth registrations in the state. Late registrations, unfortunately has been quite a challenge to overcome due to limited geographical terrains, transportation and other documentation difficulties. Since its inception in 2007, the programme has been effectively reaching out to those affected by this predicament - in both urban and peripheral areas across the state. With a high frequency of late birth registrations in the state, the initiative targets to resolve the problem by bringing the court to the people, particularly to areas where communities have difficulty reaching out to the authorities. Late birth registrations are particularly problematic as they hinder persons of concern from having equal rights as to those that have registered their births within the time period as stipulated by the law, despite the former's status as citizens of the State. Apart from managing and hearing legal cases, the mobile court team also collaborates with other governing bodies and civil organisations to provide other services such as legal advice and health services to the communities.
pads.title: Mobile Courts in the Heartlands of Borneo Malaysia

pads.content:
Membrane technology for clean water supply
Developed 25 years ago with the goal of helping Malaysia’s rural communities, UTM Membrane Technology aims to become the country's premier membrane manufacturer. It hope to reduce the country's reliance on imported membrane for filtration systems. The technology is claimed to be of equal standing in terms of quality compared with imported technologies. The team has also worked with the Education Ministry, installing water purification systems in rural schools across the country. To date, 60 water purification systems have been installed, providing these communities with access to clean water supply, and subsequently better health. The team hopes to disseminate the application of the technology in other industries, sharing its knowledge of integrating the membrane systems with various equipment to build future-ready sustainable technology. The team continues to enhance the sustainability of its membrane manufacturing process, including utilising materials from alternative sources to reduce waste.
pads.title: Membrane technology for clean water supply

pads.content:
Biogenes APTSENS
Biogenes APTSENS is a portable diagnostic technology that can be easily used by anyone with a smartphone. APTSENS provides informative disease diagnostic testing to hospitals, clinics, workplaces and even in the comfort of your home. Building on the scientific principles of a glucose test, APTSENS offers convenience to patients and their families, where they are able to perform tests in the comfort of their own homes. The APTSENS mobile app enables people to keep track of their health history, thereby enabling more informed treatment decisions. At the heart of this technology is a revolutionary ingredient called an aptamer. An aptamer is a DNA-based construct that mimics the functionality of animal-derived antibodies. Each aptamer is uniquely designed to selectively bind only to one specific biomarker, and this enables the detection of a specific disease or health condition related to the particular biomarker. To date, Biogenes has designed over 200 aptamers to capture biomarkers such as glucose, COVID-19, bacterial sepsis, dengue, cancers, hormones, toxins and pathogens. Biogenes’ technology enables us to design aptamers quickly, run tests and integrate aptamers with APTSENS.
pads.title: Biogenes APTSENS

pads.content:
PDMx: Eco-friendly anti-bacterial cleaning products
PDMx, the active ingredient in surface cleaning products, is a unique blend of plant-derived compounds and has won numerous local and international innovation accolades. The formulation is proven to be non-irritant, non-corrosive, non-toxic, biodegradable and ecofriendly. Most similar products in the market are flawed with health and environmental issues due to their micro-biocide content. Skin dehydration, intoxication, respiratory problems, hormonal imbalance and carcinogenic effects, among others, have been associated with the usage of alcohol, hypochlorite and triclosan, as micro-biocides. PDMx, or the active ingredient is a proprietary blend of plant derived compounds proven to be effective in eliminating 99.99% of germs including the infamous superbug, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The products are laboratory proven to be non-irritant and non-toxic with low-volatile content, and is biodegradable in the environment. All in all, the nature-inspired formulations eventually lead to its remarkable safety features.
pads.title: PDMx: Eco-friendly anti-bacterial cleaning products

pads.content:
AEDESTECH: Dengue fever prevention system
Mr Lim Chee Hwa has the mindset to combat dengue in Malaysia and hopefully around the globe one day after meeting an entomologist who had an idea to create a project such as the AedesTech Mosquito Home System (AMHS) to contain the spread of Aedes mosquitos. AedesTech is an invention that reduces the population of aedes mosquitos in the effort to reduce the number of dengue cases. It also can be used as a surveillance and monitoring tool. Designed to be placed anywhere, it has been proven to reduce 75% of dengue cases and 50% of labour costs. Its specialty also lies in a chemical liquid used in the device itself. Aedestech functions as a tool to control Aedes mosquitos and it also utilises 4IR technologies. As Aedes mosquitos are attracted to the trap to lay their eggs, the life span of those hatched eggs will be shortened. They would not be able to make it to its adult stage, which in turn helps combat the spread of dengue. Not only that, because Aedes mosquitos do not lay their eggs in one place, they most certainly would travel elsewhere and at the same time lay their eggs there as well. When they do leave the trap, they would carry along with them the chemical liquid which has been implanted on them, and that is how they are able to contain the spread of dengue; by auto dissemination. The chemicals used in the trap is non-toxic and non-hazardous. It is in fact safe for human ingestion (though not recommended). It also offers 24/7 protection and one only needs to refill the chemical liquid in the machine once a month.
pads.title: AEDESTECH: Dengue fever prevention system

pads.content:
MADCash for Women Entrepreneurs
Pn Aizah started MADcash when COVID-19 hit Malaysia. MADCash, which stands for Multiply, Assist and Donate Cash is a platform that allows donors to channel their money to B40 women entrepreneurs launching new businesses. The donated funds are used as loans of between RM1,000 to RM2,000 which is treated as a perpetual cash fund. MADCash also raises a separate fund to run an entrepreneurship development programme that equips these women to strengthen their businesses. Through the MADCash programme, women receive the benefits of mentorship and training by the Academy of Women Entrepreneurs to learn the ins and outs of running a business. “Instead of giving your money to charity, donate it to MADCash, impact lives and track who your funds are helping at any one time.” Pn Aizah pitches this idea to banks, foundations, NGOs and the CSR arm of corporate organisations for them to help women become financially and digitally included. As the women entrepreneurs pay back their nointerest loans within 10 months, this money is upcycled to another woman. Pn Aizah stresses that MADCash is not a bank and does not operate like one. MADCash is straightforward, which gives her the edge compared to other micro-loans programmes. MADCash follows the Islamic Social Finance Model. Another aspect of the MADCash programme that sets it apart is that it is a holistic support system. The women in the programme may also experience difficulties in personal areas. Because of this, Aizah says that “everything needs to work as a whole” and that “we know that women need support in other parts of their lives as well, if only they have someone to talk to
pads.title: MADCash for Women Entrepreneurs

pads.content:
Bateriku.com: All-in-one platform for vehicle battery solutions
Bateriku.com is a battery delivery and installation system which is based on a sharing economy model, contributing to environmental sustainability. To date, Bateriku.com has helped train almost a thousand B-Heroes who are mobile battery installers and we have also successfully recycled almost 15 tonnes of used batteries in the span of 8 years. Mr. Azarol Faizi found that the economy was slowly transitioning to more on-demand services like Uber, MyTaxi (Grab), Food Panda and others in 2012. He observed that more and more people were using their smart phones to do a search on products and request for online services which were easier and faster. At that time, he realised that there were advantages to the on-demand battery business model. This is because prior to this, batteries were mostly sold in workshops or specific battery shops. This transitional model has helped consumers save money and time, as well as overcome other inconveniences of getting batteries themselves Bateriku.com offers free training and has created job opportunities especially for the B40 community via the B-Hero programme. Participants from this programme managed to earn at least 5 times more than their peers in similar service delivery companies. Some of the challenge they need to overcome is the issue of lead acid batteries. Their irresponsible disposal may negatively affect health and also the environment. On the bright side, almost all lead acid batteries can be recycled, which is why Bateriku.com has kick started a programme called “Go Recond, Save the World” to recycle these batteries. In this programme, batteries will undergo a thorough selection process for reinstallation and restoration purposes, and a discount will be given to used-car dealers, workshop owners and others who may find them useful for their businesses. This is how they contribute to the preservation of the environment as well.
pads.title: Bateriku.com: All-in-one platform for vehicle battery solutions

pads.content:
SMART PHOTOVOLTAIC MODULE (FV-PAM)
INNOFEIT and the local company Torax (http://www.torax.eu.mk/)
Rugjer Boshkovikj st. 18 – Skopje
